title: Texas: Judge Prevents Ban on Funds to Planned Parenthood

The rule would have removed 49 Planned Parenthood clinics in Texas from the states so-called Medicaid Womens Health Program beginning Tuesday. Judge Lee Yeakel ruled that by requiring the certification the state is reaching beyond the scope of the government program and penalizing plaintiffs for their protected conduct. The state attorney general, Greg Abbott, immediately appealed to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit to lift the injunction. A spokeswoman for the Texas Health and Human Services Commission said it would comply with the ruling.

title: Small Wonder
description: When Anne Griswold Tyng entered Radcliffe College in 1938, she had already found her calling: her faith was in architecture. I was intensely drawn to the combination of science and art, of the pragmatic and aesthetic, of rigorous facts and intuitive leaps, she wrote, looking back nearly 60 years later. The child of Episcopal missionaries with deep roots in colonial Massachusetts, Tyng was born in China and educated in Jiangxi Province and New York State. One winter while she was a student at the Kuling American School, she packed snow into wooden boxes to make ice blocks and built a high-domed igloo; the following spring, she constructed a circular bamboo hut as a secret hideout. In 1942, she enrolled in the first class to admit women at the Harvard Graduate School of Design, where she studied with Walter Gropius and Marcel Breuer and readily embraced what she described as the missionary zeal of the Bauhaus-influenced faculty.

title: How Do Artists Say I Love You?
description: One of my favorite works of yours is to throw an object from one country to another, and I just want you to know that Im taking all the love from my country and throwing it into yours, said Ed Ruscha to his friend and fellow artist Lawrence Weiner via video last Tuesday night. The occasion was the Drawing Centers 2012 Spring Gala, where Weiner was being honored for his contributions to contemporary art. Ruscha, who was on vacation in Jamaica, created a three-minute tribute in the form of a parody of Bob Dylans legendary music video for Subterranean Homesick Blues with placards featuring Weiner text pieces like stars dont stand still in the sky and water in milk exists. The mash-up soundtrack, sung by Ruscha himself, was composed by the longtime Ruscha collaborator Mason Williams, while the film was shot in Ruschas studio by Gary Regester, another old friend. Weiner and Ruscha both showed at Leo Castellis gallery in the 1970s and even teamed up for a book, Hard Light, in 1978, so theres a deep personal history far beyond benefit-circuit sendups. At the end of the video, commented Brett Littman, the executive director of the Drawing Center, Ed begs Lawrences wife, Alice, to bring him into the 21st century by teaching him how to drive a car, but Lawrence is a true New Yorker and I dont think honorees are expected to do homework. See the video here.

title: Eight Things I Learned From Reading Every Last Word of Bloomberg BusinessWeek
description: Im slightly embarrassed to admit that my baseline understanding of private equity comes mainly from movies (Wall Street, Pretty Woman, Other Peoples Money) in which the profession is used as shorthand to tell audiences that a character is really, really, really bad. Despite the chainsaw-wielding corporate evildoer on the cover of this weeks Bloomberg BusinessWeek, the magazine presents a much kinder, gentler version of private equity. The corporate restructuring artists here are like fairy godmothers who show up to organize your closet and teach you a few time-saving life hacks. They turn inefficient manufacturing companies into hyperefficient economic engines, improving peoples work environments and maybe even saving the whole idea of North American manufacturing in the process. Theyre not out to fire people, just to eliminate waste (though sometimes that waste turns out to be people). But lets not get distracted by that. The real trouble, according to the article by Brendan Greeley, is that closets dont stay reorganized for long. Private equity, he writes, is a castle in the sand, a brief victory for order in the constant slide toward entropy. But by the time youve stopped putting your shoes back into their clearly labeled transparent plastic containers, your company has been sold to its next owner.

Fords most compelling answer to this tech-savvy trio may not be a V-6 Mustang with a live rear axle, but the front-wheel-drive Focus ST, for which powertrain and pricing information was announced Tuesday.

title: Obama Signs Pact in Kabul, Turning Page in Afghan War
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  President Obama, speaking to an American television audience on Tuesday night from Bagram Air Base, declared that he had traveled here to herald a new era in the relationship between the United States and Afghanistan, a future in which war ends, and a new chapter begins.

title: Stepping to the Beat
description: It was serendipitous that a headphone cable fell on top of Haman Alimardanis shoes while he was D.J.-ing one evening. The accident lent itself to his artful design: the CMYK shoe by the New York-based fashion label, hamansutra. The shoes feature stereo mini-jacks for laces.

title: A Turner Prize Shortlist Without a Painter
description: Four artists, none of them painters, are on the shortlist for Britains $65,000 Turner Prize, which was announced Tuesday. The prize, with past winners who include Damien Hirst and the duo Gilbert & George, is given annually to a British artist under 50 who is judged to have staged the best exhibition over the previous 12 months.

title: Climate Change and the Body Politic
description: The latest installment in our Temperature Rising series, just published, is about an argument between mainstream climate researchers and contrarians over how clouds will change on a warming planet. As their many other objections to climate science have been undermined by the growing evidence, the contrarians have settled on clouds as a kind of last-resort reason that the scientific majority just has to be wrong.

description: Anger, and some degrees of violence, seemed to be in the air on Monday nights schedule of playoff games. Much has been said and written about Knicks forward Amare Stoudemire striking a fire extinguisher case in Miami and slicing his left hand.

title: Uncertainty Mounts Over London Airport Expansion Plans
description: LONDON  As any pilot will tell you, landing an aircraft in a crosswind is a challenge. So, too, is deciding on where  or whether  to build a new airport runway.

Krugman, a columnist on the Op-Ed page of The Times since 1999 and a Nobel Prize-winning economist, wrote about Ben Bernankes role as chairman of the Federal Reservein the April 29 issue of the magazine,asking why Bernanke hasnt taken the sort of measures to end the economic slump that he once advocated as an economics professor. That was a little more than 15 years ago. Since then, Ms. Fisherman-Ruff, 42, a publicist in Manhattan, has stockpiled a variety of products, including a discontinued eye shadow (also Chanel) and a custom-blended Prescriptives foundation, seven bottles of which currently reside in her refrigerator alongside the butter and cheese.

They were lining up for a bright yellow catamaran called the Yasawa Flyer to speed from Fijis main island to some of its tiniest and most idyllic. And I was with them, worried I was about to spend my five precious days in paradise on a spring break-style debauch.

Inside the financier-filled Beverly Hilton here, though, the Occupy movement seemed a world away.

description: The breaststroker Michael Alexandrov looked up video of Alexander Dale Oen on YouTube last week. The United States Olympic trials are in June, and Alexandrov was studying Dale Oens technique to see how to improve his own stroke.

Like some of his new peers, he is also a fugitive from the banking business.

title: Legendary Wines, Sold in Sips
description: Chteau Ptrus and Chteau dYquem from Bordeaux, Vega Sicilia from Spain and Bryant Family from California are legendary wines, scarce and costly. But now you can taste them without a trust fund. At Alain Ducasses Midtown bistro Benoit, the wine director, Andr Compeyre, pictured, an award-wining sommelier, is pouring them by the ounce: the 1992 Ptrus for $48, a 1991 dYquem for $35, a 1983 Vega Sicilia from a magnum for $16, and the 1999 Bryant Family for $29. A Saint-milion is also on the list. An ounce may not sound like much, but its rare to find these wines by the glass anywhere, and even a few sips provide a very special sample.

title: A Taste of North Carolina, at Last
description: Long and slow: Thats how good barbecue is smoked. It also seems to be the philosophy at Blue Smoke, the barbecue restaurants owned by Danny Meyers Union Square Hospitality Group, which have taken 10 years to come up with a new sauce to slather on their pork. Unlike the companys all-purpose Original Recipe BBQ Sauce, with its fairly mild ketchup and mustard base, the tangy newcomer, Blue Smoke Carolina Kick Barbecue Sauce, can run roughshod over a pile of pulled pork, giving it a robust new personality.

title: Casual Joy and Dread, Mingling Every Day
description: NEW HAVEN  Intimations of mortality hover in the pauses punctuating the dialogue in The Realistic Joneses, the tender, funny, terrific new play by Will Eno at the Yale Repertory Theater here. Mr. Enos voice, which teases out the poetry in the pedestrian and finds glinting humor in the static that infuses our faltering efforts to communicate, is as distinctive as any American playwrights today. He writes about big matters  nothing bigger than life and death, after all  as if they were incidental oddities deserving of wry comment but no great moralizing or posturing.

title: Finger on the Button
description: As far as New York City kids go, Bibi Cornejo Borthwick, who is the daughter of the fashion designer Maria Cornejo and the artist and T photographer Mark Borthwick, and Roman Grandinetti, a D.J. and the founder of the creative agency CNNCTD+, are pretty well connected. But just how connected even they couldnt be so sure until they reached out to 100 of their cultural heroes and, using a Playbutton as a platform, loaded their words of wisdom, favorite songs and even the occasional recipe onto the wearable MP3 devices. The artist Cindy Sherman, who claimed not to like public speaking, curated a playlist; the legendary art director George Lois read from his new book, Damn Good Advice; Pharrell Williams rapped philosophic on his personal otherness (his new record label is called I Am Other). Starting tonight, and for the next three weeks, 10 different MP3 buttons will be available to the listening public at the New Museum Store as part of CNNCTD+100. Additional buttons have been planted throughout the city at special Sound Graffiti stations. (Hint: the Jason Woodside mural on Kenmare Street between Bowery and Elizabeth has something to say for itself.) Cornejo Borthwick and Grandinettis plan is to take the project global, bringing the buttons  and their collective good will  to cities like Paris and Tokyo and adding new names to the roster along the way. In New York City people are always so competitive, Cornejo Borthwick observes. The way to succeed is to collaborate.

The book was Hilary Mantels Wolf Hall, and it would have dwarfed the competition any year. Wolf Hall was a historical novel that ingeniously revisited well-trod territory (the early marriages of Henry VIII), turned the phlegmatic villain Thomas Cromwell into the best-drawn figure and easily mixed 16th-century ambience with timeless bitchery.

title: Rhode Island: Brown to Increase Pay to Providence
description: Brown University announced on Tuesday that it would increase its voluntary payments to the City of Providence, where officials are trying to shore up finances to avoid bankruptcy. The university, whose nonprofit status exempts it from paying taxes, will pay the city $31.5 million over 11 years, in addition to the annual amount it already pays under a 2003 agreement, which this year was about $4 million. Mayor Angel Taveras has pressured all of the citys tax-exempt institutions to contribute more to city coffers. On Monday, the nonprofit Lifespan hospital group agreed to pay Providence an additional $2.4 million a year; Johnson & Wales University has also agreed to increase its voluntary payments. In February, Mr. Taveras said the city would run out of money in June if, among another measures, it could not get higher payments from tax-exempt institutions and decrease its pension obligations.

title: Group Seeks Suspension of Iran From I.M.F.

title: Austerity Pain Fills Europe With Protests on May Day
description: PARIS  The annual May Day demonstrations took on special resonance across Europe on Tuesday as tens of thousands of protesters turned out amid rising anger over enforced austerity that many see not as a cure to the regions fiscal troubles, but as a deterrent to economic growth and job creation.

title: Texas: Judge Stays Order on Health Care Program
description: A federal appeals judge allowed Texas to ban Planned Parenthood clinics from participating in a health care program for low-income women late Monday night, hours after a lower court prohibited the state from doing so. The decision by the appellate judge was the latest twist in a dispute between Texas officials and Planned Parenthood that threatens a health program that serves more than 100,000 women. At issue is a state rule requiring all providers in the Medicaid Womens Health Program to certify that they do not affiliate with entities that perform or promote abortions. Nine Planned Parenthood clinics that do not perform abortions sued the state. On Monday, Judge Lee Yeakel of Federal District Court blocked the state from enforcing the rule, but the state attorney general appealed, and Judge Jerry E. Smith of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit granted a stay of the order. As a result, state health officials said on Tuesday that they had begun banning all abortion providers and affiliates from the program. Planned Parenthood said it continued to treat the programs patients on Tuesday while preparing to respond to Judge Smiths stay.

The bill matters, not just to Canada but to the world: The boreal forests and tundra of northern Canada remain a relatively intact ecosystem, absorbing more carbon than the worlds tropical forests and providing a vital buffer against global warming. Industrial development would weaken that buffer, and, as things stand now, there is almost nothing to prevent it.

title: Libya: Hague Court Is Asked to Stand Down

The request, released by the court on Tuesday, was the latest step in the dispute over who will try Mr. Qaddafi, a son of the former Libyan ruler Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, and Mr. Senussi on charges of crimes committed during Libyas uprising last year. The court has issued arrest warrants for the men and ordered Libya to turn them over, but Libya has insisted that it will try them, even though it is still rebuilding its justice system. The request said Libyan authorities were making progress in investigating the cases and preparing for trials that will meet international standards. In Mr. Qaddafis case, witnesses have been interviewed and evidence of his direct involvement in killings has emerged, the document said. But the case against the intelligence chief, arrested in Mauritania in March, has been delayed, it said, because his liver disease has prevented his transfer to Libya.

Though he acknowledges that philosophers can improve our understanding of ethics and the various sciences of the mind (neuroscience, cognitive and evolutionary psychology, etc.), he thinks no similar gains are on the cards when it comes to physics. In particular, he thinks the reflections of physicists themselves on their methods and results have been much more productive and insightful than those of philosophers. title: The Breakfast Meeting: Unfit to Be Tied and Network Television Looks Up
description: News Corporation was prepared for severe criticism in the parliamentary report released Tuesday in Great Britain but Rupert Murdoch was taken aback by the personal nature of the committees findings, which labeled him unfit to lead a major corporation. Rupert is still in denial about how quickly his influence and prestige in the U.K. has gone down the drain, said one person close to the company and Mr. Murdoch who could not publicly comment on private discussions.

title: Hovering Above the Skyline, Armed With a Camera
description: On Monday, the Empire State Building became the second tallest building in New York. So if youre not safe from being looked down upon even if your rooftop is 1,250 feet in the sky, what hope do the rest of us have?

title: Harvard and M.I.T. Team Up to Offer Free Online Courses

description: YOU thought you scored a great deal when you found that $200 rate for your $300-a-night hotel. But then you compared notes with other guests and learned that some paid even less. It happens to even the best bargain hunters  whether it is a hotel deal or airfare  and its not a good feeling.

title: After Defeating Duke, Denver Heads to E.C.A.C. Tournament
description: DENVER  In its biggest win of the season, the No. 16 Pioneers defeated highly ranked Duke on Friday night as part of the Whitmans Sampler Mile High Classic at Sports Authority Field, posting a 15-9 upset in front of a crowd of 12,282 to end the regular season.

title: Jawbones Jambox, Now With More Jam
description: Sometimes products are so compelling they deserve a big brother. Jawbone introduced the first Jambox in 2010 to some fanfare  it was a small, nicely-designed wireless speaker that filled a room or event with sound using Bluetooth. Its newest sibling, the Big Jambox, is twice as big as the original model and it weighs just two pounds more (2.7 pounds over all). It has all of its little brothers DNA but with a bigger, richer sound and a larger battery.

title: Mens Colorful Kilties Return
description: Once an inescapable facet of 1950s country clubs, a kiltie is a long fringed tongue of leather that attaches to a golf shoes inside tongue and folds over the laces.

title: New Barriers Planned on Road Where 7 Died
description: The State Transportation Department will immediately begin installing new concrete barriers on three viaducts along the Bronx River Parkway, following a catastrophic accident that claimed the lives of seven relatives last weekend, officials said Wednesday.

description: With BlackBerry 10, Research in Motion hopes for a comeback; why complacency is a problem for Google; and China's vanishing trade imbalance.

title: From Fairway to Runway
description: IN some fashion quarters, enthusiasm for old-school heritage style is fading like embers. But elsewhere, it is raging out of control, with evermore vivid hues and ornate detail. One need only glance down, at the recent spate of colorized bucks and saddle shoes. Or take a gander at the even more surprising reappearance of an over-the-vamp, over-the-top shoe detail one might have thought was gone forever: the kiltie.

title: Spring Board Book Roundup
description: The best of the seasons board books, featuring dinosaurs, bees, trains and more.

title: NBC Blankets Churchill Downs
description: Looking forward to watching your favorite horse step onto the track for the 138th running of the Kentucky Derby or the R&B star Mary J. Blige belt out the national anthem? NBC appears to have it covered. After broadcasting the major prep races ahead of Saturdays run for the roses, the network is extending its commitment to horse racing with 14 hours of planned Derby coverage.

title: An Army Apart
description: DELHI  In the fall of 2007, shortly after retiring as chief of the Indian army, J.J. Singh became president of the Delhi Gymkhana Club, one of those venerable social institutions where, sipping gin at the bar, it is difficult to imagine that the British ever left India. Pervez Musharraf was the president of Pakistan at the time, and the joke of the day was: See what distinguishes the two countries? While one army chief moves on to head a nation, the other moves on to head a social club.

title: Big Mo
description: So, in case youre wondering, the reason Im suddenly everywhere is the reality of the book trade, which is that to have a best-seller you must be a best-seller: momentum, getting on to those lists, is crucial, so a burst of sales in the first few weeks is all-important.

title: Spring Board Book Roundup
description: SIMMS TABACKS DINOSAURSWritten and illustrated by Simms Taback.20 pp. Blue Apple Books. $12.99. (Board book; ages 2 to 4)

title: Coming Soon | Rubber Soles
description: Time to start brushing up on your Gene Kelly puddle kick, gentlemen. The galosh, that protective and effective rubber overshoe, made a comeback during the fall 2012 runway shows with many designers turning the seasonal necessity into a certifiable fashion statement. At Prada, shoes featuring rubberlike sidewalls were followed by proper galoshes in navy blue and black over shiny lace-up oxfords beneath. Emporio Armanis flocked black versions so closely resembled pairs of dressy evening slip-ons that one could easily mistake the two. Collaborating with Swims, the Oslo-based company best known for making weather-ready footwear, Armani introduced the Armani by Swims overshoe, to be sold alongside four different shoe styles starting in July. Swims, which originally manufactured brightly colored rubber galoshes, now incorporates Japanese nylon and Scotchguard into a complete line that includes desert boots, dressy brogues and Chelsea boots. Its new Classic Royal overshoe, with a velvety looking finish, is perfect for a rainy night at the opera.

title: Obamas Ex-Girlfriend Details Their Relationship
description: An early girlfriend of President Obamas chronicled a relationship of more than a year in which she struggled to pierce his now famous reserve, which she termed a bit of a wall  the veil, according to journals reproduced in a new biography.

title: The 91 Percent Solution
description: Update: Whoops. Reasonable conservatives are so rare that I shouldnt get them confused, but anyway now I have the right name.

title: Wednesday Reading: Fiji for the Rest of Us
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Morning Walkabout  5/2: Middle East Jet Spree, Plane Headaches and More
description: Where the Big Birds Fly Airlines in the Middle East and in Asia are buying Airbus and Boeing jets at a quick pace, making up for a dip in purchases by Western carriers. (The New York Times)

title: Letters to the Travel Editor
description: To the Editor: Regarding Are Travel Agents Back? (April 22): As a veteran agent with over 30 years in the industry, I feel that the article should be entitled Young Travel Agents Rescuing an Endangered Profession. Do older agents have no place in this trend? The article failed to address an important question. Do these young agents have the depth of knowledge that veteran agents with decades of experience can offer? Part of travel navigation is the sharing of deep destination knowledge. Also, as an aging baby boomer, I do speak the same language and understand the stage-of-life issues facing my generation right now. Not everyone needs the creation of a sound track for their in-flight distraction.Nancy Pole WilhitePortland, Ore.

title: Taking On the Little Guy, but Missing the Bigger Ones
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission seems to think that it has done a much better job of investigating financial crisis wrongdoing than the Justice Department. And its true.

title: LinkedIn Finally Adds an iPad App
description: After reworking their iPhone and Android platforms, LinkedIn now offers users the chance to make connections on the iPad.

title: Tenor and Violinist Receive Martin E. Segal Awards
description: A tenor and a violinist have been selected as the winners of the 2012 Martin E. Segal Awards, which recognize emerging artists associated with Lincoln Center. The tenor, Paul Appleby, and the violinist, Augustin Hadelich, each received $7,500 to be used for career advancement and future study. The recipients, chosen by the Metropolitan Opera and the New York Philharmonic, were honored at a lunch on Wednesday in the Stanley H. Kaplan Penthouse at Lincoln Center.

title: Italys Own Lost Cause
description: In the same eventful spring of 1861 that marked the outbreak of the American Civil War, Italy declared its existence as a united kingdom. In fact, just as the bombardment of an island fortress in Charleston, S.C., riveted the attention of a nation plunging into civil war, the kingdom of southern Italy made a last-ditch stand against northern Italian bombardment of a waterfront fortress midway between Rome and Naples. The two sieges, of Fort Sumter and of Gaeta, came only weeks apart.

title: Army Will Reshape Training, With Lessons From Special Forces
description: WASHINGTON  The Army is reshaping the way many soldiers are trained and deployed, with some conventional units to be placed officially under Special Operations commanders and others assigned to regions of the world viewed as emerging security risks, like Africa.

title: Diesel-Powered Chevy Cruze May Be a Tough Sell
description: Chevrolet is scheduled to introduce a diesel-powered version of its Cruze sedan in the United States next year. Last week, the automaker said in a media release that it expected the vehicle to latch onto an upward swing in the popularity of diesel cars, citing market research from Baum & Associates that projected diesel sales to double by mid-decade.

title: Warren Says Shes Proud of Being American Indian
description: 6:05 p.m. | Updated Elizabeth Warren on Wednesday defended her decision to identify herself as a minority in a directory of law professors in the 1980s and 90s, saying that she hoped it would help her meet more people who had grown up like I had grown up.

title: Taking On Home Projects to Save Money
description: Let them hammer nails?

title: Reef Sharks and Humans Dont Mix
description: Sharks may have more reason to fear people than ever. In reefs surrounding Pacific islands inhabited by people, there are 90 to 97 percent fewer sharks than in similar areas without people, according to a study in the journal Conservation Biology.

title: Is Obama More Popular Than He Should Be?
description: Its well known that presidential approval ratings are a powerful predictor of election outcomes. President Obamas current 47 percent approval rating would be among the lowest approval ratings of any incumbent president who went on to be re-elected.

description: One year after taking control of NBCUniversal, Comcast posted a quarterly profit on Wednesday that exceeded analyst expectations and signaled progress at the struggling NBC broadcast network.

description: Seasons change and so must accessories.Were only two days into May and already Aprils showers have give way to  what else?  flowers. If ever there was a time to brush up on your blooms, now is it. Here, the actress Jessica Biel, with her engagement ring on-hand, stocks up at the farmers market in Los Angeles; the model Kate Moss softens all black with pale pink tulips; and Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge, pairs a more formal arrangement of roses and ranunculuses to go with her cornflower blue dress.

description: Pep Boys disclosed on Tuesday that the Gores Group, a private equity firm, was considering whether a recent earnings announcement and a possible deterioration in Pep Boys operations constituted a material adverse change, or MAC. If so, it would give Gores a basis to escape its $1 billion deal to acquire the auto parts and repair company.

description: Twitter is one busy beehive of chatter these days. People on the service now post more than a billion Twitter messages every three days, and the company is adding  more than a million users each week.

description: When I upgrade from my typical home-prepared dinners of hummus or breakfast cereal to something actually created using multiple ingredients and heat, it is to cook my chickpea stew, a sophisticated blend of canned chickpeas and jarred tomato sauce.

Frank (Lucas Kavner) and Drake McCandless (Justin Guarini) are surely meant to evoke younger versions of the famous team that created them.

description: As the functions and versatility of smartphones increase, there seems to be little point in having a handheld media device anymore. But that doesnt stop electronics companies from pumping out new versions of the phone without a phone.

description: Nicholas Kirkwood to open store in the meatpacking district; South Beach-inspired spring wear; and French Art Nouveau carved-horn jewelry.

title: Summer Essentials | Tony Melillo Tees and Tanks
description: Trust Tony Melillo, the editor turned designer whos been responsible for more than one cult clothing line in his time, to create the holy grail of summer fashion: the perfect T-shirt. Made from cloud-soft Peruvian cotton, his ATM tees and tanks for men and women have obsessive little details like shirttail hems and shoulder pleating, all in complexion-flattering colors. Making only one thing keeps you incredibly focused, so if you are a perfectionist  and I am  you are bound to come up with a great product, he says. The womens tank (a poolside staple) and mens henley (a weekend must) do for a hot summer day what wool does for winter. Youll wonder how you ever went without.

Bryan Fischer of the American Family Association, who previously said that hiring Mr. Grenell was like telling the pro-family community to drop dead, gleefully relayed the news on his radio broadcast Tuesday.

In between discussing his rehearsal schedule and his favorite all-time skit, however, Manning did take time to address the suspensions handed down by N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell, who disciplined four players for their involvement in the New Orleans Saints bounty program.

title: Whack! | Matt Singers Space Dog Piatas
description: In 1957, the Soviet Union eked out a lead in the space race by launching a Moscow street mutt named Laika into orbit on the Sputnik 2. In the years since, Laikas last hurrah  she survived only the first few hours of the journey  has inspired many longer-lived cultural artifacts: a statue in Moscow, a neo-futurist play, an oil painting in California, a Finnish surf rock band, a graphic novel and now a piata. In honor of Cinco de Mayo, the Manhattan-based designer Matt Singer has rendered Laika (shown here), along with successor space dogs Belka and Strelka  who went up together in the Sputnik 5 and survived  in papier-mch.

description: PERCHED on a stool at her studio in Williamsburg recently, Rita Ackermann was a picture of cool anonymity. She wore a battered fatigue jacket and frayed jeans, hanks of her corn-colored hair all but obscuring her features.

title: Prosecutors Focus on Pimps and Clients, Instead of Prostitutes
description: It was not exactly a run-of-the-mill prostitution case: the men accused as ringleaders were a father and his son, a pimp team coercing women to push their trade like traveling sex saleswomen, handing out business cards at hotels and strip clubs.

description: Jack White has never had a No. 1 album with any of his various bands: the White Stripes, the Raconteurs, the Dead Weather. But with the release of his first solo record, he now does, bumping Lionel Richie from the top of the Billboard chart.

title: Allergies as a Blessing in Disguise
description: Are allergies making you miserable? They may be a blessing in disguise, according to the work of Margie Profet, an evolutionary biologist who is profiled in the latest issue of Psychology Today. In the late 1980s and early 90s, Ms. Profet became one of the first scientists to argue that allergies evolved as a way to expel carcinogens and other toxins from the body, a theory that helped win her a MacArthur Foundation genius grant in 1993.

title: Smiles for a Summer Movies Cover
description: Back in March we asked readers to choose a favorite from among 10 illustrations submitted by students at the Savannah College of Art and Design as a potential cover of the annual Summer Movies issue of Arts & Leisure. Now the readers  close to 29,000 of you  have spoken, and above are the top three vote getters. The first two, which drew far more votes than the others, share a sense of playfulness and humor, while the third seems more in line with our ultimate choice: Heather Carters enchanting illustration of fireflies on a summer evening.

title: TimesCast | Dissident Exits U.S. Embassy
description: May 2, 2012  After intensive negotiations, American officials said the Chinese government promised that Chen Guangcheng and his family would remain safe and could relocate to Tianjin.

title: Shearman & Sterling Names Senior Partner
description: Shearman & Sterling announced on Wednesday that Creighton OM. Condon, a mergers-and-acquisitions lawyer, has been elected senior partner of the New York law firm.

title: Daughters of the Revolution
description: Last week, Tyler Cowen tweeted that the second episode of HBOs endlessly-discussed new show Girls is very  Douthatian. If you are a Straussian, that is. By Douthatian Im assuming that he meant implicitly socially conservative, and now that Ive caught up with the show, I think if anything its critique of contemporary (New York, upper middle class, white) sexual mores is explicit rather than esoteric. Indeed, before the conversation about Girls descended into a pointless argument about whether racial minorities are adequately represented on a program thats clearly supposed to be portraying a narrow and privileged slice of American life, the critical reaction to the show, both positive and negative, grasped pretty directly what Lena Dunhams show is doing. Its offering a fairly dystopian take on twentysomething social life, in which the comedy is dark, the sex is gross, the romance is disappointing, and the mix of nudity, jadedness and bawdy talk doesnt carry any of the aspirational frisson that was always associated with the post-sexual revolution single life on a show like Sex and the City.

title: Junior Seau, Famed N.F.L. Linebacker, Dies at 43; Suicide Is Suspected
description: OCEANSIDE, Calif.  Behind the police tape, a white coroners van sat in front of a garage on the 600 block of South the Strand. It waited to collect the body of Junior Seau, a linebacker among the most feared in N.F.L. history, father to three teenagers, son to the mother who wailed long and loud on Wednesday.

title: In-Between Days
description: Are you still here? It was early January in New York, the first week of my daughters pre-kindergarten. Waiting for the elevator in the disorienting silence of post-drop off, I found myself staring at a gargoyle on the side of the Riverside Church, where she goes to school.

title: Another Big Name Exits Reverse-Mortgage Lending
description: Yet another household name has given up making reverse mortgages  loans that let borrowers age 62 and older tap the equity in their houses without having to make monthly payments. The lenders get their money back once the borrowers move or die (and their relatives sell the house).

title: Lundqvist Is a Finalist for Lindsay Award
description: WASHINGTON  Henrik Lundqvist was named a finalist for the Ted Lindsay Award, given to the most outstanding player as voted by other N.H.L. players.

title: When Insolvency Cases Are Global
description: 12:37 p.m. | Updated The UNCITRAL Insolvency Working Group is meeting all week. (Im participating as an observer, although of course this column represents only my own views.)

title: At Milken, Feelings of Malaise
description: LOS ANGELES  If a single word captured the mood of the Wall Street contingent at this years Milken Institute Global Conference, uncertain would fit the bill.

title: Its Daffodil Day. Where Are All the Dads?
description: This morning I took a couple of hours away from my desk, and went to Daffodil Day at my two youngest childrens preschool. It was not an inspiring day for the schools annual flower-picking outing; clouds hovered, it was 45 degrees and the ground was wet from yesterdays rains. But this is New England, and we said we would pick daffodils, and the weather for the rain date looked, if anything, worse. So daffodils were picked, in the company of some 40 small children, assorted teachers and about 15 parents whod volunteered to provide transport and flower-wrapping-in-wet-paper-towel services.

title: Jonas Kaufmann Withdraws From the Metropolitan Operas Die Walkre
description: The tenor Jonas Kaufmann has again withdrawn from the role of Siegmund in the Metropolitan Operas production of Die Walkre by Richard Wagner. Stuart Skelton will take over in Mondays performance, the Met said on Wednesday, because Mr. Kaufmann is ill. Frank van Aken replaced Mr. Kaufmann on Saturday, placing him on stage opposite his real-life wife, Eva-Maria Westbroek, who is singing Sieglinde.

title: Call It Victors Secret
description: ARE men really ready to shop for underwear the way women do?

title: New Song to Benefit Amnesty International
description: One of the last musical projects Levon Helm participated in at his rustic studio in Woodstock, N.Y., was Toast to Freedom, a heart-warming single that will go on sale Wednesday to raise money for Amnesty International on its 50th anniversary.

title: Back to School for Derby Contenders
description: The 20 horses being prepared for this Saturdays Kentucky Derby have completed their final workouts. There is not much more to do at this point from a fitness standpoint. The horses will gallop each morning to keep ticking over. A few might do a short work just to sharpen up a couple of days before the race. Essentially the horse is as fit as it will be  that wont change. The goal of the trainer is to have the horse fit, sound and happy on Saturday. Being relaxed is also helpful.

title: Gingrich Quits Race and Says He Prefers Romney to Obama
description: ARLINGTON, Va.  More than half a dozen news cameras lined the back of a small ballroom packed with journalists, campaign staff members and a few supporters on Wednesday for Newt Gingrich to repeat what hes been saying for more than a week: Hes out.

title: In Iris Loves Wide Circle of Friends
description: SOME dog lovers live for their dogs and hardly give people the time of day. Others are more social. And then there is Iris Love, the New York socialite whose Pekingese won the Best in Show award this year at the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show.

title: Contradictions Temper Optimism in Deal on Chinese Lawyer
description: Did Chen Guangcheng, the blind self-taught lawyer who spent the past six days holed up in the American Embassy in Beijing, make Chinas leaders blink? Or will American diplomats come to regret the agreement they helped negotiate on his behalf?

title: Italo Train: Ferrari of the Railyard Has Automotive Pedigree
description: Americans wary of interminable waits in highway traffic and at the T.S.A. security checkpoint have dreamed for years of high speed trains like Frances TGV or Germanys so-called ICE train. But as reported in Sundays Times, from Italy comes news that two high-speed rail lines are competing on features like design, quality of cuisine and the feel of the luxury-brand leather on their seats.

title: Art and Leisure
description: WHATS a high-powered art fair without parties? New York City rolls out a red carpet for Frieze.

title: Considering Lifes End and What Comes After
description: Unless you are a poet or an undertaker, the notion of spending roughly two hours musing over death might not be high on your list of preferred ways to spend a Tuesday evening. Yet somehow the intense, insightful German baritone Matthias Goerne and the brilliant Norwegian pianist Leif Ove Andsnes made the prospect of morbid soul searching not only inviting, but also deeply stimulating.

title: The Angels in the Heavens Sing for Themselves
description: Truth be told, the Representation of Chaos that opens Haydns 1798 oratorio Die Schpfung (The Creation), sounds oddly decorous to modern ears. Granted, it begins with a short burst of brassy dissonance, and altered versions of that gesture return during the slow, dark-hued overture that pours forth before the angel Raphaels serene narration of the familiar scene from Genesis: the formlessness of the earth, the darkness on the face of the waters. And when a second angel, Uriel, announces the creation of light, Haydn provides a magnificent explosion of C major orchestral timbre.

title: An Island Villa in a Gated Compound
description: A three-bedroom beachfront villa in the northeastern part of the Dominican Republic is on the market for $1.4 million.

title: House Hunting in ... the Dominican Republic
description: A BEACHFRONT VILLA IN THE DOMINICAN REPUBLIC

title: The Frieze Art Fair Brings Its Art and Entertainment to New York
description: On Friday the London-based Frieze Art Fair flings open its tent to the public and brings its distinctive brand of arts entertainment to the city.

title: Themes From the Netherlands That Feel Familiar
description: In its 40 years the Dutch company Introdans has amassed a polyglot body of work typical of contemporary repertory companies, including dances by the usual suspects Twyla Tharp, Nacho Duato and Jiri Kylian. Its dancers are generally sleek, handsome movers, able to traverse this particular swath of modern and ballet styles efficiently.

title: Where Just Looking Is Just Fine
description: THE kook on the bus had a Starbucks cup filled with ice on his head. He was crooning a soulful version of Fly Me to the Moon. The guy was not a performance artist, and yet his serenade seemed aptly artful since the M35 bus was headed for the next big cultural destination, a rock in the East River that, as far as many New Yorkers are concerned, might as well be in space.

title: Steina's 'Orbital Obsessions'
description: An excerpt from Orbital Obsessions (1977) by the Icelandic video artist Steina. The work is on view at the Albright-Knox Art Gallery in Buffalo, N.Y. (Video courtesy of the artist.)

title: Artist, Draw Thyself (and Your Mother and Therapist)
description: For 25 years, from 1983 to 2008, Alison Bechdel wrote a buoyant comic strip that you could find only in Americas alternative weekly newspapers. Its title was Dykes to Watch Out For, and its combination of politics, college-town neuroses and heavy petting could make you blush. It was Doonesbury with all-girl sex scenes.

title: Paul Sharits's 'Dream Displacement'
description: Excerpt of Paul Sharitss film installation (original installation 1976), Albright-Knox Art Gallery, Buffalo, N.Y. (Courtesy Estate of Paul Sharits, Anthology Film Archives and Greene Naftali Gallery)

title: European Politics Dims Ukraines Chance to Shine
description: MOSCOW  This was supposed to be a moment of triumph for Ukraine. In just over a month, it is to become the first former Soviet republic to host the European soccer championships, an achievement its leaders hoped would showcase its emergence from an authoritarian past and its embrace of Western values.

title: Zeroing In on Cellulite
description: SELINA, 53, did not want to worry about her lumpy thighs before her wedding in June. So when she heard a host on The Doctors, a syndicated TV show, say that a new treatment called Cellulaze can banish cellulite, she paid $6,500 for it. The fact that its supposed to be a permanent solution was definitely what sold me, said Selina, who got a hefty discount because she agreed to be Exhibit A for a doctor-training session.

title: Renaissance in an Industrial Shadow
description: BUFFALO

title: CNN Ratings Decline Stirs Worries
description: Maybe CNN is just like an emergency room.

title: Blogging a Path Through Illness
description: Documentaries about people dealing with debilitating medical conditions dont get any more wrenching than 65_RedRoses, a film about one womans race against the unforgiving cystic fibrosis clock.

title: Lights Out for Research Satellites?
description: Earth-observing systems operated by the United States have entered a steep decline, imperiling the nations monitoring of weather, natural disasters and climate change, a report from the National Research Council warned on Wednesday.

title: Business Day Live | Google Complacency
description: Nick Bilton and Quentin Hardy discuss how the success of companies like Google makes it harder for them to understand what people are looking for in the next generation of products.

title: Paul Krugmans Reddit Chat: Europe, Partisanship and Self-Flushing Toilets
description: Yesterday, Paul Krugman took part in the first official New York Times chat to be hosted on Reddit. The IamA, whichtouched on issues from his article about Ben Bernanke in the April 29 issue of the magazine,generated more than 4,100 comments and questions and was at the top of Reddits Hot list for most of the afternoon and evening, outdoing even theVenus to Appear in Once-in-a-Lifetime Event thread.

title: Acrobat Sets Date to Cross Niagara Falls on Tightrope
description: Fans of funambulists can finally mark their calendars.

title: Hello, Stranger
description: THE Missed Connections section of Craigslist, where people post wistful and often lyrical missives to potential love objects they glimpsed on the street, is one of the sites most popular. And it has given rise to other sites that try to make up for the common human inability to act immediately on romantic impulses.

title: Exuberance Is Just One of His Skills
description: Don Was, the Grammy Award-winning producer, has a clear recollection of his first encounter with Blue Note Records. He was a teenager, listening to the car radio in his hometown, Detroit, when he heard the title track of a 1966 album by Joe Henderson. I heard this saxophone playing, and it was riveting, he said recently. I didnt know anything about jazz. But this thing jumped out and grabbed me. It was Mode for Joe.

title: Brooklyns Musical Matrix
description: About two years ago, when Bryce and Aaron Dessner began considering which acts to book for Crossing Brooklyn Ferry, the music festival they put together for the Brooklyn Academy of Music, they knew they wanted to represent the local scene. The Dessners, twin musicians who are part of the indie band the National, also realized that this was an impossible undertaking.

title: Novartis to Buy Fougera Pharmaceuticals for $1.5 Billion
description: Novartis International agreed on Wednesday to buy Fougera Pharmaceuticals, a maker of generic skin care medicine, for $1.525 billion in cash. The move would make the company the biggest manufacturer in the field.

title: Tender Trap
description: WILLIAMSBURGS indie spirit has been challenged by rampant development (Bedford Avenue is even blighted by a Duane Reade now), but not every newcomer kowtows to the condo dwellers. Tender Trap, an unassuming bar that opened in February, is practically a premillennial throwback: dirt-cheap drinks, good music and a goofy, artsy side that makes it feel like a neighborhood fixture.

title: Celebrity Perfumes Get Competition
description: WANT to smell like Cosmic Radiance? (According to Britney Spears, the perfume is a musky mix of citrus fruits and white flowers.) Or you, too, can feel as Lovely as Sarah Jessica Parker, play Truth or Dare like Madonna or ooze the official scent of Jennifer Aniston through your pores.

title: The Rail Bookshelf: How Kentucky Became Southern
description: An excerpt from Maryjean Walls book, How Kentucky Became Southern: A Tale of Outlaws, Horse Thieves, Gamblers, and Breeders.

title: Man Accused of Pushing Officer to His Death in Brooklyn Is Convicted
description: A man accused of pushing a police officer to his death from the stoop of a Brooklyn brownstone last year was convicted of manslaughter but acquitted of the more serious charge of murder on Wednesday.

title: Wiretaps Remain Crucial Evidence
description: Wiretaps are often the smoking gun that prosecutors like to use because a defendants own words can sway the jury in a criminal case.

title: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Egypt, India, Afghanistan and Syria.

title: A Satirist Goes for None-Too-Subtle Shading
description: IT took Andrew Shaffer 10 days to write Fifty Shames of Earl Grey, his parody of the best-selling erotic novel Fifty Shades of Grey. Little did he know it would land him a lucrative book deal in about as much time.

title: In Seoul, Two Hanoks Make a Modern Home
description: An art professor and preservationist combined history and modernity in two traditional wooden structures.

title: Connecting the Centuries
description: Seoul, South Korea

title: Back Spinning, After the World Stopped
description: Four months ago Jonathan Toubin woke up in a hospital bed barely alive. Mr. Toubin, a 40-year-old D.J. and rising figure in the Brooklyn music scene, had been lying in bed in a hotel room in Portland, Ore., resting up for a show, when a taxi crashed through the wall and pinned him under its wheels.

title: A Hospital in Bloom
description: To commemorate the closing of the Massachusetts Mental Health Centers old building in 2003, the artist Anna Schuleit was asked to create a work of art on the abandoned site. Some 28,000 pots of flowers were used for the Bloom installation.

title: Video: R.I.M. Rests Hopes on BlackBerry 10
description: Brian X. Chen and Peter Lattman discuss Research In Motions hopes for a comeback with BlackBerry 10. While people have been pessimistic about the companys chances to regain its footing in the smartphone market, the response to its new operating system was generally positive.

title: Balanchines Gift for Joining What Nature Has Sundered
description: The ballets of George Balanchine make the peculiar natural. You and I do not turn out our legs to 180 degrees; you and I do not dance on point. In the stage worlds of his ballets, however, these things become the premise through which music and drama become keener and more intense. Watching, we find our senses changed. The fusion of music and womanhood and academicism is heady stuff.

title: Pelfreys Fill-In Falters for 2nd Straight Time
description: HOUSTON  Mike Pelfrey had the ability to drive Mets fans mad with his inconsistency. Some of them may be missing him now.

title: Video: Complacency at Google and Facebook
description: Nick Bilton and Quentin Hardy discuss how the success of companies like Google and Facebook makes it harder for them to understand what people are looking for in the next generation of products.

title: The Business of Going Broke
description: Inside Republic Textile Equipments 60,000-square-foot warehouse, industrial-scale knitting equipment stands beside fabric-testing paraphernalia, which is next to printing machines and countless bins of spare parts. All of it, the remnants of factories and businesses gone bust, belongs to Mike Diamond, who has spent the last 50 years making a living in an industry that, for lack of a gentler term, might be called the going-broke business.

title: Seeking Redress When Air Travel Goes Awry
description: IN his 12 years as a semi-frequent traveler, David Shashoua never got bumped off a flight twice in one day.

title: Massage Spas, New Oases for the Harried Flier
description: ABOUT five years ago, Richard Laermer, a public relations executive, found himself with time to kill during a layover at Logan Airport in Boston.

title: After the Plane Gets You to the Airport, an App Comes in Handy
description: As many times as Ive seen an airport vendor selling a tired-looking sandwich for $10, Im still dumbstruck. Ill often circle the terminal for 20 minutes, starved and incredulous, before ending up with that miserable sandwich because its the least worst option.

title: The Business of Dealing With Kidnapping Abroad
description: WHEN the kidnappers shackled his feet and cuffed his hands, Edo de Ronde managed to restrain his fears. The Dutch marketing consultant, who was abducted last year in South Africa, kept calm in captivity, he recalled, until a gun was put to his head. Mr. de Ronde then asked himself, What will they say at my funeral?

title: Talking Business in Flight? Be Careful
description: PETER COCHRANE, a technology consultant, entrepreneur and blogger, usually unwinds on the train between his home in Ipswich, England, and London with coffee, cookies and a newspaper.

title: World Mind Sports Games Quarterfinals
description: At the trial to select the United States open team for the World Mind Sports Games in August, the 120-board quarterfinals were played on Tuesday and Wednesday. At the halfway stage these were the scores by captains names: Warren Spector 153 international match points, Nick Nickell 95; John Diamond 128, George Jacobs, 112; Roger Lee 121, Martin Fleisher 101; and Reese Milner 99, Jim Mahaffey 90. The final results can be found at usbf.org. Play in the semifinals (Thursday and Friday) and final (Saturday and Sunday) can be watched live at bridgebase.com starting at 11 a.m. Eastern Time.

title: How to Muddy Your Tracks on the Internet
description: Legal and technology researchers estimate that it would take about a month for Internet users to read the privacy policies of all the Web sites they visit in a year. So in the interest of time, here is the deal: You know that dream where you suddenly realize youre stark naked? Youre living it whenever you open your browser.

title: Apps That Do Everything but Pack Your Bags
description: YOUR corporate travel department is not a bad thing. It can negotiate preferred rates with hotels and car rental agencies. It can get a person on the phone when large travel companies keep you on hold until midnight.

title: V.I.P. Treatment Eases the Way Through Security
description: BIG spenders get special treatment  the world was ever thus. And those who spend the most money also receive increasingly preferential treatment at airport security.

title: Commission Rules for Bloomberg TV in Dial Dispute With Comcast
description: The Federal Communications Commission ruled in favor of Bloomberg TV on Wednesday, saying Comcast must program the less-watched cable channel in the same neighborhood on the cable dial as competitors like Fox Business and CNBC and more general news channels like CNN and MSNBC.

title: Hotels Close to the Runway, but Far From Stress
description: HOTELS at airports used to be lonely places where blackout curtains and soundproof walls were the biggest selling points. But creating ever more deluxe, relaxing retreats close to or even in the middle of airports is a growing trend.

title: The Quince, Coast to Coast
description: Quince trees, once de rigueur in Americas Colonial gardens, fell out of favor over the years. But some growers are still very attached to them.

title: In Praise of the Misunderstood Quince
description: AFTER half a century in public life, the most famous quince trees in New York are looking  lets say mature. Or how about distinguished?

title: For Health, Drink Water (but Dont Drink the Water)
description: EXPERTS agree that the best thing business travelers can do to reduce their chances of getting sick is to maximize their use of soap, water and hand sanitizer and minimize the number of times they touch their face. Other tips include:

title: The State of Mobile: Less Talking, Fewer Texts, More Data
description: People generally talk less on the phone and send fewer text messages now because there are so many ways to communicate over an Internet connection. Though this may seem obvious to anyone who owns a smartphone, a new study confirms the trend.

title: Your Road Buddies: Zillions of Germs
description: FOR Dr. Philip M. Tierno, business travel means combat. The enemy is heartless and relentless, stealthy and ubiquitous. It is poised to attack every second of the day, even when hes asleep. It exploits his rare moments of weakness and turns everyone and everything around him into agents who thoughtlessly do its bidding.

title: Is New Sex-Education Course Too Much or Just Enough?
Entrepreneuring Charity
description: Carol Roth, business analyst, evaluates an investor pitch from a small business.

title: Long Island Principal 'Horrified' by Quality of State Exams
Homes for $890,000
description: Properties in Missouri, Maine and Washington.

title: What You Get for $890,000
description: ST. LOUIS

title: What to Read on Your Way to Heaven
description: Maud Newton writes about her experience growing up among Christian fundamentalists in her Riff in the April 29 issue of the magazine on Todd Burpos best seller, Heaven Is for Real. In the book, Burpo recounts his 3-year-old sons near-death experience and resulting supernatural visions. Below is a selection of books included in Amazons Customers Who Bought This Item Also Bought list for Heaven Is for Real.

title: Prescriptions for Opioid Painkillers Climb in City
description: The number of opioid painkiller prescriptions filled for New York City residents rose 22 percent in two years, to more than two million in 2010, according to data released Wednesday by a city panel.

title: Sales at Jonathan Adler and Others
description: Bedding, pillows and table linens from John Robshaw are as much as 75 percent off, through May 4 (the Indigo Dip decorative pillow, regularly $100, is $40); 245 West 29th Street (Seventh Avenue), (212) 594-6006.

title: Market Ready
description: Q. My bedroom has worn carpet. Should I replace it with a hardwood flooring before trying to sell my home?

title: A Classic Collaboration
description: Olivia Putman has been busy since taking over as head of Studio Andre Putman, her well-known mothers Paris-based business, five years ago. Ms. Putman, 47, has designed furniture for Fermob, Emeco and Serralunga as well as the Le Rivage hotel in Hong Kong. And last week, she was in town to introduce a line of lighting created in collaboration with Lalique.

title: A Revival for a Modern Collection
description: The furniture manufacturer Herman Miller is reviving a concept it first developed in 1948: a selective portfolio of furniture for modern living that it believes will stand the test of time, known as the Herman Miller Collection.

title: Piecing Together an Interesting Tray
description: Designing a tray seems like it would be a relative no-brainer. But for Bruce and Stephanie Tharp of Materious, the Chicago-based design studio, it posed a challenge: how to bring something interesting to what is fundamentally just a flat surface, as Mr. Tharp put it.

title: Woods Is Back on the Course, but Saying Little
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  Tiger Woodss first drive Wednesday in his pro-am round for the Wells Fargo Championship split the fairway, giving credence to his assertion earlier in the week that he fixed the bad posture that led to his bad ball-striking at the Masters, his last competitive event.

title: A Countrys Attic, on Display
description: WASHINGTON

title: Inspiration Behind an Open Door
description: EVERY year, spring brings with it the promise of new planting, home improvement projects and renovations. Those in search of inspiration can find it in the houses and gardens open to the public across the country. Most tours are self-guided, unless otherwise noted.

title: An Artful Tower of Flowers
description: Several years ago, Royal Tichelaar Makkum, a Dutch ceramics company founded in the 16th century, restored two identical 17th-century flower pyramids for the Rijksmuseum in Amsterdam. At the time, the company also made a replica of one of the pyramids, which each consisted of 11 stacked vases. That replica, left, was a jumping-off point for four designers  Hella Jongerius, Studio Makkink & Bey, Studio Job and Alexander van Slobbe  to reinterpret the 17th-century pyramid. The first exhibition devoted solely to those designs, Pyramids of Makkum, opens May 10 at Gallery Libby Sellers in London.

title: Evan Roth, an Award-Winning Man of Many Tags
description: In street-culture circles, Evan Roth is already a boldface name, with a rsum that includes collaborating with Jay-Z on a music video and creating a computerized analysis of graffiti motion.

title: The Ultimate House Tour
description: A look inside the rooms at the White House that are open to the public.

title: A House Tour: Yes, That House
description: WASHINGTON

title: In Fairfield County, a Homeless Concours Seeks Shelter for 2013 and Beyond
description: A consulting group formed by the directors of the Fairfield County Concours dlgance, the collector-car weekend in southern Connecticut that traditionally marks the end of the concours season in the Northeast, announced this week that the event would not take place this year.

title: The Once and Future Mayor
description: London

title: A Hidden Nest Atop Barneys to Make Deals
description: GOLDEN birds are painted onto the thick columns of Freds at Barneys New York, the coolly elegant ninth-floor dining room of the department store. They perch stiffly, arch their necks and hold their beaks high; their plumes are perfectly groomed, their bodies remarkably thin. There is no question they inhabit the higher branches of their kingdom, much like the diners chirping beside them.

title: The Joy of Drawing on Glass
description: Much of the iPads magic  and its success  comes from the directness of the touch screen. For decades, you dragged a mouse on one surface to make the cursor move on another. And now, suddenly, you can tap or draw right on the screen.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Open Data and Turntable.fm
description: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Wednesday. See more here.

title: Bodleian Announces Crowd-Sourced Victorian Music Project
description: The Bodleian Library at Oxford is inviting citizen librarians to help describe and catalog its collection of 4,000 pieces of mid-Victorian music, the library announced.

title: Newt Gingrich Formally Suspends Campaign
description: Newt Gingrich formally suspended his campaign in a speech on Tuesday in Arlington, Va.

title: Boy Outsmarts Experts on Byzantine Empire
description: Benjamin Lerman Coady took one close look and knew it: the map on the wall of the Metropolitan Museum of Art was wrong.

title: Bodemeister Morning-Line Favorite for Derby
description: Bodemeister, coming off an impressive win in the Arkansas Derby, was installed as the 4-1 morning-line favorite for Saturdays $2 million Kentucky Derby after post positions were drawn Wednesday. Trained by Bob Baffert, Bodemeister will break from Post 6 for the mile-and-a-quarter race.

title: George Zimmermans Disparaging Remarks About Mexicans on MySpace
description: As George Zimmermans legal team began a new social media presence for him this week, one of its first challenges on the new Facebook page has been responding to questions about an old MySpace account, where he made disparaging remarks about Mexicans.

title: Airport Hotels Get an Upgrade
description: Airports and adjacent hotels are being renovated with an eye toward creating a more pleasing environment for the traveler.

title: In Brooklyn Brownstone, Future President Found a Home on the Top Floor
description: There is no plaque on the brownstone half a block from Prospect Park that says, Barack Obama slept here. Not yet, anyway.

title: Wireless Carriers Who Aid Police Are Asked for Data
description: WASHINGTON  A leading House Democrat is demanding information from the countrys biggest cellphone companies about their role in helping local police departments conduct surveillance and tracking of suspects and others in criminal investigations.

title: Americas Future Role in Afghanistan
description: To the Editor:

title: The Horses Are Noble; Some Humans Are Not
description: To the Editor:

title: Womens Rights in Turkey
description: To the Editor:

title: Organ Donors on Facebook
description: To the Editor:

title: The Good Work of Nuns
description: To the Editor:

title: Chess Leader Visits Syria Under Cloud of Ambiguity
description: MOSCOW  The president of the World Chess Federation, an eccentric Russian millionaire who last year tried to negotiate a settlement in Libyas civil war, has again shown up for talks with a faltering dictator.

title: Signs of Decision on Accused Philadelphia Priests
description: SPRINGFIELD, Pa.  Several hundred Roman Catholic priests from the Archdiocese of Philadelphia gathered Wednesday for a closed-door meeting with Archbishop Charles J. Chaput days before he has said he hopes to announce the results of an investigation into claims of sexual abuse against 27 priests.

title: Breakfast, but No Play
description: To the Editor:

title: Target, Unhappy With Being an Amazon Showroom, Will Stop Selling Kindles
description: Target, signaling its growing irritation with its rival Amazon, announced on Wednesday that it would stop selling the online retailers Kindle e-readers.

title: The Scream Sells at Sothebys for $120 Million, a Record
description: A version of Edvard Munchs The Scream, one of the most recognizable images in art history, sold at Sothebys on Wednesday night for just under $120 million, the most ever paid for an artwork at auction. Five bidders competed for the work, which sold to a telephone bidder.

title: Green Mountains Rocky Slide
description: Green Mountain Coffee Roasters reported disappointing financial results on Wednesday evening, adding weight to the criticisms of skeptical investors who are betting against the companys shares.

title: Devils Rookie Defenseman Regains His Edge
description: NEWARK  Adam Larsson, the Devils 19-year-old rookie defenseman, had grown a playoff beard, just in case he would actually get into a playoff game. His blond whiskers are thick and spiky, practically like a veterans.

title: Death of a Salesmans Dreams
description: ARTHUR MILLERs Death of a Salesman, now on Broadway in a Tony-nominated revival  and starring a heart-shattering Philip Seymour Hoffman as a Willy Loman for the ages  is the most devastating portrait of punctured middle-class dreams in our national literature. Yet as I sat through a recent performance, I wondered why the play was revived at all.

title: A Delicate New Balance on National Security
description: WASHINGTON  One moment he boasts about taking out Americas No. 1 enemy, and the next he vows to bring home troops from an unpopular war. For President Obama, the days leading up to his re-election kickoff have been spent straddling the precarious line between hawk and dove, and possibly redefining his party for years to come.

title: China Curbs on Currency Still an Issue
description: WASHINGTON  The pace of appreciation of the Chinese currency against the dollar has slowed in the last year, ensuring that Chinas manipulation of its exchange rate remains a central topic as Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner arrives in Beijing for the annual dialogue between the nations.

title: Israel Military Clears Soldiers in Deaths of Gaza Civilians
description: JERUSALEM  The Israeli military announced Wednesday that it had closed its investigation into the 2009 deaths of at least 21 members of an extended Palestinian family who were huddled in a house that was struck by Israeli shells or missiles during the Gaza war, and that no legal steps would be taken against any soldiers involved.

title: Methodists Vote Against Ending Investments Tied to Israel
description: The United Methodist Church, the nations largest mainline Protestant denomination, voted against two proposals on Wednesday to divest from companies that provide equipment used by Israel to enforce its control in the occupied territories.

title: Police Warrant Squads Were Used to Monitor Wall Street Protesters, Suspects Say
description: On Monday, the New York Police Department sent its warrant squads after an unusual set of suspects: people who had old warrants for the lowliest of violations, misconduct too minor, usually, to draw the attention of those squads.

title: Progress Is Seen in Advancing a Final Volcker Rule
description: A major new rule that has drawn the ire of Wall Street is on track for completion sooner than some bankers had expected, dashing the hopes of financial industry lobbyists, who have pressed for a delay.

title: Carlyle Prices I.P.O. at $22, Below Expected Level

Twenty 3-year-olds, mere adolescents, will go a marathon distance of a mile and a quarter for the first time, before more than 100,000 people, many teary-eyed from either the singing of My Old Kentucky Home or mint juleps.

title: Dolan and Bishops Urge Albany to Raise Minimum Wage

title: Subverting the Miranda Rule
description: When the Supreme Court ruled in the landmark Miranda case that criminal suspects in custody must be told of their right to have a lawyer and to remain silent, the purpose was to ensure that the police and prosecutors did not obtain a confession through improper means. But the office of the Queens district attorney, Richard Brown, has concocted a way around this basic principle with a central booking interview program in which prosecutors interrogate suspects before they are arraigned or have counsel assigned to them. Fortunately, a state trial judge has found the program misleading, deceptive and unethical, and will not allow the district attorneys office to use statements from this type of interview at trial.

description: LONDON  Britains biggest satellite broadcaster, British Sky Broadcasting, or BSkyB, distanced itself on Wednesday from its largest shareholder, Rupert Murdochs News Corporation, in a sign of the difficulties Mr. Murdoch faces here following a scathing parliamentary report that declared him not fit to run a global media empire.

title: A New View of the Aqueous Globe
description: There is a river in the ocean are the first words in Matthew Fontaine Maurys pioneering work, The Physical Geography of the Sea, first published in 1855. Sailors have always been aware of ocean rivers  currents, that is  but Maury was the first to produce a scientific chart of the major currents. It was based on thousands of observations recorded by seamen and was, in a sense, an expanded version of the Gulf Stream chart printed in 1769 by Benjamin Franklin after consulting a Nantucket skipper.

title: California: Faculty Agrees to Campus Strike in the Fall
description: Faculty members in the California State University system said Wednesday that they had approved plans for a two-day rolling strike at campuses all over the state. The California Faculty Association, which represents professors, lecturers and librarians at the systems 23 universities, has been negotiating with administrators for new contract for nearly two years. Union officials said that the strike was endorsed by 95 percent of the 12,500 members who voted last month. The rolling strike, which would not take place until the fall, would be the largest faculty strike in the states history and would take place over two days at each campus, ultimately affecting more than 400,000 students. The state has cut roughly $970 million from the California State University system since 2008, and university officials have responded by lowering the number of students admitted and raising tuition 23 percent. The union has asked for a 1 percent raise and says that administrators have asked to freeze faculty salaries, which have not increased since 2008.

title: Report Points to Decline in Ability to Monitor the Earth
description: Earth-observing systems operated by the United States have entered a steep decline, imperiling the nations monitoring of weather, natural disasters and climate change, a report from the National Research Council warned Wednesday. Long-running and new missions are frequently delayed, lost or canceled because of budget cuts, launching failures, disorganization and changes in mission design and scope, the report said. Its likely our capabilities will decline fairly precipitously at just the time theyre most needed, said Dennis Hartmann, a professor of atmospheric sciences at the University of Washington and the chairman of the committee that produced the report. He mentioned the continuing federal budget crisis, the aging of equipment, a severe shortage of medium-size satellite launchers, and some initiatives that cost billions of dollars without producing results.

title: South Korea: North Accused of Sending Jamming Signals to Disrupt GPS
description: South Korean government officials accused North Korea on Wednesday of sending out jamming signals in an apparent attempt to disrupt civilian and military air and ground traffic in the South, forcing 252 commercial flights to switch off their GPS devices. The North has tried to sabotage South Koreas use of GPS, widely employed in air, sea and ground navigation, at least three times since 2010, the Korea Communications Commission said. The commission said the latest jamming began Saturday, after North Koreas recent warnings of special actions to attack the government of President Lee Myung-bak in South Korea and the Souths conservative news media, which the North accuses of insulting its leadership.

title: U.N. Resolution Threatens Sanctions Against Sudan and South Sudan
description: The United Nations Security Council approved a resolution on Wednesday threatening Sudan and South Sudan with sanctions if they failed to halt escalating cross-border fighting that was called a serious threat to international peace. The resolution demanded the nations resume negotiations on fraught issues like oil sharing to try to stop the violence. Russia and China, which have resisted voting against Sudan in the past, joined in the unanimous passage of the resolution. The resolution also called for both nations to remove their forces from Abyei, arguably the most iconic of numerous contested regions along the border. Last month, hostilities heated up when South Sudan captured the oil-rich region of Heglig from Sudan. It later withdrew, after Sudanese airstrikes and pressure from the international community, but clashes between the two nations continue along the border, as well as inside South Sudans territory.

title: Honduras: Neglect Cited in Prison Fire
description: The Inter-American Commission on Human Rights said Wednesday that the conditions that led to the Feb. 14 fire that killed 361 people at the Comayagua national prison were the result of decades of neglect of Hondurass prisons and iron-fisted anticrime policies. A commission delegation that visited the prison and two others late last month concluded that the most worrisome problem in Hondurass prisons was that the authorities had effectively ceded control to the prisoners themselves, in part because guards were not properly trained. This has led to high levels of violence and corruption, in a context of absolute impunity, the commission said. The delegation also found severe overcrowding, as well as unsafe housing and inadequate food, water and medical care.

description: BEIT IJZA, West Bank  One of the first statements under oath that I took for Al Haq, a human rights organization I helped establish, was from Sabri Garaib, a farmer from Beit Ijza, a Palestinian village ten miles northwest of Jerusalem. I remember sitting on the porch of his house overlooking the garden and the low, undulating hills planted with wheat and barley that spread out on all sides. All 112 acres, I was told, were in danger of being expropriated by the new Jewish settlement of Givon Hahadasha.

title: The Soft-Shell Hard Sell
description: Although fish come and go according to the season, seafood has become, like many other foods, a global commodity that can be had at any time. The soft-shell crab remains an exception. Starting in May and throughout the summer, the blue crab abandons its shell and starts to form a new one, making its sweet, briny, delicious meat  usually incredibly tough to get at  immediately accessible. When the crab is molting, in fact, practically the whole thing is edible, and the new shell is among the best parts. The combination of tenderness and crunch makes it one of the great delights of eating. (If youre squeamish about this, I suggest you get over it, or swear off animal products altogether.)

title: Honey, I Got a Years Worth of Tuna Fish
description: Forty-five minutes before midnight on a wintry Tuesday evening, Cathy Yoder and Monica Knight, a pair of 30-something Boise women who run a popular coupon blog called Fabulessly Frugal, strode with purpose through the parking lot of their local Albertsons supermarket. It was the third and final night of doubles at Albertsons. This biweekly happening, during which the store issues coupons that double the value of manufacturers coupons, is to dedicated coupon clippers what the full moon was to Druids. Yoder and Knight, who are Mormon and have nine children between them (Yoder: seven; Knight: two) had spent the day working on their blog and then taught a three-hour couponing class  all without a drop of forbidden caffeine. Yet with the supermarket in sight, they grew visibly jazzed, like Vegas high rollers entering a casino. Well have it all to ourselves, and well know all the cashiers, Knight said.
