title: Editors Letter
description: Anyone who has ever renovated a house knows that construction invariably takes longer than expected. You make your decisions about floors and walls, and then weeks become months become, in some instances, years. And you realize that even when taste is a given, patience is a virtue. In this issue we feature homes that are a testament to the consistency and tenacity of their owners. For Francis Upritchard and Martino Gamper, as we learn in Marina Cashdans profile, it was a matter of rethinking a curious apartment with no real features (and in a London housing project, no less) over time, when their artistic careers permitted, and with the help of resourceful, clever compatriots. Then there are Jason Schmidt and Bill Mullens majestic portraits of New York style setters who dress like their sofas. Finally, in the case of Jon Rosen and Tiina Laakkonen, it was the decision to build from scratch a Scandinavian-inspired compound in Amagansett, N.Y., that was, soup to nuts, of their imagining. And did it drag on? Well, a bit.

title: A Sneak Peek at Thomas Demands Storm-Tossed Imagination

But where most viewers might have forwarded the link to their friends, Demand decided to recreate the scene, minus the people, entirely out of paper and cardboard, then film it.

description: Earlier this year, just before the governments January employment report came out, I wrote that creating 150,000 jobs per month seemed to be a rough breakeven number for President Obama. If payroll growth came in above that number, he looked to be a favorite for re-election and an underdog otherwise.

title: Deweys Fall Underscores Law Firms New Reality
description: When I graduated from law school in the 1970s, Dewey, Ballantine, Bushby, Palmer & Wood rolled off the tongue in the same company as Sullivan & Cromwell, Davis Polk & Wardwell, and Cravath, Swaine & Moore, venerable New York firms whose place at the pinnacle of the law profession seemed unassailable. For a young lawyer, a job at any of them was the first step to the golden ring of partnership and, with it, lifetime tenure, prestige and affluence.

title: Turning Virginia Blue
description: In 2008, Barack Obama became the first Democrat to win Virginia in more than 40 years, in part because of inroads he made in the Richmond area and growing suburbs in the southern part of the state.

title: Tell Us About the MCA You Knew
description: Adam Yauch was a New Yorker of countless locations  from the halls of Brooklyn Friends School and Murrow High School to the streets of the East Village to seemingly every single loft, club and venue where noise could be made and shows bum-rushed. Perhaps in his travels across the city, you met Mr. Yauch, before he was a Beastie Boy, when he was touring, or when he went by MCA or Nathanial Hornblower. Tell us about it.

title: Serbs Losing Fervor for European Union Accession
description: PETROVAC NA MLAVI, Serbia  Looking eerily like the Serbian strongman Slobodan Milosevic, a stout and stern-faced Ivica Dacic roused supporters crowded in a sports arena here this past week, promising to protect Serbs from the ravages of capitalism and warning that violence against Serbs in Kosovo was tantamount to an assault on Belgrade.

title: The Short Hot Life of Heartlands Hateful Climate Billboard
description: The online spin cycle on global warming has become so fast and toxic that an electronic billboard in Chicago can flash an ultra-offensive message designed to draw attention to a conference of climate contrarians, then generate a global burst of Web traffic and then be withdrawn 24 hours later as a necessary price to make an emotional appeal to people who otherwise arent following the climate change debate (the statement this afternoon from the Heartland Institute, the group that paid for the messages).

title: An Indie Impresario, Who Made His Mark Fast and Memorably
description: Adam Yauch, who died Friday of cancer at 47, was one of the best things to happen to American independent cinema in years. In February 2008, when Mr. Yauch announced the arrival of his distribution company, Oscilloscope Pictures, which he founded with David Fenkel, it sent a jolt through the indie world. An offshoot of Mr. Yauchs Oscilloscope Laboratories, his and Mr. Fenkels new film division entered the fray right on the heels of a very strong Sundance Film Festival, when to many of us everything still looked so right in the indie business.

title: Believe You Can Wins Kentucky Oaks
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  Rosie Napravnik was a little heart broken. She wants desperately to win a Kentucky Derby, but saw those dreams delayed earlier this week when the colt she was to ride, Mark Valeski, was not fit enough for his trainer, Larry Jones, and scratched. But that was no reason to leave town; she was riding a filly named Believe You Can in the Grade I $1 million Kentucky Oaks on Friday.

In a telephone interview from San Francisco on Friday, Gallardo said he was told he would miss the rest of the season. Yet with Milwaukee pushing for the playoffs, he returned on Sept. 25 and started Game 1 of the division series. He said he did not do extra work beyond the regular rehab protocol.

description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  No one begrudged Shivananda Parbhoo his ear-to-ear smile on Friday morning. It was the day before the Kentucky Derby, and he had a horse named Trinniberg with a date in the starting gate. He had picked the colt out himself at a sale in Florida for a bargain price of $21,000.

description: He moved slowly and relied on a walker, but Representative Charles B. Rangel vowed on Friday to wage an energetic primary fight against an aggressive Democratic challenger.

title: More Long Island Rail Road Retirees Are to Face Fraud Charges
description: A prosecutor said on Friday that about 10 more people would be charged in what the government has called a huge fraud scheme involving hundreds of Long Island Rail Road workers, some of whom collected extra benefits each year after falsely claiming to have disabling injuries while retiring to lives of vigorous activity, including golf, tennis, aerobics and biking.

title: Now Online | T Design and Living
description: For the summer Design and Living issue of T, we really get into peoples personal space. It starts with the cover story, Tiina Laakkonens farmhouse on Long Island, which the fashion stylist and former model has filled with furniture and objects from her native Finland. Then there is the London council flat shared by the artist Francis Upritchard and the furniture designer Martino Gamper, a quirky space the creative couple transformed with their own two hands. We also meet three style setters whose interiors are so in sync with their exteriors that they practically blend in with the furniture (in a good way, of course!). Thomas Beller writes about his life divided between two cities he loves: New York and New Orleans. And Susan Morgan takes a tour of the tiny house that the visionary architect Anne Griswold Tyng designed for herself. It contains all of her biggest ideas writ small. Take a peek!

title: Monserrate Pleads Guilty to the Misuse of City Funds
description: Hiram Monserrate, a former city councilman and state senator, pleaded guilty on Friday to improperly using Council money to finance a failed political campaign.

description: The largest Christian television network faces allegations of ethics violations from an unlikely source.

title: In Elections, Greeks Are Expected to Make Old Guard Pay for Turmoil
description: ATHENS  In the two years since Greece asked for a foreign bailout, its leaders have had trouble governing even with a clear majority. Now, as the country heads to elections on Sunday in which no single party is expected to secure enough votes to form a stable government, they may have to try governing with political chaos.

title: Job Numbers Become Instant Campaign Fodder
description: WASHINGTON  Mitt Romney responded to Fridays weaker-than-expected job numbers with a sweeping denunciation, declaring it a terrible and very disappointing report  evidence of an economy that is slowing down, not speeding up.

description: In the first move of what figures to be a contentious fight, the N.F.L. players union launched its defense of four New Orleans Saints players suspended for their roles in the teams bounty program with a three-pronged attack on Commissioner Roger Goodells authority.

title: Rules Tightened on Municipal Bond Deals
description: Federal regulators trying to prevent more debt disasters like the one in Jefferson County, Ala., tightened a rule on Friday for the brokerage firms that help cities and states raise billions of dollars every year.

title: Rising Early, With a New Sentence in Mind
description: Robert A. Caro, 76, has spent half his life exploring the vicissitudes of power, in his Pulitzer Prize-winning 1974 biography of Robert Moses, The Power Broker, and in his monumental biography of Lyndon B. Johnson, now up to its fourth volume, The Passage of Power, which was published this month. Mr. Caro lives on Central Park West with his wife, Ina, whose most recent book is Paris to the Past: Traveling Through French History by Train. He typically spends Sunday working.

title: For China, a Dissident in Exile Is One Less Headache Back Home
description: After more than a week of high-level diplomacy over the fate of the blind activist Chen Guangcheng, the Chinese government was widely seen as making a major concession on Friday by agreeing to allow Mr. Chen to apply to leave for the United States.

title: Rapper Conquered Music World in 80s With Beastie Boys
description: Adam Yauch, a rapper and founder of the pioneering and multimillion-selling hip-hop group the Beastie Boys, died on Friday in Manhattan. He was 47.

title: Ethics Panel Fines Espada $80,000
description: ALBANY  Former State Senator Pedro Espada Jr. was ordered to pay $80,000 on Friday by the New York State Legislative Ethics Commission, which said he had violated state law by hiring his uncle.

title: Report Lists Many Flaws in Handling of 911 Calls
description: New York Citys 911 emergency dispatch system sometimes sends firefighters or police officers to the wrong address. Operators sometimes waste precious seconds and sow confusion by failing to follow a standard script when taking information from callers. And, sometimes, an emergency operator can ask eight questions about a callers location and other details, then patch in another operator who asks six more questions, before getting to the most important one: What is the emergency?

title: In Instant, Riveras Understudy Becomes Successor
description: Until now, Dave Robertson was a rising deputy, an increasingly valuable piece of the Yankees bullpen.

title: Remember, Remember, the Fifth of May
description: Most Americans would be hard pressed to recount the events surrounding Cinco de Mayo, a holiday better associated with margaritas and lime-necked Coronas than any historical event. Some wrongly believe that May 5th is Mexican Independence Day (thats actually Sept. 16th); others believe it marks the glorious founding of the countrys alcohol industry.

title: Exit Ramps Lead Right Back Here
description: Nine years ago, when I was introduced to my future husband by a mutual friend, he was working in Nashville, and living 885 miles away, in a town house apartment in Brooklyn. To afford this unusual arrangement, he spent the three or four nights a week that he was in Tennessee at a Motel 6  not the Motel 6 closest to his place of employment, but a cheaper branch farther away from the interstate where the sheets, forgetting discussions of thread count, possessed the feel of something made at Union Carbide.

title: Lottery Numbers
In a Season Filled With Streaks, Goalie Stays on an Unsteady Course
description: Ilya Bryzgalov signed a nine-year, $51 million contract with the Philadelphia Flyers in the off-season to help stifle the goaltending despair that has hounded the team since the departure of Ron Hextall in the late 1990s. But Bryzgalovs first season on Broad Street has been inconsistent from opening night to the postseason.

title: A Clear Warning From the Jobs Numbers
description: This weeks economic news was mixed, but the employment report on Friday was unmistakably weak. The economy added only 115,000 jobs in April, versus 154,000 in March and 200,000-plus in each of the three months before that. Even taking into account that unusually warm winter weather probably distorted the recent results, the underlying trend shows an economy that has been creating about 175,000 jobs a month  enough to keep the recovery crawling along, but too weak to appreciably raise hiring or wages.

title: City Bookkeeper Charged With Stealing $2.6 Million From Estates
description: A bookkeeper in the office of the Brooklyn public administrator stole more than $2.6 million from the estates of people who died without wills over a period of three years, prosecutors charged on Friday.

title: Chen Guangchengs Uncertain Future
description: There is fresh hope in the harrowing odyssey of Chen Guangcheng. Nothing is guaranteed, but after days of frantic diplomacy by American diplomats  and bluster and threats from Chinas government  the dissident and self-taught lawyer may be allowed to travel to the United States on a student visa, and bring his wife and children with him.

title: New Yorks Children Shouldnt Pay the Price
description: Mayor Michael Bloomberg this week put out his revised proposal for the next city budget  a $68.7 billion plan that spares teachers, police and firefighters but slashes vital programs for needy children. That is not the way to balance a budget.

title: Building in Harlem Caves In
Fault Line
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  Wow, this one was a thorny grid for me to navigate. Quite a mental workout, some Stuff I Just Didnt Know, and a few misdirects (like filling in NOM de guerre instead of CRI), but ultimately doable. And yet, despite having to walk away and come back and few times, it felt very satisfying when I finished. Maybe Im just becoming a real Saturday solver.

title: A Day Off Recharges the Weary Rangers
description: WASHINGTON  After a day off to see a movie, walk around town or tour Arlington National Cemetery, the Rangers were fresh and loose at practice Friday. It was their first time on the ice since they won Game 3 in the wee hours of Thursday morning, after 114 minutes 41 seconds of sweat-drenched, bone-rattling, muscle-burning hockey.

title: The Scream on the Block
description: Looking at Edvard Munchs 1895 pastel The Scream, its hard not to see it as a commentary on the price it brought at Sothebys in New York this week  $119,922,500, the highest auction price ever paid for a work of art. In a pose treasured by winners of beauty pageants (as well as trick-or-treaters and many others), Munchs figure on a bridge seems to be shrieking with  you decide.

description: The Rails contributors welcome this years Kentucky Derby guest picker, Eddie Olczyk, an NBC Sports hockey analyst who played 16 seasons as a center in the N.H.L. before coaching the Pittsburgh Penguins from 2003 to 2005.

title: Aleppo Clash Poses Risk of Widening Syrian Revolt
description: Syrias government risked stoking a new source of rebellion on Friday when its forces fired on a mass demonstration in Aleppo, the countrys largest city, where activist groups said thousands of people had massed to demonstrate against the violent closing of the main university there the day before. At least four demonstrators were said to be killed.

description: Miles from downtown Denver, in a small warehouse on the citys edge, Bernadette Atencio watched as two men methodically bundled piles of dead eagles into boxes, careful to include enough frozen gel packs so the remains would not thaw.

description: Next week is National Teacher Appreciation Week, and, as far as Im concerned, they dont get nearly enough.

title: Mantles Knee Injury Was Just the Start
description: There had been no real competition for most famous knee injury in Yankees history. That would have been Mickey Mantles, in Game 2 of the 1951 World Series, on the games biggest stage, in front of 66,018 at Yankee Stadium. Then came the one Thursday night to closer Mariano Rivera, while he shagged fly balls in batting practice in a mostly empty stadium in Kansas City, Mo., one of the games smallest stages.

description: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif.  For 39 years, the Trinity Broadcasting Network has urged viewers to give generously and reap the Lords bounty in return.

title: Trinity Broadcasting Network: A Nonprofit Corporations Balance Sheet
description: This is the 2010 tax form filed by the Trinity Broadcasting Network, which is legally registered as the Trinity Christian Center of Santa Ana, Inc. Nonprofit corporations are required to report their sources of income, expenditures, executive salaries and other information on the 990 form. This filing, the latest that is publicly available, shows that TBN received $93 million in tax-free grants and donations in 2010.

title: Solid Start, Some Timely Hits, Then the Bullpen Was Called
description: An unforgiving script was replayed on Friday night for the Mets. A strong starting pitching performance, backed by solid run support, gave way to a relief corps incapable of holding the lead in a 5-4 loss to the Diamondbacks at Citi Field. It was the Mets fourth straight defeat.

description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  If the injured Mariano Rivera needed any convincing that age need not be a deterrent in his return from a serious knee injury, Derek Jeter provided it on Friday night.

description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  Wandering drives and errant putts undermined Tiger Woods on Friday at the Wells Fargo Championship, as he missed the cut for the eighth time in 267 P.G.A. events and for the second time in a row at this tournament.

title: Phoebe Jacobs, Publicist for Jazz Greats, Dies at 93
description: Among the many jazz stories that Phoebe Jacobs delighted in telling, one always stood out as characteristic of her tenacious and resourceful service to the music. It was the wee hours of an April morning in the 1950s, and Ella Fitzgerald had finished her last set at Basin Street East in Midtown. Ms. Jacobs, a publicist and general assistant for the club at the time, was walking her to the door when Fitzgerald, glancing at her wristwatch, casually remarked that it was her birthday.

title: After Giving Youngster a Try, the Mets Turn to a Veteran
description: When Mike Pelfrey sustained an arm injury at the end of last month, an opportunity opened for a young Chris Schwinden to hop into the Mets rotation, as he had done at the end of last season.

title: Defining the It Horse in the Derby
description: For serious handicappers, horses rise to the top of the Triple Crown contender list based primarily on their performances on the racetrack. Its a fairly straightforward premise: the horse either wins, or at least performs very well, or it doesnt. The assumption is that the more a horse wins or at least acquits itself well in challenging stakes-level company, the greater the likelihood it will continue to do so. At least thats the theory. Its basic quantitative analysis. But take away the numeric data and few handicappers  and probably even fewer $2 bettors  likely could spot a true quality horse at first glance without clutching their quantitative performance data as an essential guidepost.

title: Zvi Zeitlin, Violinist Who Championed Modernist Composers, Dies at 90
description: Zvi Zeitlin, an internationally renowned violinist known for interpreting the work of contemporary composers, died on Wednesday in Rochester. He was 90.

title: Batsman Offers New Dimension to Twenty20 Matches
description: Twenty20, the newest and shortest of crickets three formats, favors the games sluggers, Huw Richards writes in The New York Times.

title: A Religious TV Empire
description: Paul and Janice Crouch, who built the worlds largest Christian television operation, have been criticized for secrecy about their use of public donations and are now facing lawsuits by a granddaughter.

title: Armenia: Rally Balloons Explode
description: Scores of people were hurt in Yerevan, the capital, on Friday when gas-filled balloons exploded in a huge ball of flames at a campaign rally for Armenias Republican Party ahead of parliamentary elections on Sunday. More than 60 people, including children, were hospitalized after the explosion, and photographs showed bystanders fleeing as flames shot up in a crowded square. The Emergencies Ministry said 144 people had been injured; some were burned and others were hurt during the panic after the explosion. No deaths were reported. Nikolai Grigoryan, the deputy director of Armenias rescue service, told the Novosti Armenia news agency that the balloons had been filled with helium and were ignited by a bystanders cigarette. However, helium is an inert gas that does not burn.

title: Russia: Gay Rights Activist Fined
description: A court in St. Petersburg on Friday fined a gay rights campaigner about $170 in the first application of a new municipal law against distributing what the law calls gay propaganda. The charge stemmed from a rally held last month, where the campaigner, Nikolai Alekseyev, carried a poster that said: Homosexuality is not a perversion. What is a perversion is field hockey and ice dancing. The St. Petersburg law is the model for a bill that has been submitted to the lower house of Parliament, which could be applied nationwide if approved. Mr. Alekseyev said he would appeal the verdict.

title: The Powers of New York
description: Influence in New York is now wielded by a larger and more diverse array of people. Heres a look at who is at the top and who may be on the way, as identified by the reporters of The New York Times.

title: Riveras Not Ready to Close the Book
description: A look at some highs and lows of Mariano Riveras 18 years with the Yankees.

title: Israel: Brother of Rabins Killer Is Freed After Serving His Sentence
description: Hagai Amir, 43, the brother of the killer of Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin, was released from prison on Friday after serving 16 years for helping to plan the 1995 assassination. Mr. Amir emerged from the prison in central Israel raising his fingers in a V sign. He told reporters that he had no regrets, adding, I am proud of what I did. For some Israelis, the release opened old wounds of one of the most traumatic events in recent Israeli history. Dozens of leftists waiting outside the prison shouted Disgrace! as Mr. Amir was driven away in a van. The killer, Yigal Amir, a right-wing Jewish extremist, is serving a life sentence for shooting Mr. Rabin after a peace rally in Tel Aviv.

title: Equality and Fraternity Through the Eyes of an American in Paris
description: The French television channel, France 3, invited a half dozen international correspondents to examine an issue playing out in the French presidential campaign through their personal lens. Rendezvouss editor, Marcus Mabry, chose the state of Frances Arab and African minorities.

title: How Mariano Rivera Compares to Baseballs Best Closers
description: Considered the best closer in baseball history, Mariano Rivera has more saves than any other pitcher.

title: Science and Truth: Were All in It Together
description: THE greatest bird news of our lifetime occurred at the height of the George W. Bush administration. In April 2005, amid a pageant of flags and cabinet ministers in Washington, John Fitzpatrick, the director of the Cornell Lab of Ornithology, announced that an ivory-billed woodpecker had been spotted for the first time in more than half a century in an Arkansas swamp.

title: Mexico: 23 Bodies Discovered
description: Twenty-three bodies, nine of them hanging from a bridge and the rest decapitated and found in a van, were discovered Friday in Nuevo Laredo, across the border from Laredo, Tex., the Mexican authorities said. The heads of the decapitated victims were later found in three coolers near a municipal building. The gruesome discovery, believed to be related to battles among criminal gangs, comes less than a month after the dismembered remains of 14 men were found in the citys downtown. Nuevo Laredo is in Tamaulipas State, one of the countrys most violent.

title: Guilty Plea in Conspiracy Case Linked to Colombian Guerrillas
description: A former member of the Syrian military pleaded guilty on Friday in federal court in Manhattan to conspiracy to provide material support to a Colombian terrorist organization. The case stemmed from an international sting operation run by the United States Drug Enforcement Administration. An indictment charged that the defendant, Jamal Yousef, agreed to provide military-grade weapons to the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC, for hundreds of kilograms of cocaine. The supposed FARC representative he was dealing with was actually an informant for the D.E.A., the authorities have said. In return for his plea, prosecutors agreed to drop a narcoterrorism conspiracy charge against Mr. Yousef, 54, who faces a maximum of 15 years in prison when he is sentenced in August.

title: Indian State Carrier Fined $80,000 by American Authorities
description: The U.S. Department of Transportation has fined the state-run Indian carrier, Air India, $80,000 for noncompliance with regulations. The airline failed to post customer service and tarmac delay contingency plans on its website and adequately inform passengers about its optional fees by the required date, a news release issued by the department said.

title: Classic Ad: Toyota Corolla GT-S
description: The popularity of Japanese performance models from the mid-1980s among collectors, customizers and wannabe street-racers is no secret, especially since the release of the Fast and Furious films. description: Jammu and Kashmir: In southern Kashmirs Shopian district, two terrorism suspects disarmed police officers guarding a village with a majority Hindu population, Hindustan Times reported. This is one of the few villages in the Valley where Hindus have continued to live even after the migration of thousands of Hindu families from the Muslim-dominated state at the peak of militancy in 1990, the newspaper said.

title: Living in the New Metropolis
description: About half of humanity lives in a city, and by 2050, its likely that 70 percent of the worlds population will be in urban areas, according to United Nations predictions, Martin Roemers writes in the Sunday Review of The New York Times.

description: OMAHA  Tens of thousands of shareholders gathered at the CenturyLink Center here to take in Warren E. Buffetts pronouncements on his massive conglomerate, the global economy and whatever else tickles his or investors fancy. description: A little more than a week ago, the Cambodian forest activist Chut Wutty died under circumstances for which officials have already provided three different accounts.

description: 1) There are five guys on the masthead who have the title Surfer Photographer, a designation apart from the magazines Senior Photographers and Contributing Photographers. I like my job plenty, but Im guessing that Chris Burkard, Jason Childs, Todd Glaser, Morgan Maassen and Zak Noyle like theirs more.

title: James Cameron on Chinese Filmmakers, Censorship and Potential Co-Productions
description: BEIJING  James Cameron, director of Titanic and Avatar, among other well-known movies, visited Beijing in mid-April for the Beijing International Film Festival. The festival was screening the 3-D version of Titanic, which had recently opened in theaters here. More important, Mr. Cameron was here to meet with people in the Chinese film industry to talk about doing joint productions and getting greater distribution for his 3-D films, which use technology developed by Cameron Pace Group, or C.P.G.

title: At a Hearing, 9/11 Detainees Show Defiance
description: GUANTNAMO BAY, Cuba  Khalid Shaikh Mohammed fingered his long, henna-dyed beard and stared down in silence on Saturday, pointedly ignoring a military commissions judge asking in vain whether the self-described architect of the Sept. 11 attacks understood what was being said and whether he was willing to be represented by his defense lawyers.

title: Economic Tribalism
description: Hmm. This seems to be meta Saturday, with reactions to how people think  or, all too often, dont think  about economics taking center stage.

title: Surprise! A President Runs for Re-Election
description: As President Obama heads to Ohio and Virginia on Saturday to kick off his re-election campaign, it seems a curiosity to remember that it has been 20 years since an incumbent president formally announced his intent to run for a second term.

title: Mammoth Trees, Champs of the Ecosystem
description: Its important to respect your elders, children are reminded. It seems that this goes for trees, too.

description: Q. You are a new college graduate without a job or concrete career plans. You might be interested in doing public service work for a year or two. Could that help you find your way to a career?

title: Playing for Tees, and $5
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  A boy with a used set of left-handed womens clubs would spend all day playing at a par-3 course in San Diego for roughly the price of a childs movie ticket. He met another boy who became his first rival. This is how Phil Mickelson punched his ticket to the World Golf Hall of Fame, through a lifetime of identifying targets and taking aim at them as if they were flags on the practice range.

title: Burnett Records a Dubious Achievement
description: When Jered Weaver of the Los Angeles Angels threw a no-hitter last Wednesday, it was not the most unusual pitching line in the majors that day. In the last 30 years, 55 pitchers have thrown a no-hitter. But only five in that stretch have done what A. J. Burnett did Wednesday in St. Louis.

title: Guidry Can Relate to Allure of Outfield
description: Ron Guidry understood perfectly. He knew why Mariano Rivera loved shagging fly balls during batting practice and why Riveras dream has been to play center field before his certain first-ballot Hall of Fame career was over.

title: Faltering German Party, a Coalition Partner to Merkel, Faces an Electoral Test
description: COLOGNE, Germany  It is campaign season here along the Rhine River, and the main street in the gentrifying neighborhood of Deutz could be viewed as something of a microcosm of German politics.

title: Last Reactor of 50 in Japan Is Shut Down
description: TOKYO  Japans last operating reactor was taken offline Saturday, as public distrust created by last years nuclear disaster forced the nation to at least temporarily do without atomic power for the first time in 42 years.

title: Dance Lessons in Life
description: I COME from a family that loves dancing. When I was in high school my mother decided I should learn to dance, so she bought me ballroom dance lessons as a graduation gift. She believed people should be comfortable walking onto a dance floor with a partner. For a while, I was obsessive about dancing. One summer I painted a dance studio in exchange for more lessons.

title: Variety: A Gem of an Acrostic
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  What a fascinating book this quote comes from.

title: Outgoing Owner and Quiet Trainer Lend Color to a Nearly White Colt
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  Dr. Kendall Hansen is a man of many words. Mike Maker, the trainer of Hansens namesake colt, is just the opposite.

description: To the Editor:

title: Manchester City Facing a Stern Test in Newcastle
description: Two obstacles stand in the way of Manchester City and its first top-level title in England since 1967-68: Pappis Ciss and Newcastle United. Then there is next Sundays game against the relegation-challenged Queens Park Rangers to end the Premier League season.

title: Coining Terminology for Life on the Web
description: WHEN a friend recently asked for advice about using social media, I excitedly embarked on a description of my daily routine  checking in on Foursquare to share my whereabouts with friends, posting tweets to Twitter, sharing screenshots from the latest Mad Men episode on Tumblr, and skimming through the stylized images on Instagram.

title: When Hillary Meets Didi
description: On Monday in Kolkata, the U.S. secretary of state, Hillary Rodham Clinton, is scheduled to meet with the chief minister of West Bengal, Mamata Banerjee,(nickname Didi or Big Sister) a woman whose power over Indian central government decisions has been virtually unchecked but whose increasingly erratic actions are raising concern  even in her own party.

title: Damming the Amazon
description: Brazil is planning to build at least 20 hydroelectric dams in the Amazon region by 2020, but indigenous residents say they are threatened and so is the rain forest.

title: Amid Brazils Rush to Develop, Workers Resist
description: As the country moves to tap one of the worlds last great reserves of hydroelectric power, the Amazon basin, strikes and worker uprisings at the biggest projects are producing delays and cost overruns.

title: For Hard of Hearing, Clarity Out of the Din
description: DIGITAL hearing aids can do wonders for faded hearing. But other devices can help, too, as audio technology adds new options to help people converse at a noisy restaurant, or talk quietly with a pharmacist at a crowded drugstore counter.

title: Amid Brazils Rush to Develop, Workers Resist
description: JACI PARAN, Brazil  The revolt here on the banks of the Madeira River, the Amazons largest tributary, flared after sunset. At the simmering end of a 26-day strike by 17,000 workers last month, a faction of laborers who were furious over wages and living conditions began setting fire to the construction site at the Jirau Dam.

title: On the Eve of the Derby
description: In what is now an annual pilgrimage, I journey to Louisville to see the finest 3-year-old horses compete on the first Saturday of May. My first Kentucky Derby  in 2009, when Mine That Bird upset the field  was overwhelming, exhilarating and a deluge of sensory stimulation (perhaps hovering on overload). Famous jockeys, world-renowned trainers, media personalities I have seen on television, and some of the best-looking horses I have ever seen. It was incredible. It was fabulous. It was everything I could have wished for and more! And when I won a significant amount of money betting on a long shot to win, I hustled to the gift store to purchase a commemorative piece of jewelry to remind myself of that glorious moment.

title: Skowron Had a Knack for Making Memories
description: Of all the people, on all the days, to appear in the Yankees clubhouse. Bill Skowron was sitting on a couch in the visitors clubhouse at U.S. Cellular Field in Chicago. He was an employee of the White Sox, a continual presence in community relations, and yet he looked every bit as much a part of the Yankees, as comfortable and as accepted, as he had been when he played for them. Moose, as Skowron was known to generations of Yankees and their fans, could do that.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor;

title: A Rising Tide Against Class-Action Suits
description: IN 2007, Matthew Wolf returned his Nissan Infiniti about a year into his 39-month lease. For most people, that would mean a hit to the wallet, including the loss of the few hundred dollars he paid in advance to lower his monthly payment.

title: Long History of Drug Use in the Derby
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  By all accounts, the 90th Kentucky Derby in 1964 was the first to include a competitor running on the drug furosemide, then known as Lasix. The initial dose was given surreptitiously by Alex Harthill, known as the Derby Doc, to the winner, Northern Dancer.

title: A Pullback in May? Maybe Not This Time
description: ITS understandable if the month of May fills investors with trepidation.

title: Mickelson Does Not Plan to Rest on His Laurels

Mickelson, who turns 42 next month, believes some of his best results are ahead of him, which lends an awkwardness to his induction Monday into the World Golf Hall of Fame.

title: Former Royal Aikens Tells His Story
description: For 14 years, Willie Mays Aikens had longed for this weekend to arrive. Convicted in 1994 on four counts of crack cocaine distribution and one count of using of a firearm during drug trafficking, Aikens, a World Series star for the Kansas City Royals, said May 5, 2012, was once his release date from federal prison.

description: THE economic slowdown in India is one of the worlds biggest economic stories, but it is commanding only a modicum of attention in the United States.

description: BEND, Ore.  When the economic analysts write the final memo on how this Cascadian playground got its buzz back, they might not title it How Beer Saved Bend.

description: This interview with  Carl Bass, president and chief executive of Autodesk Inc. , a maker of 3-D design, engineering and entertainment software, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant .

description: MOLINE, Ill.  Representative Bobby Schillings face was twisted with tension. Another official event, another group of Democrats who craved to see him wiped from the Congressional map. Plus, he would have to smile.

title: A Leader From the Start

In February 2011, in one of his first acts after taking over the 108th-ranked defense in the Football Bowl Subdivision, Arkansas States defensive coordinator, Dave Wommack, asked each of his players to fill out an eight-page questionnaire. One answer, written by a redshirt junior named Demario Davis, struck Wommack as particularly memorable: Davis vowed that the Red Wolves defense would finish among the top 25.

title: A Blessing for Those Who Brave City Streets on Two Wheels
description: There were, to be sure, lighthearted, even silly moments at the Blessing of the Bikes at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine on Saturday, but some cyclists had gone there for very profound reasons.

description: MOSCOW  It was a rare public sighting of Russias premier political couple, but in the end it only fueled the rampant questions about whether they are much of a couple at all anymore.

description: NORTHRIDGE, Calif.  Angry about tuition increases and cuts in courses and enrollment, a dozen students at California State University have taken their protest beyond marches  their usual tactic  and declared a hunger strike.

description: NEWTOWN SQUARE, Pa.  When Joey Crawford began his career as an N.B.A. referee in 1977, there were two officials on the court for each game, no 3-point line and just 22 teams in the league, including franchises in Buffalo and in Kansas City, Mo. It was a different era, he said.

title: Mitt Romney Promises to Create Eleventeen Million Jobs
description: OK, not exactly. But he did say that we should be creating 500,000 jobs a month  which almost never happens  and that we should have 4 percent unemployment, which is way below almost anyones estimate of the lowest rate we can have without accelerating inflation.

description: The Life of Jesus Christ, a three-and-a-half-hour play with a cast of 70, made its debut this weekend in a three-day run at the Louisiana State Penitentiary.

description: ANGOLA, La.  On a December night in 1991, the man who would later play Jesus committed a string of armed robberies in New Orleans. Ten years later, the woman who would play the Virgin Mary robbed a Mexican restaurant across town. A month after that, a teenager killed his girlfriend and infant daughter. He would go on to play Joseph.

title: Obama Formally Kicks Off Campaign in Ohio and Virginia

description: As Hannah Seligson reports in Sunday Business, joblessness among the young remains at crisis levels. In April, the unemployment rate for workers under age 25 was 16.4 percent, compared with 8.1 percent over all.

title: China, in Old Tradition, Races to Airbrush Fallen Leader Out of Public Life
description: CHONGQING, China  Until recently, visitors who arrived at the urban planning exhibition hall here were greeted with a high-tech shrine to Bo Xilai, who served as the municipalitys charismatic Communist Party chief. A video recounting Mr. Bos smash black crackdown on organized crime featured mug shots of gangsters emblazoned on tombstones. Maoist revolutionary songs blared from speakers in the red culture wing. Lasers zipped across the honest government gallery.

description: Jean-Baptiste Michel is a French-Mauritian mathematician, engineer and researcher with appointments at Harvard and Google. He uses a quantitative approach to study trends in human disease, language and culture based on linguistic and grammatical patterns in vast libraries of digitized texts.

One passer-by stopped, then another and another as the line sailed across a lawn turned makeshift casting area, over a rope marking a sidewalk, and finally into the street beyond.

description: Hong Kong

title: Nanotechnology Shock Waves
description: I SING the body electric,Walt Whitman wrote in 1855, inspired by the novelty of useful electricity, which he would live to see power streetlights and telephones, locomotives and dynamos. In Leaves of Grass, his ecstatic epic poem of American life, he depicted himself as a live wire, a relay station for all the voices of the earth, natural or invented, human or mineral. I have instant conductors all over me, he wrote. They seize every object and lead it harmlessly through me My flesh and blood playing out lightning to strike what is hardly different from myself.

Theres a rink, two bulls-eye targets and smooth stones to slide. But there are also brooms and a lot of yelling, and strategy. Its Flintstones winter bowling. Its track-and-field plus ballroom dancing, done by crazy housekeepers.

Have I arrived at some final telling moment in my research on outsourcing intimate parts of our lives, or at the absurdist edge of the market frontier?

There were reports that the slogan-writing process had been a struggle for the White House, and the final product bore those rumors out. Forward, the Obama campaign will be declaiming to Americans, which feels like a none-too-subtle admission that a look backward at the Obama economic record might be bad news for the presidents re-election prospects.

title: From Misfit With Blog to Author With Deal

Unknown writers would suddenly have the reach of John Grisham or Janet Evanovich. Agents and publishers would be surfing the Web instead of sifting through the slush pile to find new talent.

description: My Sunday column looks at a particularly egregious example of a company putting greed above conscience. Im speaking of Anheuser Busch selling hundreds of thousands of gallons of alcohol on the edge of Pine Ridge Indian Reservation, knowing that almost all of it will go to illicit drinking on the reservation and feed a devastating alcohol problem there. Incidentally, if you want to learn more about the issue, you can read this Times article or watch the documentary Battle for Whiteclay. (The Times reporter and photographer were roughed up in Whiteclay during their reporting, but I ran into no problems.)

That same failure to communicate got him fired from his job at a consulting firm.

Either Bodemeister was going to give the trainer Bob Baffert, fresh off a heart attack, his fourth Kentucky Derby victory, or Ill Have Another was going to give an anonymous jockey, Mario Gutierrez, one of the most unlikely victories in the 138 runnings of Americas greatest horse race.

After shooting a six-under-par 66 in the third round Saturday at the Quail Hollow Club, McIlroy, the reigning United States Open champion and the No. 2-ranked player in the world, is two strokes behind the local favorite and leader Webb Simpson and a stroke behind two other players.

title: CBS Threatens ABC Over Reality Show
description: Lawsuits over copycatting in reality television have gone nowhere in the past, but CBS has suggested to ABC that it may consider one over a summer show called Glass House. The format is similar to CBSs long-running summer series Big Brother, and ABC has hired many former production members from that show. On Friday CBS sent a sternly worded letter to ABC about it. The letter implies, without directly saying so, that CBS will sue ABC over copyright infringement. The letter said that CBS was putting ABC on notice that its continued development and production of Glass House exposes ABC to liability. The letter said the elements of the new show are substantially and strikingly similar to Big Brother. In Glass House, which has its debut on June 18, 14 people are chosen to live in a house all summer with cameras on them in pursuit of a cash prize  the essence of Big Brother competition. In the past copyright cases have proved nearly impossible for reality-show plaintiffs to win because, in simple terms, everybodys reality is inherently different. The total number of former staff members on Glass House is at least 18, according to the CBS letter, all of whom signed nondisclosure agreements when they worked for Big Brother. The CBS letter argued that it would be impossible for anyone who signed such a letter to help produce a similar show without breaching the agreement. ABC had yet to respond to the CBS letter or requests for comment by Sunday afternoon.

Now Playing | The World Premiere of Bonnie Prince Billys New Music Video
description: Will Oldham is often described as prolific, and with good reason. The singer-songwriter of many monikers  he has recorded music as the Palace Brothers, Palace Music, Palace Songs and Bonnie Prince Billy, among other names  has seldom gone a year without releasing a record in almost two decades. He has also been known to rerecord his old songs, making instrument-packed renditions of what were spare arrangements and turning dark, slow ballads into light, country-inflected numbers. To coincide with his new book, Will Oldham on Bonnie Prince Billy, Oldham is again releasing a new batch of his own oldies  a six-song EP called Now Heres My Plan, made up of fresh versions of songs from the Prince Billy catalog. Among the recordings, available on July 24 at Drag City, is an impossibly upbeat rendition of I See a Darkness, the beautifully bleak song off his 1999 album of the same name that was later covered by Johnny Cash. To Ben Berman, who directed the music video for the new version, above, the buoyant rendition is not incongruous with the songs subject matter. To me the song is about friendship, Berman says, speaking by phone from Los Angeles. Its about a person who is dark and morose and maybe unhappy in his life but who has a friend who makes it all worthwhile. There wasnt much of a planned concept for the video, Berman says, but the result was something of a study in contrasts: black-and-white photography in cinematic Glasgow, Scotland, plus goofball dance moves and special effects that make Oldhams and his band members eyes swirl around in opposing directions like stick-on googly eyes. We share a similar sensibility for what we find bizarrely funny, Berman says. Hes the perfect amount of weird.

If an intern performs well, it seems natural for the employer to offer a regular, permanent job. But if the intern is not up to snuff, it is much less painful to let the person go after three months than to lay off a recently hired regular employee after three months. That latter course not only hurts the worker, but also helps give the employer a reputation as an undesirable place to work.

title: Shepard Fairey Paints Neil Youngs New Songs
description: The admiration between Shepard Fairey and Neil Young goes both ways. Mr. Fairey, a longtime fan of the musician, included him in May Day, his 2010 show at Deitch Projects portraying cultural heroes of the left. Then Mr. Young, who stages an annual benefit concert for the Bridge School in Northern California, asked Mr. Fairey to create art for an album marking the concerts 25th anniversary. So the artist wasnt exactly surprised, he said at the opening of his new show at Pace Prints, when Mr. Young asked him to make a painting representing each song in his new album with Crazy Horse, Americana. What Mr. Fairey didnt expect was the intensity of Mr. Youngs involvement. For all the tracks, the artist submitted several digital mockups inspired by the narrative (none based on an identifiable original source, he emphasized). Then Mr. Young picked his favorites. Mr. Fairey said he was also surprised to learn that God Save the Queen is not just a Sex Pistols song but an old British anthem and the source of the melody for My Country Tis of Thee. His finished painting depicts the Queen and Betsy Ross sewing a combination of British and American flags; its text reads God save the land of liberty a phrase with both a dual origin and a double meaning. Neil and I talked about that, Mr. Fairey said. They left England, and basically made the same mistakes. In some respect it all blends together.

Sure, it felt funny to say you go, girl when Michele Bachmann announced that shed heard that the anti-HPV vaccination causes mental retardation. I tried to explain to my friends that Newts colony on the moon would make our country great again, bring down gas prices, or cure unemployment (surely a few of those nine-year-old janitors could get hired up there someday). As each candidate dropped by the wayside, I would flit capriciously to the next, hoping that this would be the one, a relationship that could flourish on its own terms and not be turned into roadkill by the Romney money machine.

title: The Nuns and the God Within
description: Along with the death of Charles Colson, the other significant religion story to break during the time I took off for book promotion was the controversy over the Vaticans investigation into the theological drift of the Leadership Conference of Women Religious, a group that includes the leadership of the majority of Americas orders of nuns. The controversy has mostly been framed in the press as the latest round in a debate running back to the Second Vatican Council  yet another clash between Spirit of Vatican II American Catholics and a more conservative hierarchy in Rome, with familiar flashpoints, a familiar cast of characters, and the same basic political and theological issues at stake. And it is that, in part: If you read the Vatican doctrinal assessmentofthe LCWR, youll find echoes of the debates that have divided American Catholicism since the 1960s womens ordination, human sexuality, how great a stress to place on Catholic social teaching versus the dogmatic aspects of the faith, and the broader question of where authority ultimately resides within the church.

title: Jungle Gym
description: In the Costa Rican jungle near the village of Cabuya  past a bridge, through a series of wooden gates and up an unmarked trail  sits a new yoga retreat, the Sanctuary at Two Rivers. Founded by the actress Perrey Reeves, who played the very yoga-fit Mrs. Ari Gold on HBOs Entourage, and Jeff Gossett, a restaurateur, the solar-powered resort was built completely by hand: no bulldozers, only shovels. When you cook with a lot of love, you taste it; when you build with a lot of love, you can feel it, Gossett says of their decade-long project. (And when you plant with a lot of love, evidently, you can smell it: the orchids blooming right outside the showers are no accident, he adds.) Visitors can either sign up for one of the Sanctuarys regularly scheduled packages, like the weeklong Full-Moon Retreat, or rent out the entire 40-acre property for a private yogi gathering. The accessible, eco-conscious and peaceful country of Costa Rica, Reeves says, was the only place where the pair considered breaking ground. Plus, there are monkeys!

title: Stone Links: Dissecting the Dismal Science
description: What To Do About the Rich, a post at the Philosophers Beard, offers a unique approach to the problem of the 1 percent. Capitalism is salvageable, the author argues, as long as were willing to consider a modest proposal: getting rid of the rich. Asserting that, because their extreme economic independence from the rest of society leads to a de facto ethical independence, the rich dont have the same political interests as the rest of us, the author concludes that no-one can be both a member of our democratic society and rich. The solution? Once an individual reaches a certain threshold of democratically problematic wealth, they have a choice: give it back, for example to the charity or social program of their choice, and rejoin the rest of the broad middle class, or, leave the country, which the author points out shouldnt be much of an issue for the extremely wealthy, who have the ability to, and often do, maintain multiple residences across the globe.

title: Baked Fish, Fez Style

The grilled lobsters were tempting to be sure, but a highlight was fish boldly baked Moroccan-style, with spices, herbs, tomatoes and olives. I left Morocco a few weeks ago with the recipe in my notebook and thought of it for our Greek reds. Though the wines could accept a broad range of dishes, one might detect a Greek accent in the fish dish, with its garlic, lemon, parsley, peppers, tomatoes, olives and olive oil. Its an easy all-in-one recipe that can be served at room temperature. Double or triple it and you have the anchor for a summer party menu, even on a buffet that is less copious than the one in Marrakesh. Cool some Greek reds to pour alongside.

The idea came to the company founder Jrmy Emsellem, 26, four years ago while he was studying semiotics at the cole Suprieur de Publicit. To make some extra money, hed been crocheting beanies for his friends when it all got to be too much, he says. I asked my great-aunt for help. She said no but volunteered her friends. And thats where it all began. title: Confronting Evil: 3 Generations Gripped by the Holocaust
description: In Eavesdropping on Dreams, a premiere by the Barefoot Theater Company at the Cherry Lane Theater, three generations of women  an Auschwitz survivor named Rosa; her daughter, Renee; and granddaughter, Shaina  alternately deny and confront their horrifying past. The backdrop of most of their memories and nightmares is the Lodz ghetto, which outlasted all of Polands other Jewish ghettos by becoming an industrial complex for the Nazi army. Mordechai Chaim Rumkowski, the Nazi-appointed, dictatorial Jewish leader of the ghetto, plays a prominent role in the family history as well.

At her new place, 606 R&D, the small kitchen includes both a rotisserie (for exemplary roast chicken) and a Donut Robot, financed through Kickstarter, that churns out fresh cake doughnuts throughout the day. And although she wasnt in charge of pastry at City Bakery, she must have picked up a tip or two from the master baker Maury Rubin over 15 years: the pie crusts at the new place are extraordinary.

title: A Blossom That Mom Can Sip
description: Lillet, the elegant wine-based aperitif made in southwest France for the last 140 years, is best known in its original pale version: white wine flavored with citrus and a touch of quinine. Lillet Blanc was joined by red Lillet Rouge in 1962. This spring the drink has blossomed in pink. Lillet Ros is essentially the blanc with some added red fruit liqueurs and a little of the Rouge for color  a medley that is refreshing, a little fruity and excellent for a Mothers Day toast. But it is also so easy on the palate that the label should warn that, at 34 proof, it not be mistaken for ros wine. Serving it on ice dilutes the alcohol.

title: Head of Asia Society Is Moving On
description: After 22 years with the Asia Society, Vishakha N. Desai, 63, will step down as president and chief executive in September, the society is to announce on Wednesday. Ms. Desai will join the Guggenheim Foundation as a senior adviser for global policy and programs, a new consulting position. She is also talking with several universities to develop an initiative focusing on the intersection of culture and international relations. The time is right, Ms. Desai said in an interview, adding that she had overseen the development of two new multimillion-dollar buildings, one in Hong Kong and another in Houston. During her tenure the Asia Society also expanded its New York headquarters and established new offices in India and South Korea. Its more about changing the direction of my life, Ms. Desai said.

I first read his semi-utopian novel Ecotopia just after it appeared in 1975, when I was living in Somerville, Mass., and working as a cab driver and editor of an erratically appearing newspaper. The early- to mid- 70s, as frivolous and lush as they might appear in hindsight  what with free love, cool drugs, cheap living and all  were in some ways not much different from now. We had a pragmatic president

Among the approximately 350 comments were several who opposed or misread the argument underlying the piece: that plants have a more complex existence than most people believe, and that that fact should move us to reconsider our ethical approach to eating them. Id like to address some of those misreadings and objections.

Many of his young 2008 supporters learned that to their disillusionment, and as he begins his re-election campaign, the president himself seems a more somber candidate who learned by trial the limits to inspirational change. title: Roman Totenberg, Violinist and Teacher, Dies at 101

title: Ukraine: Boycott Derails Meeting
description: The Foreign Ministry announced Tuesday that it would postpone a summit meeting of Central and Eastern European countries because many leaders planned to boycott it to protest the treatment of Yulia V. Tymoshenko, an opposition leader who has been imprisoned since October. The countries planning to stay away include Germany, Italy, Austria, Croatia, Slovenia, Estonia, Bulgaria and the Czech Republic. Ms. Tymoshenko, a rival of President Viktor F. Yanukovich, was sentenced to seven years on charges of harming Ukraines interests during gas negotiations with Russia. Moscow and the West have said the prosecution was politically motivated and are pressing Mr. Yanukovich to free her. Some countries are also boycotting the Euro 2012 soccer championship, for which Ukraine is scheduled to serve as a co-host next month.

title: China: Court to Hear Artists Lawsuit
description: Ai Weiwei, the rebel artist, said Tuesday that a court in Beijing had agreed to hear his lawsuit against the citys tax authorities. Mr. Ai is suing the officials for bringing a tax case against him. Tax officials have said Mr. Ais company, Beijing Fake Cultural Development, owes the equivalent of $2.4 million in back taxes and penalties. Mr. Ai said he did not owe that amount and has argued that his wife, Lu Qing, is formally in charge of the company. Mr. Ai was detained for 81 days last year and has continued to mock the Chinese government and the Communist Party since his release.

title: Ferrari Stunt in China: Gone Awry in 60 Seconds

Audi A6 sedans (in black) are known to be the choice of party and government officials, for example. Bentleys and Ferraris are also very much in vogue among Chinas privileged 1 percenters.

title: May 9, 1994 | Nelson Mandela Chosen South Africas First Black President
description: On May 9, 1994, South Africas newly elected Parliament chose Nelson Mandela to be the first president of the post-apartheid era.

title: Time for Greece and the Euro to Part Ways?
description: For months, we have been asking the same questions: should Greece and the euro go their separate ways? Are there just too many hurt feelings? Was the relationship based on too many lies from the start? Despite everyone doing their best to work through the issues, are there irreconcilable differences?

title: In Libya, the Captors Have Become the Captive
description: One night last September, a prisoner named Naji Najjar was brought, blindfolded and handcuffed, to an abandoned military base on the outskirts of Tripoli. A group of young men in camouflage pushed him into a dimly lit interrogation room and forced him to his knees. The commander of the militia, a big man with disheveled hair and sleepy eyes, stood behind Najjar. What do you want? the commander said, clutching a length of industrial pipe.

title: Do You Prefer Your Childrens Book Characters Obedient or Contrary?
description: Maurice Sendak, one of the most important childrens book artists and writers of the 20th century, died on Tuesday. Did you ever read his most famous story, Where the Wild Things Are? His characters were not the sanitized, moralistic personalities of much childrens writing, but were headstrong, bossy, even obnoxious.

title: When Memory Sings Harmony
description: What amazing songs. Thats the lingering impression from Tuesday nights Beacon Theater concert by the reunited Beach Boys, who until this year had not performed with Brian Wilson since 1996.

title: Tearful Underdog Triumphs in The Voice Finale
description: At the outset of the second season of The Voice Jermaine Paul was all about business. In his initial blind audition, he sang Avril Lavignes bratty Complicated with muscle and imagination, if not total grace. Two of the shows four coaches turned their chairs to face him: Cee Lo Green, a whimsical eccentric whos attracted to idiosyncratic vocal powerhouses, and Blake Shelton, a gentle soul who often appears to be guided by emotion and gut more than talent.

title: Even Though It Took Me All Year, I Wouldnt Change a Thing
description: The last week in April was a stressful one for many of us seniors. For me, it came down to a Thursday night, just a few days before May 1. My certainty in my decision had been building for a couple weeks, and as I filled out the online forms to submit a deposit and commit to my final choice, I had no doubts.

title: Oh, Pipe Down
description: May 9 is the 43rd day of Major League Baseballs current regular season. (Or the 36th day, if you disregard the annoying two-game set in Tokyo between the Mariners and the Athletics during spring training.) Each team has played as many as 32 games, enough to establish a few pleasant surprises in the standings (the Orioles, the Nationals) and a few striking disappointments (the Red Sox, the Brewers).

title: The Early Word: New Day
description: In Todays Times: Richard G. Lugar, one of the Senates longest-serving members and a moderate who personified a gentler political era, was turned out of office Tuesday by Richard E. Mourdock, the Indiana state treasurer, Monica Davey reports. Mr. Mourdocks campaign was fueled by millions of dollars from Tea Party groups that deemed Mr. Lugar too willing to compromise.

title: Long View: Indias Very First Corruption Scandal
description: The political media expos, of the sort that invariably earns the suffix -gate in the United States, can come in a surprising variety of shapes and sizes. The coverage of Watergate, sustained in The Washington Post over more than 300 stories, sank a presidency. In 1987, Indias own Watergate broke in The Hindu, which printed hundreds of documents in facsimile form to expose the Bofors corruption scandal, involving kickbacks received by politicians in exchange for a defense contract. On the other hand, independent Indias first momentous political scam broke in 1957 with what seems, in comparison, to be a pebble hurled at the side of an ocean liner  and yet it forced the swift resignation of a finance minister, T. T. Krishnamachari.

title: For Union Rags, It Was Over Before It Began
description: They say a picture is worth a thousand words; these pictures tell a story of how Union Rags started poorly in this years Kentucky Derby.

title: Toyota Projects Profit to Double in Fiscal Year

title: Tip of the Week: Finding Facebook Photo Comments
description: Uploading albums of photos on Facebook is a convenient way to share multiple pictures of an event with friends. If the page for the photos is set to Album view, comments from friends on the entire album appear below the thumbnails, but you must click on each image to see the specific comments for that picture.

Rusli in Wednesdays New York Times. He has shepherded the initial public offerings of LinkedIn, Zynga, Groupon and Yandex. But now he is getting ready for the big one: Facebook. It is on track to be the largest Internet offering since Googles in 2004.

Based in Rochester, Mich., the company had introduced a product, womens sandals with interchangeable decorative tops, soon after the economic crisis hit in 2008. Almost immediately, the five-employee company was hit with cost increases of 15 to 30 percent for manufacturing and raw materials.

But the number of extra amenities passengers must pay for has been proliferating as cruise lines go beyond the usual extras (like shore excursions, cocktails and Internet access) and add increasingly elaborate offerings.

title: After a Record-Breaking Weekend, Avengers Director Joss Whedon Reflects
description: When, after a film and television career of ups and downs, you go on to direct the movie that breaks the record for highest-grossing opening weekend what do you do next? If youre Joss Whedon, the director and screenwriter whose superhero blockbuster The Avengers made $207.4 million in its first weekend in North America (and has so far grossed $702.1 million worldwide, according to boxofficemojo.com), you lay low for a few days, maybe catch up on some comics and then give an idiosyncratic interview-slash-self-analysis to the Web site Whedonesque.com.

title: Image of the Day: May 9
New Russian Aircraft Crashes During a Promotional Flight in Indonesia
description: MOSCOW  The wreckage of a demonstration airplane for a Russian-made passenger jet that vanished on Wednesday during a 50-minute flight over Indonesia was found there on Thursday on the side of a mountain volcano shrouded in mist.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Gay Characters Draw Little Outrage; Obamas Mad Man
description: When Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. talked about the effect Will and Grace had on the national debate on gay rights, he was harkening back to a time when gay, lesbian and transgender characters on network television became weapons in the culture wars. Thats no longer true, argues Brian Stelter, pointing out that gay characters and themes on shows like Modern Family and Glee dont attract the outrage and boycott threats that were once aimed at Will and Grace and Ellen.

title: Bed Bath & Beyond to Buy Cost Plus
description: Bed Bath & Beyond is going shopping.

title: Prime-Time Stern
description: IF anyone has a right to feel on top of the world, its Howard Stern  especially inside his elegant, cumulus-high apartment on the West Side of Manhattan, dominated by a solariumlike living room with views on one side extending far up the Hudson and the other encompassing the entire bucolic breadth of Central Park.

title: Lebanon Lens
description: In just five years, the 38-year-old Nadine Labaki has become the director laureate of her tiny, politically fragile country of Lebanon. She first came to prominence in 2007 with her debut, Caramel, a sleepily beguiling film about the private lives and longings of four women working in a beauty shop in Beirut, which Labaki, in the starring role, lovingly portrayed as a warmly gossipy city full of battered, Old World charm. The film refused to so much as nod at the 15-year civil war that tore the city apart. You say Beirut and people think bombs and women crying in the street, but I wanted to show a sweet, everyday Lebanon, on a sunny day, she says.

title: The TSA: What Will They Think Up Next?
description: News reports on the covert agent who infiltrated Al Qaeda and foiled a plot to destroy a US-bound airliner have stressed that he recovered an innovative bomb, a sophisticated, experimental device with no metal parts  and a different kind of detonator, designed to escape detection at airport security. If recent history is any indication, that means the Transportation Security Administration is scrambling, as I type, to come up with some sort of patch.

title: Indian Government and Vodafone Group Talk Tough
description: The British telecommunications company Vodafone Group owes the Indian government 200 billion rupees ($3.7 billion) in taxes and late fees related to its 2007 acquisition of Hutchison Essar, R.S. Gujral, Indias finance secretary, said Wednesday during an interview with NDTV. There is no question of the government negotiating.

title: Protecting Killer Frogs From Killer Humans
description: Some names turn heads. Ivan the Terrible or his acolytes may have seen the need for a name that evoked shock and awe in the 16th century. Now, the Rana (Spanish for frog) Terribilis Amphibian Reserve has opened for business in Colombia, thanks to the good offices of several biodiversity organizations.

title: AT&T and Sprint Chiefs Display a Difference in Moods
description: Differences between the chief executives of AT&T Mobility and Sprint became clear with remarks they made at the CTIA Wireless conference in New Orleans this week. One seemed to be a techno-Pollyanna, while the other was a downer in comparison.

title: The Dream Teams Very Bad Day
description: The video, nearly 20 years old, shows the Dream Team doing something they never did at the 1992 Summer Games in Barcelona: losing. They faced a group of top college players that included Grant Hill, Bobby Hurley, Penny Hardaway and Chris Webber, who vowed: Im not going to be intimidated.

title: As Soldiers Strut and Tanks Roll, Putin Calls for Respect

Putin, said on Wednesday that the country had a great moral right to the respect of other nations, particularly on matters of global security.

description: Tom Hanks is in negotiations to make his Broadway debut next year playing the Daily News columnist Mike McAlary in a new bio-drama by Nora Ephron, Mr. Hankss spokeswoman confirmed on Wednesday.

description: Mort Lindsey, who led Merv Griffins television orchestra, accompanied Barbra Streisand on the piano in Central Park and played with Judy Garland in her celebrated comeback concert at Carnegie Hall, died on May 4 at his home in Malibu, Calif. He was 89.

description: Richard Mourdock set the political world abuzz late on Tuesday when he defeated the incumbent Senator Richard G. Lugar in Indianas Republican primary, reflecting the power of his conservative and Tea Party backers by ousting a fixture of the Senate.

title: Bookshelf
description: Delightfully illustrated by the Indian artist Ram Singh Urveti, I Saw a Peacock With a Fiery Tail (Tara Books, $18) dusts off a 17th-century English nursery rhyme written in trick verse; this version has die-cuts on each page to reveal the poems hidden meanings. The formalist games continue with Sound (Faber & Faber, $18), by the hip-hop fanatic and Yale Law School grad T. M. Wolf, who also has degrees in intellectual history and urban planning. His dizzying interests somehow coalesce in this first novel, with the prose arranged here and there on horizontal lines, like musical notation. In Swimming Studies (Blue Rider Press, $30), the artist, writer and ex-competitive swimmer Leanne Shapton wades through a lifetime of aquatic souvenirs. And Ancestral Modern (Yale University Press, $50) is a dazzling survey of contemporary Australian artists working in the 50,000-year-old Aboriginal tradition. (The book is tied to a Seattle Art Museum exhibit that begins on May 31.)

title: Postal Service Holds Back on Closings
description: WASHINGTON  TheUnited States Postal Servicesaid Wednesday that it would keep hundreds of small post offices open by reducing business hours or offering stamps and packaging in grocery stores, whittling down its ambitious plan to streamline its services and balance its books by closing thousands of post offices.

title: Kraft Tries Again With a Ritz Snack, Aiming Younger

title: Swing Fever
description: Rangers slugger Josh Hamilton has collected experiences over the past year like a rolling ball of tape collects everything in its path. There was the horrifying moment last July when he tossed a ball to a fan, who fell to his death over a too-short railing trying to catch it. The World Series then delivered a crushing competitive blow as the Rangers blew an all-but-certain victory in Game 6. The offseason brought an ugly relapse into alcoholism. All of which makes Hamiltons four-homer game on Tuesday night that much more mesmerizing because Hamilton is a living, breathing poster for the full range of human emotion. If he werent real, you get the feeling Maurice Sendak might have made him up. He is definitely a wild thing.

The bill died late Tuesday night after lawmakers reached an impasse over whether it would be heard on the floor of the House of Representatives before the legislative session concluded on Wednesday.

title: Becoming My Mom
description: Growing up, we could count on Mothers Day to broadcast whose mother was dead or alive. As we stepped into church in our scuffed Mary Janes, wed be greeted by ushers with an urgent whisper: Is your mother living? If we piped up Yes! we were awarded a bright pink carnation to wear all day. If we mumbled no, we were pinned with a white one to honor a lost mom. I used to watch the children and adults wearing those ghostly corsages and pray that day would never come for me.

description: Of all the morbid beauties in Tim Burtons work, the spooky goth girls and deathly pale boys, none wear their ghoulishness as lightly or winningly as Johnny Depp. And what a bewitching corpse he makes in Dark Shadows, Mr. Burtons most pleasurable film in years. As Barnabas Collins, the scion of a wealthy family turned unwilling vampire, Mr. Depp has a face as white as chalk and long-fingered hands that skim the air like skittering spiders. After 200 years of entombment, Barnabas awakes in 1972 and, like a latter-day Rip van Winkle, only thirstier, drinks in a world populated by monsters, living and dead, and lovingly adorned with Mr. Burtons signature kinks.

title: A Return Home to Family and Stage
description: AUDRA McDONALD is glowing. She has just spied a pair of mens Adidas sneakers by the front door of her New York State country home, and with a delighted laugh slips them on to take her two rowdy dogs out for a walk. Theyre Wills shoes, she says of her fianc of five months, the theater actor Will Swenson.

title: On Our Radar: Lugar, the G.O.P. and Climate Change
description: Richard G. Lugar, the longtime Indiana senator defeated in a primary by a candidate who dismisses global warming as junk science, says that most of his fellow Republicans cannot admit to any nuance in policy on climate change. [The Hill]

title: Spain Is Likely to Take Steps to Strengthen Its Banking System
description: MADRID  Spain is expected to announce on Friday measures to strengthen the banking sector, just two days after seizing control of Bankia, the countrys largest real estate lender.

title: Coty Raises Bid for Avon to $10.7 Billion
description: Coty has raised its bid for Avon Products to $10.7 billion, hoping to persuade the beleaguered cosmetics company to come to the negotiating table.

title: China Issues New Rules to Foreign Auditing Firms
description: Two of the biggest global auditing firms are accepting a new directive from China to staff their local operations with Chinese citizens, saying they are already trending that way.

description: Our colleagues at The Timess City Room blog have a new feature called Kids Draw the News, where they assign the 12-and-unders in the audience a current article about New York City to illustrate, and post the results in a slide show. The first two assignments  a brawl at an elite athletic club and an episode in which a heckler called New Yorks mayor Michael R. Bloomberg Pharaoh Bloomberg  drew responses from as far off as Africa.

title: Shows You See Again, for the First Time
description: OFTEN it really is better the second time around. Occasionally the thrill is gone. And then there are those instances  and they are the rarest  when it all seems exactly the same.

description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: They Sure Werent Singing My Song
description: DOES it say something about the state of the American musical theater that the animating incident in the most accomplished new Broadway show of the season is the repairing of a vacuum cleaner? It almost makes you nostalgic for those dark days when the talk of the Rialto was the spectacle of a chandelier plummeting toward the stage, or a helicopter landing on it.

title: Tussle in Brussels
description: Im in Belgium for the afternoon  and yes, I mean the afternoon. One of those things. So, not much blogging today! Here are the slides for my talk (pdf).

title: Daily Report: Facebook Spawns Circle of Young Tycoons
description: With lucrative shares and a web of valuable industry contacts, some early Facebook employees have left the company to either create their own start-ups or bankroll their friends, Somini Sengupta reports in Thursdays New York Times.

title: On Graduation Day, Commencement or Brunch?
description: Dear Diary:When my daughter graduated from New York University five years ago, commencement took place in Washington Square Park. (Now its at Yankee Stadium.)

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Obama Stops Evolving on Same-Sex Marriage
description: President Obama announced his support for same-sex marriage on Wednesday in a hastily scheduled interview with Robin Roberts of ABC News. The timing was driven by Vice President Joseph L. Biden Jr.s comments that aired on Sunday on Meet the Press, Jackie Calmes and Peter Baker reported, but also by the drumbeat of reporters questions at the news briefing of the presidents spokesman, Jay Carney. While the thinking of the presidents advisers this week was that he would make the announcement next Monday on the ABC morning talk show The View, even the delay of a few days became untenable.

title: Image of the Day: May 10
Collaborating With the Cast and Playwright
description: IT may be only fitting that Clybourne Park, a play about two generations of real-estate squabbles, had to fight to land a Midtown address. Now ensconced at the Walter Kerr Theater and boasting four Tony nominations, including one for best play, Bruce Norriss bleak, funny spinoff of Lorraine Hansberrys Raisin the Sun took a circuitous route to Broadway after its well-received start at Playwrights Horizons in 2010.

title: Dispute Between China and Philippines Over Island Becomes More Heated
description: BEIJING  China escalated its quarrel with the Philippines over an island in the South China Sea on Thursday, halting Philippine bananas at customs for longer inspections and starting an official media campaign that suggested that any claims on the island represented an infringement of Chinese sovereignty.
