title: The Treaty That Could Decide the Vodafone India Tax Case
description: As the British telecommunications company Vodafone Group and Indias finance ministry edge ever closer to a full-blown confrontation over taxes related to Vodafones $11.1 billion acquisition in India, a key issue may be the India-Netherlands Bilateral Investment Treaty, signed between the two governments in 1995.

title: Still Recognizable Without Pigtails
description: A DECADE ago Spencer Kayden stole New Yorkers black, black hearts as Little Sally in the dystopian musical Urinetown. title: Biden Got Out Over His Skis, Says Obama

title: Leading Off: An Ovechkin Sighting
description: For almost the entire season, it has been tempting to request Alex Ovechkins picture be placed on the side of a milk carton. Sure, someone was skating around wearing a No. 8 Capitals jersey. He would score occasionally, celebrate wildly and flash that gap-toothed smile, but this was not the Ovechkin anyone knew. That Ovechkin was a force of nature, would score 38 goals (his 78-game total) in a dream, would take 303 shots (more than 200 fewer than in his best season) before the trade deadline, would rack up 26 penalty minutes (also a career low) in a month.

title: UniCredit Profit Rises on Debt Buyback
description: LONDON  UniCredit reported strong profit for the first quarter on Thursday, with net income rising 12 percent, to 914 million euros ($1.2 billion). Investors welcomed the gains, sending shares of the Italian bank up 7.8 percent in late afternoon trading.

title: CUNY to Open Institute Devoted to Mexican Studies
description: For many New Yorkers, the growth of the Mexican immigrant population has been not unlike the experience of falling asleep at the start of a winter storm and waking up to find the city covered in a foot of snow.

title: Alison Bechdel Talks About Drawing, Writing, Family and Shame
description: Alison Bechdels graphic-novel memoir Fun Home (2006) was an acclaimed look at the life of her gay father, who she believes committed suicide by stepping in front of a truck soon after Ms. Bechdel told her parents she was a lesbian. Her new book, Are You My Mother?, tells the story of her efforts, through therapy and reading, to understand her relationship to her mother. In The New York Times Book Review, Katie Roiphe called it as complicated, brainy, inventive and satisfying as the finest prose memoirs. The Timess Dwight Garner was less enthused. He found the books tone therapized and flat, and said that Ms. Bechdels mother was a kinder, less complex, less riveting figure than her father. In a recent interview via e-mail, Ms. Bechdel discussed the art of drawing psychoanalysis, the mild virus of shame, her influences and more. Below are excerpts from the conversation.

title: Watch Out for a Falling Spider-Man! Forbidden Broadway Is Returning
description: Forbidden Broadway, the long-running satirical revue of the artistic highs and overacting lows of New York theater, ended in March 2009 with more than 9,750 performances to its credit, after creator Gerard Alessandrini decided that Shrek the Musical, Guys and Dolls and other Broadway fare at the time werent worth spoofing. But with critically derided shows like Ghost the Musical and Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark now on the boards, Mr. Alessandrini couldnt resist a comeback.

title: For Huskies and Their Fans, a Different Picture for Next Season
description: When Connecticut announced this week that its womens basketball broadcast rights would move to SportsNet NY (SNY) from its longtime home on Connecticut Public Broadcasting, the moved seemed logical enough in that the Huskies covet more attention in the New York market. But the broadcaster it left behind, which has been showing Huskies womens games for 18 years and started long before they became a dynasty in their sport, was saddened by the move.

title: An Online Tool For Gauging the Relative Value of Efficient Cars

Ive seen great examples at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Duke University, Pace University (of course!) and now the University of California, Santa Barbara.

title: Doubling of Stafford Interest Rates May Cost Only $6 More a Month
description: The Senate may have failed to act on a bill that would have prevented the doubling of interest rates for some student loans, but the inaction may not matter much. According to two experts on financial aid, if the interest rate on Stafford loans doubles to 6.8 percent this summer, as scheduled, students would pay only about $6 more a month for one year of loans.

title: Chaplin Musical Tramps Its Way to Broadway
description: The silence has been broken: Chaplin, a new musical about the life of the comic performer and cinema pioneer Charlie Chaplin, has found a Broadway home. The production, which features music and lyrics by Christopher Curtis and a book by Mr. Curtis and Thomas Meehan (Annie, The Producers and Hairspray), will be presented at the Barrymore Theater, where it will begin previews on Aug. 21 and have its opening night on Sept. 10, its press representatives said on Thursday. Chaplin will be directed and choreographed by Warren Carlyle, who had those duties on Hugh Jackman, Back on Broadway and also choreographed the recent Broadway revival of Follies.

description: RICHMOND, Va.  Travis Pastrana crawled through the window of his No. 99 Toyota, kissed his wife and flashed his magnetic smile. Even though he had placed 22nd in his Nascar Nationwide Series debut last month, he was pleased that he had not wrecked his car or anyone elses.

title: Kings Headed to Unlikely Western Conference Final
description: Forgive hockey fans in Los Angeles if they seem a little confused right now. Its been nearly 20 years since the Kings have done this well in the playoffs and shown this much promise. The eighth-seeded Kings are in the Western Conference finals, thanks to impressive wins over Vancouver Canucks in five games and a sweep of the St. Louis Blues. Up next is the equally surprising Phoenix Coyotes, the Wests third seed.

description: Quentin Hardy discusses the latest earnings report from Cisco Systems, and what it says about the health of the technology industry.

description: What book is on your night stand now?

title: Obamas Stance Is Significant, if Not Bold Leadership
description: When they look back 50 years from now, historians may well describe President Obamas declaration on same-sex marriage as righteous or inspiring or, as my colleague Adam Nagourney put it this morning, a watershed moment. What they probably wont call it is a case of bold political leadership.

title: Gibbs and Rove Debate Gay Marriage Announcement
description: Robert Gibbs, a top adviser to President Obama, said on Thursday that it was unclear how the presidents endorsement of same-sex marriage would play out in the election, calling it a a 50-50 issue at best.

description: These pictures by Terry ONeill, from a current exhibit at the Morrison Hotel Gallery in the SoHo section of Manhattan, celebrates 50 years of photography of the Rolling Stones. The photos caught our eye recently, and also raised some questions.

title: An Endless Quest for Weight-Loss Pills
description: Right after residency, I took a summer job in a family practice in a beach town on Long Island, covering Fridays and weekends for the regular doctors. The setting was quite different from my training in an urban hospital. It was a bit of a culture shock to go from a world of critically ill hospitalized patients to an outpatient suburban setting where most weekend appointments were for sore throats, rashes and sprained ankles. But I quickly became a pro at Lyme disease identification.

title: Hot Spot | The Scotch
description: Located in St. James, Londons newest and coolest night spot, the Scotch has already hosted the likes of Kate Moss, Jay Jopling, Stella McCartney and Scarlett Johansson. Not surprisingly, the club has a tough door policy. I was given a password on my recent visit: punchy, which I mistakenly morphed into jumpy. The doorman was not amused.

title: Using Terror Charges to Stifle Independent Reporting
description: Friday 10:02 a.m. | Updated Prosecutors in the eastern African nation of Burundi are seeking a life sentence for 23 journalists, including one working for Radio France International, who have been charged with participating in acts of terrorism, according to Reporters Without Borders and local journalists.

title: A Revamping of Bing in the Battle for Search Engine Supremacy
description: BELLEVUE, Wash.  When Facebook goes public in the coming weeks, there will be a lot of winners. Among them is one of the stalwarts of the tech industry, Microsoft, which has a small stake in the company.

title: Afghan Police In Spotlight After Foiling Taliban Strike
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  An attack by six Taliban infiltrators in the eastern province of Paktika on Thursday killed three police officers but was put down before it reached the government offices that were its target, Afghan officials said.

title: Live Updates on Egypts Presidential Debate
description: Two of the leading candidates to be Egypts next president squared off in a televised debate on Thursday night in Cairo, and The Lede reported on the clash between Abdel Moneim Aboul Fotouh, a former leader of the Muslim Brotherhood, and Amr Moussa, a former diplomat under Hosni Mubarak, as it unfolded. The live video of the event has now ended, but readers can still dip into the stream of updates from Times reporters in Cairo below, and scroll through highlights of the discussion on Twitter in the widget to the right of this post.

title: With Creative Work Still to Be Done, Flashdance Now Eyeing Broadway in 2013
description: The Broadway-bound, $12 million musical adaptation of Flashdance, based on the 1983 film about a working-class welder who dreams of becoming a dancer, is now aiming to open in spring 2013 instead of fall 2012, one of the lead producers said on Thursday. The producer, Marc Routh, cited a lack of available Broadway theaters in the fall, though he also noted that more creative work needed to be done on Flashdance.

title: Tour Rookie Gets Unusual, and Delayed, Entry into Players Championship
description: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla.  As the first alternate at this weeks Players Championship, the golfer Brian Harman spent Thursday morning at T.P.C. Sawgrass hoping for a phone call that never came  until it was too late.

title: Obama Campaign Pushes the Issue of Gay Marriage
description: WASHINGTON  Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. apologized to President Obama for hastening him into an endorsement of same-sex marriage, several people briefed on the exchange said Thursday, even as the White House sought to capitalize in the campaign on Mr. Obamas long-awaited expression of support.

title: Hypermiling Taylors Set Fuel-Economy Record in Volkswagen Passat TDI
description: John and Helen Taylor, the Australian hypermilers who made news in the United States in 2009 by averaging 67.9 miles per gallon in a tour of the 48 contiguous states, recently added another record to their considerable tally. The couple drove 1,626.1 miles in a 2012 Volkswagen Passat TDI SE from Houston to Sterling, Va., breaking the Guinness record for the longest drive in a passenger car on a single tank of diesel fuel.

title: Citys Hispanic Makeup Shifts as Dominicans Leave and Mexicans Arrive
description: Reversing a trend that had held for decades, more Dominicans left New York City than arrived since 2000, a new census analysis found. And a surge of Mexican immigrants nearly bumped them ahead of South Americans into third place among Hispanic groups.

title: Lawsuit Says Sheriff Discriminated Against Latinos
description: PHOENIX  A federal lawsuit asserting a pattern of unlawful discrimination by law enforcement officials here claims that Latinos at the county jail were often referred to as stupid or addressed with a coarse ethnic slur. It also says that an e-mail circulated among jail officers contained a photograph of a Chihuahua in a swimsuit, over the words, A rare photo of a Mexican Navy Seal.

title: Finding Beauty in Old Things

title: Board Room

title: WIC Works, But Enrollment Is Down
description: Economic hardship means families have to make tough choices among basic needs. Rent, mortgage, food, heat, health care  when whats coming in is far less than what needs to go out, parents are inevitably stressed. Both the economic needs and the impact on parents are associated with health problems for children  economic struggles, in particular, increase the risk that young children will suffer from delayed development and nutritional deficiencies, and living with a depressed caregiver additionally undermines their well-being.

description: LAS VEGAS  Kyle Bass, a Texas hedge fund investor who profited from shorting the mortgage market amid the financial crisis, has had a change of heart.

title: United States vs. Joseph M. Arpaio
description: In a 32-page civil rights lawsuit, the Justice Department contended that Mr. Arpaios campaign against illegal immigration had resulted in a pattern or practice of unlawful discrimination aimed at Latinos.

title: Hip, or About to Break a Hip?
Painted Maya Walls Reveal Calendar Writing
description: Hacking through jungle growth and clearing away rubble, archaeologists made their way to excavate a house buried at the edge of ruins of a large Maya city in the remote Petn lowlands of northeastern Guatemala. It turned out to have been the studio for royal scribes with a taste for art and a devotion to the heavens as the source of calculations for the ancient cultures elaborate calendars.

title: American Idol Numbers Slide
description: While the ratings for Foxs American Idol have held steady in recent weeks as almost every other network program declined, that was not the case on Wednesday night as the singing competition hit some of its lowest numbers of the season for a performance episode. According to Nielsen data the two-hour show averaged 16.1 million total viewers, which tied a season low, and slid to a season low in the advertiser-coveted 18-to-49-year-old demographic.

title: Bell Chooses Health Over More Football
description: A month ago, the free agent offensive lineman Jacob Bell signed a one-year deal to continue his eight-year N.F.L. career with the Cincinnati Bengals. But even though he feels healthy, the rising concern about head injuries coupled with the recent suicide of the venerated linebacker Junior Seau prompted Bell to reconsider, and this week he announced his retirement.

title: Is That Credit Score a FICO, or a FICO 8?
description: Its difficult enough already to grasp the nuances of consumer credit scoring. So it doesnt help when industry players are fuzzy about just which score theyre talking about.

title: Would a Special Counsel Help or Hurt the MF Global Inquiry?
description: Representative Michael G. Grimm has drafted a letter to Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr., asking for the appointment of a new prosecutor to investigate the collapse of MF Global and $1.6 billion in customer money that went missing in its final days.

title: Facebook's Network of Tech Tycoons
description: May 10, 2012  One of Facebooks lasting legacies may just be the diaspora of Internet and technology entrepreneurs it has created.

title: Slavic History in Art  Hangs in Prague
description: The Slav Epic, a 20-painting cycle depicting the history of the Slavic people by the Art Nouveau master Alfons Mucha, is settling in for a two-year run at Pragues Trade Fair Palace. Following a bitter legal dispute over custody of these historic canvases, Slav Epic: Myth, History and Vision finally opened on Thursday.

title: It Beats Having a Space Aliens Child
description: One of the bummers about having children, Anne Enright declares in Making Babies, her excellent memoir, is that it can interfere with your drinking for up to 15 years; first because you dont want to drop them, and subsequently because you dont want to make them cry.

title: The 20-Minute Workout
description: Gretchen Reynolds, the Phys Ed columnist, on the science of high-intensity interval training, or H.I.I.T., which scientists are finding can be as effective as longer endurance training.

title: Quietly, Lazards Ex-C.E.O. Returns to the Firm
description: It was a little over a decade ago that William R. Loomis Jr. stepped down as the chief executive of Lazard, having served in that role for only a year.

title: U.S. v. Arpaio
description: The Justice Department is finally suing Sheriff Joe Arpaio of Maricopa County, Ariz., accusing him of civil-rights violations, discriminatory policing and abuse of power. The governments complaint against the man who calls himself Americas Toughest Sheriff reads like an indictment of a Southern sheriff in the time of Jim Crow, only in this time and place the racism and violence are directed at Latino immigrants and citizens.

title: The 20-Minute Workout Video
description: Instead of asking how much exercise we need, some scientists are looking into how little we can do and still get maximal health and fitness benefits.

title: D.I.Y. Biology, on the Wings of the Mockingjay
description: Genetically modified organisms are not wildly popular these days, except one: a fictional bird that is central to the hugely popular movie and book trilogy The Hunger Games. Thats the mockingjay, a cross between a mockingbird and a genetically engineered spy bird called a jabberjay.

title: UBS Hires Global Co-Head of Real Estate
description: UBS said on Thursday that it has hired Peter Baccile as a joint global head of real estate, leisure and lodging investment banking. Mr. Baccile, who was most recently at JPMorgan Chase, will lead the UBS real estate group with Jackson Hsieh and will report to Matthew Grounds and Simon Warshaw.

title: A Long Trip for Iona Water Polo
description: After winning its second straight M.A.A.C. title, Iona College (24-11) is headed back to the N.C.A.A. womens water polo championship.

title: Greeks Revel in Torch Lighting. Again.
description: Perhaps the real talent the Greeks have for the Olympic torch lighting is making every one seem like an unforgettable, sacred, once-in-a-lifetime event featuring high priestesses instead of something they stage every two years. With actresses.

title: After Fiery Speech, Voting Rights Amendment Is Pulled
description: Sometimes during lengthy floor debates on bills, interesting things happen in the witching hours.

title: Hyderabad, India
description: Where the colors make your eyes dance and the food makes your tongue sweat.

title: 36 Hours in Hyderabad, India
description: SITUATED in the southern state of Andhra Pradesh, Hyderabad is a juxtaposition of old and new unlike any other city in India. While Microsoft, Google and other technology giants have offices in the glass and steel structures in the district known as Cyberabad, the history of this more than 400-year-old city is just as alluring as destinations like Jaipur and Agra, with sites like the 13th-century Golconda Fort, once home to the famous Kohinoor diamond, and the iconic Charminar monument in Hyderabads teeming Old City. In the past, Hyderabad was often overlooked as a tourism destination. But in recent years, sleek hotels, restaurants and night spots that cater to the 20- and 30-somethings working in the information technology industry have been attracting jet-setters from around the world who come to discover the past and experience the rapidly evolving present.

title: House Approves $310 Billion in Cuts, but Passage in the Senate Is Very Unlikely
description: WASHINGTON  The House approved sweeping legislation on Thursday to cut $310 billion from the deficit over the next decade  much of it from programs for the poor  and shift some of that savings to the Pentagon to stave off automatic military spending cuts scheduled for next year.

title: A McDonalds Big Enough for Olympus
description: Tom Spiel acquired his first McDonalds franchise in 1966: store No. 855, in Riverside, Calif. Since his wife, Candace, pushed to remodel it a couple years ago, their restaurant has become, as Keith OBrien wrote in last weekends magazine, the epitome of how McDonalds has been rebuilding its image  by making customers feel better about eating at McDonalds. Hence, solar panels on the carport, eco-friendly L.E.D. lights in the ceiling panels, totally new dcor. A company executive for the Southern California region put it this way: You want to be seen in an environment that replicates the personality you want.

title: Keeping Schiap Small
description: Once Elsa Schiaparelli got going, she didnt quit. She was enormously innovative from the start of her career, in 1927, as visitors to the new Schiaparelli-Prada exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art will readily see. She created severely chic suits as well as witty party clothes and accessories for at least two generations of irreverent women.

title: Poulter Makes Himself at Home in Florida
description: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla.  Ian Poulter is from England, but he looked at home Thursday at T.P.C. Sawgrass, shooting a seven-under-par 65 to take the early lead in the first round of the Players Championship.

title: Wheelies: The Risky Business Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Artifacts | Womens Work
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Bear Gryllss Adventure Tales
description: BEAR GRYLLS knew it had been a bad idea when he took a step and his foot sank out of sight. Everyone had told him how dangerous the harbor near his childhood home on the Isle of Wight could be. At low tide the quick mud could suck a person down. He tried to free himself, but the struggle only took him farther down. By the time the mud reached his neck, he could hear it make a sucking sound. Then, almost instinctively, he found a solution.

title: A Painter Stripped Bare
description: According to many critics, Lucian Freud started making great paintings only after he let go of drawing: abandoning flat, crisply outlined figures for massively fleshy nudes nourished by a full brush. The quietly ravishing Lucian Freud Drawings, at Acquavella Galleries, gives Freuds works on paper a chance to speak for themselves, beginning with his childhood sketches and ending with the last etching plate he touched.

title: Clip: The Color Wheel
description: A scene from "The Color Wheel," directed and co-written by Alex Ross Perry.

title: Clip: Elena
description: A scene from the drama Elena, directed by Andrei Zvyagintsev.

title: Germany Signals It Will Permit Small Steps to Promote Growth in Europe
description: BERLIN  The outlines of a potential compromise in Europes battle between deficit-cutting austerity and policies to promote growth have begun to take shape. The question is whether the kind of cautious measures palatable to Germany, austeritys champion, will do enough to combat the Continents imbalances and do it soon enough to put its weaker countries on more solid economic footing.

title: Lucian Freud Drawings
description: An ambitious and revealing show of Lucian Freuds drawings at Acquavella Galleries spans eight decades of his life.

title: Christie Vetoes Health Insurance Exchange
description: In a swipe at President Obamas signature health care legislation, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey vetoed on Thursday an online marketplace that the Legislature created to help residents and small businesses buy health insurance.

title: For Devils Finances, the Playoffs Are a Definite Plus
description: The Devils may be on shaky ice financially, but they are getting a lift from their deep playoff run.

title: Fifty Shades of Red
description: My daughter is engaged to a wonderful young man. We just met his parents. In a candid moment, his mother shared tremendous excitement over the Fifty Shades of Grey trilogy. As a feminist, I find the books focus on submissive women in sadomasochistic situations offensive. But Id like to build a good relationship with my daughters future mother-in-law. Shes been asking what I think of the books. Can I share my views without condemning hers?

title: Revis Is Reserved on His Contract, and Candid About Belichick
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Amidst speculation that he might hold out for the second time in three years, Jets Pro Bowl cornerback Darrell Revis stayed away from talking too much about his contract.

title: Daughter and Mother, Chasing Adulthood
description: On one wall of her bedroom Ansiedad (Cierra Ramirez), the teenage heroine of Patricia Riggens Girl in Progress, has an outline of the stages of her planned coming of age. Derived from a longish montages worth of research, the chart is also a knowing encyclopedia of teen-movie clichs. Ansiedad is a bright Seattle high school student who looks young for her age even though she is in some ways wise beyond her years. (Ms. Ramirez turned 17 this year.) She is determined to grow up fast, and to get away from her mother, Grace (Eva Mendes), who also may have some growing up to do.

title: In Europe, Entry Closes on Start-Ups With Their Foot in the Door
description: FRANKFURT  When Next Alternative, a Canadian start-up, wanted to raise money a few years ago, it opted for a listing on a new offshoot of the Frankfurt Stock Exchange. As part of the bourses so-called First Quotation Board, the six-month-old start-up could tap investors for capital without the higher costs, stricter disclosure requirements and other regulatory hurdles of an offering on the main exchange.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Brain Surgery Tweets, and Fiorina to Zuckerberg
description: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Thursday. See more here.

title: Never Mom Enough
Before Whitneys Move, a Koons Retrospective
description: The Whitney Museum of American Art has no intention of leaving quietly. Before heading to its new, considerably larger home in the meatpacking district of Manhattan in 2015, its final exhibition will be as much a first as it is a last. The museum is planning to present a Jeff Koons retrospective that will fill all of its Madison Avenue home, with the exception of the fifth-floor permanent exhibition galleries.

title: Nadal Loses on Madrids Blue Clay After Complaining About It
description: MADRID  Rafael Nadal remains the king of clay, but not of blue clay.

title: Mere Society Paintings? Look Again
description: If, by some fluke of metaphysics, the last four decades of douard Vuillards long, prolific and rewarding career were erased from collective memory, he still would not be forgotten. Before the age of 30 he made some of the most beguiling paintings of fin de sicle Paris: intimate, compact, brushy pictures of his mother and sister in the apartment he shared with them and the dressmaking shop they worked in. Painting with special attention to wallpaper and fabric patterns, he made people almost dissolve into atomized, flattened surfaces, anticipating a century that would pulverize into air everything once taken for solid.

title: 30 Rock Will Return, but Only for 13 Episodes, NBC Says
description: There will be more of the Emmy-winning comedy 30 Rock, but not a whole lot more.

title: Video: Facebooks Diaspora
description: Somini Sengupta and Peter Lattman discuss the generation of Internet and technology entrepreneurs that Facebook has created, and how that might end up being one of the companys lasting legacies.

title: Speaking of Fashion
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art wont have to stay open till midnight to accommodate crowds for Schiaparelli and Prada: Impossible Conversations, this years Costume Institute extravaganza, mainly because the show isnt all that extravagant, certainly not on the order of the Alexander McQueen exhibition last year.

title: Justin Timberlakes Latest Project? Pillows
description: These days, fame has a tendency to metastasize, producing strange outgrowths that are often called collaborations. Is it a surprise, then, that Justin Timberlake  who has already ventured into fashion and Memphis-style barbecue  would follow in Lenny Kravitzs footsteps and design a home collection? Probably not. But it is refreshing that the entertainers enthusiasm for home dcor appears to be rather genuine. I do love a stripe, he confessed to The Moment on Wednesday, while showing off the first parts of his HomeMint collection: a series of rather anodyne throw pillows.

title: Saratoga Season for New York City Ballet May Shrink
description: Financial pressures may force New York City Ballet to reduce its Saratoga season to one week instead of two, which would be the second downsizing in five years, officials said on Thursday.

title: Shopping for Loans Online
description: SHOPPING for a mortgage online can save borrowers a lot of time, and possibly money if they find the right deal. But working with these so-called online marketplaces can also be overwhelming for some people, especially as the various lender offers start pouring in.

title: Every Exit Is an Entrance: 30 Years of Exit Art: 30 Years of Exit Art
description: Exit Art

title: Anne Arnold: Sculpture From Four Decades
description: Alexandre Gallery

title: A Fading Flower Gets Pruned, but Not Her Dialogue
description: A well-bred but heavily indebted young lady makes for a lovely social accessory, and an even lovelier extramarital scapegoat.

title: On the Trail, Romney Not Eager to Engage on Gay Marriage Issue
description: OMAHA  Mitt Romney rarely passes on an opportunity to respond to President Obama or the actions of the White House. But that is precisely what he did here on Thursday.

title: Rotimi Fani-Kayode: Nothing to Lose
description: The Walther Collection Project Space

title: AOA Tribal Art Fair
description: Fletcher-Sinclair Mansion

title: Paralysis of the Heart
description: I WAS driving my 11-year-old son, Joe, to school. It had been one of those mornings. He was singing opera and doing hip-hop moves when I needed him to put on his shoes.

title: They Use Guns for Anger Management
description: Weve become a nation of slogan-saying, bile-spewing hatemongers! Weve lost our kindness! Weve lost our soul! shouts Frank (Joel Murray), an aggrieved middle-aged everyman with plenty of reasons to be mad as hell.

title: Sidewalk Bookseller Returns to Find Shop Gone
description: 7:02 p.m. | Updated Charles Mysak has become a fixture on the Upper West Side, selling his used books for nearly a dozen years on the sidewalk of Columbus Avenue near 68th Street.

title: New Costumes at City Ballet
description: Tonight, Lincoln Center will once again be filled with stars and socialites dressed to the hilt as the New York City Ballet opens its spring season. But true fashion lovers should look not to the plaza but to the stage for the most exciting designs. In an usually fashion-focused gala, the Rodarte sisters have created the costumes for Benjamin Millepieds new premiere and Gilles Mendel has supplied the designs for Peter Martinss latest work. And in perhaps the most significant move, the classic costumes for Balanchines Symphony in C have been revamped with crystals by Swarovski.

title: Ivy League Rejects Idea for Conference Basketball Tournament
description: The athletic directors of the Ivy League have turned down a proposal by its coaches for a postseason conference tournament in mens and womens basketball, the league said Thursday.

title: Ceramists Students Keep Studio and Spirit Alive
Cloud City at the Met
description: A multipolygonal habitat of reflective stainless steel and acrylic, a new installation by Toms Saraceno, is being assembled on the roof of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Intimacys Many Facets
description: The form of dance theater that the choreographer John Jasperse develops in Fort Blossom revisited (2000/12) is often astonishing. Watching Wednesdays premiere, I was several times left with the sensation of having traveled to unknown terrain. The piece is an expanded 70-minute reworking of his Fort Blossom (2000). (We should not spend time figuring out what the title might mean.)

title: The Books We Lie About
description: Earlier this week, an English Web site published a list of the top books that Brits lie about reading. It inspired us to come forward with our own list of books weve been less than truthful about having read. Here are some voices from our staff (names have been redacted to protect the guilty):

title: Summoning the Spirit (and Bands) of Nightclubs Past
description: The Undead Music Festival exists to provide a collage of impressions collected on the fly. It claims no organizing principle other than the vitality of the music, most of which scans broadly as jazz: combo stuff, high-contrast and alert, shot through with forceful improvising. With shows in different pockets of the city each night, its not about a specific locale or scene, or isnt supposed to be.

title: The Fun Starts Here
description: GROWING up in the 1970s in Bloomington, Ind., Eric Zimmerman enjoyed what he described as an amazing childhood of play. He and friends raced around in such pursuits as Ghost in the Graveyard and Kick the Can. He recalls epic games of dodgeball. But his most vivid memories center on the games that he played with his father  the brainteasers, the wrestling matches, the pinball games at arcades. He was a very playful person, Mr. Zimmerman, now 42, said of his father, who died when he was 5.

title: Hitchcock and Mildred Pierce at Museum of Moving Image
description: If youre like the Miser, you consider a $13 Midtown multiplex ticket a luxury. And thats before youve had the privilege of overpaying for a pile of popcorn and a soda as big as your head. Double that if youre on a date, and triple it, at least, if you want to treat your family. Factor in dinner somewhere before or after. A night in with takeout Thai and Netflix starts looking pretty sweet.

title: Condo or Rental, Its New in Dumbo
description: THE housing market in the Dumbo section of Brooklyn is having a busy spring, with a major condominium building opening in the 200 block of Water Street, a rental building on the same block preparing for an influx of new residents, another rental tower beginning a conversion to condos, and work starting on Two Trees Managements latest residential project, at 30 Washington Street.

title: Futuristic Aerie With a Park View
description: IN Toms Saracenos imagination his constellation of 16 joined modules under construction on the roof of the Metropolitan Museum of Art will take off in a heavy puff of wind and float over Central Park. The whole thing will go into orbit, Mr. Saraceno, the Argentine artist who made it, said on a recent foggy morning.

title: When Walkers Were Weird and Runners Few
description: ALMOST everyone calls the dirt path undulating around the Central Park reservoir the runners track. But ever since the ugly chain-link fence from the 1920s was replaced with a reproduction of the original in 2003, the path has often been crowded with walkers, dog owners and even cyclists jockeying for position. Runners resent the new arrivals on their course  but is it theirs?

title: A Convergence of Blood, Sweat, Tears and Tchaikovsky
description: On Wednesday evening, during a particularly poignant passage of the Tchaikovsky Violin Concerto, blood began pouring out of the mouth of the young violinist Hahn-Bin.

title: Rethinking the 55-Plus Market
description: SOME would-be buyers who visit Villagio, a 55-plus housing development in South Brunswick, think theyve arrived at the wrong place.

title: Welcome-Home Houses
description: THEY met eight years ago at a Marine Corps combat center: Michael Roushion, 25, of Oakland, Calif., had served one tour of duty and was re-enlisting; Nicole Burnett, 18, newly graduated from Lincoln High School in Yonkers, was fulfilling her childhood dream of becoming a Marine.

title: Pop Goes the Rhapsodist
description: Ive got the outfit for the party, Rufus Wainwright sang as stage lights flashed on to reveal him and his band at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Wednesday night. All were in black, wearing sunglasses, except for Mr. Wainwright, with his gold-lam pants and shiny red shoes.

title: Fill In the Blanks
description: BEFORE Michael Kenducks listing for a 10-year-old three-bedroom stucco colonial in Franklin Square officially went on the market, more than 40 potential buyers had already walked through. Their previews were embellished by virtual staging of their choice  by means of an interactive tour in which each visitor painted and decorated some rooms in the house (which is actually empty).

title: Q & A
description: Tourists Flock to My Building

title: Festivals Are the Newest Thing for New Music
description: It is springtime in New York, and festivalitis has struck again.

title: Office Detectives
description: At my office, we were feeling a nagging concern about a candidate we were strongly considering for a position. So we decided to call someone at a company the person had listed on the rsum but had not provided a reference for. Wow, did we get earful on the person (not in a good way)! But then we werent sure if it was ethical to use this information in assessing the person. Of course, it was awfully hard to forget. We ultimately didnt hire the person. NAME WITHHELD, OAKLAND

title: Cant Get That Place Off My Mind
description: AFTER growing up in Far Rockaway, Queens, Bruce David Martin headed for Greenwich Village. His first apartment there, in 1973, was a shared two-bedroom on the Avenue of the Americas and Bleecker Street; the rent was $185 a month. Back then he didnt mind the noisy street.

title: So Whose Swan Lake Is It?
description: In ballet classic and 19th century are almost synonymous. Core essences of ballet  academic virtuosity, big-theater projection, formal grace, boy-hunts-girl romantic drama and spectacular ceremony  were forged in the era of 19th-century Romanticism in ways that audiences continue to respect. A good Giselle or Swan Lake can still take us to the heart of the genre.

title: A Portrait of the Artist as an Old Man in Love
description: Life was sweet for Picasso during his 10 years of romance and cohabitation with Franoise Gilot, from 1943 to 1953. Or so it would seem, judging by Picasso and Franoise Gilot: Paris-Vallauris, 1943-1953, a wonderful exhibition at Gagosian Gallery. The Picasso of these years  he was in his 60s and early 70s  seems to revel in the joys of family and domesticity. Gone are the moonstruck years with Marie-Thrse Walter and the violently conflicted ones with Dora Maar. The crazy-old-man last act is yet to come. Looking at pictures here of his young children Claude and Paloma at play, you can imagine yourself seeing through the eyes of a loving, benevolent father  who just happens to be the most inventive artist of the 20th century.

title: Stonewall in the Valley
description: As far as Civil War engagements go, the Battle of McDowell, which took place on May 8, 1862, in Virginias Shenandoah Valley, was relatively small  a few hundred casualties on both sides, out of just under 13,000 combatants. But the Confederate victory marked the beginning of one of the wars most important chapters: the Shenandoah Valley campaign, led by Maj. Gen. Thomas J. Stonewall Jackson.

title: In Beverly Hills, Preservation Gains a Toehold
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Lies, Damned Lies and Literature
description: The thud of a volume of Proust hitting the ground is among one of the first hints that the talented Chilean director Cristin Jimnez might be up to something far more narratively ambitious than it may initially seem in Bonsi. A low-key, misleadingly desultory story about love, art and memory, this movie even cites the opening lines from Swanns Way, the first volume of In Search of Lost Time. Sometimes on waking, the narrator explains, while realizing that hes been dreaming about what he had been reading before falling asleep, his thoughts run into a channel of their own, until I myself seemed actually to have become the subject of my book.

title: These Crime Solvers May Yet Kill Each Other
description: The USA Networks motto is Characters Welcome. Apparently theyre especially welcome if they resemble Oscar Madison and Felix Unger. Already stocked with Odd Couple knockoffs in Psych and White Collar, USA on Friday adds to its inventory Common Law, another comic crime-fighting show about mismatched partners.

description: Movies

title: Theater Listings for May 11-17
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Detours on the Road to a Family Reunion
description: The Japanese director Hirokazu Kore-eda  best known for Nobody Knows, about four young brothers and sisters forced to survive on their own after their mother abandons them  has such an extraordinarily delicate manner with children that his approach can feel like a code of ethics, a declaration of honesty toward these often badly used and exploited performers. The gentleness of his approach, his stylistic unobtrusiveness and the way that children open up in front of his camera are among the subtle pleasures in his latest film, I Wish, a quiet, seemingly rambling story about two exceptionally capable brothers who have been separated by their parents bad marriage.

title: Pop/Rock for May 11-17
description: Pop

title: Under the Spell of a Bombshell
description: David Rousseau (Jean-Paul Rouve), the amateur gumshoe who traipses through the snow in Grald Hustache-Mathieus sardonic neo-noir, Nobody Else but You, is a successful detective novelist drawn to a tiny French town near the Swiss border. As he navigates the icy roads of a place nicknamed Little Siberia, Jos Felicianos version of California Dreamin plays on the car radio. And in a way this French film is a Southern California dream of the sort concocted by James Ellroy in L.A. Confidential but removed to Europe and put in a deep freeze.

title: Cashman Testifies About McNamee at Clemens Trial
description: WASHINGTON  Roger Clemens must have felt a little love come his way Thursday at his federal perjury trial when Brian Cashman, the Yankees general manager, unabashedly praised his work habits, his leadership skills and his competitiveness.

title: Jazz Listings for May 11-17
description: Jazz

description: In Anatomy of a Scene, David Mackenzie narrates a scene from his film, which was shot at a Scotland music festival.

title: Did the News Media Drive the Gay Marriage Debate?
description: On the Fox News Channel on Wednesday afternoon, the anchor Shepard Smith played a clip of President Obama expressing his support for gay marriage, then delivered this stinging assessment: The President of the United States, now in the 21st century.

description: Classical

title: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Syria, Nepal, Indonesia and Israel.

title: Diet Drug Wins Panels Approval
description: Government advisers recommended approval on Thursday of a weight-loss drug developed by Arena Pharmaceuticals, making it likely that a new obesity treatment will reach the market this year.

title: Dance Listings for May 11-17
description: Dance

title: CBS Sues ABC Over Show It Says Copies Big Brother
description: 6:58 p.m. | Updated CBS followed up on its threat against ABC with a lawsuit asking the court to block a proposed ABC series called Glass House because of its similarities to the long-running CBS summer series Big Brother.

description: Art

title: Observations of an Asteroid Provide Hints of How the Earth Came Together
description: Confirmed: Vesta, the second largest of the asteroids, is a runt planet.

title: Iraqs Wounds
description: Although America has declared an end to its war in Iraq, the suffering continues for thousands of the allies it left behind.

description: To the Editor:

title: Bachmann Withdraws Swiss Citizenship
description: Alas, the Tea Party movement wont be setting up shop in Zurich anytime soon.

title: Going Social, but Not Creepy, in the New Bing
description: Microsoft rolled out a new version of its Bing search engine with new features aimed at weaving together the experience of Internet search and social networking. There is, however, one eyebrow-raising new Bing feature Microsoft was testing that it decided not to release to the public.

title: Family Way
description: Just as everyone was getting ready to throw out the Baby Bjorns and start practicing detachment parenting  la franaise comes a new book, from the esteemed philosopher Elisabeth Badinter, warning that French motherhood isnt all its cracked up to be.

title: Chemical Plant Safety
description: To the Editor:

title: First Handcuffs Lock Them Together, Then Love
description: Pop music has a way of dressing up familiar themes and emotions in new beats and sonic textures, and Tonight Youre Mine, David Mackenzies new film, does something similar. In outline it is an absolutely standard meet-cute romantic comedy, with the usual obstacles on the way to the central couples triumphant kiss, which takes place against a backdrop of fireworks and cheering crowds. There are inconvenient rivals who must be gotten out of the way, and comical sidekicks to lighten the mood. But the look, the rhythm and the scruffy, on-the-fly ambience of the film make it feel unusually fresh and lively. It may be the same old song, but its also a catchy remix.

title: Without Mentioning It, Obama Gets Applause for Gay Marriage Stand
description: SEATTLE  All it took was President Obamas quick, vague phrase  no matter who you love  and about 2,000 supporters at a Democratic fund-raiser here on Thursday erupted in applause and cheers, seeming to guess he was alluding to his newly announced support for same-sex marriage.

title: Trailer: 'Grand Illusion'
description: A trailer for Jean Renoir's "Grand Illusion," which makes a return to the big screen at Film Forum.

title: Jean Renoirs Timely Lessons for Europe
description: GRAND ILLUSION had its premiere at the Venice Film Festival in 1937, and it has been around ever since, by enduring consensus one of the greatest films ever made. It is true that Joseph Goebbels, the Nazi propaganda chief and cultural arbiter, was not a fan, but Mussolini, patron of the festival and Europes leading fascist cinephile, kept a print in his personal collection. Franklin D. Roosevelt declared that all the democracies in the world must see this film, which is still sound advice. The nations that fall within that rubric may have grown in number since those days, but none of those democracies, old or new, is so secure as to be immune to the lessons of Jean Renoirs great and piercing antiwar comedy.

Is the greater good served by a noble project if it involves the flouting of solemn rules? And once the rules have changed, and the noise has died down, how much do these debates really matter?

The village is ringed with land mines, and its cemetery is filled with the bodies of young men who have died in sectarian warfare.

He wasnt talking about Sleepless Night, but the shoe fits. Hectic and harebrained, this galloping French thriller tosses a potpourri of plot points  crooked cops, sleazy gangsters, stolen drugs and an underage hostage  into a packed-to-the-gills nightclub, and stirs. Repeatedly.

Not, she wrote, the daily stuff, but the projects  the kind of thing an adult would (should) start in advance, and an adolescent boy with a few other things on his mind might well leave until the last minute. How much, she asked, should we be making sure he gets done what hes supposed to get done?

Brian OShaughnessy comes across as a staunch advocate of manufacturing in America. description: WASHINGTON  The United States government is doing everything possible to locate Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl, who is being held captive by insurgents after being seized in Afghanistan in 2009, the Pentagons top civilian and military leaders said Thursday.

title: Can Physics and Philosophy Get Along?
description: Physicists have been giving philosophers a hard time lately. Stephen Hawking claimed in a speech last year that philosophy is dead because philosophers havent kept up with science. More recently, Lawrence Krauss, in his book, A Universe From Nothing: Why There Is Something Rather Than Nothing, has insisted that philosophy and theology are incapable of addressing by themselves the truly fundamental questions that perplex us about our existence. David Albert, a distinguished philosopher of science, dismissively reviewed Krausss book: all there is to say about this [Krausss claim that the universe may have come from nothing], as far as I can see, is that Krauss is dead wrong and his religious and philosophical critics are absolutely right. Krauss  ignoring Alberts Ph.D. in theoretical physics  retorted in an interview that Albert is a moronic philosopher. (Krauss somewhat moderates his views in a recent Scientific American article.)

title: The Last Mothers Day
description: I started making wine a couple of years ago with a bunch of guys who know far more about the ways of the grape than I do. Between the crushing, racking, barrel-tasting and bottling we talked about wine and sports, women and sports, politics and sports, and maybe some other things that I cant remember, and sports.

Easy Useless Economics

The authors diagnosis was that the U.S. economy just wasnt flexible enough to cope with rapid technological change. The paper was especially critical of programs like unemployment insurance, which it argued actually hurt workers because they reduced the incentive to adjust.

title: The Human Cost of Ideology

At the same time, they have insisted on preserving bloated military spending and unjustifiably low tax rates for the rich. That effort reached a nadir on Thursday when the House voted to prevent $55 billion in automatic cuts imposed on the Pentagon as part of last years debt-ceiling deal, choosing instead to make all those cuts, and much more, from domestic programs.

But on Wednesday, a park ranger discovered a female mallard that had been mauled by an animal, apparently a dog. A local animal hospital euthanized the duck, which had lost most of its tongue and half its bill.

title: Capitol Hill, Slower Than Snail Mail
description: For all its historic reputation at persevering, the United States Postal Service is just not making it as a business. It is running deficits of $36 million a day. It will go bankrupt this year and annual losses could rise to $21 billion a year by 2016 unless the House and Senate can agree on a sensible reform plan  one that protects consumers but also recognizes the financial realities imposed on the Postal Service by the Internet age.

His father, Walter Pollak, persuaded the Supreme Court that the Scottsboro boys convicted of rape in Alabama did not get a fair trial. And soon after clerking for a justice, he helped write the N.A.A.C.P. brief that did much to persuade the Supreme Court to outlaw segregation in Brown v. Board of Education.

title: Family Ties, Knotted Up in the Lyrics

When the Wainwrights get into it, the spat often shows up in a full-blown song, which begets other songs. That kind of thing will happen when one of Americas most bracing folk writers, Loudon Wainwright III, marries another folk luminary, Kate McGarrigle of the McGarrigle Sisters, and they have two musically gifted children, Rufus and Martha. Factor in a serious relationship, which has long ended, with another member of the folk pantheon  with Suzzy Roche of the Roches, that produced yet another musical offspring, Lucy Wainwright Roche  and cue decades of songs, many of them about a complicated life in a family of musical royalty. Some of those songs have titles that dont scan well in a family newspaper, including Loudons ditty about a fight for position at the breast of Rufuss mother and Marthas profane rocket aimed at her fathers shortcomings. Back and forth it goes, with Rufuss Dinner at Eight revealing that supper at the Wainwrights was sometimes more dark indie movie than sitcom.

title: Who Made That Clothespin?
description: The survival of the spring-hinged clothespin into the modern era is an unlikely story of Darwinian selection. From 1852 to 1887, the U.S. patent office issued 146 separate patents for clothespins. The first design that resembles the modern clothespin was patented in 1853 by David M. Smith, a prolific Vermont inventor. Smith also invented a combination lock, a lathe dog (a machine part for shaping metal) and a lifting spring for matchboxes. His spring-clamp for clothes-lines offered an elegant model of two levers hinged so that the two longer legs may be moved toward each other and at the same time move the shorter ones apart. Smiths design was later improved by the 1887 patent of another Vermont inventor, Solon E. Moore, whose great contribution was the coiled fulcrum, made from a single wire, which joined the two grooved pieces of wood at the center of the clothespin. Moores version had the advantage of being both sturdy  it kept clothes securely on the line  and easy to manufacture.

But women? Just as the sports guys mythologize the athlete, mommy writers mythologize the child, the bond, the late nights and the little toothless grin breaking out like sunshine from behind a thundercloud of tears. The proper approach to answering these deep questions is the application of the methods of science, including archaeology, neuroscience and evolutionary biology. Also, we should study insects.

title: Process of Extermination
description: In Homage to Catalonia, his memoir of the Spanish Civil War, George Orwell remarks that Francisco Francos military uprising against Spains elected government was an attempt not so much to impose fascism as to restore feudalism. Paul Prestons magisterial account of the bloodshed of that era bears this out. Fascism may belong to the 20th century, but Francos grab for power evokes earlier times: the parading soldiers who flourished enemy ears and noses on their bayonets, the mass public executions carried out in bullrings or with band music and onlookers dancing in the victims blood. One of Francos top aides talked of democratically chosen politicians as cloven-hoofed beasts, and anything that smacked of modernity  Rotary Clubs, Montessori schools  seemed to draw the regimes violent wrath. Echoing the Inquisition, Franco ordered particularly despised foes put to death with the garrote, in which the executioner tightens an iron collar around a persons neck.
