description: See dishes from four restaurants serving spirited cuisine.

title: Inside the List
description: DONT PANIC: When Douglas Adams, the author of The Hitchhikers Guide to the Galaxy, died of a heart attack 11 years ago this month, a group of fans organized an impromptu Towel Day celebration in his memory. Why Towel Day? Because a towel, as readers of Adamss delirious novel will remember, is about the most massively useful thing an interstellar hitchhiker can have. (Suggested uses: beach-lounging on Santraginus V, sailing a miniraft down the River Moth, hiding from the Ravenous Bugblatter Beast of Traal and, if it still seems to be clean enough, drying yourself off.) The tribute caught on, and this year people in at least 15 countries will observe May 25 by carrying towels to readings, movie screenings and other events related to The Hitchhikers Guide, which spent a cumulative 11 weeks on our paperback list. In 1981, when the first American edition was released, Gerald Jonas praised it in the Book Review. Humorous science-fiction novels have notoriously limited audiences, he wrote. They tend to be full of in jokes understandable only to those who read everything from Jules Verne to Harlan Ellison. The Hitchhikers Guide is a delightful exception. And yes, he mentioned the towels.

title: Houghton Mifflin Harcourt Enters Bankruptcy Process
description: 2:48 p.m. | Updated Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, the educational and trade publisher in Boston, has agreed with most of its creditors to eliminate $3.1 billion of debt and enter a prearranged Chapter 11 bankruptcy process, the company said on Friday.

title: A Rustic Retreat in Uruguay
description: Tiny Pueblo Garzn features boutiques, a noteworthy winery, a hotel with a plunge pool and more.

title: Where the Faithful Worship Among the Tourists
description: JUST before midnight, the monks were still arriving. Dressed in long, flowing white robes, they resembled fireflies as they rode through the darkness on their motorbikes, descending on the towering temple at the heart of the Cao Dai holy land in southern Vietnam. Many were attending their fourth service of the day.

title: Into Thin Air, True Believers
description: I STOPPED, again, to catch my breath in the thin Andean air, struggling to ease the dizziness as I inhaled from a portable oxygen tank. I must have been a curious sight to the Peruvians passing by. My friends, Andray and Louise, stood beside me, concerned. Realizing we were blocking pedestrian traffic, I pressed myself into the side of the mountain to let the other pilgrims pass.

title: By Her Majestys Grace
description: Confession: I am such a fan of Kristin Cashores first two novels, Graceling and Fire, that over the past three years, Ive returned many times to her author Web site to find out when I could get my hands on her latest, Bitterblue, which plays sequel and companion to the first two. Finally, I got my copy. And I wasnt disappointed.

title: In Philadelphia, Food Trucks Are Rolling
description: FOOD trucks used to be fleeting purveyors of adventurous cuisine, so hard to locate that following the right Twitter feed was the only way to find them. Now, they are a nearly inescapable part of the culinary landscape in many cities, as common as trucker hats once were among their clientele.

title: Fractured Fairy Tales
description: The business of childrens books can seem, for reader and author alike, a bit like buying a ticket for the lottery: from many similar-seeming scraps of paper, one or two will hit the jackpot, while most will be tossed or remaindered. Baffling enough in the big book world, this disproportion, in which one book gets so much and the others so little, is particularly baffling when it comes to fantasy literature for younger readers. That a lottery seems unpredictable is, of course, what makes it a lottery  still, the difference between, say, the commercially mighty Eragon and all the other Tolkien followers seems so minute one doubts anyone could have predicted its peculiar appeal.

title: A Little Bird Told Me
description: Having once been a child who read plenty of picture books, Ive learned that owls are wise, pigeons are insistent and nightingales are heartbreakingly sad. Two picture books, More and Little Bird, without exactly anthropomorphizing the magpie and blackbird within, offer different avian lessons about treasure and treasures.

title: Gumshoes
description: Members of the criminal underworld, beware the little children. Theyve been on to you for years, and the number of mystery-loving young readers seems only to grow. Now to the ranks of Encyclopedia Brown and Cam Jansen comes the newest crop of budding Hercule Poirots: two are American, one is from Botswana, one gang hails from England, and two are Canadians with twitchy noses. The one thing they have in common is that each provides the seeds to understanding how a perfectly average child (or rabbit) might go about becoming a sleuth when baddies need foiling.

title: Hotel Review: Dream South Beach
description: UPSHOT

title: The Caretakers
description: It wasnt easy to read Summer of the Gypsy Moths while living with an 11-year-old whose first literary love was the Clementine series, also written by Sara Pennypacker. The third time I retrieved my copy from my daughters bedroom  a tween lair crammed with bobblehead turtles, Tootsie Roll-scented lip balms and shells from every beach shes ever visited  I realized this book was the first of my literary possessions shes ever truly coveted.

title: It Takes Two
description: Richard Scarry, that genius at engaging and entertaining children, always insisted on featuring animals as characters. Scarry, who died in 1994, believed children might or might not identify with the way a person looked, but with animals, children could project themselves into the story no matter what. Four new picture books all wisely use an assortment of animal pairs to explore important childhood issues like sharing, overcoming differences and conflict resolution.

title: From the Killing Fields
description: Arn Chorn-Pond was 11 years old when the Communist Khmer Rouge swept into power in 1975, and his story is a catalog of the brutality of the next four years, when as much as one-fourth of the Cambodian population was executed or died of hunger, overwork and untreated disease. It is a story most young Cambodians have never heard, in a nation where the past has been buried along with the bones of the killing fields, a nation whose holocaust is not so much denied as it is smothered in denial. It is also a story that will very likely be new to most American teenagers.

title: Letters to the Travel Editor
description: To the Editor: Regarding My London, and Welcome to It (April 29): One of my fondest memories of London includes the daring businessmen, carrying their briefcases, dashing out before oncoming traffic comes around the corner at what seems like incredibly high speeds. They usually make it, but I am never willing to follow them. One great tip: fly into and out of Gatwick. Its easy to navigate, and has a direct connection to Victoria Station.Molly Robertson,Taos, N.M.

title: Boy Blogs World
description: Is Mad magazine dangerous? As a kid I thought so, reading every issue cover to cover in my local drugstore and then spending a significant portion of my allowance anyway because the owner once yelled at me for attempting a fold-in-and-run. I didnt mind: those issues were worth the $1.35 (cheap!) to bring home and parse talmudically, seeking to understand, at age 11, the parodies of Tootsie and Aliens; trying to glean some idea of adulthood from Snappy Answers to Stupid Questions; blissing out to ribald drawings of nearly unclothed ladies. Mad seemed so anarchic that I hid it from teachers who, I assumed, would cry Potrzebie! were they ever to discover I was smuggling the Usual Gang of Idiots into my locker.

title: Feels Like Home
description: Where is home  and why do we yearn for it so? Many celebrated childrens books, directly or indirectly explore these questions, from The Little House, by Virginia Lee Burton, to Margaret Wise Browns Little Fur Family to Laura Ingalls Wilders Little House series.

title: The Pilot and the Spy
description: Im in a bit of a predicament. Oh, its not the predicament of a girl pilot who has crash-landed in occupied France during World War II, or of a girl spy who has been captured by the Gestapo, but its still problematic. I have to review a book in which even the hint of plot summary could ruin everything.

title: Handle With Care
description: A master mahout becomes one with his elephant, we are told in this charming novel for middle-grade readers. He is brother and sister, mother and father, and son and daughter to his elephant. He lives, eats and sleeps with his elephant. He feeds it from his table, and bathes with it in the river. The mahout becomes an elephant, and the elephant becomes a mahout. The two are inseparable. But just as there are all kinds of elephants, so, too, there are all kinds of mahouts.

title: Restaurant Report: Tycoons in Duluth, Minn.
description: If youre going to open a restaurant celebrating millionaires, Duluth, Minn., is a surprisingly appropriate place to do it: at the turn of the 20th century, the city had more of them per capita than any other in the country. For the owners of Tycoons, which made its debut last winter as the national Occupy movement was still in full swing, though, the timing wasnt ideal.

title: Broken Family Camp
description: Over the course of one life-changing summer, Ella Mackenzie, a plucky and preternaturally mature fifth-going-on-sixth grader, is sent to what she calls Broken Family Camp. Ellas family is broken all right, in all the ways we might expect a plucky and preternaturally mature narrators family to be broken, and then some. Sick/absent/dead parent? Check, double check. Her mother has leukemia  Extreme Cancer, Ella calls it  and is about to have a stem cell transplant. Her father, who works as a guide at an outdoor travel adventure company, has literally gone fishing, as he has for most of Ellas childhood. (Her cellphones ring tone for him is Nowhere Man.) An only child, she has no memories of her parents together. When people divorce, the situation is bad but not a complete disaster, she explains. The kids eventually get stepparents and maybe half siblings, back-and-forth schedules between houses and divided-up vacations. We had a lot of that in Santa Rosa. But when we Mackenzies do things, we do them all the way. Its Extreme Divorce, like some kind of reality-TV show.

title: Summer at the Shore
description: Its all too easy for adults who write for adolescent girls to caricature their subjects, whether theyre the snooty prep school girl, as improbably vicious as any Real Housewives cast member, or the artsy outsider longing to be understood. But some young adult authors, most notably Judy Blume, respectfully develop nuanced teenage characters who are capable of doing more than furthering a story line.

title: More Quality Family Time With the Wainwrights and Roches
description: The Scene:The family showed up at Dixon Place, the cozy, pretty performance space on the Lower East Side. Cameras, both still and video, had already been set up and there was a circle of chairs waiting, but they made sure they had all hugged and welcomed each other before taking a seat. There was very little tension and subtext as they settled in, much more of it when the recorder came on, and then none of it once they had finished. The Wainwrights and Roches know how to reveal just enough conflict to make for an interesting interview, but nothing that creates lasting grudges. When the group interview was done, three generations, siblings and half-siblings, grandpa and shy grandchild, all began weighing in on where the gigantic crew might eat. This is a family that likes and loves each other very much, even if they dont always pretend to get along. Below are some additional edited excerpts from the interview.

title: Diving for Underwater Offerings
description: Lisa J. Lucero, a professor of anthropology at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, is studying ancient Maya underwater offerings in central Belize under the auspices of the Belize Institute of Archaeology, National Institute of Culture and History.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE PASSAGE OF POWER: The Years of Lyndon Johnson,  by Robert A.Caro. (Knopf, $35.) The fourth volume of Caros magisterial work spans the five years that end shortly after Kennedys assassination, as Johnson prepares to push for a civil rights act.

title: The Taliban, in Their Own Verse
description: Three-and-a-half years ago, weeks before Barack Obama was elected president and as the United States military was preparing to leave Iraq and dedicate more troops to its bogged-down campaign in Afghanistan, an Afghan writer put his name to Graveyard, a 14-stanza poem.

title: Shoe Thrown at Defendant in Norway Murder Trial
description: A man was escorted out of a courtroom in Oslo on Friday after he stood up and threw a shoe at Anders Behring Breivik, who is on trial for the murder of 77 people in Norway on July 22 last year, Norwegian news reports said.

title: Style Map | Rhine and Dine
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Weekend Fare: Mothers Day and More
description: Everything you ever wanted to sip, from classic gin martinis to a new Belvedere lemon tea, will be mixed, shaken and stirred in any number of libations at the Manhattan Cocktail Classic kickoff Friday night at the New York Public Library. Tickets are sold out, but a host of events, from workshops to tastings, will be held in restaurants and bars across the city through Tuesday. Some sessions have sold out, so check the Web site for ticket availability.

title: The Ballet Stage: To Them, the Job
description: WHEN American Ballet Theater returns to the Metropolitan Opera House on Monday, audiences wont be deprived of the usual array of full-length classics, opulent farewell performances and, of course, those glamorous guest artists, including Denis Matvienko, Polina Semionova and Ivan Vasiliev. But what about the soloists, corps de ballet members and apprentices that make up the heart of the company? For the Met season each dancer  all told around 76  will clock in roughly 160 hours of stage time, performing everything from leads, like the Firebird in Alexei Ratmanskys new production, to one of the Wilis in Giselle.

title: When Magical Thinking Wins the Game
description: In a post on our Slap Shot blog, Jay Schreiber of The Times writes about a sandwich that he believes may well be influencing the fate of the Rangers in Game 7 on Saturday night. He is certainly not alone in his magical thinking. Fans everywhere incorporate all kinds of routines into their lives, believing they could very well help steer the hand of fate.

title: Black Babies and Blackboard Predictions
description: Something very strange, but very telling, took place in the spring of 1862 during Congressional deliberations about a proposed measure to abolish slavery in the District of Columbia: senators debated black birth rates, colonization and the likelihood  the desirability, even  of blacks disappearing as a race. A debate that began as a consideration of the fate of 3,000 men and women in the District of Columbia became a wide-ranging discussion about the demographic future of the nation.

title: The Corner of Falstaff and Zerbinetta
description: THE gods had Olympus. Baseball has Cooperstown. Broadway has Sardis. And the Metropolitan Opera?

title: Paperback Row
description: ON CHINA,  by Henry Kissinger. (Penguin, $18.) Over four decades Kissinger has strived to help Washington and Beijing prevail over a history of conflict, mutual grievance and fear. His shrewd review of Sino-American relations shows how Chinas history has shaped its foreign policy; addresses the central role he played in Nixons historic trip to China; and argues that a strategic partnership is essential to global stability and peace.

title: A Higher Price Tag for a Nuclear Project
description: The flagship project of a hoped-for but not-yet-realized nuclear renaissance, the Vogtle 3 and 4 reactors under construction near Augusta, Ga., may cost about $900 million more than had been estimated, the Southern Company said in a filing this week with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Off the Charts: Germanys Trade Within the Euro Zone Falls
description: Germanys trade surplus with other members of the euro zone has plummeted since the beginning of 2012, but has risen with countries outside the European Union.

title: N.C.A.A. Preview: Against Massachusetts, Colgate Will Meet Its Match
description: The Colgate mens lacrosse team advanced to the N.C.A.A. tournament for the second time in program history on Sunday, when they were selected to play the University of Massachusetts as an at-large bid. The Raiders (13-3) secured the bid with a 13-11 win over A.C.C. powerhouse Maryland the day before. The game was fairly close throughout, but a four-goal run in the final minutes of the third quarter and the opening minutes of the fourth put Colgate up 11-9 from down 9-7.

title: May 13  19
description: IMMIGRATION is an issue everywhere in the country, but Arizona may be the epicenter, and its schools are among the places where the various positions have their most practical effects. PRECIOUS KNOWLEDGE, Thursday on PBSs Independent Lens series (check local listings), takes a look at how a Mexican-American studies program in Tucson was affected by state legislation to abolish such initiatives.

title: In New Ad, Defense of Ann Romney and Motherhood
description: Motherhood, apple pie  and political attacks.

title: S.E.C. Opens Investigation Into JPMorgans $2 Billion Loss
description: Regulators are investigating potential civil violations surrounding the $2 billion loss that JPMorgan Chase disclosed on Thursday, raising further questions about trading activities at the nations biggest bank.

title: Twice-Cooked Duck With Pea Shoots
description: Time: About 20 minutes, plus about 1 hour for initial duck simmering

title: Duck at 2 Speeds, Capturing the Woks Magic
description: I AM a huge fan of Chinese food, but Ive never had any real training in its preparation. My education, if you could call it that, has been gleaned mostly from travel, cookbooks, advice from friends and eating in restaurants.

title: Developers Cease to Offer Condo Incentives
description: THREE months ago, when Wei Min Tan, a broker at Rutenberg Realty, negotiated a deal for a new $3 million three-bedroom condominium at the Aldyn on the Upper West Side, he was able to save his buyers $95,000 in transfer taxes and other costs, as well as to finagle a free storage space.

title: Who Is Who in the British Tabloid Scandal
description: Key individuals involved in the News of the World phone hacking scandal.

title: The Sweet Spot | Creative Destruction
description: The Timess David Carr and A. O. Scott talk about creative destruction in contemporary culture.

title: N.C.A.A. Preview: Maryland Has Momentum
description: The Maryland womens lacrosse team turned around its season after a stretch of inconsistency, and won three consecutive games in the A.C.C. tournament, two against teams that had beaten them earlier in the season, to remain the class of the always powerful A.C.C.

title: President of Rock Hall to Step Down
description: The longtime president and chief executive of the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum announced on Friday that he will retire at the end of 2013, and the museums board of trustees has begun a search for a successor.The official, Terry Stewart, 66, has been in charge of the Cleveland institution since 1999.

title: Stephanie & Alastair
description: Stephanie and Alastair tell the story of how they met through a mutual friend who suggested they should date after finding photos of Alastair and Stephanie each dressed in Harry Potter costumes.

title: Chronicling the Pounds, Their Risks and Causes
description: DURING the production of The Weight of the Nation, a set of films about obesity that HBO will start showing this week, John Hoffman watched over and over again the commercials for sugary snacks and gut-busting meals that appear in excerpts. He knew exactly which buttons the ads were trying to push and why, yet he still was not immune to them.

title: City Unveils Locations of Bike-Share Stations
description: The bike-share stations will be pliable, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has said  their assembly so simple that, if problems arise, docks can be removed without leaving a trace.

title: Two Smooth Operators on the Line
description: Pillow Talk

title: Crossover Realities: The Singers and Styles That Stoke His Sound
description: The Atlanta rapper B.o.B. is known for his crossover collaborations. His debut album, B.o.B. Presents: The Adventures of Bobby Ray, which reached No. 1 on the Billboard chart in 2010, included Haley Williams, the singer for the emo rockers Paramore; Rivers Cuomo of Weezer; and a riff from Vampire Weekend, among others. A year earlier, for his first hit, Nothin on You, he collaborated with the R&B singer Bruno Mars. And Both of Us, the current chart-topping single from his second album, Strange Clouds, released this month by Grand Hustle Records/Rebel Rob Entertainment/Atlantic Records, features Taylor Swift. Nicki Minaj and Morgan Freeman also make appearances on Strange Clouds, along with the strains of B.o.B. himself strumming the guitar.

title: Dressing Up the Duck
description: In this weeks City Kitchen column, Im making twice-cooked duck, a sort of Western cooks variation on a theme. Its actually an amalgam of a few ideas. Based on the classic Chinese twice-cooked pork and packed with sweet and hot Sichuan flavor, I added cumin seeds. Not typically thought of as a Chinese seasoning, cumin is in fact used throughout northern China, and lately a number of New York restaurants have been featuring it in a dish called Muslim lamb chop, or in various other spicy lamb dishes. Im a cumin fan, and I think it works well with the duck too, but leave it out if you wish.

title: Programmers Keep Shows Prospects in Focus (Groups)
description: IN the spring of 1989 NBC seemed to have a new hit comedy on its hands. As the network prepared to announce its fall schedule, executives were thrilled to find that test audiences loved Sister Kate, a sitcom about a nun who takes in a group of orphans. Meanwhile the test results from another show about a stand-up comic and his quirky friends had also come back and seemed to be equally definitive, but in the opposite direction.

title: TMX Groups Quarterly Earnings Decline 10%
description: OTTAWA  The parent company of the Toronto Stock Exchange reported lower first-quarter earnings and revenue on Friday as it continued to wait for regulators to approve its takeover by a consortium of Canadian financial institutions.

title: N.C.A.A. Preview: For Denver, a Fast Start Matters
description: After a heartbreaking overtime loss to Loyola in the semifinals of the Eastern College Athletic Conference tournament, the University of Denver mens lacrosse team received an at-large bid to the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: An End to Bad-Hair Days
description: IT was around 1960, during her early days as a model and years before she became an editor at Vogue, that Grace Coddington met the famed hairstylist Vidal Sassoon. Ms. Coddington, born in Wales and not yet 20, was a hit among the hairdressers of London.

title: Bookshelf: Brothers and Sisters
description: Picture books about siblings.

title: Going to the Chapel and Were Not Getting Married
description: When President Obama announced his support for same-sex marriage on Wednesday, he mentioned those soldiers or airmen or Marines or sailors who are out there fighting on my behalf who are gay but cannot marry in most states.

title: Deweys Bankruptcy Big Wig Joins Proskauer
description: For the past several weeks, Dewey & LeBoeufs Martin J. Bienenstock, one of the countrys leading bankruptcy lawyers, has worked on among the most difficult assignments of his career  trying to save his own law firm.

title: Bookshelf: Brothers and Sisters
description: ONE SPECIAL DAY  By Lola M. Schaefer. Illustrated by Jessica Meserve.  40 pp. Disney-Hyperion Books. $16.99. (Picture book; ages 2 to 5)

title: Investing in Restaurants Can Work, but Its Not as Easy as Pie
description: RELAXING in a restaurant, satisfied after a good meal and maybe a glass of wine, its easy to dream about what it would be like to own the place.

title: Eike Batista to Invest in Brazilian Music Festival
description: Eike Batista, the Brazilian billionaire who made a fortune in the oil, gas and mining industries, is making a move into the music business.

title: Fte Accompli | Dance Class
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: General Motors Pursues LEED Certification in Brazil
description: As automakers rush to demonstrate leadership on environmental issues, green has become marketing gold. The latest proof came from General Motors, which said Thursday that it expected an engine plant under construction in southern Brazil to receive Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design certification.

title: Obama to Skip Economic Summit in Russia
description: As the White House pondered the meaning of President Vladimir V. Putins abrupt decision to skip next weeks Group of Eight summit meeting at Camp David, the Russians took note of the fact that President Obama was skipping an Asian summit meeting in Russia later this year.

title: For a Day, Kimmel Beats Leno in Ratings
description: This is news that can only bring a smile to the face of Jimmy Kimmel: Thursday night, he beat probably his most bitter rival, Jay Leno, in the ratings  even though Mr. Leno had a 30-minute head start on him.

title: N.C.A.A. Preview: The Case for the Cats
description: Comic-book fans eagerly awaiting the summer release of The Dark Knight Rises have been particularly intrigued by the tagline on one of the early posters of the film that reads, The legend ends.

title: Divorcing a Husband, but Not a Grandmother?
description: This weeks quandary is a simple one. Im going through a divorce, a friend posted on my Facebook page. I now have a soon-to-be ex-mother-in-law who is very much still the grandmother of my kids. Id love to see some sage advice on how to navigate this tricky relationship.

title: Britney Spears Likely to Join Judges of X Factor
description: Britney Spears is likely to be named a judge on Season 2 of The X Factor on Monday as the shows creator, Simon Cowell, reveals changes to the singing competition.

title: Reflections on the Third Annual Found Poem Contest
description: It gets harder to choose every year.

title: So Long, High School  College Awaits!
description: The process for enrolling into college is finally over. It is time for the fun to begin!

title: A Phantom Has Not Vanished Entirely
description: Suddenly, there it is. Everywhere. Almost overnight, it seems, 1 World Trade Center has inserted itself into the skyline, visible from places where the sky had seemed more empty than open since 2001.

title: Amy Goldman and Cary Fowler
description: IT was a passion for seeds that brought Amy P. Goldman and Cary Fowler together, and although their romance began fairly recently, it had been germinating for some time, invisible in both of their lives, like a kernel in the ground.

title: Outside Europe, German Trade Surplus Soars
description: GERMANYS trade surplus with its fellow euro nations has fallen to the lowest level in nearly a decade. But its trade surplus with countries outside Europe is soaring.

title: Back to Basics, Real Basics
description: TO some, our obsessive bent toward refinement has created humanitys greatest triumphs: art, architecture, music, Cobb salad. Others wring their hands at more suspect refinements  white flour, white sugar, white chocolate  and see only doom. But do we have a choice?

title: Cracking the Smart Energy Market
description: American homes are getting smarter, at least when it comes to using energy, a consumer research firm reports. By 2020, some 60 percent of homes in the United States will have some type of smart energy management system, according to estimates from the firm, Parks Associates. Still, adoption has been slower than some companies had hoped.

title: How to Mother a Mother
description: During pregnancy, many women are pampered and cared for more than at any other time of their lives. Husbands are attentive, family members call to see how the mom-to-be is feeling, and friends host baby showers, lavishing a woman with gifts and attention.

title: Forty Years Later, a Photographer Finally Gets His Show
description: Recently a photographer friend on Facebook introduced me to the remarkable work of John Myers, who had his first solo exhibition earlier this year at the Ikon Gallery in Birmingham, England. What made this feel like such a discovery is not only quality of the pictures themselves but also the fact that Myers stopped taking photographs altogether in 1988.

title: A Radio Talent Turned TV Talent Judge
description: Howard Stern, the controversial but popular radio host, will join NBCs popular summer competition, Americas Got Talent, as its latest judge.

title: Macroeconomic Morality
description: A brief postscript to todays column: contrary to what some people may think, I dont regard anyone who disagrees with me as necessarily a mendacious idiot. Economics is hard, and people will disagree. Sometimes people will give advice with the best of intentions that turns out, in hindsight, to have been disastrous; thats a tragedy but not a sin.

title: Want to Be at the Garden for Game 7? Wallet, Please
description: There are few experiences in sports like a game seven. One team wins, the other goes home.

title: Austerity, Safety Nets, and Spending
description: The latest in the attempt to make excuses for the abject failure of austerity is the claim that European countries didnt really practice austerity after all. This is mainly coming from the usual suspects  the people who, for example, used Census hiring to claim that Obama was presiding over a vast expansion of government employment. (What will it take for pundits to realize that if Veronique de Rugy, for example, cites a number you can pretty much assume that its wrong?) But I have to say that the responses Ive seen have been surprisingly weak  some people who should know better are conceding the point that maybe there havent been big spending cuts. Yes, there have.

title: Crdit Agricole Plans Contingency for Greek Exit
description: PARIS  One of Frances biggest banks, Crdit Agricole, said Friday that it was working on contingency plans in case Greece exits the euro, the latest on a growing list of European financial firms and businesses to signal they were preparing for all possible outcomes as Greeces financial and political situation deteriorate.

title: Mitt Romney, Bullying and Long Shadows
description: What you do, what you post, what you say matters  now, and for a long time to come.

title: In Black and White, a Gritty History of New York Crime
description: Heres one case where, as far as the city is concerned, crime can pay. Among the 840,000 archival images placed online recently by the citys Department of Records are 1,326 police evidence photographs mostly taken from 1915 to 1920. The Municipal Archives gallery provides free research online and at a new visitors center at 31 Chambers Street behind City Hall, but a digital file or 8-by-10 print will cost $45.

title: Book Review Podcast: A Novelists View of the Absurdities of Motherhood
description: In the New York Times Book Review, Judith Warner considers two new books about the culture and politics of motherhood, and Judith Newman reviews Anne Enrights memoir Making Babies. Ms. Enright is an acclaimed fiction writer who won the Man Booker Prize in 2007 for her novel The Gathering. Though Ms. Newman writes that, No subject offers a greater opportunity for terrible writing than motherhood, she praises Ms. Enrights contribution to the genre:

title: The Digital Lost-Dog Poster
description: BONNIE is missing blared the e-mail subject line. A 2-year-old female pit bull weighing 55 pounds, with gray and white markings, she was last seen on the corner of Maple Avenue and Myrtle Street in my community, wearing a chain collar. I am asking for your help in finding my lost dog, her owner pleaded.

title: Puerile
description: Ive been debating whether to post this, but I guess I probably should just for future reference. Apparently there are a number of people on the political right who have given up actually trying to refute what I say, and have turned to stupid pranks instead. Regular readers may recall that in recent months one guy opened a Google Plus account pretending to be me, making outrageous posts that got picked up by right-wing blogs; then someone opened a fake Twitter account in my name, doing the same thing.

title: Samurai Shopper | The Sweet Smell of Ral Esparza
description: Actors go to great, often absurd lengths preparing for roles: Robert De Niro gained more than 60 pounds to better portray Jake LaMotta in Raging Bull; Nicole Kidman did Cyrano de Bergerac one better by growing a formidable Virginia Woolf-like nose in The Hours. But real method acting is less complicated and literal than that. Its about making connections to sensory experiences  sights, smells, tastes, sounds  in order to flesh out a characters character. The consummate Broadway actor Ral Esparza is very clever in this regard: he picks a cologne/perfume for each role he takes and wears the scent until the the show shutters.

title: The Risks of Restaurant Investing
description: In the latest installment in his series on investing in a passion, Paul Sullivan, in this weeks Wealth Matters column, takes on investing in restaurants.

title: The Push to Make Cab Rides Smarter
description: When it comes to technology, 2007 was the last big year for taxis. That year, New York City began requiring that cabs be fitted with devices so that customers could pay with credit cards and with GPS devices so that they could track their progress on touch screens in the back. (Cabbies went on strike twice before the gadgets were finally installed.) Also that year, Apple introduced the iPhone, although the cab connection was not immediately apparent.

title: In JPMorgan Chase Trading Bet, Its Confidence Yields to Loss
description: When reports emerged in the first week of April that a JPMorgan Chase trader in London was making bets so big they were distorting a little-known market in credit derivatives, an embedded regulator approached executives.

title: Egyptian Campaign Focuses on Islams Role in Public Life
description: CAIRO  Twelve days before a presidential election, a televised debate that carried on into the early morning hours Friday has put the role of Islam in Egypts government at the center of the campaign, with the self-described liberal Islamist in the race coming under fire over whether his agenda is too religious or too secular.

title: Who Speaks for the Children?
description: For decades, Brooklyn prosecutors pursuing child molesters netted few complaints or convictions in the boroughs cloistered, politically powerful community of ultra-Orthodox Jews. Rabbinical authorities banned relatives of the abused from reporting the crimes to non-Jewish authorities; those few who spoke out were shunned  expelled from synagogues, their children expelled from schools  or pressured into dropping their cases.

title: When I Root, God Laughs
description: Religion, someone once said, is what goes through your mind as your plane taxis down the runway. It isnt. What goes through your mind as your plane taxis down the runway is mortality. Its aeronautics. Its the space shuttle Columbia.

title: Memories of a 1994 Classic
description: My wife remarked the other day that I seem to have acquired a second job, one with a lot of late hours. She isnt wrong, exactly. With the N.H.L. playoffs under way, I have been putting in a lot of time as a hockey fan, watching a game, sometimes two, almost every night, and the experience is so draining that it does sometimes feel like work. When Game 3 of the Rangers-Capitals series went into triple overtime, I didnt care who won. I just wanted someone to put the puck in the net so I could go to bed and get some sleep before reporting to my day job.

title: Leftist Partys Rise Upends Greek Political Order
description: ATHENS  The collapse of Greeces dominant parties in Sundays elections swept a new political force onto the scene here: the Coalition of the Radical Left, or Syriza, a pro-euro yet anti-austerity party that has Greeces creditors trembling with its calls for the country to reject its current loan agreement and nationalize the banks.

title: What Seeds Are Often Planted In
description: Administrivial Notepad Alert! The Sunday, the Variety puzzle will be a brand-new form that I wont give away just yet, but I truly hope you will give it a try. Its incredibly innovative and must have been a bear to construct. For this puzzle, there will be a Notepad that reads: In each pair of clues, one is for the answer word, the other for an anagram of the answer. Which is which is for you to discover.

title: JPMorgan Chases $2 Billion Loss
description: Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, can be clear as a bell when he denounces financial reform. But on an emergency conference call with analysts on Thursday to announce the banks stunning $2 billion trading loss, his message was frustratingly vague.

title: In Remission and on a Mission
description: Seun Adebiyi  an Olympic hopeful, Yale Law School graduate and leukemia survivor  is trying to start a public cord-blood bank in Nigeria.

title: When Will They Learn?
description: It plays right into the hands of a bunch of pundits out there, sighed Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, on Thursday.

title: When Holst Read the Mahabharata
description: It wasnt easy to compose operas in the wake of Richard Wagner, whose legacy loomed with menacing authority over the end of the 19th century. With his harmonic innovations, the mythical scope of his subjects and his delicate balance of grandeur and intimacy, Wagner was a model both seductive and treacherous.

title: New York Times Company Sells Final Stake in Fenway Sports
description: The New York Times Company said on Friday that it had sold its remaining stake in the Fenway Sports Group, the company that owns the Boston Red Sox, the latest move in a continuing effort to shed assets unrelated to the companys flagship newspaper.

title: Answers to Questions About New York
description: A College Stretch

title: E-Mails Provide Inside Look at Mayors Charter School Battle
description: The city released hundreds of e-mail messages Friday, providing a behind-the-scenes look at one of the major battles of Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs administration, the 2010 campaign to expand charter schools, or, as one dramatic e-mail put it, the fight of our life.

title: Mean Boys
description: Mitt the menace.

title: Rangers, Through Second-Guessing, Just Want to Play Game 7
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  There is not much to do about playing a Game 7 except play it, Rangers Coach John Tortorella said after practice Friday.

title: Ibanezs Homer Assures That Monteros Blast Doesnt Haunt Yankees
description: The Yankees entered last off-season with Jesus Montero as the expected designated hitter in 2012. General Manager Brian Cashman rerouted that plan in January when he traded Montero to the Seattle Mariners. That left the Yankees searching for designated hitter options before they helped filled the spot by signing Raul Ibanez in February.

title: Finding a Match, and a Mission: Helping Blacks Survive Cancer
description: A month after his 2009 graduation from Yale Law School, Seun Adebiyi learned he had not one but two lethal blood cancers and began an odyssey to find a bone-marrow donor. Mr. Adebiyi, 28, who came to this country from Nigeria as a child, made appeals through Yale, on radio stations, in a YouTube video and even on a trip to Nigeria to ask law students to volunteer.

title: In a Stylish Newcomer, a Promise of Bounty
description: A WELCOME newcomer to northern Central Avenue in White Plains, Graces Table occupies a site with an inauspicious past. Only four years ago, Gregorys was gutted and remodeled into an elegant, extravagant, but oddly named restaurant, BOE@324. It never caught on and in quick succession Ibiza, Gervasis and Crave came and went in the same spot.

title: After Difficult Start, Reyes and the Marlins Show Signs of an Awakening
description: MIAMI  Hours before Jose Reyes prepared to face the Mets for the second time this season, he insisted that he was feeling much more comfortable with his new team. As he smiled and leaned back in a chair in front of his locker, practically overflowing with Marlins gear, it certainly appeared that way.

title: Scoring Two Against Francisco, Marlins One-Up the Mets Comeback
description: MIAMI  The Mets surprising early success and the Marlins unforeseen foibles have added some texture to the National League Easts story line, which was sketched out differently a few months ago.

title: F.A.A. Chief Who Quit Is Cleared of Charges
description: A judge in Virginia has cleared the former chief of the Federal Aviation Administration of the drunken driving charges that cost him his job at the agency.

title: Thousands of Species, Each a Work of Art
description: Joel Sartore has been a conservation photographer for more than 20 years, shooting primarily for National Geographic. About seven years ago, he brought his gear into a makeshift studio and began working with zoo-raised animals, most of which have biologists and handlers tending to their every need.

title: Despite Opposition, Immigration Agency to Expand Fingerprint Program
description: Obama administration officials have announced that a contentious fingerprinting program to identify illegal immigrants will be extended across Massachusetts and New York next week, expanding federal enforcement efforts despite opposition from the governors and immigrant groups in those states.

title: Introducing Children to the Sources of Food
description: STONINGTON, Conn.

title: Yankees Demote Nunez So He Can Focus on Improving at Shortstop
description: Eduardo Nunez has played five positions and committed four errors in 20 games this season, two things that factored into the Yankees decision Friday to demote him to Class AAA Scranton/Wilkes-Barre.

title: Dimon vs. Volcker, the Television Series
description: Does Jamie Dimon think efforts to restrict banks trading have gone too far? Just ask him.

title: Inside a Storefront, Sushi Under Blue Lights
description: ANY preconceived notions of what a storefront restaurant looks like are shattered by Kashi, a year-old Japanese place in Huntington. It is drop-dead gorgeous.

title: Bloomberg Among Critics of Prosecutor in Brooklyn
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Friday sharply criticized the Brooklyn district attorney, Charles J. Hynes, over his handling of child sexual abuse cases among the boroughs large ultra-Orthodox Jewish community.

title: Certifying Good Growers
description: Four East End wine producers have founded a nonprofit education organization that will certify local growers as practitioners of sustainable agriculture.

title: Lottery Numbers
At JPMorgan Chase, a Complex Strategy That Backfired
description: JP Morgan most likely structured a complicated trade in a way that effectively magnified losses.

title: Evelyn B. Johnson, Pilot and Instructor, Dies at 102
description: Evelyn Bryan Johnson last flew a plane in 2005. Two years later, she remained eager to get back behind the controls.

title: Joyce Redman, Actress Who Feasted on Many Roles, Dies at 96
description: Joyce Redman, a distinguished Irish-born actress widely acclaimed for her intelligent stage presence in Shakespearean drama and French comedy, though probably best known to American audiences for her silent improvisation with a lobster, an oyster, a pear and Albert Finney in the exuberantly lascivious eating scene in the 1963 film Tom Jones, died on Wednesday in Kent, England. She was 96.

title: Corrections: May 12
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Mediterranean Fare, With Italian Flair
description: JOE ALBERGO spent most of his career cooking for hire, beginning at 15 in a Brooklyn luncheonette. Along the way  with stops in England, Spain, Jakarta and the restaurant of the Htel Plaza Athne in New York  he quizzed his co-workers about their favorite native dishes. When he was finally ready to open his own place, Mr. Albergo drew on that accumulated lore, as well as on the lessons he had learned at the knee of his Neapolitan grandmother.

title: The Weeks Business News in Pictures
description: Berkshire Hathaways annual shareholders meeting, the coming Facebook public offering and a stunning trading loss by JPMorgan Chase were among the weeks top business stories.

title: JPMorgan Sought Loophole on Risky Trading
description: WASHINGTON  Soon after lawmakers finished work on the nations new financial regulatory law, a team of JPMorgan Chase lobbyists descended on Washington. Their goal was to obtain special breaks that would allow banks to make big bets in their portfolios, including some of the types of trading that led to the $2 billion loss now rocking the bank.

title: Childlike Fancies and Adult Terrors
description: The grotesque old witch who becomes young and beautiful at the end of Act I has arrived in Westport. So have the prince who explains that he was raised to be charming, not sincere, the rejected cow Milky White and the bakers wife who cant have children because of a salad-related curse.

title: Alabama: Teenager Charged in Half-Sisters Death
description: A 14-year-old boy was charged with murder on Friday in the strangling death of his 9-year-old half-sister. When the girl, Katelynn Arnold, was found hanging by a rope from a tree at her house in Ragland on Thursday night, her feet were touching the ground and the police were uncertain about the circumstances of her death. Its not an accident, said Dennis Russell, the St. Clair County coroner. Its definitely a homicide.

title: Florida: Polo Mogul Is Sentenced to 16 Years
description: The polo tycoon John Goodman was sentenced to 16 years in prison for driving under the influence, manslaughter and vehicular homicide in the death of Scott P. Wilson, 23. The sentence was about half of the maximum faced by Mr. Goodman, 48, the founder of the International Polo Club Palm Beach in Wellington. In 2010, Mr. Goodman ran a stop sign in his Bentley convertible, striking Mr. Wilsons car, which careered into a canal. Mr. Goodman walked home and waited an hour before calling 911, prosecutors said, and the victim drowned.

title: Two Volumes on Parenting, From Two Perspectives
description: CHAPPAQUA, N.Y.

title: Finding Comedy in Ailments, Longing and Despair
description: The prelude to the production of Uncle Vanya at the John Drew Theater at Guild Hall is dramatic in its own way. Audience members travel down the center aisle of the lovely jewel-box theater in East Hampton and climb a stairway to the stage, where they find seating for 55 viewers.

title: Death Watch, in Two Places
description: OF the roughly 75 items on display at the Suffolk County Historical Society in Riverhead, a menacing-looking object known as the Wickham ax has been especially fascinating to many visitors.

title: A Frisky Hound Frolics on the Moor
description: Sherlock Holmes, Dr. John Watson and Sir Henry Baskerville are discussing a mysterious letter while they swelter in a sauna and  wait, no, that cant be right; there is no such sweaty encounter in Sir Arthur Conan Doyles The Hound of the Baskervilles.

title: Cooking on the Range, on the Delaware River
description: THE writer Elizabeth Gilbert is planning a family reunion in Frenchtown, where she lives, to celebrate the reissuing this month of the cookbook At Home on the Range (McSweeneys), by her great-grandmother Margaret Yardley Potter.

title: Syria: A Suicide Bomber Is Foiled in Aleppo, the State News Agency Says
description: Security forces in Aleppo killed a suicide bomber driving a stolen minibus crammed with five large canisters of explosives before he could detonate them, the state-run Syrian Arab News Agency reported Friday. The agency said the driver had intended to bomb Aleppos densely populated Al Shaar neighborhood a day after two suicide bombers killed at least 55 people in Damascus. Syrian officials say the attacks vindicate their contention that President Bashar al-Assads foes are foreign-backed terrorists, while opposition figures say the government is trying to scare people. But outside experts see growing evidence that fighters from neighboring countries, possibly sent by Al Qaeda in Iraq, are joining the fight in Syria, further complicating efforts by the United Nations and Arab League to uphold a shaky cease-fire. The number of United Nations truce monitors on the ground in Syria has now reached nearly half the planned total of 300, the chief United Nations spokesman, Martin Nesirky, said Friday. Mr. Nesirky rejected suggestions that the cease-fire was near collapse. This is a plan that has the full support of the international community, he said. No one is saying this is an easy task.

description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Gone Hollywood, Bollywood Theater in Queens Still Struggles
description: This is my exercise, said Somasundaram Gunasegaram as he scrambled nimbly up an iron ladder to the cramped projection booth in the Jackson Heights Cinema, a tired old movie house on 82nd Street just off Roosevelt Avenue in Queens, Corey Kilgannon writes in The New York Times.

title: Formula One Comes Home
description: BARCELONA  After running the first four races of the season either on the other side of the world or in the threatening unknown terrain of Bahrain, Formula One has come home to Europe. And boy, did it ever feel like home as the paddock people arrived in Barcelona for Sundays Spanish Grand Prix.

title: Five Centuries in Love: Thats a Lot of Past Lives
description: Forget till death do us part, Rachael Saltz writes about the Bollywood romance Dangerous Ishhq, which means dangerous love. In the film love transcends bodies and conquers time, Ms. Saltz writes.

title: The Early Word: Pivot
description: Todays Times

title: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
description: Jammu and Kashmir: The illegal sale of 200 acres of land owned by the Defense Ministry in Srinagar to private owners has exposed the role of state government officials who were allegedly bribed to push the deal through. The sale of the land posed a security threat to strategic army installations and the airport in the valley, around which this contested piece of land is located, The Indian Express reported.

title: Highlights From Junior Seau Public Memorial
description: Suggested reading on the public memorial for Junior Seau at Qualcomm Stadium in San Diego on Friday. Among the speakers were Dan Fouts, Bobby Ross, LaDainian Tomlinson and John Lynch. The Broncos John Elway, Peyton Manning and John Fox were among those in the crowd. A video highlight of the night can be found at ESPN.  The full speeches can be found at the Chargers Web site.

title: Getting On the Bus by Getting Off the Bus in Suburbia
description: Last week was walk-your-kids-to-school week in the district where I live, and so thats what my husband and I did. So did many of our friends and neighbors, which made for a sweet, old-fashioned scene at 8:30 each morning, as clusters of families funneled on foot onto the school property  like something out of Little House on the Prairie, except, of course, that many of us were clutching our childrens hands lest a rogue Subaru swerve out of control.

title: JPMorgan and Solyndra
description: I havent weighed in on the JPMorgan stuff, because I havent had time to figure out the whole thing. I would say that Ive always wondered why Jamie Dimon had such a reputation for smarts, since nothing Ive seen seemed to justify the reverence; maybe nothing did.

title: Europe Slips in World Influence Stakes
description: LONDON  Surprise, surprise! The international standing of European nations has declined in the past year, according to a survey published this week, and Germany is no longer the state most admired by the rest of the world.

title: Horst Faas: A Last Hurrah
description: We asked Richard Pyle, Horst Faass colleague at The Associated Press for many years, who wrote Mr. Faass obituary for the A.P. (featured on Lens yesterday), for a personal remembrance of the famed photographer and photo editor.

title: That Guy Renting Bowling Shoes Is a Beauty
description: Las Vegas has its share of drag shows, but a few cross-dressing entertainers have decided to trade their stilettos for bowling shoes.

title: Dennis Tueart: Manchester City Forever
description: Dennis Tueart, the man who brought Manchester City its last major trophy  the 1976 League Cup  before the club won the 2011 F.A. Cup, has been making the rounds in England as one of his former clubs nears winning the Premier League title.

title: Ashimas Ascent
description: Ashima Shiraishi, an 11-year-old bouldering enthusiast from New York City, has been turning more than a few heads in the climbing world.

title: Tiny Hand Over Hand
description: HUECO TANKS STATE PARK AND HISTORIC SITE, Tex.  With a concentrated squint, Ashima Shiraishi silently sized up her first rock of the day, a menacing slab of jagged beige boulder 20 feet high, scuffed by white chalk left behind from bigger, older, more experienced climbers.

title: Spy Balloons Become Part of the Afghanistan Landscape, Stirring Unease
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The traders crouched beneath the walls of an old fort, hunkered down with the sheep and goats as they talked, eyes nervously flitting up from time to time at the blimp that has become their constant overseer.

title: Romney Tells Evangelicals Their Values Are His, Too
description: LYNCHBURG, Va.  Mitt Romney traveled to Liberty University, the spiritual heart of the conservative movement, on Saturday, seeking to quell concerns about him among evangelical voters by offering a forceful defense of faith and Christian values in public life.

description: For a decade, the Knicks conducted business like a crazed QVC addict with a stack of limitless credit cards  lunging at every shiny object, no matter the price or the consequences.

title: Variety: All Mixed Up
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  If you havent done this puzzle yet, prepare to be amazed and astounded. I know I was.

title: Q. and A. With Ray Lucas
description: Ray Lucas does not blame the N.F.L. for his addiction to prescription painkillers, and he does not blame football. After contemplating suicide, he got help, and he said he wants to throw a lifeline to others. Lucas, a former Rutgers, Jets and Dolphins quarterback, now an SNY football analyst, is working with Reckitt Benckiser Pharmaceuticals to inform the public about treatment options. In his case, he took Suboxone, an opioid that he said managed his withdrawal symptoms and eventually allowed him to subdue his addiction. Lucas, 39, answered questions recently via e-mail.

title: After Divisive Primary, Shifting to the Center
description: WASHINGTON  Presidential nominees have several options for repositioning after ideologically charged primary campaigns: strategic silence, new proposals, a different tone on the brighter general election stage.

title: At the 17th Hole at Sawgrass, Awaiting a Big Splash
description: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla.  The betting window was closing. As the golfers Aaron Baddeley, Harrison Frazar and Justin Leonard walked to the 17th tee box at T.P.C. Sawgrass, the man in the bucket hat, golf shirt and khaki shorts waved a wad of dollar bills and said to the fans seated behind him, Who do you have?

title: Death Sentence Reviews Leave Unsettled Issues in Texas
description: Stanley Schneider was shocked last year when Texas highest criminal court sent his death row client an early Christmas gift of sorts, ordering the trial court to re-examine evidence from a psychologist who had decided that John Reyes Matamoros was mentally fit to face execution.

description: ATHENS  Greeces president will start negotiations on Sunday to form a coalition government in a last-ditch effort to avoid new elections and further political turmoil.

description: Want to guarantee a campaign throwdown? Toss 2 major American cities, 2 large minority populations and 15 candidates into one newly drawn Congressional district.

title: C.E.O. or Not, You Always Need Feedback
description: This interview with  Deborah Farrington, a founder and general partner at StarVest Partners, a venture capital firm in New York, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: Factions Are Forming Among Texas Republicans
description: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

title: Players 4-Homer Night Highlights Career
description: Michael Aubrey was home in Shreveport, La., last Tuesday night, studying for final exams, when his brother-in-law  a fan of the Texas Rangers  told him in a text message that Josh Hamilton had just hit his third home run. I know a guy who did four, the message said.

title: Is There a Romney Doctrine?
description: WASHINGTON

title: A Next-Generation Offering From Willie Nelson
description: On April 20, on Willie Nelson Boulevard outside Austin City Limits Live at the Moody Theater in downtown Austin, Willie Nelson witnessed the unveiling of an eight-foot, one-ton bronze rendering of his likeness. Perhaps because he is too humble to ponder his own achievements, Mr. Nelson, 79, simply said with a smile, Ill be stoned 1,000 years.

description: After they lost to the Brooklyn Dodgers in the 1955 World Series, the Yankees embarked on a six-week barnstorming tour of the Pacific islands.

description: To the Sports Editor:

description: BOSTON

title: West Bank Leader Says Security Forces Cant Get Guns
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank  President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority said Saturday that his security forces were struggling because Israel had refused to allow them to import a shipment of weapons, and that he was very, very, very afraid of what might happen if one of the Palestinian prisoners on a long-term hunger strike died.

title: Cutbacks Hurt a States Response to Whooping Cough
description: MOUNT VERNON, Wash.  Whooping cough, or pertussis, a highly infectious respiratory disease once considered doomed by science, has struck Washington State this spring with a severity that health officials say could surpass the toll of any year since the 1940s, before a vaccine went into wide use.

title: Western Conference Finals Prediction
description: No. 3 Phoenix vs. No. 8 Los Angeles

title: The Numbers Are Adding Up for the Thunder
description: Last season the Oklahoma City Thunder became the youngest team in N.B.A. history to reach the conference finals. The Thunder lost to the Dallas Mavericks, 4-1, in that series, but Oklahoma City exacted revenge by sweeping the defending champions in the first round of this years playoffs.

title: Man Arrested in Shooting in West Bank
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank  Palestinian Authority officials said Saturday that they had arrested the man they believed was responsible for the May 1 shooting at the house of the governor of Jenin, who died hours later after suffering two heart attacks.

title: Human Rights, Not So Pure Anymore
description: THE international commotion around the blind Chinese activist Chen Guangcheng aroused memories of earlier dissidents like Andrei D. Sakharov and Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, the Eastern bloc heroes of another age who first made international human rights a rallying cry for activists across the globe and a high-profile item on Western governments agendas.

title: Candidate in Egypt Makes an Insiders Run for President
description: SHIRBEEN, Egypt  At a recent campaign rally here, Alaa Zinhom said he had no interest in voting for Amr Moussa, a former Egyptian foreign minister who is campaigning for the job once held by Mr. Moussas old boss, President Hosni Mubarak.

title: A Generation Hobbled by the Soaring Cost of College
description: ADA, Ohio  Kelsey Griffith graduates on Sunday from Ohio Northern University. To start paying off her $120,000 in student debt, she is already working two restaurant jobs and will soon give up her apartment here to live with her parents. Her mother, who co-signed on the loans, is taking out a life insurance policy on her daughter.

title: Dodgers Are Starting to See Better Days
description: On his first game day as the president of the Los Angeles Dodgers, May 4 in Chicago, Stan Kasten basked in the scenery at Wrigley Field. He might have taken special pride in the flags flapping atop the center-field scoreboard.

title: A New Amenity May Show Up on Some London Roofs for the Olympics: Missiles
description: LONDON  It looked like one of those things where you get free pizzas through the post, Hilal Bozkurt said, describing the innocuous-looking leaflet that came through her mail slot recently. But this was like, free missiles.

title: Drowning in Debt
description: Like thousands of her peers, Kelsey Griffith will graduate from college owing thousands of dollars in student loans. Her university, which told her to pursue her dreams rather than focus on the price, didnt tell her about the steep monthly payments she would be facing.

title: Student Debt at Colleges and Universities Across the Nation
description: Interactive charts showing the increasing student debt levels at colleges and universities in the United States.
