description: GLENDALE, Ariz.  The Phoenix Coyotes rank last in attendance in the league. They have been operating in bankruptcy for three years. They are so hamstrung financially that they have trouble signing free agents.

title: Student Portraits: College Loans
description: The Times spoke to current and former students about taking loans to pay tuition.

title: Syracuse Lacrosse Legend Has Womens Team at No. 4
description: SYRACUSE  Gary Gait, who helped Syracuse win three consecutive N.C.A.A. lacrosse championships from 1988 to 1990, was recently watching another generation of players practicing the sport and preparing to pursue their own bit of history.

title: Australias Superstar Mare Does It Again
description: On Saturday, Black Caviar did what she has always done: the superstar mare from Australia won another race, her 21st consecutive.

title: Playoff Run Aside, Coyotes Ownership Is Still a Prickly Issue
description: After three seasons of fits and starts and various suitors, the Phoenix Coyotes could be sold in coming weeks to a group headed by Greg Jamison, the former chief executive of the San Jose Sharks.

title: In Manchester, Supremacy in English Game Is Poised to Move Across Town
description: The Premier League title will be awarded Sunday in Manchester, England; that much is certain. This is not an uncommon occurrence.

title: Sepia Tones Distort Feats of Distant Past
description: Last month, Philip Humber of the Chicago White Sox pitched the 21st perfect game in the major leagues. Last week, Josh Hamilton, the Texas Rangers outfielder, became the 16th major leaguer to hit four home runs in a game.

title: The Economics of Marginalization and Hopelessness
description: Thats one of the subject headings in this recent survey paper (pdf) on teen births, which are much higher in America than in other advanced countries. The authors find evidence suggesting that inequality and lack of mobility are central, another sign that Wilkinson-type views about the corrosive effects of inequality are going seriously mainstream.

title: Protests Over Arms Sales to Bahrain
description: One day after the State Department said the United States would resume some arms sales to Bahrain  despite what the United States acknowledges as unresolved human rights issues among the countrys leadership  activists on Saturday denounced the measure, as demonstrators descended on the countrys capital city to protest the governments detention of political prisoners.

title: Breakout Season for Sacha Kljestan
description: When Anderlecht clinched its 31st Belgian title last Sunday after a 1-1 draw with Club Brugge, it was a career milestone for Sacha Kljestan who has been a consistent presence this season in central midfield for the Brussels-based club.

title: Doan Keeps Faith in Coyotes
description: GLENDALE, Ariz.  Shane Doan, the Coyotes captain and longest-suffering member, does not often mention his religion publicly. He does not have a Tim Tebow-style celebration upon scoring a goal. But he does writes Bible verse on his hockey stick.

title: E. J. Potter, Michigan Madman of Motorcycle Racing, Dies at 71
description: E. J. Potter, a k a the Michigan Madman, a legend of the American drag strip who earned his nickname riding 170 miles per hour on a motorcycle he fitted with a Chevy V-8, and who later went nearly 200 m.p.h. on a three-wheel bike powered by a jet engine, died on April 30 in Ithaca, Mich. He was 71.

title: Whats Really Scary
description: Update: Aha, Romm credits Michael Tobis at the bottom of the post.

title: Dieting for Dollars (or Maybe a Movie Ticket)
description: BACK in 1999, Michael Paolini, an inventor at I.B.M. in Austin, Tex., was having lunch at a Ruby Tuesdays with some fellow engineers when the group decided that too many burgers and fries were translating into thicker waistlines. It was time to lose weight.

title: Meet Your Neighbors, if Only Online
description: I DONT know many of my neighbors. I blame genetics: Im hard-wired for shyness. Or so I thought until I signed up with Nextdoor.com, a neighborhood-based social network. There I have discovered a comfortable place for even a borderline recluse like myself.

title: Mexican Violence Leaves Behind Trail of Doubts
description: COLIMA, Mexico  After her son Alfredo was killed last year at his auto parts shop, Carmen Plascencia de Carrillo noticed that two half sisters skipped the wake and funeral.

title: Pregame Chatter: Preparing for Game 7
description: Preparing for a Game 7 can be tricky, as the Rangers John Mitchell discussed Saturday morning, hours before the big clash against the Washington Capitals at Madison Square Garden that would decide which team would advance to the Stanley Cups final four.

title: Patents Arent Only for Engineers
description: I NEVER considered that I might obtain a patent one day. To me, patents were mostly for engineers, not for actuaries like me.

title: Garca Rallies to Stay in Contention
description: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla.  Sergio Garca was headed in the wrong direction, with no end in sight. But rather than give in to another frustrating weekend, Garca overcame some early hiccups and ended the third round of the Players Championship in contention.

title: Brewers Owner Invests in Team That Built Team
description: Mark Attanasio is an investor, and his intuition has served him well in business and as the owner of the Milwaukee Brewers. His asset-management firm is growing, and although his baseball team is not winning  for now  it is stable.

title: From Forklifts to Photography
description: I GREW up in Brooklyn, on Flatbush Avenue near Prospect Park. One of my earliest memories is of learning to use a hand dolly to move boxes. My father, who was a truck driver, later taught me how to operate a forklift and, when I was old enough, to drive an 18-wheeler.

title: Fast Starts for Top Players at Three Elite Tournaments
description: The top-ranked players in three elite tournaments  the United States Championship in St. Louis, the Sigeman & Company event in Malmo, Sweden, and the 47th Capablanca Memorial tournament in Cuba  took early leads last week.

title: Slippery-Slope Logic, Applied to Health Care
description: THERE are lots of important things to worry about these days: terrorism, the economy, climate change and, for Yankee fans, the loss of Mariano Rivera. But worry is a scarce commodity. Even a mother  Jewish or not  cant worry about everything. So it is important that we limit our worries to real as opposed to imaginary risks.

title: Flights to Safety Cant Hide the Dangers
description: THE pattern has been repeated so many times that it might be comforting if it werent so disturbing.

title: Obama and Biden Honor Officers in Ceremony
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama, along with his vice president and the secretary of homeland security, honored 34 law enforcement officers chosen as the years Top Cops, 31 of whom joined them on a spectacular Saturday in the Rose Garden; the three absent winners are recovering from gunshot wounds.

title: Saving the Lives of Moms
description: THIS is a Mothers Day tribute to a mighty woman and to the doctor who gave her back her life  and also a celebration of a grand new womens hospital that you as readers helped to build.

title: Sunday Dialogue: Making Taxation Fairer
description: Readers offer ideas for tax reform but doubt it will happen.

title: Mary Gordon
description: Mary Gordon is a Canadian expert on child development and the founder of Roots of Empathy, a classroom program adopted in 10 countries that has been shown to reduce cruelty and bullying. The program involves periodically taking infants to elementary schools where students become attached to the babies and learn to empathize, ultimately raising their emotional and social consciousness.

title: When You Text Till You Drop
description: I DONT know about you, but Ive always found the debate about what our mobile devices are doing to us  to our behaviors, our manners, our minds  at least as interesting as reports about what were doing with these devices.

title: Rearranged Marriage: A Sequel
description: I KNOW our relationship seems to have run its course, Diane, but before you take any more meetings with that divorce lawyer, I want you to listen to this pitch: a marriage reboot. Im thinking When Harry Met Sally meets my relationship with my ex-girlfriend Cassie. With a few tweaks, Im confident we can breathe new life into this tired franchise.

title: Muddling Through Mothers Day
description: IM pretty certain it was six years ago. I know I was in a restaurant. I know, too, that I was a little tipsy  thats the only way the impulse could have come to me, the only way I would have acted on it.

title: For Obama, Its About the Children
description: In a historic interview last week, President Obama announced his support for same-sex marriage. As he discussed his journey toward that position, the president sounded many familiar themes, like the importance of distinguishing between civil and religious marriage and of living up to American ideals of fairness. At the core of his narrative, however, was a relatively novel element  an affirmation of gay couples as parents.

title: Greek Tragedy
description: AS I follow the modern Greek tragedy unfolding in Europe, I flash back to the 18 years I spent in Athens, walking to school in Plaka (the old part of the city), on the same streets that have recently been filled with protesters and violent clashes.

title: The Amygdala Made Me Do It
description: WHY are we thinking so much about thinking these days? Near the top of best-seller lists around the country, youll find Jonah Lehrers Imagine: How Creativity Works, followed by Charles Duhiggs book The Power of Habit: Why We Do What We Do in Life and Business, and somewhere in the middle, where its held its ground for several months, Daniel Kahnemans Thinking, Fast and Slow. Recently arrived is Subliminal: How Your Unconscious Mind Rules Your Behavior, by Leonard Mlodinow.

title: Capitalists and Other Psychopaths
description: THERE is an ongoing debate in this country about the rich: who they are, what their social role may be, whether they are good or bad. Well, consider the following.A 2010 study found that 4 percent of a sample of corporate managers met a clinical threshold for being labeled psychopaths, compared with 1 percent for the population at large. (However, the sample was not representative, as the studys authors have noted.) Another study concluded that the rich are more likely to lie, cheat and break the law.

title: Thanks, Maurice
description: Artists and designers pay tribute to Maurice Sendak.

title: Thanks, Maurice
description: Maurice Sendaks 1963 Where the Wild Things Are unlocked a scary, psychologically nuanced, inner world long taboo in mainstream childrens books. Mr. Sendak once told me that King Kong was a great character and had influenced him when he created Wild Things.

title: At JPMorgan, the Ghost of Dinner Parties Past
description: WHAT goes around comes around. Sometimes it happens sooner than youd think.

title: With a Hit Here, and Another There, the Mets Defeat the Marlins
description: MIAMI  The Mets 9-3 victory over the Miami Marlins on Saturday afternoon was a substantial one, without a doubt, but one that still had to be manufactured, bit by bit, through small contributions from every corner of the team.

title: Reunion, and Returning as Your Real Self
description: COLLEGE alumni departments market spring reunion weekends like Caribbean cruises with lectures, barbecues, kids camps and dancing under the stars. Many people attend them to relive in some fashion their wild, carefree youth. Others go to show their classmates that theyve made a success of their lives. When I went back for the 25th reunion of my 1982 college class, I was motivated primarily to show up as my authentic self.

title: The Human Disaster of Unemployment
description: THE American economy is experiencing a crisis in long-term unemployment that has enormous human and economic costs.

title: Winning the News Cycle, Losing the Race
description: FOR a generation or more, liberals have complained that the Republican Party uses social and cultural debates to distract voters from pocketbook issues. From Howard Deans 2003 lament about Southerners voting on race, guns, God and gays to Thomas Franks musings on whats supposedly the matter with Kansas, the Republican focus on social issues has been regularly portrayed as a bait-and-switch, designed to bamboozle Americans into voting against their economic interests.

title: The Wisdom of Slime
description: THE United States interstate highway system is often celebrated as a simple yet highly efficient transportation scheme  one that, starting in the 1950s, transformed the American economy and lifestyle. Its network of roads was designed to maximally span the country with a minimal number of links, while still allowing for enough redundancy to help drivers overcome wrong turns and missed exits.

title: Harming the Troops
description: Republican lawmakers love to say they are protective of religious freedom and supportive of the military. Last week, Republicans on the House Armed Services Committee passed two measures that undermine both in an effort to deny equal rights to gay men and lesbians.

title: The Battle for Westchester
description: America has become far more diverse in the 44 years since the Fair Housing Act was passed, and many of the barriers that kept communities separate and unequal have eroded. But the fight against unlawful discrimination has not ended. In affluent Westchester County, just outside New York City, officials continue to resist integrated housing, even as they endure repeated setbacks in federal court.

title: Haitis Cholera Crisis
description: The cholera epidemic in Haiti, which began in late 2010, is bad and getting worse, for reasons that are well understood and that the aid community has done far too little to resolve. A chronic lack of access to clean water and sanitation make Haitians vulnerable to spreading sickness, especially as spring rains bring floods, as they always do. Summer hurricanes are bound to come; more misery and death will follow. The Pan American Health Organization has said the disease could strike 200,000 to 250,000 people this year. It has already killed more than 7,000.

title: What if It Werent Called Pink Slime?
description: The first casualties of the hamburger ingredient contemptuously dubbed pink slime will likely not be anyone who eats it but rather the workers who make it. Beef Products Inc. announced last week that it will close three of its four plants and lay off about 650 workers by May 25. It had little choice. While an estimated 70 percent of the ground beef sold in this country in early 2011 contained what the manufacturers call lean finely textured beef, orders from supermarkets for ground beef containing the ingredient plummeted this spring after a series of supposed exposs raised consumer concerns.

title: This Column Is Not Sponsored by Anyone
description: PORING through Harvard philosopher Michael Sandels new book, What Money Cant Buy: The Moral Limits of Markets, I found myself over and over again turning pages and saying, I had no idea.

title: Seeking Original Bliss
description: WASHINGTON

title: Kutchers Arrival Helps Revive a Comedy
description: How much did the departure of Charlie Sheen hurt the comedy Two and a Half Men?

title: Mark Zuckerberg, C.E.O.
description: Is Mark Zuckerberg, founder of social media phenomenon Facebook, ready to be the chief executive of an 80 billion dollar company?

title: Reading Together, Knowing the Ending
description: WHEN my mother was dying of pancreatic cancer, I would often go with her to chemo, and we would usually talk about books. Discussing what we were reading was something we had done all our lives. But it wasnt until one day during her second month of treatment that we realized that we had created a very peculiar book club: one with only two members.

title: The Education of Mark Zuckerberg
description: Mark Zuckerberg is ready for his close-up.

title: Writers Cramp: In the E-Reader Era, a Book a Year Is Slacking
description: For years, it was a schedule as predictable as a calendar: novelists who specialized in mysteries, thrillers and romance would write one book a year, output that was considered not only sufficient, but productive.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, May 13
description: A few days after JPMorgan Chase reported a $2 billion trading loss, the banks chief executive, Jamie Dimon, will appear on NBCs Meet the Press. Also on the program will be Senator Carl Levin, the Michigan Democrat who was an author of legislation intended to prevent banks from taking big risks. He will discuss how more government oversight could have prevented JPMorgan Chases loss.

title: Robert Smallss Great Escape
description: As elite Charlestonians slept unaware in the lavish mansions of the Confederacys spiritual capital, a slave  a mulatto man trusted by both his owners and employers  executed a daring plot that struck at the core of the white Southern imagination.

title: Those Moms Who Need a Boost on Mothers Day
description: My Mothers Day column is about one of the great scourges of the developing world that arises in the process of childbirth: obstetric fistula. Ive seen lots of grim things in my reporting, but a fistula in a teenage girl is about the saddest. Conversely, theres nothing more joyous than a girl who has just had her fistula repaired and now has her life back again.

title: Louis H. Pollak, Civil Rights Advocate and Federal Judge, Dies at 89
description: Louis H. Pollak, a federal judge and former dean of two prestigious law schools who played a significant role in major civil rights cases before the Supreme Court, including the landmark Brown v. Board of Education desegregation case, died on Tuesday at his home in Philadelphia. He was 89.

title: Indies
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  First, Wordplay wishes a Happy Mothers Day to all who have given birth, adopted, fostered, or otherwise been important in the life of a child.

title: Yankee Stadium Welcomes Berra for His 87th Birthday
description: Yogi Berra sat in the passenger seat of a golf cart driven by his close friend and de facto valet Ron Guidry and soaked in the applause of the Yankee Stadium crowd. It was minutes before the Yankees game against the Seattle Mariners on Saturday, and the Yankees honored Berra on his 87th birthday.

title: Shortfall in Californias Budget Swells to $16 Billion
description: LOS ANGELES  The state budget shortfall in California has increased dramatically in the last six months, forcing state officials to assemble a series of new spending cuts that are likely to mean further reductions to schools, health care and other social programs already battered by nearly five years of budget retrenchment, state officials announced on Saturday.

title: Angelica Garnett, Writer of Frank Memoir of Bloomsbury Childhood, Dies at 93
description: Angelica Garnett, the last direct link to the Bloomsbury set, whose memoir of growing up amid its potent brew of sex, secrets, artistry and renown is notable for offering a childs-eye view of that darkly charmed circle, died on May 4 in the South of France. She was 93.

title: Saving a Disappearing Beach
description: Coastal erosion in South Kingstown, R.I., has shrunk parts of the towns beach to less than a dozen feet during high tide.

title: Horst Faas, Photographer Who Showed Horrors of War, Dies at 79
description: Horst Faas, a two-time Pulitzer Prize-winning war photographer who later was editor of The Associated Press staff in Saigon that produced some of the most haunting photographs of the Vietnam War, died Thursday in Munich. He was 79.

title: In Rhode Island, Protecting a Shoreline and a Lifeline
description: SOUTH KINGSTOWN, R.I.  Mike Couchie looked up from his Heineken as an opened door ushered an unearthly roar into the Ocean Mist, a seaside bar here.

title: Its That Time of Year
For Tea Party, Focus Turns to Senate and Shake-Up
description: WASHINGTON  The primary victory of a Tea Party-blessed candidate in Indiana illustrates how closely Republican hopes for a majority in the Senate are tied to candidates who pledge to infuse the chamber with the deep-seated conservatism that has been the hallmark of the House since the Republicans gained control in 2010.

title: Woman Dies in a Brooklyn Fire That Is Deemed Suspicious
description: She was 25 and curvaceous, and she often drew admiring glances in the gritty Brooklyn neighborhood where she was known to invite men for visits to her apartment, her neighbors and the authorities said.

title: Strong Start by Hughes Carries Yankees
description: Phil Hughes departed the Yankee Stadium mound nearly two weeks ago to lukewarm applause, with fans seemingly unsure whether a mild sign of progress was worthy of their cheers or still merited their disapproval. Hughes had struggled throughout the first month of the season, and Yankees fans were growing restless about his inconsistency.

title: New York Police Release Data Showing Rise in Number of Stops on Streets
description: Police officers stopped people on New York Citys streets more than 200,000 times during the first three months of 2012, putting the Bloomberg administration on course to shatter a record set last year for the highest annual tally of street stops.

title: Career in the Minors Is Interrupted by the Devils Push for the Stanley Cup
description: NEWARK  A compact man with curly black hair and a beard clomped through the Devils dressing room on skates after practice Saturday, stashing his black helmet in his locker before moving on to the next episode of his improbable and rollicking springtime adventure.

title: Gunmen in Afghan Police Uniforms Kill 2 NATO Soldiers
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A day after an assailant wearing an Afghan Army uniform killed an American soldier in eastern Afghanistan, two insurgents dressed in Afghan police uniforms on Saturday shot and killed two coalition soldiers in the south of the country, NATO said.

title: Hi, Mom, Its Me
description: A fellow only child asked me recently what I said first when I call my parents.

title: Na in the Lead, and Trying to Keep Pace

title: Echoing Out of Texas, Chinese Voice of Dissent for Religious Freedom
description: MIDLAND, Tex.  When the Chinese activist Chen Guangcheng stole the show at an emergency Congressional hearing this month by calling into the chamber during a live television broadcast, few people noticed who was holding the cellphone.

title: Lottery Numbers
Amid Signs of Economic Weaknesses, China to Free Cash for Lending
description: Chinas central bank announced late Saturday that it would loosen monetary policy in a clear effort to stimulate the economy after the release on Thursday and Friday of a batch of economic indicators for April that were considerably weaker than most economists had expected.

Carl Pettersson, who produced one of three bogey-free rounds Saturday at the Players Championship, was answering questions outside the scoring area when his visor blew off. A stiff breeze carried Harris Englishs opening drive so far left that his ball conked a marshal in the head. Tiger Woods had to back off a birdie putt at 18 when an ice cream wrapper flitted into his line.

title: U.S. May Scrap Costly Efforts to Train Iraqi Police

title: Bloomberg Defends Same-Sex Marriage in State That Rejected It

title: Logic and Neutrality
description: Heres an idea many philosophers and logicians have about the function of logic in our cognitive life, our inquiries and debates. It isnt a player. Rather, its an umpire, a neutral arbitrator between opposing theories, imposing some basic rules on all sides in a dispute. The picture is that logic has no substantive content, for otherwise the correctness of that content could itself be debated, which would impugn the neutrality of logic. One way to develop this idea is by saying that logic supplies no information of its own, because the point of information is to rule out possibilities, whereas logic only rules out inconsistencies, which are not genuine possibilities. On this view, logic in itself is totally uninformative, although it may help us extract and handle non-logical information from other sources.

A borough that people like Kate Young, Freja Beha and Sophie Theallet all call home cant be wrong, fashionably speaking, so I had to check it out for myself, Sabas says of her newest project: The Brooklyn of Fashion Insiders. Compiled by Sabas and her collective of stylish tipsters/borough residents  Maria Cornejo, Arizona Muse and Ts online editor, Jane Herman  the portable handbook celebrates and explores Kings County businesses and their cool, laid-back attitudes. Even the celebrity tattoo artists are friendly, Sabas says. (The guides cover art was created by Marc Jacobss inker of choice, Scott Campbell, who works in Williamsburg.) What struck Sabas most, though, is the boroughs wide-spreading reputation for dishing up stylishly straightforward food: I keep thinking of the words epicurean chic, something I previously identified with Europeans in the 1970s, she says. Among the restaurants that made Sabass cut: James in Prospect Heights, Romans in Fort Greene, Cafe Colette in Williamsburg and Dressler (which I personally recommended for its gorgeous dining room and elegant cocktails). But its more than just a listing of hip eateries. The guide also spotlights Brooklyns best yoga studios (Greenhouse Holistic and Shala), florists (Sprout Home and Saipua), vintage boutiques (Bogart & Moore and Erie Basin) and car services (Northside), which are handy when bridge-hopping back to Manhattan, if you must.

title: St. Louis Conductor Takes New Post in Sydney

Mr. Robertson will succeed Vladimir Ashkenazy as the orchestras leader. His contract in Sydney runs through 2018. Mr. Robertson, who first appeared as a guest conductor in Sydney in 2003, assumed his post in St. Louis in 2005, when he also became principal guest conductor of the BBC Symphony Orchestra. The Sydney Symphony seems to have made an attractive offer. In its announcement of the appointment the orchestra said Mr. Robertson would take part in at least two CD recording projects a year; a yearly concert performance of an opera; regular commissioning of new works in collaboration with other orchestras; and annual touring, with a focus on China. Much of the Sydney Symphonys season takes place during the off months at St. Louis. Mr. Robertsons contract in St. Louis ends with the 2013-14 season, but a spokesman there said he and the orchestra were in discussions to extend his tenure.

description: PARIS  It is a measure of the importance to France of the relationship with Germany that Franois Hollande, after taking office on Tuesday, will eat his first dinner as president of France in Berlin, in the company of Chancellor Angela Merkel.

title: Todays Technologies Need an Off-the-Hook Option
description: When I was a kid, Friday night was always movie night in the Bilton house. My dad would stop on his way home from work to pick up Chinese takeout and a movie from the video rental store.

title: David Robertson to Lead Sydney Symphony
description: David Robertson, the music director of the St. Louis Symphony, has taken on a position on the other side of the world, becoming artistic director and chief conductor of the Sydney Symphony in Australia starting in 2014. Mr. Robertson will succeed Vladimir Ashkenazy as the orchestras leader. His contract in Sydney runs through 2018. Mr. Robertson, who first appeared as a guest conductor in Sydney in 2003, assumed his post in St. Louis in 2005, when he also became principal guest conductor of the BBC Symphony Orchestra.

title: The Case for Overreacting
description: Via Mark Thoma, Simon Wren-Lewis argues that if were up against the zero lower bound but are uncertain about the size of the output gap  how far the economy is operating below potential  we should deliberately overreach on fiscal policy. Why? Because monetary policy can correct any excess stimulus, but not an inadequate stimulus.

title: JPMorgan Loss Puts Spotlight on Possible Ratings Downgrade for Global Banks
description: A Moodys Investors Service analyst said on Monday that JPMorgan Chases big trading loss underscored the rating agencys deliberations over whether to cut the credit ratings of 17 global banks.

title: Facebook Raises Offering Share Price
description: 8:35 a.m. | Updated with filing details

title: For New York Police, Theres No End to the Stops
description: New York Citys public advocate, Bill de Blasio, put forward a modest proposal last week. He wants the Police Department to include the number of street stop-and-frisks, which is in a state of geometric expansion, in its weekly review of precinct crime statistics.

title: Romneys Weasel Problem
description: You can wince at the cruelty of adolescence, as many did, after reading the Washington Post account of how a teenage Mitt Romney led a gang of prep school buddies to attack another boy. Senseless, vicious and stupid were the words used by witnesses quoted by name in the piece.

title: Beyond the Sandbags and Steel, 12 Lanes to Another Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Behind the black door in downtown Kabul is a place unlike any other in this city, even in the whole country.

title: Syrians Defy Leaders to Aid Those in Need
description: DAMASCUS, Syria  For 48 hours, the two Damascus residents struggled to reach the besieged city of Homs by car, trying to deliver boxes of blood bags so surgeons there could operate on the wounded. But gunfire made the roads impassable.

title: New York Council Wants Banks to Describe Efforts in Poor Areas
description: As a huge trading loss at JPMorgan Chase intensifies criticism of the nations big banks, the New York City Council plans to vote on Tuesday to require banks to make public their efforts to be socially responsible before the city decides where to deposit the billions of dollars it keeps in banks.

title: A Landmark Ruling in South Africa
description: For the past decade, South Africa has been the preferred vacation spot, shopping destination and international transit hub for members of the tyrannical and murderous government ruling its northern neighbor, Zimbabwe  a government that has rigged elections, beaten and killed opposition activists and ruined a once thriving economy. All of this could now change because of a landmark legal decision.

title: Coca-Cola Tests Sweeteners in Battle of Lower Calories
description: Coca-Cola is testing a new blend of sweeteners aimed at lowering the calorie counts in sodas, following on the heels of its rival, PepsiCo, which introduced the 60-calorie Pepsi Next at the end of March.

title: In Graduation Speech to Women, Obama Leaps Into Gender Gap
description: President Obama, shifting the focus from his recent endorsement of same-sex marriage to what he portrays as a lifelong belief in the essential role of women, told female graduates of Barnard College in New York City on Monday that they should go out and fight for a seat at the head of the table.

title: 1994 Revisited: Q. and A. With Stephane Richer
description: During the Eastern Conference finals between the Rangers and the Devils, The New York Times will revisit some of the memorable characters of the 1994 conference finals between the teams. On May 15, 1994, the Rangers and the Devils met at Madison Square Garden in Game 1. After the Devils Claude Lemieux tied the score, 3-3, with 43 seconds left in regulation, Stephane Richer scored the winning goal in the second overtime for the Devils. Now 45, Richer spoke by telephone from Montpellier, Quebec, where he owns a golf course.

title: 23 Syrian Soldiers Reported Killed by Rebels
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Nearly two dozen Syrian government soldiers were killed in intense clashes with the opposition over control of the central, rebel-held city of Rastan, opposition groups said Monday, deepening questions about the viability of a cease-fire engineered under United Nations auspices.

title: New Cast Atop Yahoo Faces Stubborn Troubles
description: As Yahoos latest chief executive and newest board members settle into their roles, they will be confronted with the same problem that has bedeviled their predecessors: how to fix one of Silicon Valleys most crisis-plagued companies.

title: Well-Rested Thunder Crush Lakers
description: OKLAHOMA CITY  In the aftermath, as the crowd at Chesapeake Energy Arena continued to rock around them, Andrew Bynum and Pau Gasol remained on the Los Angeles Lakers bench for several minutes as they searched for some answer to what the Oklahoma City Thunder had done to them.

title: Warning Signs of a Failing Tree
description: Six indicators of stress, decay or potential failure used to assess the health of trees.

title: Comedies Lead the Way for the Next TV Season
description: AS the television upfront week for the 2012-13 season gets under way, the networks announcing their schedules signaled clearly how much they are counting on comedy to improve their fortunes.

title: At Upfront, Fox Shows Off Some New-Media Tricks
description: During upfront week, it can sometimes seem as if television networks trip over one another to show off their new-media prowess.

title: Saudi Arabia Seeks Union of Monarchies in Region
description: MANAMA, Bahrain  Saudi Arabia pushed ahead Monday with efforts to forge a single federation with its five Persian Gulf neighbors as the conservative monarchy seeks to build a new bulwark against the waves of change sweeping the Middle East.

title: Bronx Lawmaker Seeks a Sharp Contrast With Disgraced Predecessor
description: Former state senators from one particularly hapless section of the northwest Bronx have something in common on their rsums: one went to jail, another is still in jail and a third now faces jail.

title: Lottery Numbers
Risk of Greek Euro Exit Rattles Markets, but Hints of More Talks Emerge
description: BERLIN  As gridlock among Greeces political parties made new elections and another month of uncertainty there all but inevitable, European markets dropped significantly on Monday amid concerns that Greeces departure from the euro was near, and right behind it a new round of financial instability for Europe and the outside world.

title: New Twist in a March Senate Election Thats Still Too Close to Call
description: It has been eight weeks since voters in South Brooklyn cast their ballots for a short-term state senator in a short-term district. Eight long weeks of accusations, legal proceedings and ballot counting.

title: Make Banking Boring
description: Lets begin by stipulating the obvious: nobody outside of JPMorgan Chase knows for sure what really happened with those trades that have cost it so much money and done such severe damage to its once stellar reputation.

title: Deadliest Danger Isnt at the Rig but on the Road
description: After working 17 hours straight at a natural gas well in Ohio, Timothy Roth and three other crew members climbed into their company truck around 10 oclock one night last July and began their four-hour drive back to their drilling service companys shop in West Virginia.

title: The Rights Righteous Frauds
description: Say what you will about Bristol Palin, shes a quick study. It didnt take her long to master the ways of her elders on the censorious right and decide that personal circumstance and past error neednt prevent someone from claiming righteous leadership. Uncle Rush must be proud.

title: The ESPN Man
description: Two of the nations smartest analysts have just come out with reports on how the presidential election looks six months out. Bill Galston of the Brookings Institution argues that at this point President Obama has a modest advantage over Mitt Romney. The pollster Peter D. Hart says that this election is no better than a 50-50 proposition for the president.

title: Mitt Likes Music, Including This
description: The Gregory Brothers present a musical video mash-up about what Mitt Romney likes  from lakes and trees to music and cars to grits and Twilight.

title: Experts Say Default Would Mean Eviction
description: ATHENS  Could Greece default on its debt and still remain in the euro zone?

title: How Bank Handles Bad Bet Is Fraught With Peril
description: If I go there will be trouble, and if I stay it will be double.

title: Turning a Phrase
description: This is the fifth in a series of writing lessons by the author, starting with the basics and leading to more advanced techniques.

title: Documents on the Oil Field Exemptions From Highway Safety Rules, Explored and Annotated by the Times
description: Documents related to the so-called oil field exemptions from highway safety rules that allow truckers to work longer hours than drivers in most other industries.

title: On Familiar Garden Ice, Brodeur Struggles to an Oft-Heard Refrain
description: Devils goaltender Martin Brodeur had barely finished scuffing the goal crease for better traction before the opening face-off Monday night when a full house at Madison Square Garden began serenading him with the Marty! chant he has heard for most of the last two decades.

title: Mitt Likes Music, Including This
description: In 2008, Barack Obama whipped voters into a hope-fueled frenzy, audaciously promising a government that would be able to pass laws. Perhaps President Obama thinks a similarly bold strategy will help him prevail this fall over his Republican rival, Mitt Romney.

description: Below are the lyrics to "Mitt Likes Music, Including This, an Op-Doc by the Gregory Brothers, and the source for each line.

title: The Perfect Hedge Remains Elusive at JPMorgan
description: At JPMorgan Chase, they called it the icing  as in the icing on the cake.

title: Iran Sees Success in Stalling on Nuclear Issue
description: TEHRAN  As Iran starts a critical round of talks over its nuclear program, its negotiating team may be less interested in reaching a comprehensive settlement than in buying time and establishing the legitimacy of its enrichment program, Iranian officials and analysts said.

title: Prison Term for Family Friend in Harlem Boys Killing
description: Tyshene Mungo lost her son on a warm night in September 2008. A longstanding dispute between two rival gangs  the Lenox Boys and 2 Mafia Family, or 2MF  escalated after one member crossed a median on Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard that separated their territories in Harlem.

title: Drug Trial Starts for Figure Prominent in Rap World
description: Prosecutors say James Rosemond is a drug kingpin, and he went on trial Monday in federal court in Brooklyn on charges that he led a criminal enterprise that sold millions of dollars worth of cocaine, laundered money and tampered with witnesses.

title: Hollow Victory
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  If youre like me, the kind of crossword solver who tends to solve from top to bottom, you probably appreciate it when the payoff is near the bottom. Theres nothing quite like wending your way through the grid, slightly puzzled (see what I did there?) as to what might possibly be tying the long entries together, then reaching the entry that will reveal all. If youre like me, theres that delicious moment where you stare at the grid, blink a few times, and then allow yourself to give in to that wonderful Aha! moment.

title: In Washington, Mixed Messages Over Tighter Rules for Wall St.
description: Conflicting signs are emerging in Washington over whether JPMorgan Chases surprise trading loss will spur tighter regulation on Wall Street.

title: Rapper Faces Death Threats in Iran Over Song
description: TEHRAN  With lyrics that tread on ultrasensitive topics and an album cover that shows the dome of a mosque in the shape of a womans breast, Shahin Najafi is an international rapper who elicits an intense reaction here.

title: Self-Promotional Pimp Draws 4 Years
description: Jason Itzler, the self-proclaimed King of All Pimps, was sentenced on Monday to four years in prison for promoting prostitution, money laundering and drug charges, but not before he called for the legalization of prostitution.

title: Red Flags Said to Go Unheeded by Bosses at JPMorgan
description: In the years leading up to JPMorgan Chases $2 billion trading loss, risk managers and some senior investment bankers raised concerns that the bank was making increasingly large investments involving complex trades that were hard to understand. But even as the size of the bets climbed steadily, these former employees say, their concerns about the dangers were ignored or dismissed.

title: Scandal Not Affecting Chinas Political Calendar
description: BEIJING  Despite a spectacular political scandal and swirling rumors of high-level infighting, signs are that Chinas once-in-a-decade leadership change is still on track for this autumn, according to party insiders and observers.

title: The Strange Life of the Closer
description: In two years since becoming the closer for the Milwaukee Brewers, John Axford ranks second in the majors in save percentage, trailing only Jose Valverde of Detroit. Last Friday he blew his first save in 50 opportunities, and left the ballpark before reporters could talk to him.

title: Mongolia: Ex-Leader Granted Bail
description: Former President Nambaryn Enkhbayar was granted bail on Monday and will remain hospitalized after refusing water for 10 days to protest his detention on corruption charges. He ended his hunger strike after bail was granted. The Sukhbaatar District Courts decision was confirmed by a Mongolia prisons service spokesman, T. Amarsaikhan. Mr. Enkhbayar and his family said his arrest last month, on charges dating as far back as 2000, was an attempt by the government to keep him from taking part in parliamentary elections next month.

title: Coty Withdraws $10.7 Billion Offer for Avon
description: Coty said on Monday that it was abandoning its pursuit of Avon Products, citing Avons unwillingness to engage in discussions.

title: As Mets Hold Breath, Francisco Holds Lead
description: Mets starter Miguel Batista did his job against Milwaukee on Monday night, and so it was time for Manager Terry Collins to do his: delicately handle a fragile bullpen trying to preserve yet another tight ballgame.

title: End of the Affair?
description: Investors are shunning the stock market, and who can blame them? As serial bubbles have burst, faith in the market has been rewarded with shattered retirements. At the same time, trust has been destroyed by scandals and  as demonstrated by the reckless trading at JPMorgan Chase  the slow, uncertain pace of financial reform.

title: Not Too Late to Curb the Filibuster
description: Fed up and rueful, Harry Reid, the Senate majority leader, made a startling admission on Thursday: he should have reined in the filibuster rule last year, when he had a chance. As Republicans engaged in yet another of their endless filibusters on what should have been a routine matter  reauthorizing the Export-Import Bank  Mr. Reid took to the floor and praised two senators for being right last year when he was wrong.

title: Confronting Keystone Again
description: The next chapter in the Keystone XL pipeline saga has now begun. In January, President Obama rejected the first proposal from TransCanada, the pipeline company, on grounds that there was not enough time for a thorough environmental review of the project, which would carry crude oil from the Alberta tar sands to the Gulf Coast.

title: A Steeplechase Death
description: Scenes from the Iroquois Steeplechase in Nashville, where Arcadius, an 8-year-old gelding, collapsed and died soon after leaving the winners circle.

title: A Sidewalk Shed in Perpetuity
description: For all the high-rise beauty of the citys silhouette, pedestrians down below must step warily beneath mine-shaft-like structures called sidewalk sheds  overhanging wood and steel constructions that are supposed to be up only temporarily to catch debris from workers repairing building facades high above. There are about 6,000 sheds at any one time, in a city that constantly needs fixing.

title: Colorado Rejects Same-Sex Civil Unions
description: DENVER  A bill that would have allowed civil unions for same-sex couples in Colorado was defeated on Monday night during a special legislative session called by Gov. John W. Hickenlooper to debate the issue.

title: Chesapeake Energys Chief, Under Investor Pressure, Seeks to Win Over Skeptics
description: HOUSTON  Chesapeake Energy sought to calm investors on Monday by disclosing details of a new $3 billion unsecured bridge loan aimed at buying time for the financially beleaguered company to bargain for the best terms in selling valuable oil fields in West Texas and other assets.

title: Mike McGrady, Known for a Literary Hoax, Dies at 78
description: Mike McGrady, a prizewinning reporter for Newsday who to his chagrin was best known as the mastermind of one of the juiciest literary hoaxes in America  the best-selling collaborative novel Naked Came the Stranger, whose publication in 1969 made Peyton Place look like a church picnic  died on Sunday in Shelton, Wash. He was 78 and lived in Lilliwaup, Wash.

title: In City Where Dogs Outnumber Children, Finding a Way for Coyotes to Coexist
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Almost all creatures, great and small, are welcome in the city of St. Francis, patron saint of animals, whose spirit imbues this place with a love and regard for our nonhuman friends. Take just one example gleaned from census and city data: Dogs outnumber children here, making already assertive dog owners an even more formidable political force.

title: Corrections: May 15
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: After the Best Race of His Life, a Horses Death
description: NASHVILLE  Even the winners can die. The steeplechase horse Arcadius  a thoroughbred like those in this weekends Preakness  won a race that rewards the hardy, the brave, the stout. Three miles. Eighteen hurdles. He galloped, he jumped, he stalked, he flew home.

title: Can Dual Citizens Be Good Americans?
One Swing Lifts Teixeira and Yankees
description: BALTIMORE  Mark Teixeira wore a worried expression Monday afternoon as he described the status of a cough he can neither shake nor understand. It has plagued him for more than a month and at times makes it difficult for him to breathe, especially after he has run the bases.

title: The Presidents Day in New York City
description: A behind-the-scenes look at President Obamas day in New York City, where he spoke at a graduation, taped a television interview and attended two fund-raisers.

title: Rangers Start Off With Strong Finish
description: The Rangers had several heroes Monday night in the latest renewal of the Battle of the Hudson.

title: Rangers-Devils: Game 1
description: After two scoreless periods, a flurry of offense provided a victory for the Rangers.

title: For Some, Same-Sex Marriage Is Not Politics, Its Personal
description: WASHINGTON  Some of their best friends turned out to be gay.

title: Rhode Island Order on Gay Unions
description: Gov. Lincoln Chafee of Rhode Island on Monday ordered all state agencies to recognize same-sex marriages performed elsewhere and to afford those couples many of the same rights and benefits that heterosexual couples get.

title: Maldives President Rules Out Early Elections
description: The president of the Maldives ruled out early elections during an official visit to India on Monday, citing the constitution, and declared that the soonest that a vote could take place was July 2013.

title: Judge Blocks Testimony for Edwards on Finance Law
description: GREENSBORO, N.C.  In a setback for the defense, the judge in John Edwardss corruption trial on Monday barred the testimony of a former federal elections official who was prepared to say Mr. Edwards did not violate campaign finance laws.

title: Inflation Rate Outpaces Predictions
description: Inflation in India accelerated faster than expected in April, as the cost of food, fuel and manufactured items all rose, complicating the central banks efforts to curb rising prices with economic growth slumping nearly to a three-year low, Reuters reports.

title: Romney Medicare Plan Draws a Stark Contrast
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama and Mitt Romney agree on one thing about Medicare: the differences between them are huge. Each man says his opponents policies would end Medicare as it now exists, undermining the rock-solid guarantee of health care for older Americans.

title: After Regaining Minutes, Kreider Capitalizes
description: As the final minutes of the game counted down, and Chris Kreider sat on the bench after his goal and assist had given the Rangers a 2-0 lead, the veteran wing Mike Rupp had some advice for the rookie. Or perhaps it was more like a command.

title: Obama Ad Focuses on Workers Who Lost Jobs When a Mill Acquired by Bain Capital Closed
description: Steel, a two-minute advertisement for President Obamas re-election campaign, will run on network television on Wednesday night in Colorado, Iowa, Ohio, Pennsylvania and Virginia. The campaign is spending less than $100,000 to air the ad, at least initially.

title: Too Many Sacred Cows
description: On May 11, a furor erupted in Indias Parliament over a black-and-white cartoon from 1949, Hartosh Singh Bal writes in the Latitude blog of The New York Times. Reproduced in a textbook for high-school juniors, the drawing depicts B.R. Ambedkar  Indias foremost Dalit leader and the chairman of the committee that drafted Indias 1950 Constitution  whip in hand and astride a snail labeled the Constitution.' The first Prime Minister of India, Jawaharlal Nehru, stands behind him, also wielding a whip. Mr. Bal writes.

title: Tackling a Hefty Reading List
description: In college, I took a course on Karl Marx that required reading everything that Marx and Hegel wrote. It was history as boot camp, and we were overwhelmed by the task.

title: How the Poll Was Conducted
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll is based on telephone interviews conducted May 11 through May 13 with 615 adults across the United States.

title: Illinois: 8 Arrested in NATO Protest
description: At least eight protesters were arrested on trespassing charges Monday after they refused to leave the building that houses President Obamas re-election headquarters in downtown Chicago. The protest, organized by a national Roman Catholic group, was the first display of civil disobedience leading up to a NATO summit meeting being held in the city on Sunday and Monday.

title: Ruling on Mine Will Be Appealed
description: The Obama administration said Monday that it would appeal a ruling by a federal judge that the Environmental Protection Agency illegally vetoed a major coal mining project in West Virginia. In a scathing decision in March, Judge Amy Berman Jackson of Federal District Court wrote that the agency overstepped its authority by retroactively revoking the waste disposal permit for the Spruce No. 1 mine in Logan County in January 2011. In taking the rare step of revoking the permit, which was granted in 2007 by the Bush administration, the E.P.A. said the coal mining would do permanent damage to rivers, wildlife and communities. The project, owned by Arch Coal of St. Louis, would have buried 6.6 miles of streams under tons of mining waste.

title: Good News for Six Types of Fish
description: A record six populations of fish returned to healthy levels in 2011, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration reported to Congress on Monday. NOAAs Fisheries Service said the count showed that its controversial and often unpopular catch limits have been working. Among the rebuilt populations are the Bering Sea snow crab, the summer flounder along the mid-Atlantic, the haddock in the Gulf of Maine, the Chinook salmon along the Northern California coast, the coho salmon off Washington State and the Pacific widow rockfish, the Fisheries Service said. Altogether, 27 fish stocks have been returned to health in the last 11 years, the agency said. Under the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act, NOAA must report annually on fish stocks in waters within 200 miles of the coast, and depleted stocks must be rebuilt to healthy levels. Scores of fish species have been in serious decline since the 1980s, largely because of overfishing.

title: Inside the China-Philippines Fight in the South China Sea
description: Fish, oil and bananas all play a role in the latest round of the high-stakes sovereignty dispute in the South China Sea, a problem that may rival Europes own 19th-century Schleswig-Holstein Question. That long-simmering territorial dispute, between Denmark and Germany, led the British politician Lord Palmerston to quip that only three people had ever understood it: a dead prince, a German professor who went mad, and I, who have forgotten all about it.

title: News Quiz | May 15, 2012
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: With Flexibility, Africa Surpasses India
description: Africa is a continent widely associated in the Western imagination with poverty, corruption, conflict and disease, Ian Bremmer writes in The New York Times. Yet Africa has become the worlds most underrated growth story  in part because many of its governments have developed the resilience that comes with the ability to pivot.

title: May 15, 1911 | Supreme Court Orders Standard Oil to Be Broken Up
description: On May 15, 1911, the Supreme Court ordered the dissolution of Standard Oil Company, ruling it was in violation of the Sherman Antitrust Act.

title: Top Murdoch Aide Is Charged in Hacking Case
description: LONDON  Rebekah Brooks, the former head of Rupert Murdochs British newspaper empire and a close friend of Prime Minister David Cameron, was formally charged on Tuesday, along with her husband and four others, with perverting the course of justice in the phone hacking scandal that has burrowed deeply into British public life.

title: Who Is Mark Zuckerberg?
description: WHO is Mark Elliot Zuckerberg?

title: Making Choices in the Age of Information Overload
description: Recently my wife and I went on an epic hunt to uncover everything possible about baby formula. We scoured more Web sites than Id like to admit to and learned about all the options: powder, liquid, milk-based, soy, D.H.A.- and A.R.A.-fortified. (Im still not clear on what A.R.A. is, exactly.) Then we learned that none of it actually matters. Since the Infant Formula Act of 1980, the F.D.A. makes sure that all formula is pretty much the same, no matter which one you buy.

title: Is TV Stronger Than Ever, or Becoming Obsolete?
description: Television, the entertainment stalwart, may have seen better days. Viewer demand for content is higher than ever, but consumers are increasingly watching it on DVR, computers, tablets or smartphones, which often allows them to skip advertising. Even with these changes, television advertising revenues were up in 2011. How do you watch TV shows? Is television as we know it in trouble?

title: Shooting More Than a War
description: Nicole Tung, 25, spent much of 2011 in North Africa, photographing upheaval in Egypt and rebels in Libya. An American citizen, she was born in Hong Kong and attended New York University. She hopes to make a book of her images from the Libyan revolution.

title: Iran Executes Man Accused as Israeli Spy and Assassin
description: LONDON  Iran said Tuesday that it had executed a man accused of being an Israeli intelligence agent responsible for the assassination of one of its nuclear scientists.

title: Euro Zone Economy Skirts Recession
description: FRANKFURT  Its way too early to call a turning point. But while Greeks were marching in the streets against austerity, their economy may actually have been growing for the first time since 2009. That surprise news resided deep within first-quarter economic data for Europe released Tuesday that also showed, to everyones mild relief, that the euro zone as a whole has still avoided slipping into a regional recession.

title: The Shingles Vaccine Returns
description: You may have seen a rugged-looking retired firefighter named Dennis Grogan in a TV commercial recently. I have never encountered such a burning sensation, he declares. Like someone had set a bag of hot charcoal on my neck. An announcer warns, As you get older, theres a greater chance shingles can happen to you.

title: What Rule Should the Fed Follow?
description: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform  Why We Need It and What It Will Take.

title: A Dream College Acceptance, With the Money to Make It Come True
description: I stood on the sixth floor of my school, staring down the seemingly endless brown and black checkerboard patterned hallway, waiting for the (1) to pop up on the mail icon on my phone. Legs quivering, heart pounding, hands shaking. Finally, it appeared: Syracuse University Admission Notification. I couldnt click the link attached to the e-mail fast enough.

title: Hollande Meets Merkel to Start a Delicate Balancing Act
description: BERLIN  The new beginning for the most important relationship in Europe  between Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany and President Franois Hollande of France  started Tuesday with a bolt from the blue, an apology, and a sense of harmony that seemed somehow more sincere for the adversity that came before it.

Q&A: Turning Off a Social App

title: Setback in Comeback for Giants Chad Jones
description: Chad Jones, a Giants third-round pick in 2010, has made impressive strides since a car accident halted his career soon after he was drafted from L.S.U. as a safety. But the decision by the Giants on Monday to release him suggests that his comeback may end one step short of the N.F.L.

title: A Youth Entrepreneurship Program Goes International
description: In 1981, a gang of teenagers mugged the owner of an import-export business while he was walking on Manhattans Lower East Side. They ran off with the contents of his wallet, $10. But Steve Mariotti took away something more valuable: the germ of an idea.

title: ESPN Doubles Up on 30 for 30 Documentary Series
description: ESPNs faith in sports documentaries is so deep that on Tuesday it will announce a second go-round for its 30 for 30 series, which made its debut in the fall of 2009.

title: Q. and A.: The Most Endangered Rivers
description: Five million Americans in four states and the District of Columbia drink water from the Potomac River. Yet according to the environmental group American Rivers, that water is at risk: in a report issued on Tuesday, it listed the Potomac as No. 1 on its annual list of the most endangered rivers.

title: Toughening Its Stand, European Union Sends Forces to Strike Somali Pirate Base
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  The European Union, which had vowed to take a tougher stand against the scourge of Somali piracy, took the fight to the pirates home base for the first time on Tuesday, destroying several of their signature fiberglass skiffs as they lay on the beach in a notorious pirate den.

title: How to Enjoy the Derby in 10 Easy Steps
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  More than a week removed from partaking in what Hunter S. Thompson called the Derbys special vibrations, Ive had time to reflect on the entire experience. The Kentucky Derby is the longest continuously held sporting event in the United States, and it truly is something to be checked off your bucket list. As John Steinbeck wrote in 1956: What an experience. I am glad I have seen it and felt it at last.

title: German Growth Gives Rare Boost to Euro
description: LONDON  There is precious little good news coming out of the 17-nation euro zone these days. So the unexpected announcement on Tuesday that Germanys economy grew by a robust 0.5 percent in the first quarter of the year was enough to give a mild boost to the battered single currency.
