title: How to Enjoy Going to the Movies Again
description: These are challenging times for cinephiles. The sanctity of our natural habitat  the movie theater  is disappearing amid the dynamite blasts of lighted phones while people text and tweet in the dark; the chain-saw buzz of disruptive conversation; and the slow erosion of common courtesy in communal spaces. As a committed moviegoer who once treasured the cathedral-like atmosphere of the movie house, I now find myself entering the auditorium anticipating a bad experience  sitting and nervously profiling every person who walks into the theater for their yet-to-be-committed misdemeanors. (Is he a talker? She definitely looks like a texter.) In fact, given the round-the-clock accessibility of movies, the advent of oversize HDTV screens and the quality of high-end home-theater sound systems, its more and more tempting just to hunker down and erect a cinematic temple in your own home.

title: Who Made That Crash-Test Dummy?
description: Before the modern dummy was invented, crash-testing relied on cadavers, animals, sandbags and the occasional human volunteer. In 1949, Maj. J. P. Stapp, an Air Force flight surgeon studying the physiology of rapid deceleration, wanted to test his rocket sled on something resembling a human. He commissioned a dummy based on plaster casts of an actual pilot. A California firm called Sierra Engineering responded with Sierra Sam, a six-foot-tall steel-and-rubber dummy with instruments in his thorax and head. Soon, it became apparent that such a dummy could have a big impact on the auto industry. With the birth of the Interstate, in 1956, Americans began driving longer distances in bigger and more powerful cars, increasing concerns about safety. In 1965, Ralph Nader published Unsafe at Any Speed, and the following year Congress passed the National Traffic and Motor Vehicle Safety Act. The same year, the engineer Samuel Alderson, who studied physics under J. Robert Oppenheimer, built the first dummy designed for the automotive industry. He called it V.I.P.

title: All I Wanted Was for Alice Waters to Feed Me
description: Forty-two years ago, when Alice Waters taught preschool at Berkeley Montessori, I was among her pupils. Waters was fired, she told me later, for wearing see-through blouses. I wish I could remember the snacks. Im sure they were good, because Waters opened Chez Panisse next, becoming the queen of our towns most exclusive social court. My parents always reminded me of this the way other Berkeley parents reminded kids about how their entire family was once tear-gassed during an antiwar march.

title: Richard Ford Is a Man Who Actually Listens
description: Your new novel, Canada, is set in 1960, the year a teenagers life changes when his parents rob a bank. Your father died of a heart attack that same year. I cant imagine thats a coincidence.  It may be a subliminal thing. I would be foolish to say that that year wasnt significant. And I have sometimes thought that because my father died when I was 16 that I write in a way thats compensatory, that I write into a void that I never experienced. Ive written two or three stories about boys and girls who have parents at age 16 and go on having parents at age 16 and what happens subsequent to that.

title: Guardian Anger
description: My younger brother, who is now 40, began drinking heavily and using drugs in high school and was in a car accident that left him with brain damage. The last 25 years have been a cycle of rehab, jail, institutionalization and halfway houses, and he is now in such bad shape that he needs a guardian. My parents, who have health problems of their own, have asked me to take this on. I have no relationship with my brother. I am a single mother with a demanding job, and I live about a seven-hour drive away. I do not want my brother near my house or my daughter. Do I need to take on the responsibility of his guardianship? L.M., WISCONSIN

title: The Duplass Brothers Have Kidnapped Hollywood!
description: Our time is worth a ton of money right now, Mark Duplass said matter-of-factly, and indeed, he and his big brother, Jay, could have been spending this particular afternoon extracting large checks from Hollywood studios  setting up a feature film or toiling on a rewrite job. Instead they were in Jays garage-turned-office in Los Angeles, preparing for a sound-looping session for their microbudget movie, The Do-Deca-Pentathlon, and generally acting like stoned teenagers in faded black jeans. Jay rooted through cardboard boxes, searching for microphones. Mark watched, strumming an acoustic guitar. They called each other Dupes a lot, a variation on Duplass that they stole from a friend.

title: Q. and A. With Gary Braness: How Do I Deal With Pests?
description: In this weeks Real Estate section, Samantha Storey writes about that most common of New York City problems: pests.

title: Things Left Unsaid
description: I would like you to write a simple story just once more, a dying man says to his daughter in Grace Paleys Conversation With My Father. He asks that she, like Maupassant or Chekhov, create recognizable people and then write down what happened to them next. The nine stories in Johanna Skibsruds first collection, This Will Be Difficult to Explain, could have been written with this mandate in mind. In them, young women stumble through summer jobs abroad, wives toy with leaving their husbands, and fathers labor to communicate with sullen teenage daughters. Her characters live in South Dakota and California, in unnamed suburbs, rural towns and far-flung capitals that, if unrecognizable in detail, are familiar in mood. What links these stories, aside from a handful of recurring characters, is their fascination with the mundane, with the instances in which the known becomes foreign or the everyday exposes a sinister architecture.

title: Retracing His Steps
description: The central character in Paul Therouxs latest novel, The Lower River, is an American named Ellis Hock who decides to return to Africa after an absence of almost 40 years. Life in his own country has become tiresome and frustrating, but theres a village in Malawi where, during his Peace Corps days, Hock had once been happy and useful. He wants to be useful again. So he prepares to say goodbye to his failing mens wear store in Medford, Mass., along with his embittered ex-wife and his grasping, heartless daughter.

title: Loving Liberals
description: The trouble with liberals, Robert Kennedy complained in 1964, was that they were in love with death  they romanticized failure, finding greater nobility in losing the whole loaf than in winning half of it. In the years since then, liberals have not only lost a lot of loaves but have acquired a mess of other troubles, among them the difficulty of getting anyone to admit to being a liberal. To wear the label today seems an act of defiance, much as members of the gay rights community have appropriated, from their antagonists, the epithet queer. Liberalism  for decades (centuries, even) the prevailing philosophy in American political life  has become the creed that dare not speak its name, except late at night on MSNBC.

title: Hating Liberals
description: Jonah Goldbergs first book was called Liberal Fascism. It was a screed, of course, but a clever one. He argued that liberals who routinely denounce extreme conservatives as fascists should take a look in their own backyard, and he wasnt fooling around: It is my argument that American liberalism is a totalitarian political religion. Goldberg has read around a bit, and he was able to lace his thesis with embarrassing quotations from progressives past who expressed admiration for Italian Fascism, eugenics and other assorted statist atrocities. But his essential point was a simple one: fascists believe in state control of almost everything, and so do liberals.

title: Respect Your Elders
description: Richard Fortey has spent most of his life looking at fossils, the imprints of the skeletons of the very thoroughly dead. Here he sets out  like a more deeply thoughtful David Attenborough, without the cameras  to describe the distinguished groups of organisms that are still recognizable and thriving after millions and millions of years. The horseshoe crabs, velvet worms and other venerable creatures he encounters are Earths true conservatives. Weve devised a system that works very well for our niche, they would tell us. No big changes necessary. Maybe just a tweak at the molecular level. As Fortey says, to look at a living horseshoe crab is to see a portrait of a distant ancestor repainted by time, but with many of its features still unchanged.

title: In New Jersey, Memorial for Comfort Women Deepens Old Animosity
description: Two delegations of Japanese officials visited Palisades Park, N.J., this month with a request that took local administrators by surprise: The Japanese wanted a small monument removed from a public park.

title: Prairie Dust
description: Near the end of Wichita, Thad Ziolkowskis first novel, the protagonist recalls a line from Rilke: You are not surprised at the force of the storm  you have seen it growing. Its a passing reference; the character, Lewis, neither dwells on the line nor mentions the poem it comes from, Onto a Vast Plain. But Ziolkowski is an accomplished poet, and its not hard to see Rilkes great poem about grief as the secret heart beating through this charming, smart and devastating book.

title: Manageable Discontents
description: As we should all know by now, Jonathan Franzen is a serious writer who plays for the highest literary stakes, who is uncomfortable with American TV consumerism, and whose last two novels, The Corrections and Freedom, have legitimately catapulted him to the front ranks of American fiction. Less known is that he has also published three nonfiction books, How to Be Alone (essays), The Discomfort Zone (a short memoir) and, now, a second essay collection, Farther Away.

title: Americas Team
description: Ben Fountain was the lead subject in a 2008 New Yorker article by Malcolm Gladwell about late bloomers. Whereas the precocious likes of Jonathan Safran Foer had books published practically the moment they got out of college, Fountains first collection of stories, Brief Encounters With Che Guevara, did not appear until he was 48, in 2006. Now, six years later, comes a novel that, appropriately enough, takes a while to bloom.

title: Perilous Crossing
description: Next time you find yourself grousing when the passenger in front reclines his seat a smidge too far, consider the astronomers of the Enlightenment. In 1761 and 1769, dozens and dozens of stargazers traveled thousands of miserable miles to observe a rare and awesome celestial phenomenon. They went by sailing ship and open dinghy, by carriage, by sledge and on foot. They endured discomfort that in our own flabby century would generate years of litigation. And they did it all for science: the men in powdered wigs and knee britches were determined to measure the transit of Venus.

title: Letter to My Father
description: Oblivion is a searing memoir written with love and blood: both family blood, the kind thats thicker than water, and the spilled blood of barbarism and murder. From the first pages we feel the internal necessity driving this story. It is obvious that Hctor Abad had no choice but to tell it  as a personal catharsis, surely, but also as a reckoning with his country, Colombia, and its near-perpetual state of violent strife. I draw out these memories from within, Abad tells us, as one gives birth, as one removes a tumor.

title: Silver Linings
description: On the cover of Inseminating the Elephant, Lucia Perillos 2009 book of poems, minimal brush strokes form what look like four legs and one red trunk with the overlapping color patterns of Czanne and a few dribbled lines of a Pollock. The painter is in fact Jojo the elephant, a sweet-tempered, tuskless bull who had been painting for 11 years at the time of the books publication. He also plays harmonica in the Thai Elephant Orchestra.

title: Up Front
description: When Poets & Writers Magazine interviewed Phillip Lopate a few years ago, it cited his well-deserved reputation as one of the most important essayists of our time. But Lopate himself originally wanted to be a novelist or poet, he told us via e-mail. It took me a while to fall in love with essays, he said. Then I saw that I could combine storytelling and character from fiction, and associative leaps and consciousness tracking from poetry, and put them all together in one flexible form. In my early 30s I stumbled on the great 19th-century English essayist William Hazlitt, who turned me on to Charles Lamb and Michel de Montaigne, and from that point I was hooked.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE CONFLICT: How Modern Motherhood Undermines the Status of Women,  by Elisabeth Badinter. Translated by Adriana Hunter. (Metropolitan/Holt, $25.) A French feminist philosopher argues forcefully that women must avoid excessive child-centeredness.

title: Paperback Row
description: SWIM BACK TO ME,  by Ann Packer. (Vintage Contemporaries, $14.95.) Packers novels, Songs Without Words and The Dive From Clausens Pier, confront loss head-on. In this piercing collection of stories, characters struggle against devastation: the broken promise of a second marriage, the resurfacing of old family wounds, the death of a nearly grown child.

title: Inside the List
description: HORSE RACE: Toni Morrisons novel Home enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 9. The book takes place in the 1950s, which is around the time that Morrison (or Chloe Wofford, as she was still known) started thinking seriously about race relations in this country, according to a recent profile in the British newspaper The Guardian. In the late 40s, as a freshman at Howard University in segregated Washington, D.C., Morrison saw news footage of white mothers in the South trying to overturn a school bus with black children inside. I didnt know if I could turn over a bus full of little white kids, Morrison said. I didnt know if I could feel that . . . fury. And I tried very hard to. This is what I did: I said suppose . . . horses began to speak. And began to demand their rights. Now, Ive ridden horses. Theyre very good workers. Theyre very good racehorses. Suppose they just . . . want more. Suppose they want to go to school! Suppose they want to sit next to me in the theater. I began to feel this sense of  I like you, but . . . ; Youre good, but. . . .  Suppose they want to sleep with my children?! Morrison laughed. I had to go outside the species! But it worked, I could feel it. You know; dont sit next to me.

title: A Close-Up for the Juvenile Hawks
description: The red-tailed hawks of Washington Square Park now resemble the regal hawks they will become.

title: For Facebook, No Division of the Spoils
description: For a moment there a few months ago, it looked as if Facebooks initial public offering might be derailed or at least troubled by angry users demanding a cut of the loot. After all, they literally built the site with their photos and updates. Facebook would be nothing without them. Why shouldnt they get some of the $100 billion the company was going to be worth? Google had much less claim to have been created by its users but it nevertheless sold its shares in a Dutch auction, allowing ordinary geeks to get in on the action. Facebook could at least do as much, it seemed.

title: Since the Opening Curtain, a Question: Is Willy Loman Jewish?
description: A Yiddish play with the title Toyt fun a Salesman opened at the Parkway Theater in Brooklyn early in 1951. As most of the audience recognized from the name alone, the show was a translation of Arthur Millers drama Death of a Salesman. It seemed a mere footnote to the premiere production, which had completed its triumphal run on Broadway several months earlier, having won the Pulitzer Prize.

title: Guatemala-U.S. World Cup Qualifier on PPV Only
description: There may be more live soccer games on television available in the United States than nearly any other place in the world, but the United States World Cup qualifying match at Guatemala on June 12 will not be one of them  unless you are willing to stick a crowbar in your pocket and pull out $29.95 for a pay-per-view only telecast.

title: Business Day Live | May 18, 2012
description: An interview with David Kirkpatrick, author of "The Facebook Effect". | Why initial public offerings catch the public imagination. | James B. Stewart takes a critical eye to the hype.

title: A New View for the Hawk Cam
description: As the baby hawks of Washington Square Park prepare to take flight, weve adjusted the Hawk Cam to maximize the view of the ledge on which theyre nesting. Boo and Scout, who hatched April 9 and 10, no longer resemble the helpless bobble-headed fuzzballs that first appeared on screen. Their white downy coats have been replaced with chocolate brown feathers, giving them more of the likeness of their regal parents.

title: Business Day Live: The Facebook Hype
description: An interview with David Kirkpatrick, author of The Facebook Effect. | Why initial public offerings catch the public imagination. | James B. Stewart takes a critical eye to the hype.

title: Mission Chinese Food Arrives Next Week
description: One of the years most anticipated openings in New York  a branch of Danny Bowiens wildly popular San Francisco restaurant Mission Chinese Food  is now set for Tuesday. And like the West Coast original, the new outpost on the Lower East Side will break a number of rules.

title: Morning Walkabout  5/18: Medellns Revival and a Concert for Delayed Travelers
description: Flight Delay=Free Concert An Air Canada flight bound for Romania was delayed. Luckily, some of the passengers happened to be members of Lemon Bucket Orkestra, who describe themselves as a BalkanKlezmerGypsy-Punk-Super-Party-Band. The 20-minute delay soon became an impromptu concert. (Consumerist)

title: Times Square, 9:30 A.M.
Psychiatry Giant Sorry for Backing Gay Cure
description: PRINCETON, N.J.  The simple fact was that he had done something wrong, and at the end of a long and revolutionary career it didnt matter how often hed been right, how powerful he once was, or what it would mean for his legacy.

title: Acura Recalls 53,000 TL Sedans for Leaking Power-Steering Hoses
description: In a news release sent earlier this week, Honda said its Acura luxury division would recall nearly 53,000 of its 2007-8 TL sports sedans because over time, the power-steering hose may deteriorate, causing it to leak.

title: A Rolling Room With a View
description: Scenes from an RV trip, featuring hot springs, high-fives and a doggie swimsuit competition.

title: Overnight in the Parking Lot
description: During a road trip in the West, a night at Hotel Walmart.

title: Stop. Snap. Move. Repeat for, Oh, 10 or 20 Years.
description: FOR the last seven years, John Frame has been working on a film in his home in Wrightwood, Calif. Its cast includes a cockeyed skeleton, a bespectacled monkey and a horned man sporting a cloak adorned with eyeballs. Mr. Frame made all of the characters himself out of wood and found objects, built the sets, even composed the score. When he discovered that his characters were going wherever they wanted to go, he let them. For the first four years of the project, he worked completely alone, driven by what may have been a muse or daemons, hes unsure which; not even his closest friends and colleagues knew what he was up to.

title: Just Me and My RV
description: I HAVE spent the night in a Walmart parking lot. I have driven through a national park with a trail of cars in my rearview mirror. I have learned how to dispose of my waste through a plastic hose, and I have filled my gas tank more times in one week than I thought was possible.

title: Big Oil, in Big Pictures
description: The Photographers Gallery reopens this weekend in London, completing an 18-month renovation, and its main exhibit is Edward Burtynskys  13-years-and-counting project Oil. More than 30 large-scale prints will be on display.

title: Now Online | T Travel Summer 2012
description: The summer travel issue of T kicks off in Oslo, Scandinavias next capital of cool, with the citys model-movie star couple as our guide. Next stop is the French department of the Gers, where the joie de vivre includes plenty of Armagnac and foie gras. And then we make merry with the fife and drum players of Mississippi hill country as they celebrate one of Americas oldest forms of music. Between stops, we take the pulse in a remarkably resilient Bangkok, check into Londons latest hotels and have a romp through Sicilys hot spots. And for a little reading along the way, Abraham Verghese heads to his ancestral homeland of Kerala, India, and Joyce Maynard says goodbye to Lake Atitln, Guatemala, reminding us of the importance of seeking out ones happy place, even if you have to let it go. See more from the issue >>

title: Found Poem Favorite | Free Flight Into the Wordless
description: This poem, one of 11 winners of our Third Annual Found Poem Contest, comes from Vick, who is 25 years old and lives in Nottingham, England.

title: The Cartoon That Taught Indians The Meaning of Many
description: For the generation that grew up in India in the 1980s, television was synonymous with Doordarshan, the national broadcaster. In the absence of cable television, which came to India a decade later, children grew up with limited television programs. This meant that their appetite for cartoons had to be satiated with the weekend staple of Spider-Man, He-Man and the Masters of the Universe and The Mickey and Donald Show.

title: Kanye West and Marilyn Manson Take Films to Cannes
description: The Cannes Film Festival is typically regarded as a celebration of moviemaking in its purest form and a launching pad for films that might otherwise challenge or baffle mainstream tastes, like V Tumane (In the Fog) or Madagascar 3: Europes Most Wanted. But if you just want to gawk at celebrities and see rock and hip-hop stars out of their musical contexts, Cannes can provide that, too.

title: A Bar Mitzvah, With Autism
description: It should be interesting.

title: Romney Unveils First Ad of General Election
description: Mitt Romney unveiled a series of television ads in English and Spanish on Friday, kicking off his campaigns general election advertising effort with a short and straightforward commercial that lays out what President Romney would accomplish on his first day in office.

title: 10 Views From the Road
description: Take a trip from California to Vermont and explore some of Americas top drives.

title: 10 Correspondents, 10 Drives
description: The bureau chiefs and national correspondents of The New York Times work from offices in 14 cities across the country, and report from all 50 states. The work requires a great deal of driving. The reporters have bureau cars with extra rations packed into the trunks in case they have to stay where they are going for a while. They carry water bottles and spare batteries and extra notebooks and underwear, energy bars and a suit in case theres a chance to meet a governor. They drive and they observe and they eat and they buy and they report. Then they drive again. These are some of their favorite stretches of road.    SAM SIFTON, National Editor

title: Tunes for the Road
description: We asked a group of critics and reporters who cover music for The Times about their go-to tunes for road trips. Here is a selection of their picks.

title: Where Garrison Keillor Gets Carried Away
description: GARRISON KEILLOR, 69, has been roaming the country with his traveling radio show A Prairie Home Companion, for nearly 40 years. Below he answers questions about the America hes known.

title: Evernote Will Go Slow on an I.P.O.
description: TOKYO  Amid the frenzy over Facebooks long-awaited initial public offering, a question has emerged: Which Internet darling might go public next?

title: My Car, My Sanctuary
description: ON Monday, the wind blew so hard that only a fool would have ventured near the rim of the canyon. On Tuesday, a sandstorm colored the sky the yellow of motel linoleum and left a film of grit in your mouth. By Wednesday, I was properly stir crazy, and so when I stepped out into a cold Arizona morning of cerulean skies and the medicinal smell of sage, I got into my car and, for no particular reason, decided to hit the road.

title: When Your Guru Calls Shotgun
description: BY the time we reached the first rest stop, a Burger King in Cle Elum, in central Washington State, I was suffering two anxieties: That I would kill the guru, and that if I didnt, he would ignore me for the next 3,000 miles.

title: Letters to the Travel Editor
description: To the Editor: Regarding Easy China, Through Three Doors (May 6): China is well worth the visit, but take it from a nearly six-year resident  personal habits evolve more slowly than living standards, and you should be ready for some boorish, self-centered behavior. Hawking and spitting, line-breaking, pushing, bewildering driving, cellphone screaming, unsanitary food preparation, shouting in stores, poor service, shameless staring, smoking in nonsmoking zones (including elevators), yelling and slamming doors in hotel hallways late into the night  these are day-to-day pitfalls on the mainland, including Shanghai and Beijing. Hong Kong feels more refined but not as authentic  call it China Lite. Best advice: maintain your sense of humor and awareness of the countrys dense population and difficult history and get ready for a fascinating trip.

title: Editors Letter
description: In 2008, this paper published a story about Joyce Maynards house on a lake in Guatemala. It was an escape from all that story, a celebration of the ability to start ones life anew in midlife with limited means but abundant vigor. Friends of mine, trapped in their aging urban routines, still refer to the story, four years on, when fantasizing about the lives not led. It was that intoxicating.

title: In the Undoing of a C.E.O., a Puzzle
description: When the activist shareholder Daniel Loeb confronted Yahoos directors on May 3 with the possibility that Yahoos recently hired chief executive, Scott Thompson, might have falsified his rsum by claiming to have a computer science degree, their initial reaction was disbelief. Scott is a forthright, no-nonsense, straightforward personality and a likable guy, one director said.

title: At 71, an Olympian Again
description: The Japanese equestrian Hiroshi Hoketsu, who is 71, will likely be the oldest Olympian competing in the London Games this summer and is one of the oldest Olympians ever to compete. He was the oldest athlete in the 2008 Beijing Games and is currently training in Germany in dressage. He was interviewed by phone.

title: Book Review Podcast
description: This week, Joe Klein talks about Jonah Goldbergs The Tyranny of Clichs; Jeff Shesol discusses Eric Altermans history of liberalism from the New Deal to the present; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

title: New Classroom Science Standards Up for Review
description: The first substantial update to national science teaching standards in roughly 15 years  and the first including the science of human-driven climate change  is open for public comment through this month. Heres a short video description:

title: U.N. Nuclear Chief Will Go to Iran, Elevating Talks
description: The United Nations nuclear monitoring agency said on Friday that its leader would travel to Iran on Sunday for a meeting with the countrys top nuclear negotiator. The unexpected development signaled that both sides had stepped up both the urgency of resolving their dispute and the seniority of the officials doing the negotiating.

title: Facebook Engineers Hack the Nasdaq Button
description: David Garcia, a senior software engineer at Facebook, says a small group of Facebook engineers hacked into the Nasdaq button that Mark Zuckerberg pressed to begin trading in the stock so that it would automatically update Mr. Zuckerbergs Facebook status when he pushed it. In a guest blog post on TechCrunch, Mr. Garcia explains how it happened.

title: Stream of Thoughts
description: Facebook is getting the headlines, but dont forget about that other wildly popular social network, Twitter. Follow what Twitter users are saying about Facebooks initial public offering.

title: A Half-Century-Old Road to Today
description: IF there is such a thing as a visionary time capsule, the newly released boxed set of Route 66 is it. Watch these discs (from Shout! Factory) and you are transported back to a version of the United States that was still basking in postwar success, a country rich in blue-collar jobs and industrial production and somewhat oblivious to its problems. But while enjoying that return to America as it was, you may also be struck by how often this half-century-old black-and-white television series tackled issues that seem very 21st century.

title: A Man Who Creates Coincidences
description: ON a recent Saturday afternoon in New York, Diplo, the Los Angeles D.J. and producer, was in a bar on the top floor of the Standard hotel, reminiscing about being arrested. He had been invited to New York last year to work with Beyonc. The first day had gone well.

title: Idealistic Lawmen Taking Crime Very Personally
description: The Big Heat

title: Songs From the Border and the Clouds
description: The Royalty

title: For Cal Softball, Another Chance at a Title
description: Last season, the stars aligned for the Arizona State softball team. The Sun Devils began the year ranked No. 10 in the nation, steadily climbed to the No. 1 spot, and defeated Florida to win the 2011 Womens College World Series.

title: Guest Post | Teenager Writes About Crushing Weight of College Debt
description: This week, The Times is publishing a series on student debt that includes articles, video and interactive graphics, as well as an invitation to write in to tell about how student debt has affected your life. On Tuesday, we published a lesson plan full of ideas for using the series in the classroom.

title: Paying for Robo-Calls
description: Say you buy a new cell phone, and immediately start getting robo-calls from a debt collector. Youre not the intended recipient of the callstheyre for the deadbeat who owned the number before youbut several times a day a pre-recorded message insists you pay off a credit card loan, or an electric bill.

title: Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau, Lyrical and Powerful Baritone, Dies at 86
description: Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau, the German baritone whose beautiful voice and mastery of technique made him the 20th centurys pre-eminent interpreter of art songs, died on Friday at his home in Bavaria. He was 86.

title: Facebook Closes at $38.23, Nearly Flat on Day
description: 4:16 p.m. | Updated

title: On Our Radar: Tackling the Tsunami Debris
description: Senators from Western states grill a NOAA official about his agencys plans to deal with debris from Japans 2011 tsunami that is washing up in the United States. He replies that the agency lacks the funds for a cleanup and that the work will probably fall to individual states. [ABC News]

title: Weekend Fare
description: Friday is the last day of City Harvests Skip Lunch Fight Hunger campaign, which raises money to feed hungry children and their families. Participants can make donations online.

title: Lady Gaga Shows Prompt Protest in Philippines
description: Scores of Christian youths protested against Lady Gaga in Manila on Friday, calling for her concerts there to be canceled because they object to her sexually charged lyrics and skimpy costumes, The Associated Press reported.

title: In Prague, a Beer Festival Branches Out
description: Since its founding in 2008, the Czech Beer Festival has become an instant classic, the largest beer event in a country that drinks more beer per capita than anywhere else. But for this years celebration, taking place through June 2, visitors can expect several changes.

title: Off the Charts: The Older the Worker, the Better
description: Employment for traditional working-age Americans remains well below where it was at the end of 2006, before the economy began to weaken. But the proportion of older Americans with jobs has risen, as baby boomers put off retirement or return to the work force.

title: The Beast in the Big Easy
description: After Flag Officer David Farragut captured New Orleans in April 1862, Maj. Gen. Benjamin F. Butler occupied the city at the head of some 10,000 Union soldiers. That Butler should be in charge of the Union occupation of the Souths largest city is surprising: a former member of the Massachusetts State Senate, he had been chosen as a delegate to the 1860 Democratic National Convention, where he voted 57 times to nominate then-Senator Jefferson Davis for president, on the belief that only a Southern moderate could keep the party from splitting.

title: Van Halen Postpones Dozens of Tour Dates
description: It appears that all is not right inside the classic rock band Van Halen. The veteran rockers announced late Thursday that they were postponing more than 30 dates on their current tour to promote their new album, A Different Kind of Truth, The Associated Press and CNN reported.

title: Spying Balloons as Artistic Muse
description: Some stories strike a chord with readers. And these days it is easy to share your thoughts on most of the things we publish here on The New York Times Web site. Most of that feedback comes in the form of comments  the letters to the editor of the modern era. But one story out of Afghanistan published last week inspired a different kind of tribute. It started with a story by Graham Bowley, who wrote about spy dirigibles, white surveillance balloons, called aerostats by the military, which have become constant features in the skies over Kabul and Kandahar, and anywhere else American troops are concentrated or interested in. Mr. Bowley writes:

title: Image of the Day: May 18
Video: This Weeks Movies, May 18
description: In todays edition of This Weeks Movies, The Times critics look at a big-budget blockbuster, a low-budget indie and a star-driven comedy. Neil Genzlinger reviews Battleship, the action film loosely based on the board game. And A. O. Scott looks at both The Color Wheel, a black-and-white road movie, and What to Expect When Youre Expecting, an ensemble comedy based on Heidi Murkoffs best-selling book. Our critics full reviews of the films can be found here.

title: Should You Talk Puberty With a Stepdaughter?
description: How, D. asks, should I talk with my almost 10-year-old stepdaughter about puberty?

title: Navigating New Trenches After a Breakup
description: SOME years ago, when I was living in Britain, I received an e-mail from a college friend who had recently announced her first pregnancy. We have become good friends with a black/white couple, she wrote. They have a precious baby boy  you and Dan are going to have the cutest kids!

title: The Sweet Spot | Future of Television
description: David Carr and A. O. Scott wonder whether TV is still TV  and where it is going.

title: What Will President Obama Say?
description: Mitt Romney is decidedly unpopular. Polling by the Times and CBS News shows his approval rating languishing at around 30 percent. Other polls show voters think President Obama is more likely to have good ideas about improving the economy than Mr. Romney.

title: Soba With Green Garlic, Spinach, Edamame and Crispy Tofu
description: Green garlic and luscious spinach are both in abundance in the markets right now. If you cant find soba (buckwheat noodles), you can serve the stir-fry with brown rice or other grains.

title: Naming Her World, Part by Part
description: As a child growing up in a tiny, German-speaking village in Romania, on the edge of Transylvania, Herta Mller was assigned chores that included herding cows. Out in the pastures with little to do, she amused herself by giving names and personalities to the flowers she collected and the clouds that drifted by, or imagined a future as a seamstress, like her aunt, or perhaps as a hairdresser.

title: Northwestern Takes Game Directly to Eastern Recruits
description: The Northwestern womens lacrosse team traveled to Stony Brook, N.Y., last spring and won its sixth national title in seven years. Even though the Wildcats were more than 800 miles from their campus in Evanston, Ill., the stands were filled with young girls sporting their teams colors.

title: Trial Vaccine Made Some More Vulnerable to H.I.V., Study Confirms
description: A follow-up study on an AIDS vaccine trial that had to be stopped early has confirmed the worst fears of researchers: The vaccine made it more likely, not less, that some men would become infected with H.I.V.

title: Friday Flashback: Sometimes Being First Doesnt Mean Victory
description: The Swedish modern pentathlete Hans-Gunnar Liljenwall was once a fixture on the international scene. He competed in three Olympics1964, 1968 and 1972in the team and individual divisions. He was a middle-of-the-pack finisher in the individual event, but was a good contributor to the Swedish team effort.

title: During Mille Miglia, a Rare Sighting of the Fiat Scion
description: Sansepolcro, Italy, received a distinguished visitor Friday.

title: Sentiment Against Foreigners Flares in China
description: Last Updated | Monday, 7:45 a.m. Two of Chinas largest Internet companies are urging users to help crack down on misbehaving foreigners, the state-run Peoples Daily reported on Friday, after a high-profile case of sexual assault by a British man in Beijing last week and amid a push by the authorities to rein in foreigners illegally in the country.

title: Look of The Moment | Natalia Vodianova
description: The Look: Dolled up. A pleated mini takes a prim spin with the addition of a crocheted pilgrim collar.

title: Some European Companies Try Bonds to Raise Cash
description: Among the midsize, family-owned companies that power the German economy, it has long been an article of faith: credit comes from the friendly local banker, not from cold and distant capital markets.

title: Mexico Holds 4 High-Ranking Army Officers

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: The Relationship of an Artist and an Original Beatle
description: New to our graphic books hardcover best-seller list this week, at No. 7, is Babys In Black, which chronicles the relationship between the artist Astrid Kirchherr and Stuart Sutcliffe, the original bass player of The Beatles, who met in Hamburg during the earliest days of the band. The graphic novel, by the cartoonist Arne Bellstorf, is already a success in Germany, and does a wonderful job of capturing the small moments of everyday life. It feels authentic, no doubt thanks to the extensive input from Ms. Kirchherr. The illustrations, in black and white with sketchy gray tones, are, for the most part, warm and inviting. Babys In Black has a couple of drawbacks: all of Mr. Bellstorfs faces have small swirls of gray on their cheeks. Its easy enough to get used to, I suppose, but this graphic tic often makes the characters look dirty (is that a smudge?) or surprised (are they blushing?). For those who know their Beatles history, the ending will be a foregone conclusion, but the story was new to me and I found the handling of Mr. Sutcliffes death quite abrupt.

In numerous appearances over the years  most recently at the Barnard graduation  he has made reference to how women are smarter than men. Its all so tired, the kind of fake praise showered upon those one views as easy to impress. As I listen, I am always bracing for the old go-to clich: Behind every great man is a great woman.

title: Making Schools Work
description: AMID the ceaseless and cacophonous debates about how to close the achievement gap, weve turned away from one tool that has been shown to work: school desegregation. That strategy, ushered in by the landmark 1954 Supreme Court decision in Brown v. Board of Education, has been unceremoniously ushered out, an artifact in the museum of failed social experiments. The Supreme Courts ruling that racially segregated schools were inherently unequal shook up the nation like no other decision of the 20th century. Civil rights advocates, who for years had been patiently laying the constitutional groundwork, cheered to the rafters, while segregationists mourned Black Monday and vowed massive resistance. But as the anniversary was observed this past week on May 17, it was hard not to notice that desegregation is effectively dead. In fact, we have been giving up on desegregation for a long time. In 1974, the Supreme Court rejected a metropolitan integration plan, leaving the increasingly black cities to fend for themselves.

He told the newspaper The Hill that he had been talking with Senator Sheldon Whitehouse, Democrat of Rhode Island, the sponsor of a much-needed bill requiring timely public disclosure of donors writing checks of $10,000 and more for election ads, plus stand-by-your-ad identifications from the five biggest donors.

title: Will Iran Take the Next Step?

For years, it was split on how much pressure to apply, and Tehran deftly exploited that division. Since President Obama took office, the major powers have imposed increasingly strong sanctions aimed at Irans banks and oil trade. It is crucial to maintain that cohesion as a second round of negotiations opens this week in Baghdad.

The War of 1812, whose end inspired our national anthem, marks its bicentennial this summer, an occasion that will be celebrated in military re-enactments, symphony concerts and historic tours in Ontario, Ohio, Maryland and other sites where battles were fought.

description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The Pakistani government blocked access to the social networking service Twitter for much of Sunday, after publicly holding Twitter responsible for promoting what it described as a blasphemous cartoon contest taking place on Facebook, officials said.

description: LONDON  Abdel Basset Ali al-Megrahi, the only man ever convicted of the 1988 Lockerbie bombing, has died in Libya almost three years after he was released from jail in Scotland on the compassionate grounds that he had only three months to live.

description: I am flooded daily with pitches from Silicon Valley start-ups that boast they are the next big thing. The problem is, that next big thing is often an inconsequential variation on a previous big thing.

title: Romney Says Obama Policies Undermine NATO Alliance
description: In Chicago Tribune op-ed on Sunday, Mitt Romney accused President Obama of undermining NATO. At the same time that President Obama has been weakening our military, he has sent the message  intentionally or not  that the worth of NATO has diminished in Americas eyes, Mr. Romney wrote. The op-ed was published as Mr. Obama and other world leaders are gathering in Chicago Sunday and Monday for a NATO summit meeting.

title: Cannes Film Festival: Taboos and Tourism
description: CANNES, France  The Austrian director Ulrich Seidl makes a habit of blurring boundaries: his work encompasses fiction (Dog Days) and nonfiction (Animal Love), and he typically works with nonprofessional actors using documentary-like settings and improvisatory techniques. But there is little middle ground when it comes to the reception of his films. Mr. Seidl tends to be condemned as a misanthrope who goes to unseemly lengths to prove the depths of human misery or hailed as a maestro of discomfort whose taste for confrontation masks a seriousness of purpose and a measure of compassion.

title: Battleship Pulls Up Lame at Box Office
description: LOS ANGELES Rotten buzz and superheroic competition sunk Universals Battleship over the weekend. Costing over $300 million to make and market, Peter Bergs Battleship managed to sell about $25.4 million in tickets in its first weekend in North American theaters  a second-place finish behind Marvels The Avengers (Disney), which took in an estimated $55 million for a three-week domestic total of $457 million. Overseas, Battleship, inspired by the Hasbro board game, has taken in about $227 million since opening last month, a respectable total but not enough to make the expensive film profitable without better support from the United States, analysts say.

title: In Rutgers Spying Case, Voices for Gay Rights Urge Leniency
description: In the two months since he was found guilty of using a webcam to spy on his roommate, Dharun Ravi has gone from being a symbol of antigay bias to being something of a folk hero, with rallies of his supporters urging the court to free Dharun.

title: Selections by the French, From Tortured to Carefree
description: The French composer Ernest Chausson was puzzled by his bouts of depression, which occurred despite a seemingly charmed life that included a contented marriage, children, good health and an inherited wealth that allowed him to compose at leisure. But while he didnt suffer the financial woes and chaos that often plague artistic careers, what he described as his wretched, uneasy and violent brain led him to write melancholy, tortured music.

title: Digging Deeply Into Beethoven in Head and Heart
description: Recording the 32 Beethoven piano sonatas is an unusual way for a young artist to make a debut on a major record label, but EMI Classics is taking a chance with the distinctive 24-year-old Korean H J Lim. Ms. Lim, who performed the complete cycle in Paris over eight consecutive days in 2010, offered two sonatas  No. 29 in B flat (Op. 106, Hammerklavier) and No. 30 in E (Op. 109)  in her American debut on Thursday evening, for a small audience at Le Poisson Rouge.

title: When Pain From the Past Is a Script for the Present

Mr. Ferver has the stage to himself for all of this 40-minute production. Mr. Swanson designed the remarkable set, a construction of mirrors and thin wooden pillars that stands in for multiple places but most of all for a dance studio, a home for Mr. Fervers imaginings.

title: Letting Jazz Have a Turn Interpreting the Poets
description: Jazz at Lincoln Center did something really self-assured last week. It presented two major large-ensemble pieces by members of its orchestra, neither very well known as composers, for a three-night run at the Rose Theater: Gods Trombones, by the trombonist Chris Crenshaw, and Inferno, by the saxophonist Sherman Irby.

title: DOh!
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE We havent seen Ian Livengood since February (Across Lite, Solution, blog), but I, for one, welcome him back. I like Mr. Livengoods puzzles, and todays offering is oh-so-smooth. Just the thing for a Monday.

title: Would Departed Fido Want to Leash Up Again? Ask Him

Thousands of people arrived garlanded and festooned with plastic blossoms to match the name of the new electronic dance music festival in town, Electric Daisy Carnival New York. Well, not quite in town; it took place Friday through Sunday at MetLife Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J.

title: At Cannes, Love Beset by Age and by Faith
description: CANNES, France  By Sunday morning the 65th Cannes Film Festival had its first masterwork and an overwhelming critical favorite in Michael Hanekes Amour. A tender, wrenching, impeccably directed story of love and death, the French-language film stars Emmanuelle Riva and Jean-Louis Trintignant as a Parisian couple in their 80s  named Georges and Anne, as are most of Mr. Hanekes middle-class couples  struggling with an increasingly debilitating illness and the specter of what comes next. One day over breakfast she suffers a frightening episode that leaves her briefly locked in a mute, seemingly unaware blankness. Shes there, but not, and then just as suddenly she returns.

title: Protesters and Police Clash at NATO Meeting; 2 Held on Terrorism Charges
description: CHICAGO  Protesters at the NATO summit meeting clashed with the Chicago police late Sunday as officers tried to disperse thousands of people who had gathered several blocks from the site of the meeting and refused demands to leave.

title: The Mechanics of Loving and Grieving
description: Peter Carey has said that he worked backward to create his latest novel, The Chemistry of Tears. He assembled an inventory of seemingly unrelated elements that intrigued him, then found ways of stitching them together. On top of it all, he added an eerie sensuality: I would rather scrub your bones and place them in the open air, scrub your sternum, labor at your spine, scrub and scrub, with love, each vertebra, as particular as a nose, and lay you in the grass amongst the bluebells. That heady blend of sex and death is almost enough to keep the seams from showing.

title: Trouble in Rhode Island for Boston Baseball Hero Trying Out a New Game

Curt Schilling is a hero to Boston Red Sox fans who remember him pitching valiantly against the Yankees in the 2004 American League Championship Series with an injured ankle and a bloody sock. But a strange chain of events last week left some Rhode Islanders feeling differently.

title: Only Connect | Doug Aitkens Song1
description: The artist Doug Aitken likes to bring people together. His 2006 book Broken Screen featured conversations with 26 artists, from Robert Altman to Rem Koolhaas. One of his favorite mediums is the happening, a sort of catchall for dynamic events he produces that can entail anything from live musical performances to panel discussions to line dancing. And yet in his video work, he tends toward lonely, restless souls like the insomniac city dwellers in the 2007 video Sleepwalkers (see trailer, here) or the any of the solitary animals that found themselves cooped up and climbing the walls in a remote desert motel in his 2008 piece Migration (empire). Song1, which finished a two-month run at the Hirshhorn Museum yesterday, is no exception. Only in this piece, the individual characters find a connection in the notes and lyrics of the doo-wop ballad I Only Have Eyes for You, which Aitken calls the perfect pop song. The gritty romanticism of the piece suggests searching or loneliness, but the song binds the characters together, says Kerry Brougher, the Hirshhorns deputy director and chief curator. The video, which was projected onto the windowless exterior of the Gordon Bunshaft-designed building from dusk until midnight, had a similar effect on the local community. Most nights the National Mall is a pretty desolate place after the sun goes down. It turned the museum inside out, Brougher says of Song1, noting that some nights there would be as many as 3,000 people camped out on the museum grounds, all watching together in quiet isolation.

It said 29 fishermen had been detained, but a reporter from China National Radio said Zhang Dechang, the owner of one of the boats, said the number was 28. On Sunday, the North Korean Foreign Ministry announced that all the fishermen would be freed. Chinese news media reported last week that the gunmen had initially demanded a ransom of $189,000 and then lowered it to $142,000. It is unclear if any money was paid. China is North Koreas closest political ally.

title: The Syria Paradox
description: It took a month of protests to depose the president of Tunisia and 18 days to remove Hosni Mubarak from power in Egypt. Libya took longer. Rebels there spent more than eight bloody months fighting Muammar el-Qaddafi before defeating him. But Syria  where protests began at roughly the same time as in Libya  remains in a vicious civil war, and the fighting seems very far from over. One reason for this is simple: Syrias economy was designed to all but prevent a broad coalition from forming against Bashar al-Assads regime. This is, of course, awful news for most Syrians. But it also calls into question some Things We Thought We Knew About Revolutions  the most important being that countries with diverse economies and a growing middle class are supposed to be better at overthrowing despotic rulers than petrocracies like Libya or Iraq.

God Forgotten Face is the result of the two years Maddock spent taking pictures in the English coastal town of Plymouth, where he has family ties. He devoted the three years before that to documenting the police raids in Hackney, East London, where he used to live. That work culminated in Maddocks first book,Our Kids Are Going to Hell.

description: ATHENS  The Greek government will pump 18 billion euros (about $23 billion) into the countrys four largest commercial banks this week to help them guard against losses from a worsening economy, bankers in Athens said on Tuesday, a step that will improve the banks ability to raise money but will still leave them unable to lend money normally.

title: Merkel Defensive Amid Fresh Calls for Bonds
description: BERLIN  The pressure for Germany to reverse its defiant course on issuing euro bonds continued to grow on Tuesday, one day before a dinner meeting of European leaders. But German officials remained adamant that there was no way they would bend on collective debt, even if the new French president, as expected, makes it a dining-room topic.

title: More L.I.R.R. Retirees Charged in Disability Fraud
description: Ten retirees from the Long Island Rail Road were charged on Tuesday with filing fraudulent disability claims to increase their pension payouts in what prosecutors called a massive fraud scheme.

title: Satellite Images Show More Work at North Korean Nuclear Site
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea warned on Tuesday that it would have to take countermeasures if the United States insisted on sanctions, while the latest satellite imagery of the countrys nuclear test site suggested heightened preparations for a possible underground nuclear test.

title: Sino-Forest and Executives Charged With Fraud in Canada
description: OTTAWA  The Ontario Securities Commission on Tuesday filed charges against the Sino-Forest Corporation, a Chinese company that once traded in Toronto, and five of its former executives, saying the company had overstated its timber resources and misled investigators.

title: Gaining Entry to That Stomping Ground
description: OFTEN the shifts in the city are talked about in terms of place. This store used to be that store, which used to be that restaurant, which was once this sweatshop: oh, how time has passed, and oh, how meaning is wrung from the vagaries of real estate.

title: SAP Agrees to Acquire Ariba for $4.5 Billion
description: SAP, the German business software giant, has agreed to buy Ariba, a provider of cloud computing services, for $4.5 billion.

title: Ross for Summer, and All Year Long
description: With the Memorial Day weekend approaching, along with a deep psychological exhalation that leaves us in a more casual state of mind, my column focuses on some easygoing drinking suggestions for the warmer weather.

title: Freaky Friday, N.B.A. Style: When the Clippers Were the Celtics
description: Cheer up, Clippers fans! Its no disgrace to lose to the Spurs. You have a promising future with Chris Paul and Blake Griffin anchoring the team.

title: Cuomo Picks 2 to Lead New York Democratic Party
description: ALBANY  Solidifying his control over New York Democratic politics, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said Tuesday that he would seek to install a mayor from upstate and an assemblyman from New York City as the state partys new leaders.

title: Super PACs Release Dueling Ads
description: A former Obama aide on Tuesday criticized a new ad by a Republican super PAC for featuring a fictional family suffering from President Obamas economic policies.

title: As U.S. Retailers Retreat, a Japanese Chain Sees an Opening
description: Many American retailers are cutting back at shopping malls. Chains like Gap Inc., Abercrombie & Fitch, Coldwater Creek and Talbots say they have too many stores at too many malls. Hundreds of stores are on the chopping block.

title: Philippines Chief Justice Denies Corruption Charges
description: MANILA  At times weeping on the stand, the chief justice of the Philippines, Renato C. Corona, testified on Tuesday for the first time in his impeachment trial in the Philippine Senate. He denied the corruption charges against him, challenged his accusers to disclose their own finances and then tried to walk out of the proceedings.

title: Venture Capital Partner Claims Sexual Harassment
description: 9:35 p.m. | Updated  A partner at Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, the blue-chip Silicon Valley venture capital firm that was an early investor in Google and Amazon, is suing the firm, claiming that she faced sexual harassment and discrimination there over a six-year period.

title: The Growing Fed
description: One part of the economy thats growing rapidly is the Federal Reserve.

title: Follow a Hungry Chef and See Where It Takes You
description: DANIEL BOULUD is inevitably drawn to an intense but basic roast chicken in the West Village. Missy Robbins craves East Village ramen. And for Hugue Dufour, only those pristine oysters in Grand Central Terminal will do.

title: Ron Darling Reflects on the End of His Playing Career
description: I think it was denial, the former Mets pitcher Ron Darling tells Rob Trucks at Deadspin about his surprise at being released by the Oakland As in the summer of 1995 (on his birthday, no less). I thought that my position on the ballclub was secure enough, despite a bad year. Who would release someone in August? I mean, hows that going to make a difference? Not surprisinglybecause its Darlingits a thoughtful recollection. You can read the full storypart of the sites Tell Me When Its Over serieshere.

title: Sweets With a Side of Savory
description: A food-focused book club lighted the oven for Erin Patinkin and Agatha Kulaga. Ms. Patinkin, who was working for a nonprofit, and Ms. Kulaga, a psychiatry researcher, met through the club and discovered they shared entrepreneurial ambitions. So they started Ovenly, a wholesale bakery in Greenpoint, Brooklyn; building on its success over the last two years, they have added a retail store. It opens Friday, and though they turn out red velvet cakes, chocolate chip cookies (bottom photo) and carrot spice cupcakes, most of their specialties offer uncommon flavors. Black olive shortbread, blue cheese-pecan scones, coconut date pistachio coffee cake (top), and a jelly doughnut muffin are all buttery and intriguingly savory-sweet, thanks to a good pinch of salt. Even the chocolate pudding frosting on the blackout cake is salted. The shop has a few seats for those wishing to indulge on the spot, with Stumptown coffee.

title: Britain Charts Way to Wider Nuclear Investment
description: LONDON  Britain announced plans Tuesday to finance a new generation of nuclear power plants and renewable energy facilities in a move that illustrates divergent energy policies within the European Union as it grapples with the challenge of reconciling economic and environmental objectives.

title: Medical Costs Contribute to Credit Card Debt
description: Medical bills are a leading contributor to credit card debt, a new survey finds.

title: The Romney Campaign Joins the Birther Brigade
description: Whenever the birther movement rears its head, sensible people argue that the press should just ignore it, since its so far out on the lunacy spectrum.

title: Memories of Beer and a Taste
description: Having trouble keeping track of all the craft breweries in and around the city? The current surge in suds is nothing if you glance back in time. The New-York Historical Society points out that by 1898, when the five boroughs were consolidated, there were more than 100 breweries in New York, with clusters on the Upper East Side of Manhattan and in Bushwick and Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Prohibition finished off most of them. But some brands, like Schaefer, Ruppert and Rheingold, linger in memory. And on Friday, the museum will open an exhibition on beer in New York that includes hundreds of artifacts like old mugs, posters and trays. One end of the ground-floor gallery will feature a beer hall, with tables, stools and a bar where more than 50 visitors at a time can buy a draft or bottled beer and a pretzel from Sigmunds. Talks and weekly tastings from various breweries will be offered throughout the summer.

title: Recipes and Lists at Your Fingertips
description: MORE than a decade ago, I was confronted with a crisis: planning a weeks worth of menus and writing out the accompanying shopping list were gobbling up a humongous slice of my precious weekend. It stressed me out and caused a bit of marital strife. How, my new husband would ask, could it take me that long to make a list?

title: A Brawny Line of Tools Adds Precision to Grilling
description: If you need proof that grilling is a guy thing, just wrap your fist around the wooden handles of the substantial new spatulas and turners in the Tim Love Collection at Sur La Table. Mr. Love, a chef in Fort Worth (and briefly in New York several years ago) has put his name on a hefty spatula with a 4-by-6-inch surface that will not be daunted by a whole flank steak, and a big, sturdy but gracefully curved slotted fish turner, able to lift a striped bass fillet. Both are stainless steel with walnut handles and a leather strap, and made in the United States by Lamson & Goodnow. Finely finished, they are beveled to a knife-sharp edge, the better to release your meat or fish cleanly from the grill, or even to make a test cut for doneness.

title: Pictures of the Day: Iraq and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Iraq, Pakistan, India and Florida.

title: Education Cuts Met With Strike in Spain
description: MADRID  It was no mistake that university campuses proliferated during Spains decade-long, construction-led boom years. Education and health care have long been two of the most prized  and seemingly sacred  parts of the European social model favored by Spain. Even as the economic crisis has spread through Europe, Spaniards had shielded social spending in those areas from the consequences.

title: U.S. Mens Eight Qualifies on Final Chance
description: The United States mens eight pulled out a victory Tuesday just when it needed one most  on the final day of Olympic qualifying for the eight, in the final race that would give one final boat a berth at the London Games.

title: Greek Businesses Fear Possible Return to Drachma
description: ATHENS  For the last couple of weeks, the phone at Tasos Ioannidiss five-star hotel on the breezy island of Mykonos has been ringing steadily, but not with the types of inquiries he wants to field.

title: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston Gets Major Gift of Photographs and Other Works
description: The Museum of Fine Arts, Boston has received a bonanza from one of its longtime trustees, according to a report in The Boston Globe.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Kickstarter Report and a Singing App
description: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Tuesday. See more here.

title: L.B.J. Was Wrong
description: More interesting stuff from the annual scientific meeting of the American Geriatrics Society, which I attended in Seattle this month:

title: A Genetic Cure for Tomato Rot
description: Gardeners are all too familiar with the experience. You plant a handful of shriveled sand-colored tomato seeds, urge them out of the ground with diligent tending, and then smile with self-satisfaction as the first plump fruits ripen, flush on their furry stalks.

title: At $25 Million, a Record Sale in Miami Beach
description: A MEMBER of the family that controls the German shoe company Birkenstock has sold a triplex penthouse in the South Beach section of Miami Beach for $25 million, a record price for a Miami-area apartment, eclipsing the previous record of $21.5 million reached five months before.

title: Big Willie Robinson, Who Sought to Bridge Social Divides at the Dragstrip, Dies at Age 70
description: Andrew Robinson, known as Big Willie Robinson to a vibrant automotive subculture that melded illegal street racing and organized drags, died Saturday at age 70. The National and International Brotherhood of Street Racers, an organization founded by Mr. Robinson and his late wife, Tomiko, said Mr. Robinson had been ill in recent months but did not disclose the nature of the illness.

title: A Hard Drive for High Security
description: When it comes to video surveillance, its either feast or famine. Most professional solutions depend on hard drive recorders that cost in the thousands of dollars or dinky little cameras with barely enough storage to keep an eye on a bodega for an hour.

title: Three Dishes at Le Bernardin
description: I was just talking to a colleague at The Times who ate at Le Bernardin a few weeks ago. We started describing dishes wed both eaten, and each of us found that we could recall the smallest details of flavor and plating. Eric Riperts cuisine is like that: its so focused, and so devoid of extraneous elements, that to recall one aspect of a dish is to call up the whole thing. On Tuesday, before my review went up online, I spoke with Mr. Ripert on the phone, and asked him to tell me what was going on in three dishes that I thought were characteristic of the restaurants approach.

title: Invitation to a Dialogue: The Facebook Offering
description: To the Editor:

title: CNNs Shrinking Prime-Time Audience
description: CNN has not reacted much to bad ratings before, so another week of distressed numbers may not faze its management.

title: Met Reverses Itself on Reviews Ban by Opera News
description: The Metropolitan Opera on Tuesday backed away from its decision to bar reviews of its productions in Opera News, its affiliated magazine and the leading opera publication in the country.

description: Just a few questions during a recent conference call cost the nutritional supplements company Herbalife more than $1 billion in stock market value.

Capturing the Essence of Cage, if Not With Jackhammers
description: Wherever we are, what we hear is mostly noise, the composer John Cage said in a 1937 lecture later published as The Future of Music: Credo. Noise, Cage contended, constituted a disturbance only when you try to ignore it: When we listen to it, we find it fascinating.

title: Whats Worse Than Being a Single Mother?
description: I never thought I would be a single mother. When I got pregnant at 19, my boyfriend and I asked each other: How are we going to tell our parents? What about money? Where will we live? We knew raising the baby would be hard, but I thought we wanted the same things: marriage, good jobs, a nice family.

title: The Euro Zone Crisis: A Primer
description: FRANKFURT  With the daily drumbeat of alarming news from the euro zone, its often hard to hear above the din. Heres a quick chance to catch up before the shouting starts again.

title: Whisper and Repeat. Meditate a Little, Then Just Whisper and Repeat.
description: Some music can instantly seduce with eclectic elements, whether Bachs counterpoint and Schuberts melodies or Steve Reichs hypnotic energy and Georg Friedrich Haass soundscapes. Then there are works, including pieces by Morton Feldman, that often require substantial effort from listeners. Indeed, those who have mastered the art of lengthy meditation may be best equipped to concentrate on his glacially slow, highly repetitive sounds.

title: Moraya & Chris
description: Moraya and Chris tell the story of how they met in college and realized after graduation that a long distance relationship wasn't for them. They decided to get married instead.

title: Peekaboo With a Curtain and Cascading Hair
description: The title of Luciana Achugars latest work, which just finished a two-week run at the Abrons Arts Center, strings many words into one: FEELingpleasuresatisfactioncelebrationholyFORM. A much shorter one-word title would have served, but its been used before: Hair.

title: Dangerous and Funny: Shes Still a Flapper
description: The flapper  the tough-talking party girl with bobbed hair, a spangled headband and a shocking disdain for propriety  may be an archetype associated with the 1920s. But since her ascendance, she has never really disappeared. Wearing different outfits, the British bird of the 1960s and the breakdancing b-girl of the 1980s are among countless offshoots. Lets not forget that defiant pop shape-shifter Madonna, a flapper to her bones, no matter what she wears.

title: Revenge in a Bowl, Served Cold
description: The Shanghai Kunqu Opera made its biggest news in New York when it failed to show up. This is the company that was to have presented Chen Shi-Zhengs 19-hour production of The Peony Pavilion, the Chinese opera written by Tang Xianzu in 1598, at the Lincoln Center Festival in 1998, but Shanghai municipal authorities blocked the troupes departure for political reasons. When the production did appear, in 1999, with performers gathered from around China, only the star, Qian Yi, and the flutist and orchestra leader, Zhou Ming, remained from the original troupe.

title: Time Travel via Baton, With Nary a Pit Stop
description: The English conductor Jonathan Nott is becoming less of a stranger to New York audiences, but not quickly enough. He has visited most years since 2005, usually with the Bamberg Symphony, though he has also made a strong impression conducting the Ensemble Intercontemporain and as a guest of the New York Philharmonic.

title: Navigating Personal Space: Guarded, Infringed and Shared
description: The choreographer Helen Simoneau hails from Quebec, but judging by the animated crowd at the Joyce SoHo on Friday night, shes no stranger in the United States. In 2010 she won first prize at The A.W.A.R.D. Show! in New York  a dance competition hosted by the Joyce Theater Foundation  and her company, Helen Simoneau Danse, is based both in New York and Winston-Salem, N.C. At first the setting seemed more suited to a cocktail party than a dance performance. One woman asked, How do you know Helen?

title: Charter School Group Reports Steady Demand for Seats
When Coaches Fight, NBCs McGuire Has the Best View
description: When Rangers Coach John Tortorella and Devils Coach Peter DeBoer were jawing at each other in the third period of Game 4 of the Eastern Conference finals on Monday, no one had a better listening post than NBCs Pierre McGuire. His reporting perch is conveniently located between the teams benches.

title: A Guinea Pigs Night at the Theater
description: Even when it is not executed perfectly, theater can stir a range of feelings, from boundless elation to existential despair. On rare occasions, it can even impart blinding pain, as an overly tight mask presses your glasses into your face, setting off sensitive nerve endings you did not know you possessed.

title: Spirits That May Be Stronger Than Their Fans
description: AT Cask, a San Francisco liquor store run by the people who own that citys high-end cocktail bars Rickhouse and Bourbon & Branch, the spirit most coveted by customers is George T. Stagg, a limited-production bourbon that can exceed 70 percent alcohol. The stores owner, Brian Sheehy, said the waiting list for Stagg is 190 names long.

description: The news on Tuesday that Google closed its $12.5 billion deal for Motorola is welcome for both companies, which have been waiting almost a year for the acquisition to get the final green light from regulators.

description: With more than 20 kiosks and stalls, the Plaza Food Hall will feature a diverse array of vendors and bakeries.

title: Surprising Guests in a Bigger Plaza Food Hall
description: THE first surprise came about two years ago, with the opening of the shiny marble- and mosaic-covered Todd English Food Hall, in the lower-level concourse of the Plaza. The somewhat daring move brought a collection of counter-style dining options and food shops to an underused area that had been home to fashion boutiques.

description: As Foxs American Idol wraps its 11th season this week with a sing-off between Phillip Phillips and Jessica Sanchez, those involved with the show are asking what went wrong, a rare dose of soul-searching for a show that has been the runaway hit of this century.

description: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. continued the assault on Mitt Romneys business background on Tuesday, saying it did not qualify him to be president, even as another prominent Democrat expressed misgivings about the White House strategy.

description: The young filmmakers in the Filipino director Marlon Riveras satire The Woman in the Septic Tank are creatures of privilege. They drive around Manila in a nice car, drink fancy coffees and fiddle with their abundant Apple products (MacBook: check; iPad: check; iPhones: got em).

description: RailAmerica, one of the largest operators of short-line railroads in the United States, said on Tuesday that it was considering strategic alternatives, including the possible sale of the company.

title: The Shared Fate of Treece, Kan., and Geamana, Romania
description: The magazines recent article about Treece, a Kansas town rendered virtually uninhabitable  only two residents remain due to mining waste and environmental degradation,evokes the fate of another spot half a world away: Geamana, in Romania. description: PITTSBURGH  Andres Torres acknowledged Tuesday that he might need to change his hitting approach in order to get out of a slump and retain his place in the Mets lineup.

title: A Community Springs From Acres Once Held by a Reclusive Magnate
description: GREENVILLE, S.C.  Over the last decade this city of 60,000 invested $76 million to erase memories of the malaise that had settled over its downtown. Not long ago, Main Street was a place to avoid, a skateboarders paradise with little but concrete sidewalks and ratty parking lots. The grand Poinsett Hotel, built in 1925, stood vacant and was occupied by squatters.

title: Traffic Plan for a Brooklyn Arena Cuts Parking Slots by Half
description: The conundrum that Samuel I. Schwartz, the traffic engineering expert, faced was this: How could the already jam-packed streets in the heart of Brooklyn accommodate thousands of extra cars filled with fans traveling to a basketball arena and desperately searching for parking?

description: ON Saturday night, I returned home from a business trip in China, on a flight made extraordinary by the presence of another traveler, who was leaving his country for mine: Chen Guangcheng.

title: Recession Possible if Impasse Persists, Budget Office Says
description: WASHINGTON  The economy could relapse into a recession if President Obama and Congress remain at an impasse and allow several big tax increases and spending cuts to take effect at the start of 2013, the Congressional Budget Office reported on Tuesday.

description: More than a decade after the City University of New York ended open admissions to its four-year colleges, a marked shift has occurred at its top institutions as freshman classes now enter with far better academic credentials and also a different demographic mix.

description: The end of open admissions in 2000 and the recent recession have led to significant shifts in competitiveness and demographics at the City University of New Yorks top five four-year colleges.

title: Leader of Catholic Order Admits Knowing Priest Fathered Child
description: The head of the Legionaries of Christ, a Roman Catholic religious order, sent a letter to his members on Tuesday admitting that he had known since 2005 that his most prominent American priest, the Rev. Thomas Williams, had fathered a child. The Associated Press reported that the Rev. Alvaro Corcuera, the orders superior in Rome, said he regretted allowing Father Williams to continue giving public lectures and television interviews on living a moral life and teaching moral theology to seminarians. The Legion is trying to recover from revelations that its founder sexually abused seminarians and fathered several children. Father Williams, whose affair became public last week, sent an e-mail to Legion members on Tuesday, apologizing for failing to heed his superiors advice to keep a lower profile.

title: Christopher Schlank
description: Mr. Schlank, 45, is a managing partner and the founder of Savanna, a private equity and asset management firm that invests in commercial real estate. All of its properties are currently in the New York region, including 31 Penn Plaza and downtown buildings like 100 Wall Street. The company was founded in 1992.

title: If Video Sites Could Act Like Cable Companies
description: BOSTON  Most consumers have no idea what an M.V.P.D. is, but they mail a check to one every month. What they call Comcast or Time Warner Cable or DirecTV, the government calls a multichannel video programming distributor, or M.V.P.D. for short.

title: The Modest Worth of Big Banks
description: What can we afford to do about the financial industry?

title: A Mutual Benefit from Chinas Private Link to Treasury Auctions
description: WASHINGTON  The revelation that China is the sole country that can bid on and buy debt directly from the United States Treasury, rather than through a financial intermediary, has raised concerns that the Obama administration is giving a secret, sweetheart deal to its biggest creditor.

title: Hamas-Run Schools Set Out to Teach the Language of the Enemy
description: GAZA  There are few electives in the Hamas-run high schools here. Students can study health and the environment, or they can learn French. And, starting this fall at some schools, they will be able to sign up for a new course called Know Your Enemy.

title: Montana Football Team at Center of Inquiry Into Sexual Assaults
description: MISSOULA, Mont.  Montana advanced to the semifinals of last seasons Football Championship Subdivision playoffs  the 11th time the team made it that far, and yet another indication of why the Grizzlies have long been a source of pride in this bucolic, football-obsessed city of 67,000.
