title: U.S. Sees Other Countries Luring Expatriates to Return
description: The United States is facing intense competition from foreign countries, especially China, that are seeking to persuade highly skilled citizens who have settled in this country to return home to start businesses there, according to a report released Tuesday by an immigration group led by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York.

title: Binghamton Basketball Team to Hire Coach
description: Binghamton is on the verge of hiring Rider Coach Tommy Dempsey, according to a person with direct knowledge of the hiring. An announcement is expected Wednesday. Dempsey, 38, will take over a team that went 2-29 last season and whose talent and finances have been gutted in the wake of Kevin Broaduss coaching tenure. More coverage at nytimes.com/thequad.

title: Iran Recalls Its Ambassador From Azerbaijan
description: BAKU, Azerbaijan  Iran has recalled its ambassador from neighboring Azerbaijan, citing a religious insult, in the latest sign of escalating tensions between the countries.

title: U.S. Files Suit Against Jobs Agency Used by City
description: Federal prosecutors, claiming that they had found widespread fraud in Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs much-vaunted job placement program, filed a multimillion-dollar lawsuit on Tuesday against a nonprofit agency that was once among New York Citys favorite contractors.

title: In Remote Alaska, Financing Puts a Rare Refuge at Risk
description: EMMONAK, Alaska  There are no roads that lead to this tiny fishing village 500 miles west of Anchorage, no doctor and a single state trooper, who is also responsible for patrolling a dozen other far-flung Yupik Eskimo hamlets along the coast of the Bering Sea. The nearest village, Alakanuk, is eight miles away.

title: Eugene Polley, Conjuror of a Device That Changed TV Habits, Dies at 96
description: Eugene Polley, an inventor whose best-known creation has fostered blissful sloth, caused decades of domestic discord and forever altered the way consumers watch television, died on Sunday in Downers Grove, Ill. Mr. Polley, the inventor of the wireless television remote control, was 96.

title: Even When His Latino Roots Might Help Politically, Rangel Keeps Them Buried
description: He utters basic Spanish phrases every now and then, waves a Dominican or Puerto Rican flag at annual parades and takes regular vacations on the white sand beaches of the Dominican Republic.

title: Womens Shelter in Remote Alaskan Village Faces Closing
description: The Emmonak Womens Shelter, the only center for abused women located in an Alaska Native village, may close by the end of the summer.

description: OKLAHOMA CITY

title: Deal Allows Development in Brooklyn Bridge Park
description: A long-simmering dispute over the relocation of a cutting-edge theater to Brooklyn Bridge Park has been resolved by a sweeping agreement among city officials, state lawmakers and several nonprofit groups, paving the way for the theaters eventual move while expanding the park.

title: Russia Demands Inquiry in Death of Child in U.S.
description: The United States government tried to head off a diplomatic row with Russia on Tuesday after Russian officials demanded an investigation into the death of a Russian child in an adoptive American family. American news media reported last week that Anton Fomin, a nine-year old Russian child adopted into a Nebraska family, died in a house fire while his parents were gone. On Monday, Russias childrens rights ombudsman, Pavel Astakhov, demanded an investigation, saying that American investigators had established that the child had been locked in the basement. Either the boy was punished or he was neglected and got into the basement accidentally, Mr. Astakhov said, according to RIA Novosti news service. Why the boy was locked in the basement and why he could not get out, we will ask the U.S. attorneys about this. The United States Embassy in Moscow expressed its condolences to the childs family on Tuesday, and corrected what it called unsubstantiated reports that he was brought to the United States through an adoption program. Anton immigrated to the United States with his biological parents, not through intercountry adoption, the statement said. Russian authorities have repeatedly criticized lax checks on adoptive American parents after a spate of high profile deaths involving negligent and abusive families. Last December, Mr. Astakhov threatened to demand a moratorium on adoptions by Americans after a Pennsylvania court released a pair of adoptive parents with time served after they were convicted of involuntary manslaughter in the death of a child.

title: For Native American Women, Scourge of Rape, Rare Justice
description: EMMONAK, Alaska  She was 19, a young Alaska Native woman in this icebound fishing village of 800 in the Yukon River delta, when an intruder broke into her home and raped her. The man left. Shaking, the woman called the tribal police, a force of three. It was late at night. No one answered. She left a message on the departments voice mail system. Her call was never returned. She was left to recover on her own.

title: Binghamton Expected to Hire Rider Basketball Coach

The bomb threat came a week after a failed assassination attempt in Bogot against Mr. Uribes former interior minister, Fernando Londoo. title: Stone Links: Badiou on Love and Politics
description: Alain Badiou is Frances most famous living philosopher, an unrepentant communist and hardened veteran of the student protests of 1968. Yet a recent profile in the Guardian notes that this most anti-bourgeois of thinkers has released a book called In Praise of Love, which is apparently as much a personal memoir as it is a philosophical meditation on what many see as a particularly bourgeois virtue. According to Badiou, solving the existential problems of love is lifes great joy, and our society has confused that joy, directed towards the very being of the other with a mere sexual pleasure that fetishizes the body. Unfortunately for us, when you liberate sexuality, the problems of love remain unsolved. It would seem that the greatest love of Badious life, however, has been politics, which still makes his eyes gleam. As the piece concludes: Perhaps politics and love are not, if youre a French Maoist, so very different.

description: EVERY March my most organized friends start reserving waterfront rooms, urban oases or country cabins for their perfect summer getaway, while I procrastinate, overwhelmed by the options. Recently, I logged onto VRBO.com (Vacation Rental by Owner), only to find my head spinning at the length of its roster  180,000 properties worldwide. Scrolling through Hotels.com (145,000 hotels in more than 60 countries) and Airbnb.com (over 100,000 short-term rental places in 192 countries), I almost gave up.

title: Obama Wins Contests in Arkansas and Kentucky
description: President Obama easily won two more Democratic primaries on Tuesday, earning victories in largely uncontested contests in Kentucky and Arkansas, where he nevertheless faced a challenge from a perennial candidate.

title: How Judge Views Law Might Sway the Jurors at the Edwards Trial
description: GREENSBORO, N.C.  Legal analysts awaiting a verdict in the John Edwards federal corruption trial say the judges interpretation of the law could shape what the jurors might ultimately decide.

title: How Twitter Matters: Casting a Worldwide Net
description: As regular readers know, I came around to Twitter slowly but now find it an essential combination of sensory apparatus and global conduit for ideas and information. A demonstration of its power to plumb the collective mind occurred on Tuesday, while I was in Washington attending The Science of Science Communication.

title: Baby and Child Care, the African Way
description: NAIROBI  Earlier this month, I met Richard Turere at a TED talk in Nairobi, Kenya. His story electrified the audience: using LED lights, an old battery and motorcycle parts, hed created a lighting array to protect his familys cattle from lions prowling on the outskirts of Nairobi. The invention so effectively mimicked a human with a flashlight that it was being used by several neighboring households.

title: Unclear Future for Mainstay of Niagara Mist
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y.  The Maid of the Mist tour boats have plied the roiling waters of the Niagara Gorge since the 1840s, taking tens of millions of visitors, including the future King Edward VII (1860), Marilyn Monroe (1952) and Mikhail Gorbachev (1983), past the American Falls to the base of the Horseshoe Falls, whose staggering height and swirling mist feel almost biblical.

title: The (Home) Birther Movement
description: Ina May Gaskins crusade to expand access to, and to legalize, midwife-assisted homebirth.

title: Business Day Live | May 23, 2012
description: Silicon Valley lawsuit highlights scarcity of women in top tech jobs. | Why Greek businesses fear a return to the drachma. | Athenians talk about the economic crisis.

title: At CUNY, an Ethnic Shift Because of Stricter Admissions
description: More than 10 years after the City University of New York ended its open-enrollment admissions at its four-year colleges, the freshman classes at its top institutions have far better academic credentials and also a different demographic mix, our colleague Richard Prez-Pea reports:

title: Facebook Shares Close With a 3.2% Gain
description: 4:12 p.m. | Updated All is not lost.

title: On Our Radar: Radiation at Fukushima
description: The World Health Organization releases a preliminary estimate of the radiation doses received by the public during the meltdowns at the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant in Japan. They are generally below the governments maximum recommended dose, suggesting that few cancers can be expected as a result of the releases. [Nature News]

title: Business Day Live: Greek Banks Receive Financing
description: A Silicon Valley lawsuit highlights the scarcity of women in top technology jobs. Why Greek businesses fear a return to the drachma. Athenians talk about the economic crisis.

description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: I Found a T. Rex!
description: Being named after a circus impresario (P.T. Barnum, the most famous circus owner in America) is a dubious birthright at best. But Barnum Browns parents hoped their son, born in 1873, would go on to accomplish unusual and excellent things.

title: Stalked by Shadows (and a Rabbit)
description: AFTER seeing the The Normal Heart on Broadway last June, three teenagers from Minnesota were in a frenzy explaining why they had chosen the play. Sheldon! they all shouted, naming the socially clueless lead character on the CBS hit comedy The Big Bang Theory played by Jim Parsons, who had a small role in the play.

title: Found Poem Favorite | Just Pure Innocent Fun
description: This poem, one of 11 winners from our Third Annual Found Poem Contest, comes from Florence, who is 13 and lives in Germantown, Md.

title: New Obama Ads Focus on Medicare and Veterans
description: President Obamas campaign on Wednesday rolled out two new ads promoting his achievements, part of a $25 million advertising effort that his campaign unveiled this month.

title: The Maim Event
description: You know something is officially askew when N.B.A games start to look like hockey games, N.H.L. games like scenes from Braveheart, and when the N.F.L. tries to make small move to try to reduce the number of unpadded knees ramming into players heads, the players squawk like kindergartners told there will be no milk and cookies at recess. Athletes seem to be conspiring to inflict as much bodily harm as possible between whistles. You can almost here the U.F.C. folks thinking, And were still illegal anywhere?

title: Morning Walkabout  5/23: A Theme Park Rivalry and a Plane Diversion
description: Theme Parks, the Battle Universal Studios and Disney are heavily investing in their theme parks, which have been a safer bet than their big-budget films. Universal, home to the $265 million Harry Potter ride, has just opened a $100 million 3-D Transformers ride. Disney, for its part, is spending an estimated $500 million on an Avatar addition to its Magic Kingdom. (The New York Times)

title: Was Greed Good?
description: As the debate moves  appropriately!  to a discussion of Romneys career at Bain, one thing Ive noticed is that everyone on the right, and a fair number of people who should know better, basically believes that Gordon Gekko was right. Before the Gekkos came along, they assert, American business was sluggish, unproductive, and uncompetitive. Then came the LBOs and all that, and our economic energy was unleashed.

title: Finding Harlem Culture and Music at Ginnys Supper Club
description: WHILE supper club conjures up images of bandleaders and showgirls, this bustling new joint below the Red Rooster in Harlem pays homage to no particular decade or movement in the arts, but to the entirety of Harlems cultural influence, from poetry to soul to hip-hop. Ginnys Supper Club is a place to evoke the Harlem of not only Count Basie and the Cotton Club, but also Nina Simone and Kool Moe Dee.

title: The Raw Food Diet for Pets
description: For years, raw food enthusiasts have touted the health benefits of uncooked food for humans. Now, some veterinarians and pet owners believe that a raw meat diet is best for pets.

title: Secret Service Chief Sees No Systemic Problems
description: WASHINGTON  Under skeptical questioning from senators, the director of the Secret Service insisted on Wednesday that the prostitution scandal that erupted in Colombia last month did not indicate a systemic problem with sex and alcohol in the service.

title: In Meetings on the Web, Owners Turn to Owners for Advice and Support
description: On a recent Tuesday just after noon, D. Penn Moody, an Indianapolis optometrist and owner of Moody Eyes, was the first business owner to present a problem to his peer advisory group.

title: Olympus Goes Back to the Future
description: You have to wonder if Marty McFly and Doc Brown are working for Olympus, whose new camera, the OM-D E-M5, is meant to evoke 1972s groundbreaking Single Lens Reflex Olympus OM-1. Back to the Future indeed.

title: The Beats Hit the Road Again on Screen
description: FOR filmmakers trying to capture the spirit of the Beats, there has always been the pressure  stated or not  of their work living up to the legends. Survivors of the movement, and the scholars who chronicled their every move, are certain to cast an unforgiving eye.

title: In the Kipuka, Birds Take Shelter
description: David J. Flaspohler, an avian ecologist and conservation biologist at Michigan Technological University, writes from Hawaii, where he is studying the influence of human activities on birds and the natural ecosystems that support them.

title: Cannes Film Festival: An Early Look at On the Road
description: 6:49 p.m. | Updated  CANNES, France  At one point in On the Road, Walter Salless respectable, muted take on Jack Kerouacs ecstatic American story, Sal Paradise (Sam Riley), whos trailed after his friends Carlo and Dean, watching them cavort in a handsomely lighted gutter and atmospheric slum pads, delivers what should be a cri de coeur. The only people that interest me, Sal says in voiceover, with Mr. Riley scatting out the famous words, are the mad ones, the ones who are mad to live, mad to talk, desirous of everything at the same time, the ones that never yawn or say a commonplace thingbut burn, burn, burn like Roman candles across the night. Yet these boys scarcely simmer.

title: What Would Your Ballpark Intro Sound Like?
description: Whats your favorite ballpark music?

title: The Eggplant Parm Chronicles, Game 5 Edition
description: Jumping over the boards and returning to the ice for Game 5, Rangers-Devils, will be the eggplant and chicken parmigiana sandwiches from Manganaros Hero Boy on Ninth Avenue in Manhattan.

title: In Mexico, Santos Turns the Tables
description: GUADALAJARA, Mexico  Recent chases for silverware and titles have been a tale of two cities, and three teams from the north of the country, a region gripped by violence and cartels fighting for lucrative drug routes to the United States.

title: When a Boy Found a Familiar Feel in a Pat of the Head of State
description: WASHINGTON  For decades at the White House, photographs of the president at work and at play have hung throughout the West Wing, and each print soon gives way to a more recent shot. But one picture of President Obama remains after three years.

title: Sorry, Folks, Parks Closed (Hours Early)
description: Just after 10 p.m. on Tuesday, James Drysdale was about to enter Tompkins Square Park when he was surprised to find his passage barred by a metal gate chained shut at East Seventh Street and Avenue B.

title: Nicole & Steven
description: Nicole and Steven tell the story of how they met at a restaurant while Nicole waited for a date to arrive. Luckily for Steven, the date was mediocre.

title: Imagine That: Peter Dinklage to Star in All-Male Imaginary Invalid
description: As they say on Game of Thrones, a Lannister always pays his debts. But does a Lannister always fill out a dress? Perhaps Peter Dinklage, the Golden Globe and Emmy Award-winning actor who plays the cynical aristocrat Tyrion Lannister on that HBO fantasy series, can answer the question: This summer he will be starring in a new production of Molires satire The Imaginary Invalid, as one of its lead female characters.

title: Would You Be Comfortable Using an Online Peer Group?
description: On a recent Tuesday just after noon, D. Penn Moody, an Indianapolis optometrist and owner of Moody Eyes, was the first business owner to present a problem to his peer advisory group. He had recently expanded his vision practice and glasses store, and he said he was having difficulty balancing medical consultations and product sales. When a medical equipment manufacturer from Boston asked him for his value proposition, Dr. Moody replied, I think the value proposition is that were the middle of the road.

title: The Siren of the Shenandoah
description: It was an oddly conspicuous act for a girl purporting to be a spy: On May 23, 1862, Belle Boyd, newly 18 and possessed of a little rebel heart, sprinted across the battlefield in Front Royal, Va., crinoline swinging, bullets plowing up the earth around her. She waved her white bonnet in grandiose loops, a signal for Confederate troops to advance, and caught the attention of staff officer Henry Kyd Douglas.

title: A V.I.P. Room at a Middle School Dance
description: The blogger Marcy Magieras son is off to his Los Angeles area middle schools spring dance this week, and to add to the usual angst  the girls on one side of the room, the boys on the other; the questionable lighting and dcor; the too-loud music and hovering chaperones  the school has introduced a new element: a V.I.P. lounge.

title: Postcard: Memphis
description: Members of the Fatback Collective, an all-star team of Southern chefs and pitmasters, competed in their second Memphis in May Barbecue World Championship last weekend. The eclectic team brought together a wealth of culinary knowledge and a healthy respect for American barbecue traditions, including the heritage-breed pigs raised by small-scale farms. The members gathered in Memphis to smoke three pigs for competition in the whole hog category.

title: Spring Staples | Wrapped Up
description: Seasons change and so must accessories.

title: Shopping Snapshots: May 24
description: Chic summer sandals; regal headpieces; and hand-braided bracelets.

title: Carnegie Hall Announces Program Change
description: Carnegie Hall announced on Wednesday that Yefim Bronfman, the pianist scheduled to play Brahmss Second Piano Concerto with the Cleveland Orchestra on Wednesday evening, had canceled the performance because of illness. He will be replaced by the violinist Gil Shaham, playing Brahmss Violin Concerto. The rest of the program  Kaija Saariahos Laterna Magica, in its New York premiere, and Shostakovichs Symphony No. 6  remains intact.

title: Image of the Day: May 23
Scouting Report
description: OPENINGS

title: Powell Criticizes Romney on Foreign Policy
description: Colin L. Powell, the retired general and former secretary of state, indicated on Tuesday that he was not yet ready to endorse President Obama for re-election.

title: An American Jihadist Now Has a Memoir Out
description: The mystery of Omar Hammami  a 28-year-old American jihadist wanted by the F.B.I. after joining an Al Qaeda affiliate in Somalia  has only deepened in recent months.

title: Extra Mooga Festivalgoers Get a Refund
description: One of the recurring conversations around the picnic tables in the Extra Mooga section of the Great GoogaMooga festival last weekend was whether the $250-a-day tickets to that premium section (the festival itself was free) were worth the price.

title: Turkey May Indict Senior Israeli Officers Over Deadly Gaza Flotilla Raid
description: A prosecutor in Turkey has prepared indictments and recommended life sentences for four senior Israeli officers over the killing of nine activists aboard a Gaza-bound aid flotilla forcibly intercepted by Israeli commandos two years ago, Turkish news services reported Wednesday.

title: Obama More Conservative Than Hoover? Someone Thinks So
description: COLORADO SPRINGS  Its not every day that a White House boasts of being more conservative than Herbert Hoover. But there was Jay Carney, the presidential press secretary, on Wednesday telling reporters aboard Air Force One that Mr. Hoover was a more profligate spender than President Obama.

title: TimesCast | May 23, 2012
description: Egyptians go to the polls to select a president in an election cast as a watershed in their political history.

title: Brooklyn Private School Reinstated as SAT Testing Site
description: The Packer Collegiate Institute and the College Board have reached a truce, allowing the school to continue to serve as an SAT testing site, including for two exams in June.

title: A Secret Behind the Whales Mighty Gulp
description: Somewhere in the vastness of the northern oceans, a fin whale is feeding.

title: Insecurity Touches the Tycoons of Greece
description: ATHENS  While money pours out of Greek banks and Europe debates whether or not Greece deserves its next handout, the people potentially in the best position to help shore up the nations finances are mainly keeping their heads down.

title: Sequoia Capital Said to Be Expanding to Brazil
description: SAO PAULO, Brazil  Sequoia Capital is expanding to South America, becoming the latest Silicon Valley stalwart to tap into the regions growing economy, according to two Brazilian investors with direct knowledge of the plans.

title: Consumers Getting Savvier About Credit Scores
description: Consumers are getting savvier about credit scores, according to new findings from the nonprofit group Consumer Federation of America.

title: Brooklyn Breeds a New Hotelier
description: ANDREW TARLOW doesnt like to think of himself as a founding father of all things precious in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. It sounds too stodgy, too grand and old-school to him.

title: Indians Keep Winning, but Drawing Few Fans
description: The question is being whispered around Cleveland, and in the other corners of the American League: are the Indians for real?

title: Going Negative
description: Gail Collins: David, why do you think theres so much negative campaigning? The crazy billionaires who want their own nutty super PAC? The years-long presidential races where the candidates just run out of stuff to talk about? Our fraying national moral fiber? Or is it just because it works?

title: How the Season Ended for Hopkins
description: BALTIMOREImitation may be the sincerest form of flattery, but forgive Johns Hopkins mens lacrosse head coach Dave Pietramala if he was not entirely charmed by the strategy used by University of Maryland head coach John Tillman in the Blue Jays quarterfinal loss to the Terrapins on Saturday. With a slowed-down pace of offensive play and a tenacious defensive effort, Tillman utilized the same game plan Pietramala installed back in 2007 that led those Blue Jays to a national title. But this time around, it was Hopkins feeling the frustration of a game, and a season, slowly slipping away.

title: Inventor of Wireless Remote Dies: Clunky Technology Lives On
description: When I read Margalit Foxs gorgeous obituary of Eugene Polley, the creator of the wireless television remote, I was struck by the vision he displayed when he invented the so-called Flash-Matic back in 1955. I was also struck by the fact that more than half a century later, the technology he invented, which managed to be convenient and clunky at the same time, has yet to be really improved upon. The troubles in the system  which worked with TV sets built with a photo cell in each corner of the screen  were there right from the start.

title: Site of SAT Mishap Is Reinstated as Testing Site
description: The Packer Collegiate Institute, a Brooklyn private school where the SAT scores of 199 students were invalidated because of serious violations with the tests administration, will be allowed to continue serving as an SAT testing site starting in June.

title: Falling Interest in American Idol as It Prepares to Crown a Winner
description: Theres only one way to say it: American Idol lost a big chunk of its mojo this season.

title: The Caucus Click: March of the Graduates
Pollution Tourism: Andrew Blackwell on Visiting the Worlds Not-So-Hot Spots
description: In Visit Sunny Chernobyl: And Other Adventures in the Worlds Most Polluted Places, Andrew Blackwell travels to the titular fallout site; Linfen, China; Port Arthur, Texas; and other deeply despoiled places, driven by concern for the planet but also by a desire to see what such unpopular places might have to offer. In a recent interview via e-mail, Mr. Blackwell discussed the wildlife around Chernobyl, the one place he wishes he had visited, possible futures for environmentalism, and more. Below are excerpts from the conversation.

title: Growing Up With a Home Advantage
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md.  An Aston Martin, a Bentley and a Jaguar are among the cars parked at the Tennis Center at College Park. Through the door of the private club one will find luxury locker rooms; 30 courts; a health club; and an office, about 120 square feet with one window, that was once a makeshift apartment the janitor called home.

title: International and U.S. Olympic Leaders Agree on Revenue-Sharing Plan
description: The United States put itself in position to once again win a bid to host an Olympic Games after Olympic leaders this week ended their longstanding, contentious debate about how to divvy some of the Games revenue, two people close to the discussions said Wednesday.

title: Trying to Click Online
description: WITHIN 24 hours of Oscar de la Rentas resort fashion show on Monday evening, more than 500 people had endorsed his look No. 42, a green and white sequined silk sweater that was based on a classic baseball T-shirt. By endorsed, we mean that they clicked on a photo of the sweater on Fancy (TheFancy.com), one of the new sites that allow users to communally create, browse and comment on portfolios of just about anything.

title: Cannes Film Festival: A Return Visit for a Director Fond of Repetition
description: 3:07 p.m. | Updated  CANNES, France  Another Cannes, another Hong Sang-soo film. By now a new work by Mr. Hong, the prolific South Korean director, is as much a Cannes ritual as standing in line or drinking a midday glass of ros. Eight of his 13 features have shown at the festival here, three of them  including In Another Country this year  in the main competition, and he won the top prize in the Un Certain Regard section in 2010 for Ha Ha Ha.

title: New Study Outlines How the Military Could Create a Leaner, Less Expensive Force
description: WASHINGTON  The war in Iraq is over. The war in Afghanistan is winding down. Today, the challenge facing the Pentagon is identifying the best military plans in an era to be defined by economic austerity. The world will be just as dangerous, but in different, even more unexpected ways, than in the years after the Sept. 11 attacks, when the Defense Department had a virtual blank check to pay for its programs.

title: Nude Paintings of Leaders Cause Stir in South Africa and Canada
description: The first protester applied a pair of strategically placed Xs in red paint to the face and genitals of a seminude portrait of the South African president, Jacob Zuma. The second went further, smearing the image with black oil paint, obscuring all but the silhouette of his form.

title: Remembering 1994: Q. and A. With Claude Lemieux
description: During the Eastern Conference finals between the Rangers and the Devils, The New York Times will revisit some of the memorable characters of the 1994 conference finals between the teams. Perhaps no player in N.H.L. history was able to ramp up his intensity and effectiveness for the playoffs like Claude Lemieux, who won four Stanley Cups. In 1994 Lemieux tied Game 1 for the Devils with 43 seconds left, setting the stage for Stephane Richers double-overtime game-winner; received double unsportsmanlike-conduct and double 10-minute-misconduct penalties for going after Adam Graves in Game 2; and helped set up Valery Zelepukins tying goal with 7.7 seconds left in the unforgettable Game 7.

title: Russell Westbrook Stays in Control
description: In the wake of last years 4-1 conference finals throttling at the hands of eventual champion Dallas, many doubted whether the Oklahoma City Thunder had the pedigree  and chemistry  to take the next step. At the center of the storm was whether Russell Westbrooks shoot-first-ask-questions-later ethos too closely mimicked the talents and tactics of the teams tenured superstar Kevin Durant.

title: Collision Warning Systems Win Favor in Federal Test
description: An overwhelming majority of drivers who participated in government tests of wireless crash-avoidance technologies viewed the systems favorably, according to a report released Tuesday by the Transportation Department.

title: Business Day Live | Women in Tech
description: May 23, 2012 - Silicon Valley lawsuit highlights scarcity of women in top tech jobs.

title: Sweden 1912: A Tough Ticket
description: One hundred years ago the summer Olympics were held in Stockholm. As we count down the days to London 2012, well take a look back at what was happening at the games a century ago.

title: Martha Stewart Returns as Chairwoman of Her Namesake Company
description: Martha Stewart is back at the helm in the boardroom.

title: The Get | JewelMints Garden Party Rings
description: Designed by the actress Kate Bosworth and the stylist Cher Coulter, JewelMint is an online-only jewelry line that combines outstanding prices (everything is under $30) with ethical action. (Portions of the proceeds from celebrity-supported pieces go to charity; currently, a pair of Bermuda earrings picked by Krysten Ritter benefit Autism Speaks.) The brand changes designs and inventory monthly, and its latest fashion film (the sixth) features Bosworth paying homage to the 1920s screen legend Louise Brooks  replete with black bob and thick lip  while sporting delicate baubles. The May collection has a ladylike vintage appeal that we felt would work well against a black-and-white 20s backdrop, says Bosworth of the film, screening exclusively here at T. Among this months Deco-like diamonds and door knockers are these quieter adornments, a set of three rings decorated with dainty flora and the teensiest stones. Stack them or scatter them about.

title: U.S. Attorney in Chicago to Step Down
description: Patrick J. Fitzgerald, the United States attorney who oversaw the criminal prosecutions of successive Illinois governors on corruption charges as well as of the former Bush administration White House aide I. Lewis Libby Jr., will resign at the end of June, the Justice Department announced Wednesday.

title: Lacmas Rock Gets an Official Opening, Finally
description: LOS ANGELES  The journey is almost complete.

title: The Economic Crisis in Greece
description: May 23, 2012 - Why Greek businesses fear a return to the drachma and Athenians talk about the economic crisis.

title: Ask About the Egyptian Election
description: This week, Ill be answering your questions about Egypts historic presidential elections here on Rendezvous. Leave your question by using the comments box below. Feel free to respond to others questions. Ill post my answers as well.

title: Former Employees Feel Silenced on Library Project
description: The New York Public Librarys plan to turn part of its flagship Fifth Avenue research center into a lending library has unleashed a torrent of commentary, with scholars, writers, artists and students signing a petition and writing articles, many of them critical. But one highly informed contingent has been notably silent: former curators, department heads and librarians.

title: Google Cleared of Infringing on Oracles Java Patents
description: Google did not infringe on any Oracle patents when it used Java software in the Android operating system, a federal jury said on Wednesday.

title: Pregame Chatter: Satisfied With Production, DeBoer Sticks With Same Lineup
description: NEWARK - The Devils scored four goals in Game 4, the most allowed so far by the Rangers this postseason, so why mess with success? That seemed to be the thinking of Coach Peter DeBoer, who after the teams morning skate said he would use the same lineup for Game 5 on Wednesday night at Madison Square Garden.

description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: F.A.Q. About Fledging Hawks
description: We are approaching fledge day, when the juvenile hawks of Washington Square Park take their first flight out of their 12th-floor nursery at New York Universitys Bobst Library and begin the next phase of their development in the broader confines of the park. Wednesday is 43 and 44 days since Boo and Scout emerged from their shells. Typically, red-tailed hawks take flight between 42 and 46 days of life, though hawks in urban areas can take longer. Last year, the baby hawk named Pip by readers first used its wings after 49 days on the nest and sailed to a rooftop on a neighboring building.

title: More Thoughts on the Ravi/Clementi Case
description: The Dharun Ravi case clearly evokes strong reactions, manifest in the number of comments my post yesterday received. I was glad to read through them and fascinated as I did. I admit I wasnt able to give each a careful look, but I did get a sense of the variety of sentiments and of some recurring themes.

title: Adam Lambert Tops the Billboard Chart
description: Adam Lambert has a mixed victory on the Billboard chart this week. With his latest release, Trespassing (RCA), he has scored his first No. 1 album, and he is the seventh American Idol finalist to reach the top spot on the chart. But with music sales slow, it had the least sales for a No. 1 album in almost a year.

title: Romney, Dipping Into Education, Pushes School Choice
description: A revised version of this post is available here.

title: The Secret Lives of Cater Waiters
description: From graffiti artists to interior designers to circus performers, eight cater waiters share their day jobs and career aspirations, as well as memories from the evening party shift.

title: Does It Mean Anything That a Record Low Are Pro-Choice?
description: The percentage of Americans who call themselves pro-choice is at a new low, according to a Gallup poll. Asked to pick one of the two labels applied to the abortion debate, a full 50 percent said they were pro-life, whereas only 41 percent said they were pro-choice, down from the previous low of 42 percent recorded in May of 2009.

title: Silver Trays and High Hopes
description: WITH the summer social season around the corner, photo-ready pretty young things arent the only ones popping up from Manhattan to Montauk. So, too, are the handsome cater waiters who flank the entrances of parties, hold trays of Champagne and pass around plates of truffled foie gras.

title: One of 2 Suspects Arrested in Pickpocketing of Blind Woman
description: One of two suspects in the bump-and-grab pickpocketing of a 68-year-old blind woman at a Queens subway station was arrested on Wednesday, the police said. The suspect, Latisha Richardson, 39, was arrested on charges of larceny, possession of stolen property, drug possession and jostling, the police said.

title: Managing Care Online
description: When Wendy Naumanns father and three siblings received her mothers diagnosis  a terminal brain tumor  they were overwhelmed. Just communicating within the family to keep everybody updated on her mothers condition was exhausting, as they were spread out across the country.

title: Hazing Ritual of a Band Is Described in Documents
description: MIAMI  Hoping to earn the respect of his band mates, Robert Champion agreed to enter Bus C in an Orlando parking lot one evening last fall and walk to the back in a common but brutal Florida A & M University hazing ritual  one that cost him his life, according to documents released Wednesday by prosecutors.

title: Niese and No Need for Much Else
description: PITTSBURGH  The only bit of dissonance after Jon Nieses glittery outing Wednesday involved how perturbed he was following his previous start.

title: Education and Prevention: Creating Public Service Campaigns About Type 2 Diabetes
description: Overview | In this lesson, students read about a new study showing a rise in Type 2 diabetes among adolescents. They learn more about Type 2 diabetes and its causes, then develop a public awareness campaign to promote education and prevention.

title: But Now, What to Wear?
description: THE bride wore Carolina Herrera, the other bride wore Ralph Lauren. That was the big reveal at the wedding of Christine C. Quinn, the New York City Council speaker, and her longtime partner, Kim M. Catullo, a products liability lawyer, in a ceremony held in the meatpacking district last Saturday evening.

title: Unsteady Big East Pins Hopes on TV Deal
description: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla.  If television producers wanted to cast the Big East Conference as a 1980s sitcom, the plot would revolve around a series of hastily arranged marriages constructed to avoid deportation. As the conference braced to grow to 18 teams in basketball and 13 in football and stretch from Boise to Providence to Tampa, its many athletic directors, coaches and officials met here this week. Call them college athletics Imperfect Strangers.

title: The New Masters of Parsons
description: EVEN from across the classroom, there was something that stood out about the jacket on Lucia Cubas dress form. A simple design on canvas, it was printed with repeating black-and-white photographs of a small boy standing at attention. You might have thought the jacket verged on adorable.

title: Student Show
description: Looks created by the first graduates of a new M.F.A. program at Parsons the New School for Design.

title: New Polls Underscore Close Presidential Race
description: Two new national polls show a close race between President Obama and Mitt Romney, while a new Florida poll shows Mr. Romney with a lead in a crucial swing state.

title: Battle an Alien Horde at Sea
description: Battleship may be sinking at the box office, but you can still put on your captains hat and duel with alien warships at sea with a movie-inspired version of the Battleship iPhone app from Electronic Arts.

title: Military Will Remain Strong With Cuts, Obama Tells Cadets
description: COLORADO SPRINGS  President Obama vowed on Wednesday to keep the military strong even as he winds down the wars of the last decade and takes the budget knife to Pentagon spending in an age of increasing government austerity.

title: 14 Charged With Dealing Prescription Drugs in Washington Heights
description: The police and federal authorities announced the arrests of 12 people on Wednesday on charges of buying and selling prescription painkillers in open-air drug markets in Washington Heights.

title: The 40th Annual FiFi Fragrance Awards
description: A look inside the Oscars of the fragrance industry.

title: What Were Reading
description: News of the Olympics from around the Web.

title: The Triumphant Smells of Success
description: NEARLY everyone on the dating market has certain things that are deal breakers. Some people cancel the second date after finding out the person votes Republican (or Democratic). Id say, You smell good, but Im allergic, she said. I dont like perfume. I like scent.

Mr. Carney said this proves the president has demonstrated far more restraint and responsibility than his critics would allow.

description: For each of the 36 years that the New York City Marathon has existed as a five-borough race, Steve Mendelsohn could be found in the lead vehicle with the race director, cruising along with the lead male runner and relaying messages on his ham radio.

description: Barring a successful last-minute challenge by environmental groups, Shell will begin drilling test wells off the coast of northern Alaska in July, opening a new frontier in domestic oil exploration and accelerating a global rush to exploit the untold resources beneath the frozen ocean.

title: Government Report Says Medical Discharge Process Is Getting Slower
description: Since the deep embarrassment of the Walter Reed Army Medical Center scandal in 2007, the Departments of Defense and Veterans Affairs have been trying to make the process of getting a medical discharge from the military less complicated, time-consuming and contentious. Seamless transition to civilian life was their oft-repeated goal.

description: You could argue that women have never been able to easily access the birthing experience they desired. The old days of childbirth, fraught with risk to mother and baby, were followed by a variety of innovations, some more welcome than others. In her story on Ina May Gaskin and the home birth movement, Mommy Wars: The Prequel, in this coming weekends New York Times Magazine, Samantha M. Shapiro writes that women once fought to move birth out of the domain of midwives and the home and into the hospital:

title: A Garden Gala at MoMA

description: This summer, men can look forward to light, less structured suits that keep cool and are fun to wear.

title: A Uruguayan Derby With a Twist (or Tag)
description: Every spring, it seems, as if to counter the attention on the UEFA Champions League or Englands Premier League, the Uruguayan club Pearol thinks of big ways to get people to look its way. Last year, Pearol unfurled what it thought was the worlds largest flag, created in the team colors of black and gold and covering about half of the seats in its stadium. But flags are so  old fashioned.

description: THAT time of year is upon us: the sticky season, when the only suit a man can get excited about has one of two words in front of it: swim or birthday.

title: James Lecesne Will Replace an Injured Michael McKean in Best Man

title: Poetry and Other Texts, Fitted for a Song (or Two)
description: A primary focus of the Mirror Visions Ensemble is performing different settings of the same text, an interest shown by its name. So the groups 20th-anniversary celebration at Merkin Concert Hall on Tuesday evening included two settings of the Heinrich Heine poem Das Fischermdchen (The Fisher Maiden), one in the original German by Meyerbeer and a Russian translation by Reinhold Glire. It also included La Mer Est Plus Belle (The Sea Is More Beautiful), a text by Verlaine, in settings by Debussy and Louis Durey.

title: Single Again, and Embracing Playtime
description: Not many television shows these days can be said to have courage, but a new sitcom on TBS called Men at Work certainly does. It has the courage to announce: Guy shows can be just as crass, penis-obsessed and vacuous as all those gal shows that started turning up last fall. More, even.

title: Parks Working Out as Smoke-Free Zones, City Says
description: When a ban on smoking in city parks took effect one year ago, some tobacco partisans vowed it would not stick, that it was unenforceable, that they would flout it to their dying breaths.

Usually that work is dark and angst-laden, conforming to what Americans think of as Continental. But on Tuesday, during the second program of the companys run at the Joyce Theater, the message from across the Atlantic seemed to be: hey, we can be fun, too.

title: What Good Is Sitting Alone at Your Keyboard?
description: With a schoolboys enthusiasm  indeed, looking a bit like Harry Potter all grown up  the writer Greg Pierce flipped through the three-ring binder on his lap, his forehead crinkling as he searched for the mornings to-do list. He was sitting in the Upper West Side studio of John Kander, the Tony Award-winning composer of Cabaret, Chicago and more than 15 other musicals over the last 50 years. Show posters of all that fame hung on the rooms west wall, most of them featuring the legendary names Kander & Ebb  the latter, of course, being the lyricist Fred Ebb, who died in 2004.

title: No Smiles. No Fusion. Just That Old-Time Flamenco Sadness.
description: Everybody says I have the face of a dead man, Manuel Agujetas sang in Spanish, in a dire, unaccompanied, ancient-sounding modal chant, its tonality blurred by his rasp. Its what happens to good Gitanos when life isnt going well. He sat on a chair, staring forward, hands on knees, his eyes like deep creases, an old scar running in a lateral slice on his right cheek.

title: Technology Reaches Remote Tibetan Corners, Fanning Unrest

title: Paul Fussell, Literary Scholar and Critic, Is Dead at 88
description: Paul Fussell, the wide-ranging, stingingly opinionated literary scholar and cultural critic whose admiration for Samuel Johnson, Kingsley Amis and the Boy Scout Handbook and his withering scorn for the romanticization of war, the predominance of television and much of American society were dispensed in more than 20 books, died on Wednesday in Medford, Ore. He was 88.

OBrien wrote about Googles Street View project, an ambitious endeavor to map the world by sending specially equipped cars out to photograph every street. The cars also collected data sent over unencrypted wireless networks. That so-called payload data contained bits of personal e-mails and Internet postings and searches  whatever someone was doing on a computer as the car passed by. The collection of that data, as the article recounts, has been the subject of numerous investigations in the United States and elsewhere.

Trott has spent a career carefully cultivating the image of the discreet investment banker, a behind-the-scenes consigliere to some of Americas wealthiest businessmen, including his star client, Warren E. Buffett. At Goldman Sachs, Mr. Trott was so vigilant about guarding clients confidences that he was known to fire underlings who discussed private matters in the banks elevators.

title: The Danger Downwind
description: In 2006, then-Senator Barack Obama co-sponsored a tough law aimed at protecting the public from an accident or terrorist attack at one of the nations chemical plants. Opposed by industry and President George W. Bushs White House, the bill never made it to the Senate floor. A weak substitute was passed instead, and the dangers remain. President Obama can fix the problem.

A bun and a thing, Mr. Mau said, referring to the stylish knot of hair perched high on his scalp and the smaller tuft gathered near his collar. If its not the coiffure you associate with the ancient vocation of woodworking, you clearly did not spend time at the International Contemporary Furniture Fair, which on Tuesday ended its annual four-day run at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center.

They have long seized on the work of a towering figure in psychiatry to justify their position.

title: China: Mysterious Inquiry About a Blood Sample
description: A prominent American forensic scientist, Henry C. Lee, said Wednesday in a telephone interview that he was contacted in February by a police detective from the Chinese city of Chongqing who wanted Dr. Lees laboratory to analyze a blood sample from someone who had died after drinking. Dr. Lee never received the sample and was not told whose blood it was. The inquiry to Dr. Lee, first reported in other newspapers, came in the same month that Wang Lijun, who had just been removed as Chongqing police chief, drove to a United States consulate and spoke of the death in Chongqing of Neil Heywood, a British businessman. Police officials said at the time that Mr. Heywood died of excessive drinking. Mr. Wang told American diplomats that Gu Kailai, the wife of Bo Xilai, then the Chongqing party chief, was involved in murdering Mr. Heywood.

title: Questions of Fair Play Arise in Facebooks I.P.O. Process

title: For Hospitals and Insurers, New Fervor to Cut Costs

She regularly sees a host of pediatric specialists, including an ophthalmologist, an endocrinologist and a neurologist at UCLA Health System. Her care has cost hundreds of thousands of dollars so far, and she will need special treatment for the rest of her life.

Thats the purpose of the Court Interpreters Act of 1978, which allows federal courts to order losing parties to pay prevailing parties the cost of interpreters.

Each had paid $35,800 to spend two hours at a fund-raiser with President Obama, but the timing proved awkward: A few hours earlier, Mr. Obamas campaign had begun a blistering attack on Mitt Romneys career in private equity, the same business in which Mr. James has earned his many millions.

title: Who Cares if the Rupee Keeps Falling?

In an op-ed column last weekend in The Business Standard, a leading business daily in India, Shankar Acharya said: The real cause of the rupees weakness is the relentless deterioration in our economic policies in recent years. A falling rupee is simply a symptom of the underlying disease: unsound economic policies. Mr. Acharya was part of the team that helped design the original economic reforms of 1991 and is a former chief economic adviser to the Indian government so his words should be taken seriously.

Having given American jazz artists a home away from home since the 1920s, the city still knows how to welcome them and their fans from all over the world. So it is only natural that a jazz festival was established there. Now in its 12th year, the St. Germain Jazz Festival runs through June 3, featuring a top-flight line-up that includes Kurt Elling, Ahmad Jamal, Yusef Lateef and Jacky Terrasson.

One is a small-government Jeffersonian perspective that abhors bigness and holds that prosperity flows from competition among independent businessmen, farmers and other producers. The other is a Hamiltonian agenda that believes a large, powerful country needs large, powerful organizations. The most important of those organizations is the federal government, which serves as a crucial partner to private enterprise, building roads and schools, guaranteeing loans and financing scientific research in ways that individual businesses would not.

title: 36 Hours in Dresden, Germany

Roughly midway between Berlin and Prague, the capital of Saxony has largely restored the major architectural treasures damaged by Allied bombing raids: the Zwinger Palace, the Frauenkirche and the Semperoper. But while the Old Town, or Altstadt, was busy turning the clock back, the Neustadt across the Elbe River was looking forward. The ussere Neustadt (Outer New Town) quarter is now filled with new bars and shops catering to a younger generation that doesnt remember the days under Communism, much less the war. In the heart of this artsy district, youll find such delights as the Kunsthofpassage complex, home to an ingenious turquoise building that has rigged its drains, which are shaped like instruments, to play water music after it rains. Old and new come together in the Military History Museum reconceived by Daniel Libeskind in 2011, which, with its focus on the causes and corollaries of war and violence, represents a stark, contemporary rethinking of the past.

Wrung out perhaps by the arduous work of watching movies all day and night at the 65th Cannes Film Festival, they have begun to boo and jeer louder and more insistently, or so it seems. Are the selections really all that disastrous, deserving of the contemptuous dismissals or post- (and mid!) screening Twitter alerts? Certainly the antipathy aimed at the more formally experimental entries seems reflective of the same ungenerous, unadventurous mind-set (except when I boo, of course) that asserts itself here every year.

title: Scouting Out a Paradise: Books, Music and No Adults

In his latest, the wondrous storybook tale Moonrise Kingdom, a girl and a boy, both 12, run off to a remote inlet on an island where most of the adults seem disappointed and more than a little sad. The girl and the boy are very serious  about love, their plans, books, life itself  and often act older than their age. She wears bright blue eyeliner; he puffs on a corncob pipe. You wonder what their hurry is, given that here adulthood, with its quarrels, regrets and anguished pillow talk, can feel as dangerous as the storm thats hurtling toward the island, ready to blow it all down.

title: Temptation Dominates the Road to Recovery
description: Joachim Triers Oslo, August 31st is a perfectly linear story that bristles with suspense and ambiguity. The title and the structure make literal the recovery movement mantra one day at a time, and also show just how long and how full of danger a single 24-hour span can be. Stories of addiction frequently pass through a metaphorical crossroads  redemption down one path, catastrophe down the other  but Anders (Anders Danielsen Lie), Mr. Triers protagonist, faces such a choice at every waking moment. You are never sure what he will do next, and it is clear that he is not, either. Nor does he necessarily know why he makes the choices he does, or what they mean.

She performs these tasks in the shadow of Arthur Ashe Stadium, the site of her greatest accomplishment, close enough to hit with a long forehand, yet far enough for her star turn there to seem like it took place in another life.

Conversely, parks and protected areas with armed guards and anti-poaching patrols  places like Nouabal-Ndoki National Park in the Republic of Congo, Kahuzi-Biega National Park in the Democratic Republic of Congo, and Volcanoes National Park in Rwanda  have not only retained their ape populations, but have seen population increases.

Mr. Clayman has obsessive-compulsive disorder  specifically harm O.C.D., which involves intense anger and violent imaginings  and Aspergers syndrome, which inhibits the grasp of social cues. This moving, penetrating documentary records his attempt to describe his conditions, confront them and learn to manage them.

title: Illinois: Departing Prosecutor Has a Regret
description: A day after announcing he would resign as the United States attorney for the Northern District of Illinois, Patrick J. Fitzgerald, who oversaw the prosecution of Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich, expressed regret for saying that the governors conduct would makeLincoln roll over in his grave. Mr. Fitzgerald was criticized for making the comment after the 2008 arrest of Mr. Blagojevich, who was eventually convicted of trying to sell Barack Obamas vacated Senate seat. I probably could have had a colder shower, a little more sleep and some decaf, Mr. Fitzgerald said Thursday at a news conference. Having said that, I did get grief over it, and what bothers me about that, frankly, is I dont want it to overshadow what the agents did in that case. Mr. Fitzgerald, whose other high-profile prosecutions include public corruption charges against former Gov. George Ryan and a C.I.A. leak case against I. Lewis Libby Jr., the former chief of staff for Vice President Dick Cheney, said he would consider other government work, but ruled out running for office. She thought he was an airline pilot, and she did not tell him that she had a flourishing second career as a singer  and would be on the road for weeks at a time.

title: The Netherlands: Mladic Trial Reset

Judges granted the extra month to the defense because the prosecution had been late in delivering a portion of the evidence  about 3 percent of the total, according to the prosecution  that must be shared with the defense team. But the judges turned down the request from the defense for six extra months of preparation time. The long-awaited trial is one of the most important to deal with the Bosnian war, from 1992 to 1995, in which Mr. Mladic was the overall commander on the Serbian side. He faces charges of war crimes, crimes against humanity and genocide.

title: Inside the List
description: CARROT AND STICK: Buried deep in the 9/11 commission report, in the footnotes to a chapter tracing Al Qaedas determination to strike, theres a reference to an active spy identified only as Henry, who before the attacks lobbied unsuccessfully for further C.I.A. involvement in Afghanistan. That spy, we now know, was Henry A. Crumpton  or Hank, as hes been called since his childhood in rural Georgia  and his memoir, The Art of Intelligence, is new on the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 3. After 9/11, Crumpton was one of the C.I.A. operatives responsible for defeating the Taliban and Al Qaeda in Afghanistan. In 2010 he told the 60 Minutes correspondent Lara Logan how he went about it: In a very crude way, it would be a carrot and a stick. The carrot would be, If you come cooperate with us, we will reward you and your people. The stick was, If you do not cooperate, the chances of your survival are greatly diminished. And we would prove this by attacking Taliban leaders who had rejected our overtures.

title: Up Front
description: David Leonhardt came to The Times from Business Week in 1999 and began a steady ascent, starting as a business reporter, becoming an economics columnist in 2006 and winning a Pulitzer Prize for commentary last year. Since September he has been The Timess Washington bureau chief. In his writing as in his career, Leonhardt has positioned himself at the intersection of economics and politics, viewing issues with a skeptical but pragmatic eye. As he said in his final column last summer, We do not spend enough time focusing on our actual economic problems. We are too often occupied with distractions, rather than trying to answer a simple question: What works? What economic policies have succeeded before and are most likely to lead to the best life for the largest number of people? Instead, weve effectively decided that because the United States is the richest, most successful country in the world, it is guaranteed to remain so.

title: Only Yesterday
description: What can you say about a 72-year-old man who died? More salient, what can you say about a 27-year-old novel that survives him?

title: Minding the Gap
description: Writing in the middle of the 19th century, Karl Marx predicted that the gulf between the newly rich and the miserable urban poor, made much worse by the Industrial Revolution, would continue to widen indefinitely. This ever greater disparity, he thought, would ultimately undermine capitalism. Marx turned out to be wrong. Income inequality in Britain (and, from what we can tell, elsewhere in Europe too) began to narrow after the 1860s, and inequality in wealth peaked by the time of World War I. In America, inequality in both incomes and wealth began to lessen after the 1920s. The rich continued to live far better than the poor, but over the next 50 years the gap between them narrowed substantially.

title: Paying for Labors of Love
description: Theres one mistake I worry readers will make about this book, so let me correct it right away: The Outsourced Self is not a work of journalism. Though it isnt exactly not one, either. I guess youd call it popular sociology, but I think of it more as an act of mourning. Arlie Russell Hochschilds look at how we meet some of our most personal needs with the aid of paid strangers doesnt try to be exhaustive; goes light on figures and statistics; and, when itemizing the most outrageous advances in the market for love and care, never lapses into that magazine journalists tone of wry amusement.

title: The Sexagenarian Lothario
description: From the start, I made it clear to the man with whom I was involved that I cared deeply about being safe from sexually transmitted diseases. He assured me he would be loyal and agreed that if he strayed, he would not have unprotected sex. He lied. He had sex with three women without using condoms. He has agreed to get tested but not to tell the other women about one another. They all believe him to be in a monogamous relationship with me. Two of the women are our age (were in our 60s); the third is younger. I know all three women via Facebook. Do I have an ethical obligation to tell them about his activities? NAME WITHHELD

title: Noomi Rapace Arrives in Hollywood, by Way of Outer Space
description: In 2007, Noomi Rapace read for the part of Lisbeth Salander in the Swedish film version of The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo as a long-shot contender. Though she was a smart and seasoned actress who had worked in film as well as onstage, she was known mainly to Stockholm theatergoers. Her name barely surfaced in the lively public debate in Sweden over who should play Lisbeth, one of the most sought after film roles for a Swedish actress in recent memory. Moreover, the films director, Niels Arden Oplev, feared that Rapace was too attractive to portray the androgynous Lisbeth. After working through a scene with her, though, he changed his mind. When shes Lisbeth and you put a camera on her, and shes just sitting there looking at you, you think, Oh, my God, what is she going to do? he says. Theres an unpredictable, dark, dangerous energy that flows from her.

title: How Roland Barthes Gave Us the TV Recap
description: Among the brand-name French theorists of the mid-20th century, Roland Barthes was the fun one. (Foucault was the tough one, Derrida was the dreamy one, Lacan was the mysterious one  I like to imagine them sometimes as a black-turtlenecked, clove-smoking boy band called Hors de Texte, with the hit album Discipline n Punish.) Instead of constructing multivolume monuments of systematic thought, Barthes wrote short books built out of fragments. He was less interested in traditional coherence than in what he called jouissance: joy, surprise, adventure, pleasure  tantric orgasms of critical insight rolling from fragment to fragment. He proclaimed the death of the author and advocated a style of reading he referred to as writerly, in which readers work as active creators of a text. His critical metabolism ran unusually high: he would flit from subject to subject, defining new fields of interest (semiology, narratology) only to abandon them and leave others to do the busywork. He treated canonical French works with such unorthodox flair it drove conservative professors crazy. (Barthes first rose to prominence, or notoriety, thanks to the furor surrounding his early book about Racine.) In his inaugural lecture at the Collge de France  a sort of mission statement for the most prestigious academic post in the country  Barthes announced that he aspired above all to forget and to unlearn and proposed, as a kind of motto, no power, a little knowledge, a little wisdom and as much flavor as possible.

title: Who Made That Fly Swatter?
description: The first modern fly-destruction device was invented in 1900 by Robert R. Montgomery, an entrepreneur based in Decatur, Ill. Montgomery was issued Patent No. 640,790 for the Fly-Killer, a cheap device of unusual elasticity and durability made of wire netting, preferably oblong, attached to a handle. The material of the handle remained unspecified, but the netting was crucial: it reduced wind drag, giving the swatter a whiplike swing. By 1901, Montgomerys invention was advertised in Ladies Home Journal as a tool that kills without crushing and soils nothing, unlike, say, a rolled-up newspaper might.

title: Swallows, Amazons and Bolsheviks
description: Arthur Ransome is a beloved if minor figure in 20th-century letters. Generations of British readers have grown up with his Swallows and Amazons series of young adult novels, the first of which was published in 1930. In these 12 books, children on holiday in the Lake District of England and elsewhere occupy themselves sailing, camping, fishing and playing at pirates. Contemporary readers raised on blood sport in Panem may find the series tame, but the novels are charming and well told. In the few weeks that Ive contemplated the story of Ransomes life, every mention of his name to a British acquaintance has elicited a fond smile; from every American it has drawn a blank.

title: A Bloody Season
description: Hilary Mantel belongs to the same generation, roughly, as her compatriots Martin Amis, Julian Barnes and Ian McEwan, and is every bit their equal. Yet until Wolf Hall, her historical novel about the reign of Henry VIII, won the Man Booker Prize in 2009, she was much less well known in Britain, and in this country she barely registered at all. There may be nonliterary reasons for this: Mantel, who has been in ill health for much of her life, doesnt live in London, doesnt have a posh accent, doesnt travel much, doesnt regularly turn up on the chat shows. But another reason she isnt better known may be that shes a hard novelist to know, or at least to categorize: shes always reinventing herself. Her new book, Bring Up the Bodies, a sequel to Wolf Hall, is one of very few Mantel novels that bear much resemblance to any of the others.

title: Your Favorite Road Trips, Collected
description: As a companion to our recent road trip issue, we asked for your favorite U.S. routes, via Twitter, using the hashtag #faveroadtrip, and on Facebook. Here is a selection of your responses.

title: Thank You for Your Service, Sort Of
description: The familiar narrative of the American military experience traces the long, occasionally glorious, always bloody march from Lexington and Concord to Iraq and Afghanistan. Those Who Have Borne the Battle amends that account by adding two subjects of acute contemporary relevance: how the United States has raised the forces with which it wages war; and how, in the aftermath of battle, it cares for and remembers those who fought.

title: Set in Motion
description: In Peter Careys 12th novel, much depends on two voices. The first belongs to Catherine Gehrig, an horologist working at the (fictional) Swinburne Museum in London. We join her  she begins to speak to us  at the very moment she learns of the sudden death of her lover, Matthew Tindall, Head Curator of Metals at the same institution. For 13 years, Catherine has been Tindalls mistress. He was older, married, a father, but the pair of them lived a blissful, secret life together. Now Tindall is gone  felled by a heart attack on the Underground  and gone with him, in Catherines mind, is all good, all possibility of happiness.

title: State of Paradox
description: India and change were once virtual antonyms: old India hands returned again and again in large part because the subcontinent was so dependably different from the West. But since 1991, when a financial crisis forced Indias government to devalue the rupee, lower import barriers and relax controls on private investment, things have nearly reversed themselves. As the journalist Akash Kapur demonstrates in his lucid, balanced new book, India Becoming, his homeland now seems almost synonymous with change.

title: The Countercultures Mark Twain
description: Richard Brautigan burned through his short career like a rock star. Born in Tacoma, Wash., in 1935, he handed out poems on the streets of pre-hippie San Francisco, then caught an updraft in the zeitgeist with his 1967 novel, Trout Fishing in America, that even he couldnt have seen coming. Playfully elliptical, without plot or conventional characters, the book sold two million copies and transformed Brautigan into a libidinous Mark Twain for the new counterculture: a distinctly American voice that was so of its moment that it had nowhere to go but into a time capsule. By the time he ended his life in 1984, buffeted by drink and debt, he could not get an acceptable offer to publish his last novel. Thomas McGuane, a friend and sometime rival, summed up Brautigans arc succinctly: When the 1960s ended, he was the baby thrown out with the bath water. In life and death he was a moral fable for an era that invites easy moralizing.

title: Philippine Chief Justice Defends Finances at Impeachment Trial

title: Daniel Kahneman on the Trap of Thinking That We Know
description: The National Academy of Sciences did a great service to science early this week by holding a conference on The Science of Science Communication. A centerpiece of the two-day meeting was a lecture titled Thinking That We Know, delivered by Daniel Kahneman, the extraordinary behavioral scientist who was awarded a Nobel Prize in economics despite never having taken an economics class.

title: Gooding Lays Out Blue Chips, Including Maserati A6G and Bugatti 57C, Ahead of Pebble Beach
description: Gooding & Company of Santa Monica, Calif., released the first of what should be many teasers ahead of its auction event, scheduled for Aug. 18-19 during the collector-car festivities centered around Pebble Beach. And if these early glimpses are any indication, it should be an impressive catalog.

title: Found Poem Favorite | Seduction of Movement
description: This poem, the 10th of 11 winners in our Third Annual Found Poem Contest, comes from Sonal, 17, of Latham, N.Y.

title: Found Poem Favorite | Illinois Is Trying, It Really Is
description: This poem, the last of 11 winners from our Third Annual Found Poem Contest, comes from Aaron, 21, of Sioux Falls, S.D.

title: This Weeks Movies, May 25
description: In todays installment of This Weeks Movies, A. O. Scott looks at Will Smiths return to the big screen in Men in Black 3. Manohla Dargis offers a positive take on Wes Andersons latest film, Moonrise Kingdom, which had its premiere at the Cannes Film Festival. And Mr. Scott also looks at the French blockbuster that is making its way to the United States, The Intouchables. Full reviews and features about some of the other films opening this week can be found here.

title: Inmate Is Awarded $16 Million After Injury Led to Quadriplegia
description: Updated, 2:44 p.m. | The New York Court of Claims has awarded nearly $16 million to a state prison inmate, saying the man did not receive proper medical care from prison doctors after suffering a head injury in an inmate basketball game that ultimately led to his quadriplegia.

title: Look of The Moment | Liu Wen
description: The Look: Black Magic. The LBD is glamorously reinvented with an armor-like neckline, dramatic cut-outs and feathery fringe. Paired with accessories that echo these elements, its an absolute showstopper.

title: King of Thailand Makes Rare Visit Outside the Bangkok Area
description: BANGKOK  Amid widespread anxiety in Thailand about his health, King Bhumibol Adulyadej made a rare visit outside his hospital suite on Friday in what senior Thai officials described as a demonstration of his improved fitness.

title: The Dark Nooks in JPMorgans Fortress Balance Sheet
description: Banks get to play a fun game every quarter that could be called Guess the Value of Your Assets! JPMorgan Chase plays it more than its peers.

title: Students Tap Tribute to Bojangles
A Campaign Pitch Rekindles the Question: Just What Is Liberation Theology?
description: The year 2012 looks a lot like 2008: high unemployment, a candidate named Obama promising to do something about high unemployment, and the Giants beating the Patriots in the Super Bowl. And one more thing: conservatives are still ridiculing liberation theology. With the complicity of clueless pundits and incurious journalists, they are reducing an important theological movement of the past 40 years to an abusive sound bite.

title: On Our Radar: North Dakotas Oil Boom
description: Western North Dakotas oil boom has brought a surge in population, crime, air pollution, littering and health problems. Still, the toll is hard to measure. [OnEarth]

title: Drawing Warriors
description: For over a year, a group of artists has been visiting Walter Reed National Military Medical Center to document the experiences of wounded service members.

description: In Brooklyn, the non-profit, Art Start, offers young people with a blighted past a chance to become producers and performers of hip-hop.

title: Peninsula Prep Continues to Plan for the Fall Semester
Where a Hip-Hop Career Begins With a Court Sentence
description: Less than two years ago, Torey Baker was an 18-year-old high-school dropout facing prison time for robbery. When a judge in the Bronx sentenced him instead to six months in an alternative program, plus probation, he considered himself lucky. But he didnt know the half of it.

title: Book Review Podcast: Market Values
description: In the New York Times Book Review, David Leonhardt reviews Michael Linds Land of Promise, an economic history of the United States. Mr. Leonhardt writes:

title: Summer Reading: Between the Lines and Chomp
Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Regarding Paying Less for That Rental Car (May 20): There are advantages to renting a car through an airline. Ive linked several car rentals with recent reservations on British Airways, and not only was the rate cheaper than renting outright, but the combination flight and car puts you into a holiday category with much faster access to management, should something go wrong. This came in handy when an overseas flight was canceled and my car was automatically rebooked.DONNA ANTONHayle, England

title: More Laffering
description: I gather that one of the things we may be talking about tonight on Bill Maher is Art Laffers claim that low state tax rates are the key to economic growth. What should you think about that claim? Thats easy: its junk economics (pdf). See the data in the linked piece.

title: Winemaking Lures the Wealthy, but Not With Profits
description: IF there is one investment that has more to do with the heart than the head, its vineyards. It is also one that lends itself to jokes whose punch lines are always about losing money.

title: Morning Walkabout  5/25: Air Frances Plans and Tuscan Beer
description: Changes for Air France Air France is reducing reduce staff  for now, through attrition, not layoffs  and overhaul its flight operations. (Reuters, via The New York Times)

title: A Companys Stand for Gay Marriage, and Its Cost
description: In the months leading up to North Carolinas vote this month to ban gay marriage, most of the states business leaders were conspicuously silent. While some executives spoke out against it as individuals, not one Fortune 500 company based in North Carolina, including Bank of America, Duke Energy, VF Corporation and Lowes, opposed it.

title: Case Study | Armagnac in the Raw
description: Every distiller on the planet secretly wants to know the same thing: whats the next vodka? That is to say, whats going to be the next spirit to go from zero to 110 in the collective fancy of imbibers?

title: Will the U.S. Ever Apologize for Torturing an Innocent Man?
description: Earlier this week, the White House received a petition bearing 60,000 signatures demanding an apology to Maher Arar, a Canadian citizen who was the victim of one of the more outrageous abuses of power under President Bush.

title: Weekend Fare
description: From delicate macarons at FP Patisserie by Francois Payard (above) to Maine lobster-filled buns at Lukes Lobster, its opening weekend for more than 20 kiosks and stalls that fill the new Plaza Food Hall, which joins the Todd English Food Hall on the concourse level of the Plaza, 1 West 59th Street, in Midtown.

title: Voted Most Likely to Slaughter
description: READING The Slasher Movie Book is like paging through a 1980s yearbook from a high school for maniacs. Look how young Michael and Jason look! Oh, and theres Freddy in that sweater he wore, like, every day. And whatever happened to Chucky, that little monster?

title: Leading Off: Just the Two of Us
description: For a while, it looked like it could go seven, maybe even provide the N.B.A. playoffs with yet another upset of a top seed. The Indiana Pacers were feisty. Chris Bosh was out of the picture for the Heat, and Miami would be without the effective Udonis Haslem for Game 6. But then the series ended with a 12-point Miami victory on Thursday night  was the idea, or hope, of an epic series just an illusion?

title: Ukrainian Lawmakers Debate With Their Fists
description: Tensions were high in Ukraine on Friday as opposition lawmakers blocked a session of Parliament and the speaker called for new elections after a violent bout on the floor of the legislature that some observers have dubbed the rumble in the Rada.

title: The Challenge of Starting an Airline
description: Where are the start-up airlines?

title: As Memorial Day Nears, a Single Image That Continues to Haunt
description: Memorial Day. The unofficial kickoff to summer. Barbecues sizzling. Lawn sprinklers hissing. Local marching bands tooting out Sousa. Red, white, and blue bunting hanging from the porch railings, and on TV, someone begins a recitation of Lt. Col. John McCraes classic poem: In Flanders field, the poppies blow/Between the crosses row on row

title: Hints of a Bottom in Home Prices
description: The median price of existing homes sold in the United States in April was $178,000, the National Association of Realtors reported this week. While the monthly figures are volatile, that was the highest figure in 20 months, and the average of the 12 most recent figures has also begun to rise. Only in the two major Texas markets, however, are median prices now at or above where they were in 2006.

title: That Memorable Glass of Wine
description: The idea of owning a winery is enticing, especially for those with the wealth to indulge their passion. But, as Paul Sullivan notes in his Wealth Matters column this week, many wineries are not profitable. In fact, the definition of success in the business is breaking even, and most investors seem to accept the prospect of losing a manageable amount of money over many years.

title: Marijuana Meets Moonshine
description: SPEAKEASY-STYLE bars with secret entrances and Prohibition themes may be popular, but their illegality is only an illusion.
