description: Pedro Hernandez, a 51-year-old man who confessed to killing 6-year-old Etan Patz, could be arraigned by video from Bellevue Hospital.

title: Angels Reliever Piling Up Punchouts
description: 1:10 p.m. | Updated With Saturdays GameFrieri entered Saturday nights game against the Seattle Mariners with two outs in the eighth inning and struck out Miguel Olivo for his 20th strikeout in nine innings. He remained in the game for the ninth, striking out two more batters and earning his second save for the Angels.

description: The Boston-based private equity firm Thomas H. Lee Partners said on Friday that Scott A. Schoen had stepped down as vice chairman of the firm.

description: Kelly Slater, 11-time ASP World Champion, surfs around the globe.

description: Following last weeks Real Estate article about handling pest problems in New York City, readers submitted questions to our guest expert, Gary Braness, a pest management consultant and owner of Yosemite Environmental Services, about how to evict their unwanted roommates.

title: Kelly Slaters Wave-Finding Tips
description: AS a child, Kelly Slater surfed the modest swells near his home in Cocoa Beach, Fla.

title: J.R. Smith Arrested in Miami Beach
description: J.R. Smith, the Knicks guard with a history of legal troubles, was arrested in Miami Beach on Thursday for failing to appear in court on a traffic matter.

title: 4 Lisbon Restaurants Not to Miss
description: IF I say that I saw the future of Portuguese cooking in a martini glass, you might conclude that I was having drunken visions.

title: How I Fell for Lisbon
description: WE meet the places we wind up loving much the way we meet the people we fall for: on purpose and accidentally; at precisely the right moment and exactly the wrong time; in the highest of spirits and the lowest of moods.

title: Great Meals in Tokyos Tiny Outposts
description: ONE evening my French friend Pierre and I were browsing in a tiny embroidery store in the Shimo-Kitazawa neighborhood of Tokyo, a district of alleys and narrow streets not far from downtown, when a Japanese man in a chefs white jacket emerged from a door at the back, offering  of all things  slices of French baguette with hunks of rillettes on top. He held out the plate and encouraged us to try it.

title: Where Fish Outnumber Phones
description: IT was an hour before sunset on the remote Indonesian archipelago of Karimunjawa, a scattering of 27 tiny islands in the Java Sea, south of Borneo. My husband, Carsten, two children and I were on a turquoise outrigger canoe, paddling along the shoreline of the island of Menyawakan, which was lined with clusters of mangroves. Looking down into the clear, shallow water, we spotted a black sea cucumber that wound its sinuous way along the sand like a snake.

title: Restaurant Report: Boucherie, New Orleans
description: Last May, three gunshots ripped through Nathanial Zimets body, and, in a sense, the whole New Orleans food community. The young chef, who had transformed food truck fame into a successful restaurant called Boucherie, was critically wounded in an attempted robbery and, though he survived, the road to recovery was complicated by financial difficulties.

title: Beyond San Diegos Surf and Sun: Suds
description: DURING a recent trip to San Diego, it took a while for me to fully appreciate the extent of the citys beer obsession. There was the unexpectedly extensive tap list at the popular new ramen shop Underbelly, and the beer chitchat at the shoe store where I picked up some sandals. Then I tried to rent a surfboard in La Jolla and mentioned the reason for my trip, the sales guy handed me a slip of paper scrawled with the Web address for his beer review blog. Beer, it seems, has become as much a part of the San Diego identity as surf and sun.

title: Walking the Streets of a Nuclear Ghost Town
description: THE tour guide smiled as he repeated a gesture he had made many times before. Surrounded by a busload of tourists, he pulled out a cellphone-sized radiation reader.

title: Places and Faces of Lisbon
description: On a neighborhood crawl, discover a bookstore with catwalks and meet some of the citys people.

title: A Government Program That Could Improve the Economy
description: Considering how often the federal government is depicted as a huge, bloated, incomprehensible bureaucracy, its always refreshing when it does something forward-thinking and consumer-friendly. In the technology realm, it does that fairly often.

title: Missing People and Faded Posters
description: If your computer permits you to view these photographs in full-screen mode, we recommend it.

title: Shipyards Go Chic in Sweden
description: Where docks once went bust, video art is shown at a train station, and local herring is served up fresh.

title: Charting the Rise of the King of Retail
description: One thing that CNBCs profile of Millard (Mickey) Drexler, the chief executive of J. Crew, made clear on Thursday night is that his life is not the stuff of novels. True, he had what sounded like a lousy childhood, sleeping in the foyer of his familys Bronx apartment. And later, as a very rich man, he bought classy real estate, including Andy Warhols former compound at Montauk. And true, he got the boot from Gap, in 2002, after a mostly innovative 19-year run that included the creation of Old Navy. (According to a Wall Street Journal profile, Mr. Drexler collected around $350 million when he cashed out his Gap stake.)

title: Giant Lender in Spain Asks for Billions to Fend Off Collapse
description: MADRID  Spains banking crisis worsened Friday as the board of Bankia, the countrys biggest mortgage lender, warned that it would need an additional 19 billion euros ($23.88 billion), far beyond what the government estimated when it seized the bank and its portfolio of delinquent real estate loans earlier this month.

title: For Would-Be Cougars, the Prom Is a Good Start
description: RECENTLY, as I heard my daughter, a junior in high school, and her friends discuss their plans for the prom, I had a vaguely troubling thought: can a 16-year-old be a cougar?

title: Push Comes to Shove, and Punch, in Ukraine Parliament
description: MOSCOW  What began as a legislative debate over Ukraines official language policy escalated into a fist-swinging, clothes-ripping brawl between screaming, sweaty lawmakers that reverberated around the Internet on Friday, embellishing the countrys standing in the pantheon of parliamentary punchfests that are captured on camera.

title: Brooklyn School Backs Off Condom Giveaway on Prom Night
description: 8:15 p.m. | Updated  The principal of Bedford-Stuyvesant Preparatory High School told ABC that condoms would not be available after the dance, saying he did not want to violate Education Department policy.

title: Mainstreaming Sex Toys Through Better Design  and Conversation
description: Over at the Atlantics Web site, Andy Isaacson tells the story of the sex-toy company Jimmyjane (with entertaining diversions into the history of commercial products for genital stimulation). Steve Jobs helped us all recognize the benefits of good design in daily life, but it was nonetheless surprising to read about the entrepreneurial epiphany ofJimmyjanes founder, Ethan Imboden. He was at a sex-products expo, surrounded by cheesy, blinking, tawdry junk, when he realized that he was looking at the only category of consumer product that had yet to be touched by design. . . . The category had been isolated by the taboo that surrounded it. I figured, I can transcend that.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: A Teenagers Obsessions
description: The first volume of The Flowers of Evil, by Shuzo Oshimi, enters our manga best-seller list this week at No. 3. It tells the story of Takao Kasuga, a teenage student with two obsessions: a female classmate and the poetry of Baudelaire. The books plot sounds creepy: Takao takes home the gym clothes of his crush, Nanako Saeki, but he doesnt get away with his theft. Another girl in his class witnesses the event and blackmails Takao to do her bidding. On its Web site, Vertical, the publisher of the book, describes The Flowers of Evil as a romantic comedy, but reviews of the work suggest something more complex.

title: Parent Un-Trapped | When Advice Goes Viral
description: Anyone whos been at a dinner party where the conversation has stuck to the topic of strollers  Uppababy or Bugaboo? City Mini or Bob?  knows that moms love to talk kid gear. Sounds extremely dull, but it can be riveting if youre about to have a child yourself and wondering if its crazy or necessary to buy a $300 organic crib mattress, and, if you do, is it a good idea to get the babys bed at Ikea for a hundred bucks?

title: Will Someone Please Say Youre Fired?
description: The Romney campaign has a new offer out: Donate 3 bucks for a chance to dine with the Donald (and Mitt Romney, who gets second billing). Its not clear whether the winner will really get a tte--tte--coiffure, or just an invitation to a fundraiserlike the recent Obama campaign raffle for a seat at a $15 million George Clooney event.

title: In White Plains, Tesla Motors Sells the Sizzle and Maybe a Car or Two
description: WHITE PLAINS  I hope we never sell a car here, George Blankenship, vice president of worldwide sales and ownership experience at Tesla Motors, said as he gestured Thursday around the companys newest storefront. The space officially opened here Friday at the Westchester, an upscale shopping mall. Our goal instead is to interact with people when theyre looking at new things in the mall and not necessarily in the market for a car. The focus is on answering the many questions they have about electric vehicles and the Tesla Model S.

title: Living In | Glen Oaks, Queens
description: Apartments make up most of the housing stock in this Queens neighborhood built on property once owned by William K. Vanderbilt.

title: N.C.A.A. Preview: For Florida, a Rematch With Meaning
description: The Florida lacrosse team made history on Saturday with its 15-2 win over Penn State as it advanced to its first Final Four and became just the second team to ever do so as a program in its third year of existence.

title: Could You Spend Summer (More) Smartphone Free?
description: My older daughter had her school years last performance assembly this morning, and while the children were lining up, I scanned down the row: parent after parent, including me and my husband, with smartphones in hand, skimming e-mails with our younger children milling about our chairs. (Moments later, all phones shifted to camera mode, and all hands went up as the show began  synchronized parenting.)

title: Sweden 1912: What a Trip
description: One hundred years ago the summer Olympics were held in Stockholm. As we count down the days to London 2012, well take a look back at what was happening at the Games a century ago.

title: Put One Foot in the Past, Point One to Tomorrow
description: GROWING up in Colorado, Jodee Nimerichter was a serious bunhead: a driven young ballet dancer, whose dedication had landed her in a conservatory program. And then one day, in 1992, for reasons she still cant fully explain, she quit. Full stop.

title: Dimon Agrees to Testify, Without Committing to Specific Date
description: Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, has agreed to testify before a Congressional committee in June to discuss the banks recent multibillion-dollar trading loss.

title: N.C.A.A. Preview: Can the Orange Beat the Gators Again?
description: When Syracuse and Florida met for the first time on March 3 in Gainesville, Fla., the matchup didnt exactly look like a Final Four preview.

description: ARE government-imposed limits on borrowing a good thing?

title: Composing a More Useful Future
description: WHEN economic waters are rough  or perhaps just to shake things up in times of stagnation  musical institutions try to redefine themselves, sharpen their sense of mission and do some image tweaking. That can be hard when your mission is already unusual and clearly defined. But the American Composers Orchestra, which has been putting a spotlight on (mostly contemporary) American music since 1977, has lately been reinventing itself as a hybrid performing ensemble and service organization.

title: Unplugged and Fully Recharged
description: MIAMI BEACH

title: A Weekend Visit to History
description: AMERICAN fashion, like many Americans, is torn between the past and the future. While designers are swaddling and coddling customers in fondly retooled visions of yesteryear  just pick a decade  some designers are trying to take a blindfolded whack at the future. Some hit the piata, and some hit the wall.

title: From Punk Rock Snarl to Song Circle Leader
description: BEARDED, willowy and often dressed in white, Alexander Ebert, the frontman of the folk-rock act Edward Sharpe and the Magnetic Zeros, has a hippie leader vibe. It helps that his bands music feels like a community singalong, with group harmonies and whistling, snaps and hand claps as percussion. Mr. Ebert started the band in California with the singer Jade Castrinos; their romance was captured on their 2009 debut album, Up From Below, in tracks like the hit single Home.

title: French Opens Defending Champion Remains Under the Radar
description: Leading Maria Sharapova, 6-4, 4-0, in the final of the Italian Open on Sunday, Li Na seemed poised to enter the French Open  where in 2011 she became Chinas first major singles champion on a hot streak. But then things fell apart.

title: Management Buyouts Can Be Too Cozy
description: Some corporate decisions leave you wondering what the board might have been thinking at the time. That seems to be the case with the board of Venoco, a California oil company that is the subject of a proposed $770 million management buyout.

title: Brooklyn School Reverses Decision to Give Out Condoms at Prom
Police in Azerbaijan Arrest Protesters at Eurovision Rally
description: BAKU, Azerbaijan  About 50 antigovernment demonstrators were arrested Friday evening in Baku while trying to stage a flash rally in the city center, as opponents of President Ilham Aliyev sought to use the Eurovision Song Contest to draw international attention to human rights abuses.

title: A Detectives Early Search for Etan
description: Visit msnbc.com for breaking news, world news, and news about the economy

title: May 27  June 2
description: THE Accademia Carrara in Bergamo holds one of Italys most distinguished collections of Venetian painting. And while it is closed for restoration, some of its choicest items are on the road. The itinerary brings 15 pictures to the Metropolitan Museum of Art in  BELLINI, TITIAN AND LOTTO: NORTH ITALIAN PAINTINGS FROM THE ACCADEMIA CARRARA, BERGAMO.

title: Students Complain About New Dress Code at Stuyvesant
Forget the London Games, Try Kafkarate in Prague
description: The Olympic torch is on its way to London, but a Czech advertising campaign is set on getting Britons to flee their homeland this August and instead take part in the Prague Games, with events including Kafkarate and Heavyweight Shopping.

title: DealBooks Week in Review: Questions of Fair Play
description: In Washington, lawmakers and regulators are scrutinizing the fairness of Facebooks I.P.O. process. In New York, a prosecutor continues his broad campaign to end insider trading. A look back on our reporting of the past weeks highs and lows in finance.

title: N.C.A.A. Preview: For Duke, Faceoffs Will Be a Factor
description: Meeting for the third time this season and the sixth time in the past two years, Duke and Maryland are hardly strangers to one another.

title: Klinsmann Trims U.S. Roster to 23
description: United States Coach Jurgen Klinsmann trimmed four players from his 27-man training camp roster Friday, streamlining the national team for its coming five-game, 18-day burst of exhibitions and World Cup qualifiers.

title: A Veteran Stabilizes the Young Sixers
description: The 76ers will look to extend their remarkable postseason run on Saturday when they take on the Celtics in Game 7 in Boston.

title: What Scares Oren Peli?
description: For Oren Peli, the filmmaker who helped usher in a new wave of found footage horror movies after the success of his first feature, Paranormal Activity, the scariest devil is the one you dont know. His latest project, Chernobyl Diaries, follows young travelers who participate in what the film calls extreme tourism. A tour guide drives the group into the city of Pripyat, the former home to workers at the Chernobyl nuclear reactor, a place that was evacuated after the disaster. The travelers, of course, learn that the town isnt completely deserted.

title: On the Market in New York City

title: On the Market in the Region
description: A five-bedroom expanded Cape in Redding, Conn., and a five-bedroom 1920 colonial in Bayonne, N.J.

title: Less-Fuss Paella Arrives in Time for Summer
description: PAELLA, the classic rice dish from Spain, is considered picnic food  a one-dish meal prepared over a fire at an outdoor party like our hamburger cookout. It is also cooked indoors, but always in a flat steel paellera or in an earthenware cazuela. The main rules are to cook the rice uncovered and, unlike risotto, not to stir once the simmering has begun.

title: Big Ticket | Sold for $14,380,000
description: The last of three thoroughly modern new town houses on Downing Street in the West Village, changing hands for $14.38 million, was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

description: He inhaled.

title: N.C.A.A. Preview: Maryland on a Mission
description: John Tillman has used three words to consistently motivate his Maryland mens lacrosse team this season: Why not us?

title: A Paella Picnic, With Favas
description: In this weeks City Kitchen, Im making paella, the indoor version. Though classically cooked outdoors over a fire, its not a hard and fast rule, and what with the current bout of rainy weather, at my house both the picnic and the cooking happened inside one recent Sunday.

title: XOXO Aims to Be an Alternative to South by Southwest
description: Anyone who has ever trekked down to Austin for the Interactive portion of South by Southwest, a jumble of talks about technology, parties and music performances, knows that while it is an amazing confluence of the best and brightest in the start-up world, it can also be something of a nightmare to navigate.

title: Warren Faces New Allegations on Ancestry
description: 6:10 p.m. | Updated Elizabeth Warrens Senate campaign in Massachusetts had hoped the controversy over her ancestry would die down after a poll this week indicated that voters thought it was insignificant.

title: Senate Panel Mildly Rebukes Coburn for Role in Ensign Scandal
description: 4:30 p.m. | Updated The Senate Ethics Committee has smacked the hand of Senator Tom Coburn, Republican of Oklahoma, for his minor role in the sordid scandal that ended the career of John Ensign, the former Republican senator from Nevada.

title: Where Etan Patz Walked, Many More Eyes
description: Could it happen now? Could someone sinister pluck a small child off that same street at that same hour on the same day, so that he vanished into the ether for 33 years?

title: Now Coveted: A Walkable, Convenient Place
description: WALKING isnt just good for you. It hasbecome an indicator of your socioeconomic status.

title: Duck Dynasty Also a Power in the Ratings
description: The Robertsons, a down-home Louisiana family and the stars of the A&E reality series Duck Dynasty, may have earned millions of dollars from their duck calling business, Duck Commander, but now they can also claim to have drawn in a far more elusive prey: television viewers.

title: When Doctors Grieve
description: MY mother died of breast cancer in 2005 after living with the disease for nearly 20 years. Her oncologist, whom I knew from the time I was 9 years old, was her doctor for most of that time. I practically grew up in the hospital, and my family felt quite close to the health care providers, especially the oncologist. After my mother died I wondered if the feeling was mutual.

title: Cannes Film Festival: The Actor as Literal Shape-Shifter
description: 8:07 a.m. | Updated  CANNES, France  In its purest form, cinema is an art of motion, and no contemporary performer better expresses that truth than the French actor Denis Lavant. A former acrobat with a wiry frame and puckish features, Mr. Lavant is a one-of-a-kind screen presence who brings to his roles both a Chaplinesque pathos and eruptions of pure kinetic energy: think of his giddy moment of dance-floor release at the end of Clarie Deniss Beau Travail (1999) or the lurching, pirouetting sprint he breaks into as David Bowies Modern Love comes on the radio in Leos Caraxs Mauvais Sang (1986).

title: N.C.A.A. Preview: Loyola Is Still the 1
description: It has been a great year for Loyola (Md.) athletics. The mens basketball team made the N.C.A.A. tournament for the first time since 1994. The womens lacrosse team won the Big East for the second consecutive season.

title: In Europe, Divorce and Separation Become a Burden for Struggling Fathers
description: MILAN  The pain of Europes economic crisis is being felt sharply by a new class of people: separated and divorced men who end up impoverished or on the streets as they struggle to maintain themselves while keeping up child support and alimony payments.

title: Facebooks Royal Wedding
description: PALO ALTO, Calif.

title: At a Reunion, the Glamorous Faces of a New York Beer
description: Here is a question that no one asks of a Miss Subways: Does a Miss Rheingold miss Rheingold?

title: The Invisible Art: A Womans Touch Behind the Scenes
description: THAT the Cannes Film Festival chose not to include any work by female directors in its competition this year created a mini-scandal. But it obscured a couple of other points about the state of women in film. For instance, only 2 of the 22 features in question were shot by female cinematographers. On the other hand, a full third of the movies were cut by female editors.

title: Just Call It a Pre-Prenup
description: A BREAKTHROUGH occurred last November on the CBS comedy The Big Bang Theory. Sheldon Cooper, the commitment-wary physicist, ramped up his courtship of Amy Fowler, the skittish neurobiologist.

title: With Andretti, Baltimore Hopes Third Times a Charm for Grand Prix
description: BALTIMORE  With three months before the green flag was scheduled to drop, it seemed the Baltimore Grand Prix was in an irreversible skid.

title: A Camaros Legacy: Testing the Pack Alpha of Muscle Cars
description: THE 2012 Chevrolet Camaro ZL1 has a heavy load to bear. Its model designation, borrowing the General Motors option code for one of the most storied V-8 engines of the muscle cars glory days, sets lofty expectations among those who lived through Detroits horsepower wars.

title: Muscles on Its Muscles, but Nuance in Its Soul
description: ALTON, Va.

title: Brawn, With a Touch of Ballet
description: Sure its heavy, and no, it doesnt come cheap. But the Camaro ZL1 is light on its feet, delivering on-track performance that sets it apart from the average muscle car.

title: Berlusconi, Hinting at Ambition, Urges Direct Vote for President
description: ROME  After months out of the spotlight, former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi of Italy made a rare public appearance on Friday to call for an overhaul of the countrys Constitution that would allow Italians to directly elect the nations president, instead of letting Parliament make that choice, as is now the case.

title: Diaper Duty, Divided and Decided: Sign Here.
description: If you could sit down with your new love interest, romantic partner or spouse, and create an operating manual for your relationship, what would the rules be? Would writing them down give them more gravitas than a conversation over a glass of wine? Would you consult a couples counselor? Even use lawyers?

title: Devils Get High Praise From Elias on Eve of Game 6
description: NEWARK  The greatest Devils teams in franchise history dominated the N.H.L. about a decade ago, rising to prominence with a stifling neutral zone trap, an impenetrable goalie and opportunistic forwards that thrived on the counterattack. It was a group that, as Patrik Elias fondly remembered, knew if we just played good enough that wed beat anybody, and the Devils often did, playing for the Stanley Cup three times in four seasons and winning it twice, in 2001 and 2003.

title: Idol Winner Had Surgery for Kidney Stones
description: Phillip Phillips, this years winner of American Idol on Fox, underwent eight surgical procedures to remove kidney stones during the competition, his father told People magazine. Some references were made to Mr. Phillips health problems during the show, and he often appeared wan, but his father, who is also named Phillip Phillips, said his son, a 21-year-old pawnshop worker, was suffering more than he let on. Theyve just seen a glimpse of what Phillip can do, the father said. We cant wait to get him well and 100 percent and really see how he can perform. The singer will undergo another surgery in the next few weeks to reconstruct his kidneys, then go on tour with the rest of the finalists on the show. The recoverys probably two to four weeks, the elder Phillip Phillips said. Mr. Phillips, an indie rocker from Leesburg, Ga., with a rootsy vocal style and solid guitar skills, won the competition on Wednesday night, besting Jessica Sanchez, a 16-year-old singing prodigy from Chula Vista, Calif.

title: A Car Hoard, Pruned to a Collection, Gets a Fitting Home
description: TACOMA, Wash.

title: A Beacon for Car Lovers, Shining in the Northwest
description: The $65 million LeMay museum in Tacoma, Wash., which opens on Saturday, hopes to become a new center of car culture in America.

description: A clip of the Swedish actresss performance in the film adaptation of Stieg Larssons novel.

description: In addition to creating a popular restaurant, Fat Radishs youthful duo have kept catering and event design in the spotlight.

description: Latin jazz at its best enacts a kind of diplomacy, a dialogue between two separate but related parties. The trumpeter and conguero Jerry Gonzalez has long been an emissary in the field, equally fluent in hard bop and the music of the Afro-Caribbean diasporas, and given to reconciling the two.

title: As Apps Move Into Cars, So Do More Distractions
description: THERE have been the sexy horsepower wars and dull best-in-class fuel-efficiency battles. Now automakers are fighting an undeclared, escalating war over in-dash apps, worrying regulators about even more distracted driving.

description: Only after I became a parent, P. writes, did my spiritual self matter to anyone but me.

description: David Carr on why a city like New Orleans is losing a daily newspaper.

title: Admissions Letters for Gifted and Talented Programs Go Out
A Christmas Story Musical Inching Closer to Broadway
description: A musical adaptation of A Christmas Story, based on the Jean Shepherd stories of the 1960s and the popular 1983 film, is aiming to open on Broadway later this year for a limited run through Thanksgiving and Christmas, a spokesman for the production confirmed on Friday.

title: Yes, Even Fashionistas Have to Eat
description: THE artist John Currin was mid-speech at the Art Production Fund gala last month when platters of roasted Norwich Meadows Farm heirloom carrots and barbecued Piedmontese beef brisket suddenly appeared from behind a white wall, carried by a brigade of artisanally handsome L-train-esque waiters.

title: Audio: Veteran Times-Picayune Reporter on How Staff Heard the News
description: Bruce Nolan covers religion for The Times-Picayune, the New Orleans newspaper where he has spent most of his career. He has served as a reporter, a suburban bureau chief and assistant city editor. In that time, he has worked on hundreds of stories, including many about Hurricane Katrina and the Gulf oil spill.

title: BMW Unveils Zagato Coupe at Villa dEste
description: Befitting its role as the primary sponsor of the Concorso dEleganza, BMW unveiled a conceptual coupe on Friday at the vintage-car event, held at Villa dEste, on Lake Como in northern Italy.

title: Caramel Sauce
description: Melissa Clark shows how to make easy, delicious caramel sauce at home.

title: A Famous Couples Tale Revives a Noted Pairing
description: ALMOST a quarter of a century has passed since the director Philip Kaufman last worked with the film editor Walter Murch. In 1988, when their Unbearable Lightness of Being was released, the Soviet Union was still in existence (the film memorably depicts the 1968 Soviet invasion of Prague) and Pauline Kael was still the film critic at The New Yorker, where she gave it a rave review.

title: Inside a Rock Stars Skin, or a 120-Pound Costume
description: For their shared program at Danspace Project, Andrew Dinwiddie and Michelle Ellsworth have scrutinized the act of transformation in two virtuosic solos. Mr. Dinwiddie is a rock star who turns into an object of worship in Farewell Tour. And Ms. Ellsworth, in a 120-pound, 5-foot-wide and 9-foot-high costume in The Pythagodress, becomes a wearable, portable set.

title: Sassy Rap and Afro-Brazilian Beats
description: Rye Rye

title: Like Its 1999? The Sixers Bring Back Some Memories
description: BOSTON  Watching the Philadelphia 76ers push the Boston Celtics to the limit in their Eastern Conference semifinal playoff series harks back to another team that defied the odds more than once: the 1999 Knicks.

title: With a Job Like His, Youd Brood Too
description: FOURTEEN years before Lisbeth Salander tortured her legal guardian, and 16 years before Sarah Lund began badgering her superiors in the Copenhagen police department, Kurt Wallander ran over a rabbit.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Kickstarters Hidden Failures and Blaming Facebook
description: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Friday. See more here.

title: Rhubarb, It Turns Out, Can Be a Sweetie
description: SOME ice cream is perfectly smooth, with nary a nut or chocolate fleck to distract your tongue from its voluptuous texture. Then there is ice cream akin to a sundae in a pint container: so full of nutty brittles, veins of fudge and chunks of cookie or brownie that the ice cream itself becomes pretty much secondary.

title: Just a Minute: Why New Orleans?
description: David Carr discusses why New Orleans and Michigan are on the leading edge of corporate experiments to end daily print newspaper publication in favor of Web-based news sites.

title: New Victory Season Will Include Opera Adapted From Philip Pullman Novel
description: The 2012-13 season for the New Victory Theater, an Off Broadway presenter that specializes in productions for all ages, will include a new opera based on a novel by Philip Pullman (author of the trilogy His Dark Materials) as well as two new productions drawn from Shakespeares work.

title: Bergmans Bittersweet Ode to Youths Sunset
description: THE film Summer With Monika, released in 1953, isnt among the best known or most representative works of Ingmar Bergman, but it may be his most influential. The story of two working-class teenagers from Stockholm  Monika (Harriet Andersson), who works in a grocery store and lives with her brawling, heavy-drinking parents in a crowded apartment, and Harry (Lars Ekborg), a shy stock clerk in a porcelain factory whose home life with his widowed father is tense and silent  it was Bergmans 12th feature as a director.

title: Easy-to-Swallow Ballet for the Masses, With a Broadway Perspective
description: In 2004, just before New York City Ballet first presented Double Feature, a two-part homage to silent films by the Broadway choreographer Susan Stroman, Peter Martins told The New York Times that he had hired Ms. Stroman because he wanted to sell tickets. Sometimes you get what you pay for. On Thursday the audience at the David H. Koch Theater greeted the return of Double Feature with great enthusiasm.

title: A Sweet Primer
description: This weeks column features rhubarb ice cream shot through with pockets of homemade caramel sauce.

title: The Week in Pictures for May 25
description: Subjects include the wedding of the City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn; crane operators at 1 World Trade Center; and an uncertain future for the Maid of the Mist at Niagara Falls.

title: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Afghanistan, Egypt, Washington and New York.

title: Reviewing the Chevrolet Camaro ZL1
description: In Sundays Automobiles section, Ezra Dyer reviews the 2012 Chevrolet Camaro ZL1, a throwback piece of American muscle capable of romping through the quarter -mile in under 12 seconds.

title: Jaunt Through Fallout Zone Goes (Shock!) Awry
description: Most good horror movies are rich with subtext. You could read Psycho as an Oedipal parable, say, or George Romeros Dawn of the Dead as a sendup of voracious consumerism. Chernobyl Diaries? You could conceivably consider it a warning about nuclear power, but its really about the dangers of seeking adventure in a foreign country and trusting former Soviets. But please, dont give it that much thought.

title: Cannes Chorus
description: Vampire makeup, pinched breasts and an onslaught of sequins sometimes define Cannes fashion, as it does this year. Group pictures of actresses are almost blinding, and tans under the hot lights look repellant. For this reason, minimally fussy gowns in sharp colors look best, like those on Kristen Stewart and Nicole Kidman (when does she ever look bad?), as do the short-and-skippy dresses worn by Lily Cole and Diane Kruger. Jeremy Irons looks like a musty boarder in his long jacket and vest, while Brad Pitt nicely surprises with a full Cleveland in his tan Gucci suit.

title: Before Chinas Transition, a Wave of Nationalism
description: BEIJING  As an English-speaking talk show host on China Central Television, Yang Rui likes to think of himself as a bridge between East and West.

description: Nice, France

description: When Barry Rigal read last Mondays column, he wrote to say it reminded him of this diagramed deal, which occurred during the World Transnational Mixed Teams Championship in Rhodes, Greece, in 1996.

title: Icahn Discloses Stake in Chesapeake Energy
description: Carl C. Icahn has made his latest fight public.

title: Looking Directly at Lifes Decline
description: CANNES, France  The Austrian director Michael Haneke has made an art of exploiting audience discomfort. In a sense his new film, Amour, continues in that vein by staring down the least palatable of subjects: aging, sickness and death. But the universal specter of mortality has brought with it a tenderness seldom seen in Mr. Hanekes cool, analytical cinema, and the film remains the closest thing to a consensus favorite among critics at the Cannes Film Festival here.

title: The G.O.P.s Spending Addiction
description: If Congress cuts federal spending, does that help or hurt an economy in recession? The Republicans say it helps. What if Congress cuts federal defense spending? In that case, the Republicans say it hurts.

title: Katie Finneran Will Be Miss Hannigan in Annie Revival
description: Little girls of Annie, beware: Broadways new Miss Hannigan knows a thing or two about stealing scenes, no matter how cute the moppets are. Katie Finneran, the two-time Tony Award winner  most recently for playing a barfly in the 2010 revival of Promises, Promises  will play the alcoholic orphanage manager in the revival of the musical Annie that begins performances in October.

description: More Photographs

title: Hugging the Seine: Fashion, Design Restaurants and Club
description: Paris has many places to take in contemporary art, including the avant-garde Pompidou Center, the trendy Gat Lyrique and the newly renovated Palais de Tokyo. But the city was missing an all-encompassing hub for fashion and design until last month, when Les Docks, Cit de la Mode et du Design (34, quai dAusterlitz, 13th Arrondissement) was officially inaugurated.

title: Criminal Complaint Against Pedro Hernandez
description: Pedro Hernandez is charged with murder in the second degree in the death of Etan Patz.

title: Why Cisco Stopped Making Tablets
description: Cisco announced on Thursdaythat it would be discontinuing its Cius tablet. Cisco cited the failure of the product on a market transition, which is a good way to describe the reality: people didnt buy it.

title: Apple Strikes Back at Government E-Book Lawsuit
description: A few days ago, Apple filed a formal response to the antitrust lawsuit filed by the Department of Justice in April against it and several book publishers.

description: Madison Square Park held its childrens fair on May 19 with music, games, popcorn and cotton candy. The children, in their summery hats, resembled butterflies.

description: Freelance reporter revisits an Army helicopter crash in Afghanistan on May 30, 2007, that took the lives of seven soldiers.

description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: Hiring Woodson, the Knicks Make the Logical Move
description: The historically predictable company move would have been to try to lure Phil Jackson back to New York with a vault of Dolan dollars and the seat that belonged to his mentor, Red Holzman. But the lessons of nearly four tumultuous and championship-free decades tell us that Fridays official hiring of Mike Woodson, the interim coach and another longtime Holzman admirer, made more sense.

description: Watch out, Britain! Im on my way, and the Telegraph says that Im a false Messiah with Satanic intent.

title: After Digs at His Predecessor, Obama Will Host Bushes at White House
description: President Obama will host former President George W. Bush and his wife, Laura, at the White House next week for the unveiling of their official portraits, bringing the two presidents together at a time when Mr. Obama has been castigating Mr. Bushs record on the campaign trail.

title: Climbing Into the Future, or Just Into an Artists Whimsy
description: Participatory art is all the rage these days, an ever-expanding category and, increasingly, a means for museums to signal their hipness to the younger, broader audiences they so desperately want to attract. Nothing says accessible like something you interact with physically.

description: The beauty highlights at the 65th Cannes Film Festival, from nude and unfussy makeup to carefully coifed updos.

description: To the Editor:

title: Hope and Frustration in New U.S. Effort to Help Homeowners
description: As mortgage rates have hit one record low after another, millions of homeowners have been forced to watch, longingly, from the sidelines. They havent had the option of refinancing because sliding home values pushed their mortgages underwater, meaning they owe more than their homes are worth. The banks would just not work with them.

title: Have You Tried to Refinance Your Underwater Mortgage?
description: This weeks Your Money column looks at the governments latest attempt to extend a life jacket to homeowners who want to refinance but whose mortgages are underwater  in other words, they owe more than their homes are worth.

title: Glamour in Cannes
description: Celebrities, including Diane Kruger and Heidi Klum, sparkled at the Cannes Film Festival.

title: Prime Burger, Where the 60s Were a Side Order, to Close
description: If youre a fan of Prime Burger at 5 East 51st Street  and that would put you in the company of approximately half of New York, to judge from Fridays lunchtime crowd  you should come Saturday for a burger and curly fries in your booth for one. You may never again have the chance.

title: Albanys Unkindest Cut of All
description: Albany

title: New YouTube Channel Aims to Add Context to Activist Videos
description: A new YouTube channel devoted to human rights was introduced this week to help raise awareness and provide context for the growing number of videos created by citizen journalists and activists all over the world, YouTube announced in a blog post.

title: One More Reason to Fear the Beach
description: As if we didnt have enough probably fictitious but possibly real beings to worry about. All over basic cable, people are searching for Bigfoot, hunting down ghosts, looking for extraterrestrials. Now, it turns out, we need to add mermaids to the list.

title: The Call of the Wild Salome, and Other Musical Temptations From Cleveland
description: All this season in New York, opera lovers and longtime admirers of the storied Cleveland Orchestra had been eagerly anticipating the concert performance of Strausss Salome at Carnegie Hall that finally took place on Thursday night. This was a chance to hear Strausss incandescent score played by that great orchestra from the stage of the acoustically glorious Carnegie Hall, with the stunning dramatic soprano Nina Stemme in the title role, and the powerhouse bass-baritone Eric Owens as Jochanaan.

title: Have an Enjoyable Memorial Day Weekend
description: Wheels will be taking a short break in observance of Memorial Day, but well return on Tuesday, May 29, with our regular coverage. Whatever mode of transport conveys you to your destination, the editors and contributors at Wheels wish you safe and happy travels this holiday weekend.

title: Seeing HBOs Girls Without Buying a Television
description: Would the Girls character Hannah Horvath, a young Brooklynite without much cash, subscribe to HBO? Or would she rely on her friends?

title: Leaving a Dark Day Behind
description: INDIANAPOLIS  As usual, thousands of race fans found seats, mostly in the shade, on a hazy Friday morning at Indianapolis Motor Speedway, parking their coolers to watch the final practice session before the Indianapolis 500 on Sunday. Dario Franchitti was the fastest.

title: Inconveniences Aside, a Picnic Can Be a Delight
description: A GOOD picnic is a challenge. It can be done, but like tying a bow tie or driving a tractor, it doesnt come naturally. A picnic sounds wonderful, but somehow, when the blanket is spread over rocky, wet earth, and the warmed potato salad is opened up like an invitation to the flies, when the sea gulls surround you, when you drop your sandwich in the grass, or lightning crackles overhead, the whole thing sours.

title: Liukin Returns, a Veteran at 22
description: CHICAGO  It was just practice, just two hours of run-throughs for Saturdays U.S. Classic gymnastics meet, but Nastia Liukin, the reigning Olympic champion in the all-around, was still anxious.

title: In Vatican Whodunit, a Punch Line of a Suspect
description: ROME  A mysterious source named Maria. A room furnished with a single chair where sensitive Vatican documents are turned over to an investigative journalist at regular meetings. The arrest of the popes butler. Perhaps the greatest breach in centuries in the wall of secrecy that surrounds the Vatican.

title: Intensity Cools After 2 More Draws in Chess Championship
description: After the fireworks and decisive results of Games 7 and 8, the world chess championship match between Viswanathan Anand, the titleholder, and Boris Gelfand, lapsed back into relative calm as Games 9 and 10 were drawn on Wednesday and Thursday.

title: Yankees Sign Maine, the Former Mets Right-Hander
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  The Yankees signed the former Met right-handed pitcher John Maine to a minor league contract on Friday. He will join their extended spring training program in Tampa, Fla.

title: After a Summer Hike, a Delicious Reward
description: SUMMER is the time to get outdoors and immerse yourself in nature, and hiking makes that as easy as lacing up your boots. The three parks below provide varied enough terrain to suit most levels of experience. The pleasure of walking through beautiful landscape is its own reward, but you will also have earned a delicious meal, on or off the trail, so recommendations for provisions and dining accompany each entry.

title: A Challenging Bounty for the Clean-Plate Club
description: IF you plan to go to LAcqua Ristorante, a homey little Italian place in downtown Freehold, I hope you have the experience I did on the second of my two visits. If you do, you will find good food, nicely presented by attentive servers. And you will manage to avoid the excesses that marred my first meal here.

title: Hendrick Reclaims Spot Atop Nascar in Big Week
description: CONCORD, N.C.  Rick Hendrick jammed his leg into the No. 48 Chevrolet, straddled the drivers side windowsill and held on for dear life on a precarious victory ride down the front stretch at Charlotte Motor Speedway last Saturday night.

title: In Brooklyn, Taste of L.I. Wines
description: Geographically speaking, Long Island begins just across the Brooklyn Bridge from Manhattan. And Brooklyn was the setting for a showcase of East End wines this month, along with a few from the Finger Lakes and the Hudson Valley.

title: Bloomberg Added Home No. 11 in 2011, His Tax Records Show
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg may rule New York City, but he is also expanding his empire in Westchester County.

title: TimesCast Politics: Romney Team Leader
description: Michael Barbaro reports on Mitt Romneys biggest fan, Jim Wilson, who has become an unexpectedly valuable campaign asset.

title: A Culinary Homage to an East End Industry
description: THE North Fork Oyster Company, a restaurant that opened about a year ago in Greenport, is an homage to the oyster industry on the East End; there are more than two dozen oyster farms in the area, according to the executive chef, Alex Algieri. Diners approaching the restaurant see a chef in the window opening oysters and otherwise tending the raw bar.

title: Death on the Moor, Played for Laughs
description: The moors  by which we mean the open wastelands, not Othello and Emperor Macrinus  really need a P.R. person. Whenever they appear in literature, film or the theater, it seems, it is always nighttime, frighteningly dark and at least potentially stormy. And some wrongly accused man is running in terror for his life. Or the ghosts of young lovers are meeting to lament their failure to find happiness in life. Or a huge, mysterious, unseen, baronet-murdering dog that is said to glow like phosphorous is howling into the midnight air.

title: Shipwrecked on a Magical Island, Windswept by Words
description: The gloomy caves, turbulent seas and wafting breezes of a faraway island cocoon the inhabitants, human and otherwise, of Shakespeares last great play, The Tempest. But in the vivid new Hartford Stage production, the director, Darko Tresnjak,  has banished this natural world and replaced it with an ocean of words, words, words.

title: Plantations, Prisons and Profits
description: Louisiana is the worlds prison capital. The state imprisons more of its people, per head, than any of its U.S. counterparts. First among Americans means first in the world. Louisianas incarceration rate is nearly triple Irans, seven times Chinas and 10 times Germanys.

title: If Tradition Holds, Hope and Wit Will Shower the Mets Stadium in Sheets
description: The long march of Mets history resumes Sunday after a 16-year break, as Banner Day materializes anew before the clubs 1:10 matinee game against the San Diego Padres. If precedent is a reliable indicator, paint will be spilled, linens will be ruined and at least a few people will have something clever to say.

title: Germany Looks to Its Own Costly Reunification in Resisting Stimulus for Greece
description: MUNICH  When Germany wants to understand Greece and the crisis afflicting Europe it not only looks south to the Continents periphery but also turns inward, to the former East Germany, still struggling more than two decades after German reunification.

title: A Frisky Musical With Many Lives
description: People have snickered for years about Cats, suggesting that the reason the show became the second-longest-running hit in Broadway history (after The Phantom of the Opera) was that the dance-driven extravaganza was an ideal attraction for tourists who did not speak English. But I suspect that some who dismiss this musical as mere spectacle have never actually seen or heard it. Maybe it is time they did.

title: A Trio of Events With Music in Many Moods
description: THE rock-and-rap Bamboozle Festival in Asbury Park and the Electric Daisy Carnival of electronic dance music in East Rutherford may have grabbed the spotlight in New Jersey this month, but fans who favor other genres  and a more intimate scale  have plenty to look forward to in June.

title: A Young Witness Propels a Farce
description: The gentleman of the house answers the doorbell in his bathrobe. He recognizes the cleaning woman (the cleaner, that is; we are in London), but has no idea what her name is. She is almost nine months pregnant and has brought along her daughter, who is almost 9, for the day. The lady of the house has disappeared. We are off and running.

title: Brazil: President Vetoes Major Parts of Bill to Open Up Forests
description: President Dilma Rousseff on Friday vetoed portions of Brazils new Forest Code, a bill drafted to open big areas of protected forests to large-scale agriculture. The decision by Ms. Rousseff, which removes 12 articles from the bill, alters legislation sought by powerful agricultural groups. The bill had provoked outrage among environmentalists, some business leaders and cultural icons, especially over a provision that effectively granted amnesty to landowners who illegally deforested some areas. Responding to these concerns, Environment Minister Izabella Teixeira said the presidents line-item vetoes ruled out amnesty. Still, Ms. Rousseffs action fell short of the expectations of environmental groups, which had wanted her to veto the entire bill. Details about the changes to the bill were sparse on Friday, with Brazils powerful Agriculture and Livestock Confederation withholding comment. The official text of Ms. Rousseffs alterations, which include dozens of suggested changes to the bill in addition to the vetoed portions, is expected to be published on Monday.

title: Media Executives Father Ordered to Pay $250,000 in Suit Over Fake Picasso
description: LOS ANGELES  Jack and Leslie Kavanaugh, the parents of the Relativity Media chief executive, Ryan Kavanaugh, got a double shot of bad news, as the elder Mr. Kavanaugh was ordered in Los Angeles County Superior Court on Friday to pay $250,000 in punitive damages for his role in the sale of a fraudulent Picasso drawing.

title: Margaritas and Tacos Beneath the Bridge
description: Gran Elctrica, in Brooklyns Dumbo neighborhood, is a brick-walled, votive-lighted, tin-ceilinged amalgam of the sustainably local and the whimsically loco. The mescal beverage options promise to knock your Birkenstocks off, as does the back garden, where the Brooklyn Bridge curves overhead like a distant awning. Set in a landmarked 1835 brick building that began as a purveyor of fire insurance to the shipping trade, the restaurant, at 5 Front Street, is owned by the group that brought Colonie to Brooklyn Heights last year. The chef, Sam Richman, honed his haute French technique at Jean Georges and Per Se but spent a month in Mexico on a culinary cram course before taking over the kitchen. Pacifico Clara beer ($6) makes its New York City debut on tap. About those skulls and skeletons on the walls: the Da de los Muertos motif of the Mexican artist Jos Guadalupe Posada has been customized in Dumbo-centric wallpaper. It works its intended macabre magic.

title: Quietly Finding Haitis Audacious Beauty
description: To much of the outside world, the image of Haiti  when it pops up at all  is one of catastrophes, both natural and man-made. Violence, grinding poverty, flood, earthquakes all leave a lingering image of a benighted nation bereft of tender moments.

title: Rules for the Road
description: That man Haupt has built a bridge across Potomac Creek, about 400 feet long and nearly 100 feet high, over which loaded trains are running every hour, declared President Abraham Lincoln on May 23, 1862, and, upon my word, gentlemen, there is nothing in it but beanpoles and cornstalks!

title: On the Road for Romney, 40,000 Miles and Counting
description: CLEVELAND  In Florida, a state trooper pulled Jim Wilson off the highway, but instead of issuing a speeding ticket, asked a favor: Could he have a few Romney for President bumper stickers?

title: Deciphering Mitt-Speak on Schools
description: Today, were going to talk about Mitt Romneys education speech.

title: Billionaire Finds New Role in Effort to Defeat Obama
description: When news broke last week that the billionaire investor Joe Ricketts had considered financing a $10 million advertising effort linking President Obama with the fiery race-based rhetoric of his former spiritual adviser, the Rev. Jeremiah A. Wright Jr., Mr. Ricketts quickly distanced himself from the proposal and Mitt Romneys campaign denounced it.

title: Balls, Strikes and Noodle Pudding
description: C. B. Bucknor, 50, was a physical therapist at what was then New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center when, on a whim, he used vacation time to attend umpire school in 1990. A career change ensued. Now, most of his Sundays involve ballgames and airline travel; he umpires 135 Major League games a season, not counting spring training and the playoffs. (He has worked the playoffs three times, but never a World Series, and his calls have sometimes been controversial.) In the off-season he spends time in his hometown, Savanna-la-Mar, Jamaica, where he helps run an annual Treat 54 party (named for his uniform number) for local children. He lives in Prospect-Lefferts Gardens, Brooklyn, with his wife, who is a registered nurse, and their children, ages 9, 15 and 17; his mother lives upstairs.

title: Some Comma Questions
description: Who knew people were so interested in commas? Commenters to my post The Most Comma Mistakes raised many points, questions and objections; collectively, they concentrated my mind wonderfully. Here are excerpts of a few representative comments, edited for clarity, followed by my responses.

title: Control: An Update
description: Last weeks Anxiety post, Control, featured an interview with Dominick Brocato, conducted and transcribed by DW Gibson, the author of the forthcoming book and documentary film, Not Working. Many readers who commented wanted to know how Mr. Brocato was managing his various challenges  unemployment, illness and a lack of medical insurance among them  since the interview, which took place in July 2011. To provide that update to readers, Mr. Gibson contacted Mr. Brocato by e-mail and phone earlier this week.

title: Friday Night Music: Ten Favorites
description: Too busy to hunt up new stuff, and going into makeup soon. So, for old times sake, ten of my favorite Arcade Fire performances, most featured at some time in the past, after the jump; consider it a sort of fantasy concert.

title: Bank Regulators Under Scrutiny in JPMorgan Loss
description: Scores of federal regulators are stationed inside JPMorgan ChasesManhattan headquarters, but none of them were assigned to the powerful unit that recently disclosed a multibillion trading loss.

title: Facebooks Brilliant Disaster
description: So I guess youve heard about the recent initial public offering that didnt turn out the way it was supposed to. The companys Wall Street advisers misjudged the market, and, on its first day of trading, the stock went a little haywire. Then it slowly sank, dropping around 10 percent over the next month.

title: For Cyclists, Revolution Must Catch Up
description: As someone who rides a bicycle in New York City, I am still waiting for the smartphone revolution.

title: Unease in Lacrosse Amid Race for Earlier Commitments
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  When the junior varsity boys lacrosse team at Chaminade High School faced St. Anthonys High School on Long Island in New York on Tuesday, a dozen Division I mens lacrosse coaches were in the stands watching.

title: Russia: Free Apartments for Injured Police Officers
description: The Moscow city government has promised to provide free apartments to four police officers who were injured during a brawl with protesters on May 6, in another demonstration of officials frustration with the antigovernment protest movement. A police spokesman confirmed to the Interfax news agency that the four officers would receive apartments, an extraordinary reward in a city with sky-high real estate prices. State-controlled television gave lavish coverage to the injured officers, who sustained bruises when they were hit by chunks of asphalt flung from people in the crowd. President Vladimir V. Putins spokesman, Dmitri S. Peskov, told an opposition lawmaker that for an injured policeman, the liver of demonstrators should be smeared on the asphalt.

title: A Nightclub on Fire Island, Destroyed by Fire, Is on Track for a Rebirth
description: This Memorial Day weekend, visitors to the Fire Island Pines will find the prominent waterfront site long occupied by the Pavilion, the islands legendary dance club and social hub, to be little more than a forlorn lot containing sand, ashen debris and memories of giddier times.

title: Nuclear Power After Fukushima
description: The resignation of Gregory Jaczko, the embattled chairman of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, means the country is losing a strong advocate for public safety who was always willing to challenge the nuclear industry and its political backers in Congress.

title: Drug for Adults Is Popular as Childrens Remedy
description: Since it was first introduced 13 years ago, a drug called Miralax  an odorless, tasteless laxative that can be easily diluted in orange juice or water  has become a staple in many American households.

title: Neighborhood Joint | Suzanne Couture Millinery
description: Suzanne Newman, the owner of Suzanne Couture Millinery, wandered into a millinery shop on East 59th Street in the mid-1980s and found her vocation.

title: The Lesson of Bain Capital
description: Mitt Romneys campaign claims to be outraged that President Obama would dare criticize its candidates experience of running Bain Capital, a private-equity firm. Some Democratic politicians have also said the president went too far in tarring an important driver of economic growth. The financial price has been high: Mr. Romneys campaign is reaping unusually generous Wall Street contributions, while Mr. Obamas campaign is raising far less from the financial sector than it did four years ago.

title: In Patz Investigation, a Confession Is Not the Final Word
description: The man breaks down and cries and says yes, I did it. I killed that 6-year-old boy 33 years ago. I did it.

title: Corrections: May 26
description: NEW YORK

title: Doctors Tips for Childhood Constipation
description: Too much dairy, too little fiber, and too few vegetables and fruits can contribute to constipation. In particular, P-letter fruits may help: prunes, pears, plums and peaches.

title: Fabulous Hats That Tilt Just So
description: I WANT the fabulous hat, Caroline Traugott said with a laugh. And whatever goes with it, who cares?

title: A Game to Help Doctors Ask Tough Questions
description: CHICAGO  As Dr. Danielle McCarthy listens to a man beg for a prescription for painkillers, she weighs her possible responses.

title: Bodies Built by the Bar
description: Douglas Chapman has developed an acrobatic use of New York City's playground bars, and he runs a league for the sport, which he calls barmetrics.

title: Edible Floppy Disk
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  Wow, and other such celebratory words, this one was fresh and crunchy. I broke a mild sweat finishing it, but Peter Wentzs grid is packed with some Scrabbly, sparkling goodness. Dont miss this one.

title: Taking the Bar to New Heights
description: DOUGLAS CHAPMAN, 39, beamed as his guys arrived  a dozen muscular men who entered a Bronx gym last weekend and walked right past the weights and exercise machines, and headed instead toward a set of jungle-gym bars.

title: Knicks End the Waiting and Keep Woodson as Coach
description: Mike Woodson will be the Knicks coach next season, and he will almost certainly have Jeremy Lin running his offense.

title: The Loss of a Friend
description: SPECIAL POST  It is with great sadness that Wordplay announces the loss of a very special person in the world of puzzling.

title: Alkalinization, Lasix and Milkshaking: A Veterinarians View
description: The Kentucky Horse Racing Commissions hearing on race-day medication last November revealed that Lasix alkalinizes horses, elevating their racing TCO2 values.

title: Icahn Buys a Stake in Chesapeake Energy
description: Carl C. Icahn, the billionaire investor, bought a 7.56 percent stake in the Chesapeake Energy Corporation and demanded a new slate of directors amid growing shareholder concern about the companys management.

title: Sharing Outsider Status and a Style of Coping
description: The United States quietly passed a milestone this spring, mostly lost amid the clamor of the presidential race: for the first time, neither partys candidate is a white Protestant. The contenders are both from outsider groups that were once persecuted, and despite Harvard degrees and notable successes, both men have felt the sting of being treated as somehow strange or different.

title: The Appeal of Being First in Food
description: Much of the food-snob energy in the city this summer will percolate in street markets, festivals, food truck feedlots and underground events, and revolve around the inaccessible or artisanal, the locally sourced or handcrafted.

title: Eat, Talk, Tweet
description: DANIEL DELANEY, 26, decided recently that he wanted to smoke and sell brisket, bringing small batches of what he called real Texas barbecue to New York.

title: The Casino in Central Park
description: A selection of Times articles from the 1920s and 30s about the Central Park Casino.

title: Presidential Panel Urges More Flexible Use of Spectrum
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A just-completed report from a presidential advisory committee urges President Obama to adopt new computer technologies to make better use of a huge swath of the radio spectrum now controlled by federal agencies.

title: Israel Is Anxiously Watching Egyptian Vote
description: CAIRO  Both candidates for Egypts presidency have pledged to respect the countrys peace treaty with Israel, but they differ greatly in their approach, especially regarding the Palestinians.

title: Mets Find There Are Options Other Than Wright in Win
description: For one night, the Mets exorcised their demons. The cleanup hitter who preferred singles hit a home run, the stalwart in a 0-for-15 slump found his swing, the No. 4 pitcher who had mentally stumbled over himself looked unhittable at times and scored the go-ahead run  and Ike Davis hit a two-run single.

title: The Night Spot That Roared
description: IF I could return to just one moment in New Yorks story, I would go back to the Roaring Twenties, with their radiant gatherings in Harlem and the rise of the Chrysler Building, when the city threw its most jubilant parade for Charles Lindbergh, the shy young pilot who, F. Scott Fitzgerald wrote, had seemingly nothing to do with his generation except allowing us to dream once more of our greatest possibilities. I would watch Babe Ruth round the bases with odd little steps, and at night I would visit the one place to be: the Casino, the elegant night spot in Central Park.

title: Hefner Remains Only Option for No. 5 Spot in Mets Rotation
description: Mets Manager Terry Collins may not know what he has in Jeremy Hefner, a 26-year-old right-hander, but he may have no choice but to keep trusting him. Hefners first career start Thursday was as confounding as the No. 5 spot in the rotation that he is trying to stabilize. When Collins was asked about Hefner on Friday, he started his answer by sounding confident, then ended it sounding desperate  mirroring the way Hefners first start went.

title: They Are Taxis, Not Limos
description: Watching the meter climb in New York Citys yellow cabs could get a whole lot more stressful this summer after the Taxi and Limousine Commission raises basic fares for the first time since 2006. (The state added a fee of 50 cents per ride in 2009.)

title: Lottery Numbers
Capital Punishments Latest Folly
description: The history of capital punishment in this country has had many horrifying turnings, few more macabre than a warning from states employing lethal injection that a federal court ruling has left them facing a shortage of the imported drug they rely on to kill death-row felons.

title: Syracuse Reaches Final by Rallying Past Florida
description: STONY BROOK, N.Y.  Trailing by seven goals in the second half on Friday, No. 4 Syracuse appeared headed toward an 0-3 record in N.C.A.A. womens lacrosse tournament semifinals.

title: Special Parking Rules in New York
description: On Sunday, because of Shavuot, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City. Other regulations will remain in effect. Alternate-side street-cleaning regulations also will be suspended on Monday because of Shavuot and Memorial Day.

title: Expression Will Be Free, but Only Partly
description: The resumption of Banner Day on Sunday comes with a proviso: the Mets reserve the right to deny access to the parade to anyone deemed to have an inappropriate banner.

title: Beach Town of Eclectics
description: A few months ago, I received a letter from someone whose business card, included in his envelope and containing only a small fraction of his rsum, described him as a trained lawyer, educator, speaker, boxing journalist and, perhaps most significant, a historian of Sea Gate. Occupying the western tip of Coney Island, in Brooklyn, Sea Gate is a neighborhood of about 800 or so mostly single-family homes, with two gated entry points.

title: Kings Investment in Doughty Is Paying Off in the Postseason
description: EL SEGUNDO, Calif. (AP)  Drew Doughty began this season holding out for an eight-year, $56 million contract from the Los Angeles Kings, demanding and getting an enormous sum for a young player with more potential than accomplishment.

title: Edoardo Mangiarotti, Olympian Fencer, Dies at 93
description: Edoardo Mangiarotti, who won more Olympic medals and world championships than any fencer, starting with the Berlin Games in 1936, died on Friday at his home in Milan. He was 93.

title: How Sweet It Is
description: In New York, beekeepers are scurrying to keep pace as colonies go into reproductive overdrive and proliferate, spurred by the citys flowering plants and trees.

title: H. H. Brookins, Influential A.M.E. Bishop, Dies at 86
description: The Rev. H. H. Brookins, a retired bishop in the African Methodist Episcopal Church whose role as a civil rights leader and a political kingmaker was clouded by accusations of financial chicanery, died on Tuesday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 86.

title: The Colonies Expand
description: ITS a busy time of year for bees. As the citys flowering plants and trees reveal their sweet nectar, colonies go into reproductive overdrive as they build armies large enough to take in the spring flow. And the urban beekeepers tending to these exploding colonies are scurrying to keep pace.

title: Knicks Smith Arrested in Florida
description: J. R. Smith, a Knicks guard with a history of legal trouble, was arrested in Miami Beach, Fla., on Thursday for failing to appear in court on a traffic matter. Smith was cited in May 2011 for operating a scooter without a valid drivers license and was ordered to stand trial on July 25. When he failed to show, a bench warrant was issued for his arrest.

title: Shades of Guilt in One Soldiers Purple Heart
description: The unofficial marker for summers beginning is upon us, and beyond the noise of summer barbecues, some will take time to honor the service members who fought and died in our nations wars. As a veteran of a recent war, I feel it is important to look past the general niceties spouted over heroic service, and to truly reflect upon the costs of war, and to honor the complexities of the situation that we soldiers are fighting in.

title: Brain-Damaged Woman Wins Suit Against City Hospitals
description: A Bronx jury awarded about $120 million on Friday to a woman who has been incapacitated since she was treated at three local hospitals in 2004.

title: Holiday on Monday Memorial Day
description: NEW YORK

title: Devils Advance to Finals After Ending Rangers Season
description: NEWARK  On May 25, 1994, the Devils stood on the verge of eliminating the Rangers in Game 6 of the Eastern Conference finals, but blew a 2-0 lead and lost the game and the series.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,967 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

title: With a Bipartisan Flurry, Becoming a Do-Something Senate
description: WASHINGTON  For the Congressional chamber where bills usually go to die, the Senate is on something of a roll, passing bipartisan legislation, confirming nominees  and potentially isolating House Republican leaders who have made Senate inaction a centerpiece of their political appeals.

title: Police Officer in Alabama Is Arrested After Fires
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala.  A Birmingham police officer with almost three years on the force has been arrested after a series of arsons in abandoned houses in the city and a suburb this month.

title: In Overtime, Henrique Has Answer
description: NEWARK  Balloting for the Calder Trophy, awarded to the N.H.L.s best rookie, ended at the conclusion of the regular season, which is a shame for a 22-year-old member of the Devils who has scored not one but two series-clinching goals this postseason. The latest stroke of opportunism by that rookie, Adam Henrique, set off a celebration that echoed throughout Prudential Center on Friday night and a euphoric scrum to the left of the Rangers net, in which the puck that he nudged past Henrik Lundqvist at 1 minute 3 seconds of overtime had settled moments earlier, launching the Devils into the Stanley Cup finals with a 3-2 victory.

title: As Hip-Hop Devotees Come in, Many Miami Beach Residents Prepare to Leave
description: MIAMI BEACH  This small city is accustomed to big events. But every Urban Beach Week, residents and businesses take in a collective deep breath and do not exhale until its over.

title: Grab Your Suit! The McCarren Pool Is Almost Open
description: Once, the pool was an alternative to dips in the citys filthy waterways. Then, things fell apart and it closed. Now, it is on the verge of a gleaming, new, expensive beginning.

title: North Carolina: Edwards Jurors Take a Break
description: Jurors in the corruption trial of John Edwards ended their sixth day of deliberations without reaching a verdict and will not come back to court until Tuesday because of the holiday weekend. Before dismissing the jury, Judge Catherine C. Eagles briefly cleared the courtroom of spectators to discuss a juror issue with the prosecution and defense lawyers. Once she reopened court, she warned the jurors to discuss the case only when the full complement of 12 was present. You shouldnt talk about the case in small groups, she said. She also planned to resume court at 9 a.m. in case the jury issue needed more attention. Jury behavior has drawn attention in recent days. On Thursday, the four alternate jurors came to court in yellow shirts. On Friday, they wore red. Two of the women alternates also giggled and glanced at Mr. Edwards, prompting speculation by courtroom observers that at least one of them was flirting.

title: Fatigued or Not, the Rangers Cant Climb Out of Another Early Hole
description: NEWARK  Inspired by their captain, Ryan Callahan, the Rangers managed to overcome another slow start in Game 6 of the Eastern Conference finals. But as in their loss two nights earlier, they could not finish the job and lost to the Devils, 3-2, on an overtime goal by Adam Henrique, bringing their season to an end on Friday night.

title: Lazy, Hazy Summer Days: A Guide
description: New York can be a sweltering concrete jungle in the summer. But the city is also a huge, beautiful playground. And if ever there was a year to schedule a summer staycation, 2012 might be it. With food festivals, free concerts and a safe and sanctioned dip into the East River, there is more than enough happening to keep you happily occupied till Labor Day. Whether you are an athlete, aesthete, scholar, theatergoer, concertgoer, tourist or most anything else, here are some suggestions to get you started. STEVEN McELROY

title: In Cambodia, Sentencing of Women Activists Sparks Outcry
description: Many around the world have died protecting it: land. The issue is highly charged in Cambodia where it flared again last week after 13 women, including a 72-year-old, were jailed for illegal occupation of land and aggravated rebellion after demonstrating on the site of their former homes in Phnom Penh, knocked down to make way for a commercial development, The Associated Press reported.

title: A Most Committed Romney Supporter
description: For the past year, Jim Wilson has devoted himself with the single-mindedness of a college-age groupie to following Mitt Romney around the country.

title: Elephant Rights Movement Clashes With Tradition in Kerala
description: Elephants are revered across India for their majesty and loyalty, personified in the figure of Lord Ganesha, but no Indian state is prouder of its elephants than Kerala. And among Keralas elephant lovers, few are as famous for their devotion as the Malayalam movie star who goes by the single name of Jayaram. Mr. Jayarams own elephant, named Kannan, is a movie star in his own right, with over 30 South Indian films to his credit.

title: Back in Oakland, and Back in the Groove
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  The Yankees have been searching for a consistent winning groove all season, but the only consistency they have shown is their inability to find any, even at home. But if there is one place that seems to generate victories for the Yankees, it is Oakland.

title: Despite Boos, Chavez Relishes Return to Oakland
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  Eric Chavez made his return to Oakland for the first time since he left the Athletics following the 2010 season. But even after 13 successful seasons here, Chavez was booed when he came to the plate for the first time in the Yankees 6-3 victory over the A's on Friday.

title: Mumbai in the Bad Old Days
description: Ashim Ahluwalias film Miss Lovely is set in in the seedy and violent back streets of Mumbai, where he grew up, Joan Dupont writes in The New York Times.

title: Dempsey Easing Away From Fulham, With a Nudge From Klinsmann
description: United States forward Clint Dempsey is coming off what might have been the strongest season in Europe for an American player, and he has a year left on his contract with Fulham. But United States Coach Jurgen Klinsmann strongly suggested on Friday that he find himself a new, bigger club.

title: Beyonc: Coming Back and Catching Up, Then Conquering
description: ATLANTIC CITY  Beyonc gave birth to her daughter, Blue Ivy Carter, on Jan. 7, and is now between albums and tours. From a distance, her four-night run of shows through Monday at Revel, on the Boardwalk here, seemed to be functioning as an advertisement for the grand opening of a $2.4 billion casino, hotel, and luxury-shopping cosmos. It was a little unclear what she was going to do for her first post-maternal gig.

description: Todays Times

title: Dozens of Children Die in Brutal Attack on Syrian Town
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  More than 90 people, including at least 32 children under the age of 10, were killed in a central Syrian village, top United Nations officials said Saturday, accusing the government of perpetrating the indiscriminate shelling of civilian neighborhoods.

title: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
description: Jammu and Kashmir: In the state capital of Srinagar government employees called for a three-day strike on Thursday to demand that the retirement age of employees be increased from 58 years to 60 years, Kashmir Live reported. Additional demands included stabilizing the employment of daily wagers and removal of pay anomalies, the newspaper reported. Almost 450,000 state employees did not report to work.

title: Vermont Tourist Draw Expands After Storm
description: Nine months after Tropical Storm Irene struck Vermont, causing extensive property damage, the states third-largest tourist attraction has been rebuilt. The glassblowing workshop at the popular Simon Pearce Mill in Quechee, Vt., which draws 300,000 people a year, has reopened in a restored and enlarged space.

title: Postal Service Offers Buyouts to 45,000 Mail Handlers
description: The United States Postal Service said late Friday that it was offering buyouts to about 45,000 mail handlers, part of the financially troubled agencys efforts to cut its staff and reduce its operating costs.

title: Belmont Sold Out? Not So Fast
description: When 3,000 reserved-seat tickets were made available online Monday after Ill Have Another won the Preakness Stakes to keep his Triple Crown bid alive, they were snatched up in about three minutes, causing some to incorrectly assume that the Belmont Stakes was sold out.

description: As a major league pitcher for 15 seasons, including time with the Red Sox and the Mets, Bob Ojeda had an intense relationship with pain.

description: Id lived with pain in my left arm since I was 12, when my dad would have me ice it after a Little League outing. My dad, who had pitched in the Army, was something of a pioneer in caring for young arms. Besides, he told me, Sandy Koufax iced his arm.

title: Gleefully Devoted to Motherhood
description: Mary Lou Retton, the first American female gymnast to win a gold medal in the all-around, was the star of the 1984 Summer Olympics in Los Angeles. She won five medals, including two silvers, for team and vault, and two bronzes, for uneven bars and floor exercise.

description: Once upon a perfect game, Yogi Berra leapt into Don Larsens arms.
