description: Remember the furor over liberal political correctness? Yes, some of it was over the top  but it was mainly silly, not something that actually warped our national discussion.

title: Some Disdain Both Options in Egypts Narrowed Race
description: CAIRO  Faced with what seemed like an impossible choice  between a conservative Islamist with a rigid social agenda and a former minister with deep ties to the Mubarak government  Ahmed Abdel Fattah, 33, said he planned to sit out the remainder of the voting for Egypts president and hope for better choices in four years.

title: Rangers Grind to Halt as Deeper Devils Play On
description: When the final blow to their psyche had been dealt and the Devils charged into one corner of the Prudential Center rink to celebrate madly Friday night, the Rangers fell to their knees in front of the net, staring off in a different direction. Their stunned expressions said they had no idea how Adam Henrique had poked home the winning goal, how the Devils had ended their season in overtime of Game 6 of the Eastern Conference finals.

title: With Personal Data in Hand, Thieves File Early and Often
description: MIAMI  Besieged by identity theft, Florida now faces a fast-spreading form of fraud so simple and lucrative that some violent criminals have traded their guns for laptops. And the target is the United States Treasury.

title: Spent Fuel Rods Drive Growing Fear Over Plant in Japan
description: TOKYO  What passes for normal at the Fukushima Daiichi plant today would have caused shudders among even the most sanguine of experts before an earthquake and tsunami set off the worlds second most serious nuclear crisis after Chernobyl.

description: Caleb Lloyd did not take his baseball glove to Great American Ball Park in Cincinnati last Monday.

title: Sketching the Wounds of War
description: War is one of arts oldest muses. A work of art can both bear witness and rewrite history; it can also be a plea not to repeat the past. Our colleague Carol Kino writes that a new genre may be developing at Walter Reed National Military Medical Center via the Joe Bonham Project, a year-and-a-half-old group dedicated to documenting the experiences of wounded service members by drawing their portraits.

description: EDINBURG, Tex.  For decades, the first stop for illegal immigrants making their way across the Texas border has often been a stash house or drop house, an apartment or rental home where they might spend hours or days in squalor waiting to be transported elsewhere. Often it is where they are held until their families pay the smugglers fees.

description: MIDDLETON, Mass.  As the lone Democrat seeking to challenge Elizabeth Warren in the Senate primary in Massachusetts, Marisa DeFranco has been ridiculed, admonished and, worst of all, ignored.

description: BANGKOK (AP)  Numerous small protests have arisen in Myanmar over persistent power shortages as the past years democratic reforms have led to rising expectations from a long-suppressed population.

title: In Peru, Wounds of Civil War
description: More than a decade after Peru vanquished a long-running insurgency, a bid by some former Shining Path guerrillas to form a political party reopened a bitter national debate on the war and how to move on.

title: Peru Forced to Confront Deep Scars of Civil War
description: LIMA, Peru  During a scorched earth military campaign that threatened to topple the government here, the Maoist guerrilla group known as the Shining Path terrorized Peru with assassinations, bombings, beheadings and massacres. So Peruvians were rattled last year when a group of former guerrillas began collecting signatures to create a political party to participate in the democratic process they had once sought to destroy.

title: A Family and a Series Seek a Fresh Start at Indy
description: INDIANAPOLIS  A 25-year-old racecar driver, wearing a sponsors cap with sunglasses perched on top, a wristwatch almost as big as a saucer and a supply of stubble, talked excitedly last week about his chances of winning the Indianapolis 500 for the first time.

title: Patrick Takes to Nascar, and Feeling Is Mutual
description: CONCORD, N.C.  Four months into her new life as a full-time Nascar driver, Danica Patrick says she is far too busy to spend much time thinking about the Indianapolis 500. Yes, she watched some of the qualifying on television. No, she does not long to be there.

title: Quick Getaways, at the Divorce Hotel
description: THE American marriage, it seems, is on the rocks. The common line  true or not  is that half of all marriages in this country end in divorce.

Parks, restaurants and friends who once seemed beyond plausible commuting distance on public transportation will seem a lot closer. description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Both President Hamid Karzai and NATO commanders ordered an investigation on Sunday into reports that a family of eight had been killed in a coalition airstrike in eastern Afghanistan.

description: CANNES, France  At 40, Carlos Reygadas is firmly established as the leading enfant terrible of Mexican cinema and a favored son of the Cannes Film Festival. All four of his features, starting with his 2002 debut, Japn, have been shown here; on his previous trip, in 2007, he won the Jury Prize (the equivalent of third place) for the Dreyer-inspired Silent Light.

title: Honoring the Exchange of Life for Life
description: The face never comes into view in my dreams, but I know its him. The twisted mouth is agape, molded in an eternal gasp of shock. The lower half of his body is gone, and theres a black hole where his guts should have been. When Chevy was blown from the Stryker hatch, he took flight for an incalculable measure of time before landing on the slat armor of his vehicle. His uniform was blown off, which never happens in the movies. But he was whole, as complete and pure as the day he was born, Im told. I never got the chance to see for myself before he disappeared into a body bag. The continuing ambush prevented that.

title: U.N. Security Council Issues Condemnation of Syria Attack
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The United Nations Security Council on Sunday unanimously condemned the Syrian government for its role in the massacre of at least 108 villagers, with new details emerging from international observers that appeared to prompt rare Russian cooperation in criticizing its ally in Damascus.

title: From Massacres to Shortages, Syria Is Under Pressure
description: LONDON  The Houla massacre is being widely described as a turning point in the Syrian uprising. But a turning point to what? Will it finally provide the impetus for unified international action to force a political transition in Damascus or will it mark a slide to full-scale civil war?

title: The Leprechaun Factor
description: In understanding the Great British Blunder  the Cameron/Clegg/Osborne decision to engage in unforced austerity, which increasingly looks as if it may cripple the UK economy for many years to come  it is, Im increasingly convinced, crucial to understand the leprechaun factor.

title: A Poem for Penny
description: A poem written for Penny Chenery, breeder and owner of the 1973 Triple Crown winner Secretariat, and her daughter Kate, all about you know who.

title: A Few Minutes With Alex Morgan
description: Alex Morgan made her debut for the United States womens national team in 2010 and quickly established herself as a valuable substitute. Last summer, Morgan came off the bench in five of the six games at the World Cup  scoring in both the Americans semifinal win over France and their championship game loss to Japan  but this year she has made a case for a regular starting role with a string of stronger performances. Morgan, 22, is the national teams leading scorer in 2012 with 12 goals, and her 7 assists on second to Lauren Cheneys 10. Last week, two months before the Olympic soccer tournament kicks off, Morgan spoke with the Goal blog about her preparations for the Games, her goals for this summer and the one opponent shes keeping an eye on.

title: A Caddie in Your Pocket, or on Your Belt
description: Not many of us get to play with a caddie, which is too bad because it is a great, productive pleasure  the confluence of two trying to master a golf course together.

title: F.A.A. Gives Tips on Seats for the Littlest Fliers
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has recommended using safety seats for small children on flights in recent years, but parents often have a hard time figuring out which ones are best.

title: In Stunning Tennis Comeback, Scars Show a Career Arc
description: PARIS  The scars remind Brian Baker of the career that never really started. They number five, one for each operation in the six years Baker spent away from professional tennis.

title: A Lost Bag and a Lost Night, but Not a Lost Cause
description: Those who have misplaced personal belongings on the streets of New York know this: The city does not care if you need your keys or wallet back.

title: Cannes Film Festival: David Cronenberg on Adapting Unadaptable Books
description: CANNES, France  The Canadian director David Cronenberg has a long and eventful history at the Cannes Film Festival: he has competed for the Palme dOr three times and was awarded a lifetime achievement prize in 2006. He has also stirred controversy both as a filmmaker (presenting the divisive Crash in 1996) and as the president of a jury (in 1999) that was both applauded and attacked for its surprising underdog choices.

title: Romney Faults Obama After Syria Crackdown

description: Republicans have been assailing President Obama and his re-election team for days for pointedly  and they say unfairly  questioning the private equity experience of Mitt Romney. description: This is how high the summer movie stakes have become: Men in Black 3, representing the return of Will Smith after a four-year hiatus, took in about $55 million over its first three days in North American theaters  and Hollywood collectively winced.

description: TEHRAN  Irans nuclear chief, reversing the countrys previous statements, said on state television on Sunday that the country would not halt its production of higher-grade uranium, suggesting that the Iranian government was veering back to a much harder line after talks in Baghdad with the West last week ended badly.

description: CANNES, France  On the last day of the Cannes Film Festival, festival attendees swap last-minute guesses about who will win the Palme dOr and catch up on any of the selections in the main competition during the reprise screenings. By this point, the festival has largely cleared out, save for journalist laggers and, of course, those winners who have stayed in town hoping for a callback to the evening awards ceremony. The market, where thousands of titles are bought and sold by thousands of industry professionals closed Friday, and many journalists are already back home, where doubtless some will decide (as usual!) that this year really wasnt as bad as it sometimes seemed.

description: For the United States Olympic womens team, it is all a numbers game.

title: Amour, a Wrenching Love Story, Wins at Cannes
description: CANNES, France  Heavy rain dampened the final day of the 65th Cannes Film Festival, but it mattered not at all when the Palme dOr was awarded to Amour. Brilliantly directed with an atypically tender touch by the Austrian director Michael Haneke, this story about an octogenarian husband and wife facing their mortality  beautifully played by the French actors Jean-Louis Trintignant and Emmanuelle Riva  had left audiences stunned with its artistry and depth of feeling.

title: Rivals Gamble Ends in Crash, and Third Win for Franchitti
description: INDIANAPOLIS  The back seat of the convertible was just wide enough for a third passenger to join Dario Franchitti, the 39-year-old Scotsman who had just won his third Indianapolis 500 on Sunday, and Franchitis wife, the actress Ashley Judd.

title: Bacharach and the Beatles: The Sunny Side of the 60s

But no, it wasnt Ms. Par but Ms. Sheehan, the rising cabaret star transformed into Ms. Pars doppelgnger for her effervescent new show, I Know a Place, an anthology of 1960s songs that takes its title from the Petula Clark hit that led off the evening.

title: Mommy Wars Redux:  A False Conflict
description: The mommy wars have flared up once again, sparked most recently by the publication of the English translation of Elisabeth Badinters book, The Conflict: How Modern Motherhood Undermines the Status of Women. In it, Badinter argues that a certain contemporary style of mothering  a style that requires total devotion of mother to child, starting with natural childbirth and extending through exclusive and on-demand breastfeeding, baby-wearing and co-sleeping  undermines womens equality. Badinter claims that it does this in several ways: by squeezing fathers out of any meaningful role in parenting; by placing such high demands on mothers that it becomes nearly impossible to balance paid work with motherhood (especially once fathers have been sidelined); and by sending the message that day care, bottle feeding, sleep training and the other things that allow women to combine motherhood with paid work are harmful to children, and that the women who use them are selfish.

title: Frozen Treats, All Year Round
description: December is not the best time to sell a strawberry-rhubarb ice pop. So Peoples Pops, a Brooklyn company that specializes in deeply fruity frozen confections on a stick that are made mostly with Greenmarket ingredients, closes its many market stalls and outdoor stands around New York during the colder months. The same goes for its bright new shop (in photo) in Park Slope, Brooklyn, which will be open only until late October, reopening next May. But now, with expanded production facilities gearing up, the company will soon produce enough pops to sell to grocery stores. So yes, well have strawberry-rhubarb in the snow.

title: Brews and Bites Off the Usual Track
description: Suppose you are deep downtown, where Canal Street and the Lower East Side disappear into blocks of apartments past Seward Park, and you crave a beer. No, not just a Corona, but maybe something artisanal, like Ithaca Beer, from upstate. Kevin M. Healds smartly tailored little shop, Malt & Mold, is there to help. With his beard and hat, Mr. Heald (shown), 43, looks every bit the monger of cheese and beer he calls himself. He has assembled about 50 craft beers, mostly domestic, and a well-curated assortment of cheeses, also artisanal and American, along with some imports like taleggio. Pickles and chocolates from Brooklyn, yogurts, vinegars, crackers and cured meats line the shelves and display cases. For now, the beers are in bottles and cans; eight tap lines, and growlers in various sizes, await a state permit. The shop may be out of the way, but itis the only local retailer for the excellent sweet and savory knishes from Knishery NYC, a new company; for salami by Charlitos Cocina, of Long Island City, Queens; and for ice cream from the Bent Spoon, of Princeton, N.J., which shares the freezer with Blue Marble, Adirondack and Van Leeuwen.

title: The Get | Prestats Diamond Jubilee Truffles
description: So, the De Beers Talisman Crown is way out of your price range. Theres another decadent (and delicious) way to partake in Queen Elizabeth IIs Diamond Jubilee this weekend  with a box of special-edition truffles from the queens official chocolatier, Prestat. Awarded the royal warrant by Her Majesty in 1975, Prestat was first established in 1902 and has accompanied the British monarch on everything from business trips to family holidays aboard the Royal Yacht Britannia. The Jubilee box, designed by the royal florist Kitty Arden, features a cheery illustration that incorporates the Union Jack, a gold coronation state carriage, a unicorn and the queens favorite corgis. (Shes owned more than 30 since being given her first, named Susan, on her 18th birthday.) Flavors include 1895 Gianduja, Marc de Champagne and Earl Grey. Sweet!

title: Bob Dylan Among Recipients of Presidential Medal of Freedom
description: It would be an overstatement to say that the whole wide world was watching when Bob Dylans ship came in, but surely his fans pinched themselves and squealed and knew that it was for real when he was awarded a Presidential Medal of Freedom on Tuesday afternoon. Mr. Dylan, 71, whose career of more than 50 years stretches from early folk songs like The Times They Are A-Changin' and When the Ship Comes In to the recondite rock of recent albums like Modern Times and Together Through Life, was presented with the medal at a ceremony in the White House, where President Obama said of him, There is not a bigger giant in the history of American music. Mr. Obama also praised Mr. Dylans voice for its weight and unique gravelly power that redefined not just what music sounded like but the message it carried and how it made people feel.

title: Flutes Revised Age Dates the Sound of Music Earlier
description: In hillside caves of southwestern Germany, archaeologists in recent years have uncovered the beginnings of music and art by early modern humans migrating into Europe from Africa. New dating evidence shows that these oldest known musical instruments in the world, flutes made of bird bone and mammoth ivory, are even older than first thought.

title: In Crown Heights, Malfatti for the Trilbys
description: THIRTEEN years ago, no one in Manhattan went to Brooklyn for dinner by choice. You had to dangle Peter Luger as bait, and a car service back to the city, or at least an escort to the subway.

title: Answers About How to Deal With Pests, Part 2
description: Following an article in the Real Estate section this month about handling pest problems in New York City, readers submitted questions to our guest expert, Gary Braness, a pest management consultant and owner of Yosemite Environmental Services, about how to evict their unwanted roommates.

title: Pictures of the Day: Qatar and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Qatar, Italy, Egypt and Somalia.

title: Israel to Aid Wider Range of Rabbis
description: JERUSALEM  The Israeli government announced on Tuesday that, for the first time, it planned to pay the salaries of a small number of Reform and Conservative rabbis, as it does with many Orthodox ones.

title: High-Priced Tickets Help Make for a Record Year at the Broadway Box Office
description: Broadway musicals and plays had another record-setting season at the box office, grossing a total of $1.139 billion from 40 new productions and other long-running shows during the 2011-12 theater season, according to data released by the Broadway League on Tuesday. Audience attendance was 12.33 million, roughly the same as in the 2010-11 season, according to the League, a trade association of theater owners and producers.

title: Business Day Live  Microsoft and Skype
description: May 29, 2012  Microsoft still working to integrate Skype.

title: Few Buy Chromebooks, but Google Keeps Pushing
description: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg NewsWhat I am sure of is the level of commitment inside the company, said Sundar Pichai, the head of Chrome at Google.

title: Now Showing | Lone Star
description: The blazing sun is at the heart of the artist Jason Glassers mesmerizing new show, Lone Star, which is on view through June 10 at Parkers Box in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Born in Connecticut, Glasser lives in Paris with his wife, whos French. But his latest work sprouted out of the year they just spent in Texas a self-imposed exile, Glasser called it, intended to help his young children learn English. That sojourn produced a trippy silent film, streaming above, which was made around Barton Springs, a popular place to swim in Austin. In the exhibition, this film is projected onto a concave piece of glass that was once a television screen. My tourist-grade camera does some interesting things when the sun reflects off the water so intensely, Glasser said. The images in this film have not been manipulated other than what I got just using my camera.

title: A Kill List, a Marine Ritual and a Therapist for 3,500 Patients
description: Welcome back from the Memorial Day holiday, readers. Here are a couple of articles you dont want to miss.

title: Ask About the Euro
description: European Union leaders are known for muddling through. Unfortunately, that means the euro zone sovereign debt crisis can be a muddle for readers trying to follow it. Here at the IHT we try to anticipate what questions readers may have, but no doubt we have missed plenty. So please ask me whatever youd like to know about the European Central Bank, Grexit, euro zone banks or any other topic related to the debt crisis, and Ill do my best to answer.

title: Digital Notes: Samsung Music Hub Takes on Just About Everyone
description: are download stores, Internet radio players, streaming services, online lockers and services tied to mobile devices. The only way for a company to distinguish itself, it would seem, would be to combine as many of these features as possible into a single product.

title: Cheap Natural Gas Prompts Energy Department to Soften Its Line on Fuel Cells
description: The Energy Department estimates that 95 percent of the United States hydrogen is produced from natural gas. The abundance of that contentious fossil fuel has revised the cost equation for fuel-cell vehicles. Even hydrogen skeptics like Energy Secretary Steven Chu are taking a second look.

title: Will Nuclear Plants Withstand Quakes and Floods?
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission should consider requiring nuclear power plants to analyze their vulnerability to natural hazards like earthquakes by using the same advanced tools that the industry uses to understand the risks from mechanical accidents,  a new report from the Government Accountability Office argues.

title: Dining Calendar
description: Benefits (Appetites Welcome)

title: Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company Announces New Season
description: The Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company said on Tuesday that it would go on two major tours next season, a month-long swing in Germany, Italy, France and the Netherlands starting in late September and a two-week series of stops in the United States in November. The tours help mark the companys 30th anniversary. The repertory will include Story/Time, which was inspired by music of John Cage; new and reconstructed works set to classical music and a group of early avant-guard works called Body Against Body.

title: Noomi, Rooney; Rooney, Noomi
description: In this weeks issue of the magazine, Karen Olsson profiles the Swedish film star Noomi Rapace, whose next movie is Prometheus, a big-budget science-fiction opus from the director Ridley Scott. American audiences are likely to know her, though, as the original girl with the dragon tattoo  which is to say, she played Lisbeth Salander in the Swedish film adaptation of the best-selling thriller before Rooney Mara played Lisbeth Salander in the American adaptation of the same book.

title: Video: Microsoft and Skype
description: Microsoft is still working to integrate the online calling service Skype, which at $8.5 billion was the biggest acquisition in Microsofts history.

title: A Theatrical Patriarch, Onstage and Off
description: James Earl Jones smiled broadly as he recalled the moment, years back, when his young son couldnt figure out why people were hovering nearby, asking for autographs.

title: A Palestinian Whose Cameras Are Witnesses and Casualties of Conflict
description: 5 Broken Cameras provides a grim reminder  just in case you needed one  of the bitter intractability of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. A chronicle of protest and endurance, punctuated by violence and tiny glimmers of hope, this documentary is unlikely to persuade anyone with a hardened view of the issue to think again. For anyone who retains an interest in the human contours of the situation, however, the movie is necessary, if difficult, viewing.

title: At the French Open, Tennis Isnt the Only Attraction
description: When it comes to lunch at Roland Garros, the complex has much more to offer than hot dogs and popcorn.

description: In a cutthroat world with fierce competition, a disembodied voice says.

title: A Profusion of Tiger Killers and Their Temple Maidens
description: To watch successive performances of the three-act ballet La Bayadre, no matter what the company or in whose production, involves its trials. The choreography, by Marius Petipa and a number of successors, ranges from the sublime to the ridiculous; the music, by Ludwig Minkus, is often trivial; the narrative is melodramatic and the storytelling repeatedly hammy.

title: Give Me Your Tired, Your Over-Taxed
description: A couple of conservative news outlets reported today that New York State shed 1.3 million residents on net over the last ten years, with more than 600,000 leaving for Florida. During the same period, more than 200,000 Pennsylvanians also moved to Florida.

title: Over 30 Is Far From Over the Hill in the Mens Draw
description: PARIS  In 2002, there were 11 men playing singles in the French Open who were age 30 or older. A decade later, there were 37 of them, making up nearly a third of the initial singles draw. That is an Open-era record, and they are not just here to make up the numbers.

title: Butler, Shine Keeps Mini Cooper Account
description: Anyone who has been watching Mad Men this season knows how fiercely advertising agencies fight to win automotive accounts. Now comes a real-life reminder of how fiercely they fight to keep them.

title: For Private Equity, Fewer Deals in Leaner Times
description: It is not easy being a private equity firm like the Blackstone Group or Kohlberg Kravis Roberts these days. Not only do you have to worry about being dragged through the mud in a presidential election, but the business isnt the money machine it used to be.

title: More Room for Ideas in a Smaller Office
description: Ever since the economy started to slow down about five years ago, companies have been looking for ways to reduce their office space costs. One option that has become more popular is reconfiguring the office to fit the same number of workers in a smaller space, and either subleasing the leftover square footage or returning it to the landlord.

title: A Rental Market Surge in Brooklyn
description: The market for multifamily buildings in Brooklyn has been heating up over the last year. But the recent sale of 111 Kent Avenue in Williamsburg was stunning even in a hot market.

title: For Japanese Job Seekers, Overseas Study Can Be a Deal Killer
description: In this mind-boggling. eye-popping piece  given todays global economy  our colleague Hiroko Tabuchi reports that for young Japanese professionals an overseas education can be a bad thing.

title: With Recall Election Near, Walker Raises More Than $5 Million
description: Gov. Scott Walker, the Republican of Wisconsin who faces a recall election next week, raised more than $5 million in the last month alone, his campaign announced on Tuesday, a day when new fund-raising reports have to be filed to state officials.

title: Shuffling Through an Underground Artery to Gaza
description: RAFAH, Egypt  They stood just outside the gates of the Rafah crossing on the Egyptian side of the border with Gaza, a couple of inconspicuous Bedouin men waiting for people to be denied entry. As the disappointed travelers retreated, the Bedouins whispered from behind the gates: You want to go to the tunnels? Fifty dollars. Their gaze fixed on the Egyptian border police officers, who turn a blind eye to the Bedouins so long as they do not mention the tunnels within earshot.

title: On Night of Trump Fund-Raiser, Romney Jokes About Presidential Requirements
description: LAS VEGAS  Mitt Romney, who is trying to distance himself from Donald J. Trumps remarks about President Obamas citizenship, joked about a new constitutional requirement for the presidency on Tuesday evening: business experience.

description: To the Editor:

title: A Declining Source of Energy
description: While coal still remains the primary source of electricity in the United States, its share has fallen.

title: Pep Boys Terminates Sale to Private Equity Firm
description: Pep Boys said late Tuesday that it had agreed to end its proposed $1 billion sale to the Gores Group, after the private equity firm raised concerns about the companys deteriorating financial health.

title: Presidents Cup Captains Named
description: Fred Couples and Nick Price were named captains for the 2013 Presidents Cup, which will be held at Muirfield Village Golf Club.

title: Lawsuit Accuses Citys Jails of Condoning Inmate Abuse
description: Eleven current and former inmates in New York Citys jails have filed a lawsuit charging that correction officials have tolerated and even condoned the unprovoked beatings of inmates by guards, resulting in serious injuries to prisoners and millions of dollars in legal settlements paid by the city.

title: A Little-Used Fire Company, Rescued Annually
description: It has become a rite of spring on City Island in the Bronx, as reliable as the tourists who descend with warm weather or the traffic that backs up the main avenue. It is time, again, to save Ladder 53.

title: Even in Coal Country, the Fight for an Industry
description: LOUISA, Ky.  For generations, coal has been king in this Appalachian town. It provided heat, light and jobs for the hundreds of people who worked in the nearby coal mines and the smoke-coughing Big Sandy power plant that burned their black bounty.

title: Doc Watson, Blind Guitar Wizard Who Influenced Generations, Dies at 89
description: Doc Watson, the guitarist and folk singer whose flat-picking style elevated the acoustic guitar to solo status in bluegrass and country music, and whose interpretations of traditional American music profoundly influenced generations offolk and rock guitarists, died on Tuesday in Winston-Salem, N.C. He was 89.

title: As Rumors Swirl, Dustin Johnson Returns
description: DUBLIN, Ohio  Dustin Johnson was gone from the PGA Tour for 11 weeks, but he was not forgotten. While Johnson rehabilitated a back injury that he said he incurred while pushing a Jet Ski into the water, his agent, David Winkle, was shooting down rumors in the blogosphere that Johnson had failed a tour-administered drug test and was in drug rehabilitation.

title: A Prize-Winners Personal Insight
description: The National Press Photographers Association announced on Tuesday its final group of Best of Photojournalism 2012 winners. Ross Taylor of The Virginian-Pilot was chosen Photojournalist of the Year (Larger Markets), and David Weatherwax of The Herald, in Jasper, Ind., was named Photojournalist of the Year (Smaller Markets).

title: City Pushes for More Authority in Sexual Misconduct Cases
I Apologize, Ex-Rutgers Student Says Before Going to Jail
description: TRENTON (AP)  A former Rutgers University student who used a webcam to spy on his roommates intimate encounter with another man days before the roommate killed himself apologized on Tuesday and said he had accepted responsibility for what he had done.

title: Tech Suits Endanger Innovation
description: Casual observers would find little in common between the smartphones in their pockets and the funky backbeat of the Beastie Boys Car Thief. But these two creations will go down together in the annals of creativity as reminders of the flaws in our intellectual property laws.

title: Paul Simon Takes Us Back
description: Of all the raw and compelling voices in Joe Berlingers must-see documentary, Under African Skies, about the making of Paul Simons classic Graceland album in South Africa in 1985  and his reunion with the same African artists 25 years later  my favorite is that of Graceland bass player Bakithi Kumalo. He tells about that day in 1985 when he met Simon in a Johannesburg recording studio:

title: Still Rooting Against Brodeur
description: After Martin Brodeur and the Devils vanquished the Rangers in the Eastern Conference finals last week, one might have thought that talk of the Devils loss to the Rangers in 1994 was finally vanquished too. But apparently not.

title: Our National Mammal
description: The United States has a national bird, of course  the bald eagle, which was adopted as such on June 20, 1782. Last week, Senator Mike Enzi, a Republican of Wyoming, and Senator Tim Johnson, a Democrat of South Dakota, introduced a bill to name the North American bison as the national mammal. It is hard to think of a better or more deserving creature for that distinction.

title: Couples and Price Named Presidents Cup Captains
description: DUBLIN, Ohio  Fred Couples and Nick Price on Tuesday were named captains for the 2013 Presidents Cup, which will be held at Muirfield Village Golf Club, site of this weeks Memorial Tournament.

title: Dewey Hopes to Resolve Bankruptcy Quickly
description: As Dewey & LeBoeuf began its bankruptcy proceedings on Tuesday, its advisers said their aim was to speed the failed law firm through Chapter 11.

title: After Scandal in Soccer, Italys Leader Urges Break
description: ROME  In his efforts to save Italy from the brink of economic disaster, Prime Minister Mario Monti has repeatedly incurred the wrath of taxpayers and pensioners upset by the severity of his measures.

title: Rhode Island: Third City Loses Control of Finances
description: Gov. Lincoln Chafee appointed a commission on Tuesday to oversee the finances of Woonsocket. Officials in the struggling city, whose schools face a $10 million budget deficit, requested the commission this weekend, after a supplemental tax increase failed to pass. This is the third time Rhode Island has taken over the finances of a municipality; East Providence and Central Falls have fiscal overseers.

title: North Carolina: Tease, Not a Verdict, in Edwards Case
description: Deliberations in the federal corruption trial of former Senator John Edwards stretched into a seventh day on Tuesday, with little indication that a decision was near. Noting that high school graduation season had arrived, Judge Catherine C. Eagles asked the jury to send her any potential coming conflicts. The stress inside the courtroom has built steadily as the jury seeks a verdict in the trial that began April 23. But on Tuesday, the judge inadvertently injected a little tension-relieving humor. The jury sent me a note saying they have reached a, she said, causing nearly every observer to jerk to attention. After a moment, she continued: good stopping point. The courtroom erupted in laughter and Abbe Lowell, Mr. Edwardss lead lawyer, dropped his head to the defense table. That was mean. Im sorry, the judge said.

title: Heavy Debt, but No Degree
description: In the weak economy, people who graduate from name-brand colleges are struggling to repay the heavy debt they often rack up getting through school. But college debt is an even bigger problem for the growing numbers of borrowers who drop out without degrees.

title: Clintons Make Great Neighbors, but for How Long?
description: CHAPPAQUA, N.Y.  It might be assumed that Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton has more pressing items on her to-do list than making it each year to the local Memorial Day Parade.

title: With Records Gone, Odds of Finding Boys Remains Are Even Slimmer
description: On the morning after Memorial Day in 1979, the sidewalks in the Manhattan neighborhood where Etan Patz lived would have been overflowing with trash accumulated over the long weekend, clumps of refuse from the homes and studios of artists and the few stores and restaurants that catered to them.

title: To Screen or Not?
description: A panel of experts that advises the government on screening tests stirred up controversy last fall when it proposed that healthy men should not routinely get a blood test to detect prostate cancer. It warned that the test may push them to undergo unnecessary invasive tests and treatments apt to harm more people than help. This month, the panel, after further review of the scientific evidence, issued the same recommendation in final form.

title: A Stumble Is Surprising, but Its No Longer Rare
description: PARIS

title: The Massacre at Houla
description: The decision on Tuesday by the United States, Britain, France and at least five other major nations to expel senior Syrian diplomats was a powerful sign of international revulsion at the massacre of more than 100 Syrians in the village of Houla. But it was still short of the tougher diplomatic and economic sanctions needed to put real pressure on President Bashar al-Assad and his cronies. Russia, in particular, can finally help, or continue to be a roadblock to tougher action.

title: Nomination His, Romney Steps Up Attack on Obama
description: WASHINGTON  Mitt Romney, having initially weathered the first sustained general election attack, is entering a critical 90-day stretch to the Republican convention on relatively equal footing with the White House and is unleashinga new offensive to win over independent voters and further undermine confidence in President Obamas stewardship of the economy.

title: Using Dirty Products to Clean Up
description: FOR decades, fans have been able to buy merchandise, like T-shirts and coffee mugs, inspired by their favorite television shows. Now, a show has produced products meant to be practical.

title: Euro 2012 Rosters Released Under Racism Cloud
description: The final rosters from the 16 teams competing in next months European Championship in Poland and Ukraine were released Tuesday. UEFA has the final lists here, or see below. There were few surprises, as most teams had narrowed their rosters earlier.

title: Romney Calls for Action on Syria, but His Party Is Divided
description: WASHINGTON  The massacre of more than 100 civilians, many of them children, in Syria over the weekend has presented Mitt Romney with a new opportunity to sound a familiar theme: that President Obamas foreign policy is feckless and lacking in courage.

title: Challenges Mount for Chinese Maker of Electric Cars
description: HONG KONG  Four years ago, the BYD Company promoted the electric battery technology it was developing as a way to help China transform the automobile. No less an investor than Warren E. Buffett, one of the worlds richest men, boasted about the companys prospects and bought a 10 percent stake.

title: Seeking Easier Way to Fire Teachers in Sex Cases
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said on Tuesday that the city should have the final say on whether teachers accused of sexual misconduct should be fired, even if hearings determined that they should keep their jobs.

title: Mets Shortstop Roulette Turns to No. 6
description: One turned ankle has led to the Mets trotting out their sixth shortstop this season, although at least the latest option has experience at the position.

title: Plea Deal in Robbery Involving Nuns Death
description: A 20-year-old Harlem man who was initially charged with murder pleaded guilty on Tuesday to an armed robbery that he and an accomplice committed two years ago and which ended when their getaway car killed a nun in Harlem.

title: Supporters and Critics of Annan See Crisis in Syria as a Threat to His Legacy
description: Kofi Annan, the soft-spoken former United Nations diplomat and secretary general, has successfully navigated through multiple wars in the Middle East, the Balkans breakup, African genocides, a corruption scandal that touched his family and a raft of other crises over a career that spans more than five decades, winning a Nobel Peace Prize along the way. But friends and critics alike say Syria could be Mr. Annans undoing.

title: Andromeda Is Coming!
description: WASHINGTON

title: Allen Sees His Sweet Jumper Go Awry
description: MIAMI  The artistry of Ray Allens jump shot is as evident in the jump as in the shot, as much about feet as it is about hands. When Allen rises and lands in the same spot, all is right. Baskets swish, records fall, the Boston Celtics celebrate.

title: Public-Place Laws Tighten Rein on Sex Offenders
description: HUNTINGTON BEACH, Calif.  Convicted sex offenders are barred from surfing at the famous pier in this Orange County city.

title: Being Smart Can Beat Being Big
description: The N.B.A. championship might be claimed by an East Coast city (Miami or Boston) that ranks high on the list of Americas most celebrated sports markets or by a Western Conference outpost (San Antonio or Oklahoma City) that many would have difficulty finding on a map.

title: Thats Not Recyclable, Mom. Thats My Savings!
description: At age 12, Max Becker can admit that he and his twin sister, Drew, have the kinds of issues that simmer between siblings day after day, year after year. My sister is, I dont feel, the most trustworthy, he explained on Tuesday. She has stolen a lot of my stuff in the past.

title: Romney, on His Big Day, Finds Himself Upstaged
description: LAS VEGAS  It was supposed to be a day of triumph for Mitt Romney, when he would at last formally claim the Republican presidential nomination with a victory in the Texas primary. And Mr. Romney was to focus attention on an aggressive new attack on President Obama, highlighting the White Houses role in backing failed companies like Solyndra.

title: Midtown Manhattan, 8:32 P.M.
Yankees Claim Former Mets Reliever Igarashi
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  The Yankees added another bullpen option to the organization Tuesday when they claimed the former Mets right-hander Ryota Igarashi off waivers from the Toronto Blue Jays. Igarashi reported to Class AAA Scranton/Wilkes-Barre in time for Tuesdays game.

title: Lottery Numbers
Drug Maker Seeks Protection Within Bill Favoring Generics
description: WASHINGTON  One of the few bills moving through Congress with bipartisan support this spring would speed government approval of lower-cost generic copies of brand-name drugs. But one company, with help from an influential former congressman, is lobbying to protect its most lucrative brand-name product against generic competition and appears to have had some success in the House, potentially altering the bill to make it more favorable for the company.

title: Long-Running TV Show
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  We lost DICK CLARK in mid-April, but today we get to remember all of the pleasure he gave us as the Worlds Oldest TEENAGER and host of televisions iconic music show AMERICAN BANDSTAND.

title: Romneys School Surprise
description: Last weeks speech by Mitt Romney, in which he presented his education reform plan to a group of Latino leaders in Washington, drew attention mainly because he criticized teachers unions and endorsed private school vouchers. But those points were perfectly predictable for a Republican candidate and not especially newsworthy.

title: Adding to Unease of a Drug War Alliance
description: MEXICO CITY  The biggest military corruption case here in recent years has worsened an already frayed relationship between American law enforcement officials and the Mexican Army, the institution most trusted and empowered by officials here to fight the drug war.

title: Two Exiled Flyers Land In Good Place
description: NEWARK  Eight months later, the shock had subsided for Mike Richards. Several questions remained unanswered  chief among them being just why, exactly, the Flyers had felt compelled to trade him, their captain, to Los Angeles last June as the pice de rsistance of Philadelphias biggest single-day shake-up since it mortgaged its future for Eric Lindros 20 years ago. But in the interim, Richards had vented plenty and reflected enough to have realized that there are worse things than wearing flip-flops to work in winter.

title: Wasting Time Is New Divide in Digital Era
description: In the 1990s, the term digital divide emerged to describe technologys haves and have-nots. It inspired many efforts to get the latest computing tools into the hands of all Americans, particularly low-income families.

title: Home-Court Edge Includes Short Walk to Work
description: PARIS  This May, same as every May, tennis players descended on the French Open from all corners of the world. They came from Australia and Argentina, from Croatia and Kazakhstan, from Japan and Slovakia and points in between.

title: Two Close Calls in the Outfield for Swisher and Granderson
description: ANAHEIM, Calif. Nick Swisher had just finished describing to reporters late Monday night how he avoided a serious injury during his outfield collision with center fielder Curtis Granderson when he went around a corner to grab a bottle of water.

title: Waivers for 8 More States From No Child Left Behind
description: The Obama administration freed eight states from core provisions of the No Child Left Behind education law on Tuesday, bringing to 19 the number of states granted waivers this year, and officials said that even more states would soon qualify for them.

title: Known for Scoring, and Now for Leading
description: NEWARK  The main concourse at Prudential Center is just one long escalator ride up from the floor of the glass atrium where Ilya Kovalchuk, shaven and wearing a dark suit, was the focal point of a news conference 22 months ago to herald his gigantic contract with the Devils.

title: Nudging Bahrain, Without Pushing It Away
Indias Economy Slows, With Global Implications
description: NEW DELHI  Indias coalition government just celebrated the third anniversary of its tenure with a self-congratulatory banquet that could not have been more poorly timed: Indias currency, the rupee, is falling; investment is down; inflation is rising; and deficits are eating away at government coffers.

title: After Texas Vote, Romney Secures G.O.P. Nomination
description: After a long and wearying primary battle, Mitt Romney officially secured the Republican presidential nomination on Tuesday with a victory in a Texas primary that delivered the final batch of delegates needed ahead of the partys convention in August.

title: Deportation Decision Awaits WikiLeaks Founder
description: LONDON  Britains highest court is to announce Wednesday whether the WikiLeaks founder, Julian Assange, should be deported to Sweden to face allegations of sexual abuses there, the culmination of an 18-month legal battle.

title: Corrections: May 30
description: FRONT PAGE

title: U.S. Proposal Would Arm Italys Drones
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration plans to arm Italys small fleet of Reaper surveillance drones with Hellfire missiles and precision-guided bombs, a move that advocates say supports a staunch NATO ally in Afghanistan and that critics contend represents a potentially risky proliferation of advanced technology.

title: From Baseball to Books, Dickey Shares Thoughts With Fans
description: R. A. Dickey can make a baseball waggle and turn in astonishing ways, subverting the expectations of those who face him.

title: Unexpected Hitting From Pitcher and Shortstop Lifts Mets
description: If Jeremy Hefner was auditioning to keep his job as theMets fifth starter, he did plenty Tuesday night to bolster his case. And this time, even a rain delay could not get into his way.

title: Premier of Turkey Seeks Limits on Abortions
description: ISTANBUL  Calling abortion an act of murder and an insidious plan to reduce the Turkish population, Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan called on Tuesday for legislation to restrict womens access to the procedure.

title: Finals Preview: Devils vs. Kings
description: For every player involved, being in the Stanley Cup finals is a dream come true. This year, it is especially true. The Devils finished ninth over all in the regular season and the Los Angeles Kings 13th, the first time both teams in the finals have come from outside the N.H.L.s top eight since the playoffs expanded to 16 teams in 1980. But Los Angeles has gone 12-2 through the first three rounds, becoming the first playoff team to go 8-0 on the road. And the Devils, after needing a Game 7 overtime to beat Florida, knocked off Philadelphia and the Rangers in a surprisingly quick 11 games. Despite their seedings, this is a championship series between two very deserving clubs. JEFF Z. KLEIN

title: A City Confronts Its Image
description: A recent magazine article dubbed Lawrence the most godforsaken place in Massachusetts, and for many of its residents, those were fighting words.

title: Rangel Forcefully Defends His Record, as a Challenger Looks On
description: Representative Charles B. Rangel, acknowledging on Tuesday that he faces a significant challenge to his re-election, offered a rambling but forceful defense of his service and his ethics while appearing beside his best-known challenger, State Senator Adriano Espaillat. Mr. Rangel said that he was the only candidate with the experience and qualifications to represent his Congressional district.

title: Halladays Injury Is Latest to Test Phillies Resilience
description: On May 29, 2010, Roy Halladay tossed a perfect game for the Philadelphia Phillies. Ryan Howard made the final putout at first base, and catcher Carlos Ruiz wrapped Halladay in an embrace. On Tuesday, two years to the day later, Halladay joined Howard on the disabled list, and Ruiz sat out with a strained hamstring.

title: Texas Runoff Set in G.O.P. Race for Senate
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  In a heated race for the open United States Senate seat in Texas, Lt. Gov. David Dewhurst failed to win enough votes in the Republican primary on Tuesday to avert a runoff with Ted Cruz, a Houston lawyer who cast the election as a battle between the moderate Republican establishment and Tea Party conservatives.

title: After Seeing a Dismal Reflection of Itself, a City Moves to Change
description: LAWRENCE, Mass.  There is a litany of reasons one might avoid this city: double-digit unemployment, high crime rates, struggling public schools and, at the top, enduring suspicions of chronic mismanagement.

title: How China Flouts Its Laws
description: SINCE I arrived in the United States on May 19, people have asked me, What do you want to do here? I have come here to study temporarily, not to seek political asylum. And while I pursue my studies, I hope that the Chinese government and the Communist Party will conduct a thorough investigation of the lawless punishment inflicted on me and my family over the past seven years.

title: Marina Keegan, Journalist and Playwright, Dies at 22
description: Marina Keegan, a journalist and playwright who won national attention for urging her fellow college students to resist the lure of Wall Street, died in a car crash Saturday afternoon in Dennis, Mass., just days after graduating from Yale. She was 22.

title: Kathi Kamen Goldmark, Writers Catalyst, Dies at 63
description: Kathi Kamen Goldmark had made a lot of friends in the literary world by shepherding authors on book tours when one day inspiration struck: what the very best authors yearn to be, she realized, are rock stars.

title: How Exercise Can Jog the Memory
description: From our archives.

title: New Stephen King Thriller Coming Next June
description: You dont have to be Stephen King to find small-town amusement parks inherently terrifying, but that author sees enough suspense in the environs of a 1970s-era carnival  and all the rusty arcade attractions and rickety roller coasters that suggests  to set a new novel there. On Wednesday the Hard Case Crime imprint of Titan Books plans to announce that it will publish Joyland, a new work of fiction by Mr. King, whose protagonist is a college student working at a North Carolina theme park in the summer of 1973. While employed there the character confronts the legacy of a vicious murder, the fate of a dying child, and the ways both will change his life forever, the publisher said in a news release. Charles Ardai, the Hard Case Crime editor, said in a statement that Joyland is a whodunit, its a carny novel, its a story about growing up and growing old, and about those who dont get to do either because death comes for them before their time.

title: Syracuse University Filmmaker Killed in Syria

title: Richard W. Lyman, Ex-President of Stanford University, Dies at 88

title: Canada: Governing Party Headquarters Receives Package Containing a Foot
description: A parcel containing a severed human foot was delivered to the headquarters of the governing Conservative Party of Canada on Tuesday. Fred DeLorey, a spokesman for the party, said that a suspicious package was sent to our office but referred all other questions to the police. The Ottawa police said the package was bloodstained, but have provided few other details. The coroners office later confirmed that it contained a human foot. Since 2007, eight feet have washed up on British Columbias coastline, and three have been found along the coast of Washington State.

title: Trumped

title: How the Art Market Thrives on Inequality
description: A few weeks ago, when Edvard Munchs iconic painting The Scream went for about $120 million and became the most expensive artwork ever sold at auction, it seemed like we had reached the climax of a fine-art bubble. After all, from 2003 to 2007, the fine-art market grew even faster than subprime housing. And then it kept on growing, pausing only momentarily during the crisis before hurtling even further upward. Eleven of the 20 highest prices ever paid at auction have occurred since 2008, when the global economy all but collapsed. Less than a week after the Munch auction, Mark Rothkos Orange, Red, Yellow sold for nearly $87 million.

title: Craig Venters Bugs Might Save the World
description: In the menagerie of Craig Venters imagination, tiny bugs will save the world. They will be custom bugs, designer bugs  bugs that only Venter can create. He will mix them up in his private laboratory from bits and pieces of DNA, and then he will release them into the air and the water, into smokestacks and oil spills, hospitals and factories and your house.

title: Q&A With 2012 Hall of Famer Tony Meola
description: U.S. Soccer will induct four new members into the National Soccer Hall of Fame on Wednesday before a friendly against Brazil (8 p.m., ESPN2) at FedEx Field in Landover, Md. One of them will be Tony Meola, a New Jersey native who played 100 times for the national team, appeared in two World Cups and was a reserve for a third. Meola was a transitional figure in soccer in the United States, bridging the gap between an era when few followed the national team to one it which it drew 100,000 people to the Rose Bowl for a World Cup match. He was an ambassador for the countrys first World Cup and then for its new league, M.L.S., where he played for the MetroStars and won a championship with Kansas City. He now runs his own company, GK1 Sports; coaches two youth teams; and works with U.S. Soccer sponsors like Allstate, for whom he conducts clinics and appearances as part of its Good Hands FC program.

But the focus in this first trailer is firmly on Anne Hathaway, who as the ill-fated Fantine offers a rendition of I Dreamed a Dream thats as unembellished as her closely cropped hair. title: Image of the Day: May 30
Spring Interactive and Pop-Up Book Roundup
description: UP, TALL AND HIGH!Written and illustrated by Ethan Long.40 pp. G.P. Putnams Sons. $15.99.(Picture book; ages 1 to 6)Doubling as a baby book and an early reader, this book about the ups and downs of avian rivalry succeeds abundantly on both fronts. Three linked stories feature three birds trying to outdo the others in one way or another. Who is tallest? Who flies highest? Is it better to be up or down? With clever humor, thesimple text conveys lessons about adjectives, opposites and early math concepts. Longs brightly colored exotic birds look like a cross between Mo Willemss pigeon and Nickelodeon cartoons  animated, expressive and entertaining. A judicious sprinkling of oversize flaps provides an interactive element that expands  literally  on the proceedings.ANIMAL 123By Britta Teckentrup.18 pp. Handprint Books/Chronicle Books. $12.99.(Picture book; ages 2 to 4)

title: Kim France, Starting Over at 48
description: YOU might guess that working for a shopping magazine is pure fun and frivolity, but after a decade as editor in chief of Lucky Magazine, the Cond Nast title she founded, Kim France was suffering from serious, pretty much daily migraine headaches that I had begun to suspect only a pretty profound lifestyle change could improve, she said recently.

title: Vietnam War Images, Photosynthesized
description: Growing up in California, Binh Danh was fascinated by the weird discolorations left on the lawn by the sun. Shaped like a garden hose or a rake, the images were baked into the grass, the sun bleaching the bent blades. At the time, Mr. Danh could only marvel at the effects of photosynthesis  the process that sustains all plants  but by college hed discovered that the suns power could also be used to replicate other images.

description: PARIS  Sloane Stephens rolled past Bethanie Mattek-Sands, 6-1, 6-1, to advance to the third round of the French Open.

description: Two weeks ago, I had a back-and-forth with The New Republics Alec MacGillis over whether it was fair to suggest (as I had) that the Obama White House would much rather talk about social issueslike the contraception mandate, the DREAM Act, and even gay marriage than about the economy and jobs. title: More Genes Than Humans: The Tomato Decoded
description: The tomato, whose genome has just now been decoded, turns out to be one well-endowed vegetable, possessing 31,760 genes. This rich legacy, possibly a reflection of the disaster that killed off the dinosaurs, is some 7,000 more than that of a person, and presents a complex puzzle to scientists who hope to understand its secrets.

title: Detached From His Label
description: ON March 16, just two days after Simon Spurr received a nomination for best mens wear designer from the Council of Fashion Designers of America, he stunned the fashion industry by resigning from his own label, which is only six years old.

title: A Gap in College Graduates Leaves Some Cities Behind
description: DAYTON, Ohio  As cities like this one try to reinvent themselves after losing large swaths of their manufacturing sectors, they are discovering that one of the most critical ingredients for a successful transformation  college graduates  is in perilously short supply.

title: On Climate Change, Its Money vs. Mouth
description: A number of major United States corporations publicly support climate change science but contribute heavily to politicians and research groups that deny or play down the threat of global warming, according to a new study from the Union of Concerned Scientists.

title: Behind the Poster: The Bad and the Better
description: When the playwright Derek Ahonen needed a poster for his latest work, the dark detective comedy The Bad and the Better, he asked Danica Novgorodoff, a graphic novelist and illustrator, for the kitchen sink.

title: An Art Project Provides a Snapshot of a Closing School
Images of Vietnam War, Transferred to Plants
description: Over on the Lens blog, our colleagues have published a post on the work of Binh Danh, a photographer who has used photosynthesis to re-envision the Vietnam War.

title: Books Under Glass: The Many Faces of E-Readers
description: IN some ways, the only reason to stick with dead tree books these days is nostalgia. E-readers are more fully featured and much more impressive than ever, and they have fallen far below the $100 price tag because of improved technologies. If you are still content to read the latest Stephen King novel in its full five-pounds-of-paper glory, get ready to rethink your habits.

title: A Retreat for Haves, a Shelter for Have-Nots
description: With its curved lines and steel exterior, the House Arc may resemble an old Airstream trailer, but its design was inspired by a bike rack.

title: Hidden Water: Where Does It All Go?
description: Water, a plentiful banality to some Americans but a source of conflict for millions of others, is a more intriguing commodity than you may have thought. At least, thats the conclusion one might draw from Surface Tension: The Future of Water, an exhibition that opened today in Manhattan as part of the 2012 World Science Festival.

title: Academy Picks Piano and Pali to Design Film Museum
description: LOS ANGELES  The new movie museum planned by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences has its architects. Renzo Piano, whose work includes the recent expansion of the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, and Zoltan Pali, who has helped restore the Greek Theater and other buildings here, will join in building the film museum. The institution will be located in the old May Company department store next to Lacma.

title: RIM Shares Drop, and Analysts Warn of Further Trouble
description: Research in Motions already depressed shares fell sharply on Wednesday after the company unexpectedly warned that it would probably post a loss for its first quarter, and several analysts predicted worse is yet to come.

title: Leap Producers Keep the Faith by Underwriting Tony Awards  Number
description: The producers and investors in the Broadway musical Leap of Faith lost more than $14 million when the show closed on May 13 after receiving terrible reviews from critics. Usually the only thing left would be the tax write-offs. But even as the biggest flop of the season, Leap of Faith had an unusual asterisk  its single Tony Award nomination, a major one, for best musical. And so the producers had a decision to make: Whether to leave Leap of Faith dead and buried, or capitalize on the nomination and pay to stage a musical number on the Tony Awards telecast on CBS on June 10?

title: A Teacher's Aide, Accused of Sexual Abuse, Waits for Justice
New Digs | The Hole Shop at the Hole Gallery
description: Back in 1999, before retail moved in and skinny jeans became the neighborhoods de facto uniform, the hippest place on the Lower East Side was Alife, a sneaker shop-cum-gallery on Orchard Street that served as both clubhouse and launch pad for a generation of downtown artists, including Steve Powers, a k a ESPO; Ryan McGinley; and Dash Snow. Two of Alifes founders, Rob Cristofaro and Arnaud Delecolle, have since gone on to found a design agency called New York Art Department, under the guise of which theyve taken on a new retail project: the Hole Shop at the Hole Gallery. The idea is to bring some of what we were doing at Alife, before the scene was appropriated and commercialized, and apply it to whats going on today, Delecolle explains. The merchandise includes books, T-shirts, Polaroid cameras from the Impossible Project, Krink markers and sustainable furniture made by the Brooklyn design firm Uhuru. Since taking over the Bowery space a couple of months ago, NYAD has also hosted book-release parties  the French graffiti artist FAFI dropped by last week to sign copies of her first comic book  as well as film screenings and a 24-hour-a-day curated video screen thats currently under the auspices of Luck You, a collective of teenage artists who work out of a loft in Chinatown. Continuing Delecolle and Cristofaros tradition of introducing new artists to wider audiences, on June 1 theyre curating their first show at the Hole Gallery. It will feature the work of a graffiti artist known only as Jim Joe, whose combination of anonymity, ubiquity (Jim Joes cryptic tags are all over the East Village and the Lower East Side) and epigrammatic use of social media has spurred a cult following. Jim Joe is one of those artists who have one foot in the graffiti world and one foot in something weirder and more conceptual, says Kathy Grayson, the Holes founder. Im really excited to see what he comes up with for his first gallery exhibition. Im sure that it will capture the odd humor and serendipitous, random mischievousness of what he does in public places, and I get the sense that he is sophisticated enough to make it work in a new way in a gallery space. I would definitely say that this is a very hotly anticipated show as no one knows who he is and everyone wants to see what he does next.

title: Vintage Murano Glass on the Block
description: Frank Toskan, a founder of MAC Cosmetics, spent about two decades amassing his collection of Murano art glass, and on June 9, Wright in Chicago will auction it off.

title: DwellStudios New Dwelling
description: DwellStudio, a furniture and accessories company known for its boldly patterned textiles, is opening its first store on Friday.

description: Mario Marsicano and Chris Lenox founded Jellio in 2005. The company, which is based in New York, makes whimsical home furnishings.

title: Divergent Path on Israel Helps Lobby Group Grow
description: WASHINGTON  There was a time not so long ago when political contributions from Americans supportive of Israel inevitably veered toward those Congressional candidates who were the most hawkish and outspoken in defending Israel and its security.

description: The BlackBerry maker Research in Motion projects more losses. India faces sluggish growth and tough economic choices. Most aid to Greece skips over Greek citizens.

title: Paying Rent on Minimum Wage
description: As part of its 2012 report on rent affordability, the National Low Income Housing Coalition released a chart thats been floating around the Internet. It shows that there isnt a single state in the country where its possible to work 40 hours per week at minimum wage and afford a two-bedroom apartment at Fair Market Rent. In West Virginia and Arkansas, youd need to work at least a 63-hour week, and thats as good as it gets. In California, Maryland, D.C., New Jersey and New York youd need to work 130 hours or more. Hawaii comes in last place: 175 hours.

title: House Democrat Is Defeated in Texas Primary
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Representative Silvestre Reyes, a Democrat in his eighth-term who is a former chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, was defeated Tuesday in the Democratic primary by a former El Paso city councilman, Beto ORourke.

title: Facing Down the Bankers
description: WASHINGTON  Sitting in a corner office high above K Street here, Dennis M. Kelleher, one of the most powerful lobbyists on financial regulatory reform, looks every bit the corporate lawyer and high-ranking Senate aide he formerly was: tailored suit, quick smile, assertive tone.

description: 8:54 p.m. | Updated

title: After a Frustrating Election, Young Egyptians Look for a Way Ahead
description: In recent months, Mayy el Sheikh, a 24-year-old Egyptian reporter and researcher for the Cairo bureau of The New York Times, has written about Egypts political transition for The Lede. Here she describes her own familys and friends experiences after the first round of the presidential election this month.

title: The Products Sell, but Can Jellio Make Enough of Them?
description: Weve just published a case study about Jellio, a maker of whimsical home furnishings that is based in New York. Mario Marsicano, a former advertising agency account director, had long collected old toys  Rock em Sock em Robots were among his favorites. He collected so many that he decided to experiment with embedding some in a table made of Lucite. When his friends started asking for their own Rock em Sock em tables, he figured he might be on to something. He and Chris Lenox, a co-founder, introduced Jellio with a Web site in 2005.

title: An Interview With Alex Morgan
description: The Timess Andrew Das spoke with the United States womens soccer star about her teams preparations for the Summer Games.

title: Acme
description: TAKE a spot once occupied by a lowly Cajun restaurant, bring in a team from Indochine, install the Norwegian chef Mads Refslund and add a subterranean lounge with an oppressive doorman. Thats the calculus behind Acme, a restaurant and cocktail bar that, since opening in NoHo last February, immediately joined the gilded caste of places youre obligated to visit.

description: BAGRAM, Afghanistan  Gen. Ghulam Farouq is not exactly the master of his own house, the Parwan Detention Facility, at least not yet.

description: Battery-powered buses that do not require frequent stops at charging depots might seem a maybe-someday proposition. But Conductix-Wampfler, a wireless-charging engineering company based in Weil am Rhein, Germany, claims the bus of the future is fully operational on the streets of Turin and Genoa, Italy, and has been for 10 years.

But viewers who find those discussions a bit light on references to Marxist theory and other intellectual heavy artillery now have another place to go.

The bluecoats had spent the wee hours resting on their arms beside a stone wall that runs along a path from the Shiloh battlefield visitors center down to the Tennessee River. On the other side of the wall ran the gravestones of their 19th-century counterparts covering a dewy hillside in tidy rows and half circles.

description: Are you having trouble getting your 9-year-old daughter to make her bed every day? How about your 11-year-old son? Does he get up in the morning and run down to the dining room to set the breakfast table for the family? And after breakfast, does he clear the dishes and wipe down the table? He doesnt? title: Table Talk | Rosemarys in Manhattan
description: When the restaurateur Carlos Suarez (owner of Bobo) was away at English boarding school, he missed the rustic meals cooked by his mother, Rosemary. My father had his own business, so he worked a lot, Suarez said. Family dinner was our opportunity to sit together and enjoy her cooking: salads with tomatoes or avocados from the garden, shepherds pie and schnitzel (shes English with an Austrian background). Now living in a house with an olive grove in Lucca, Italy, Rosemarys specialties have since changed, and it comes as no surprise that her son has named his new Italian restaurant in her honor. In the space that once housed Cushmans, then Sutters Bakery, Suarez has Wade Moises, former chef de cuisine of Eataly, overseeing a kitchen that makes fresh pasta and focacce, as well as seasonal dishes prepared with ingredients grown on the restaurants organic rooftop garden. (The days harvest gets dropped down to the dining room in a basket on a block and tackle.) Its an opportunity to bring the source of the food literally a flight of stairs away from your dining table, said Suarez, who plans to give students from the local Public School 41 tours and lessons on how to turn those vegetables into lunch. Were hoping to offer generosity, camaraderie and engagement  a sense of community, he said. Theres another unusual aspect to the joint. Beyond the reclaimed wooden table tops, Suarez has gone green with a Dekar Design interior: Instead of filling space with taxidermy and black and white photos, we used nature as our dcor. Inside are towers of artichokes and lemons, even little Dr. Seuss blueberry trees. Outside, the roof will also soon feature a beehive and chicken coop.

title: Eisenhower Family Welcomes Some Proposed Memorial Changes, Rejects Others
description: The family of Dwight D. Eisenhower on Wednesday said it welcomed some aspects of a modified design for a memorial to honor the former president on the National Mall, but still has reservations about other components.

The report says that newer radio technologies could help share spectrum among, say, government agencies and companies, and thereby increase capacity a thousandfold. In other words, the technologies would help carriers serve the exploding number of data-guzzling smartphones and tablets on the market.

description: WASHINGTON  Chinese manufacturers of towers for wind turbines received unfair subsidies and must now pay duties of 13.7 to 26 percent, the Commerce Department said on Wednesday in a preliminary decision in a case brought by four American manufacturers of the towers.

description: A leading French academic whose naked body was found in a Midtown hotel room last month died of heart disease, the medical examiners office said on Wednesday.

description: In certain circles, the Miracle House benefit signals the start of the summer social season.
