description: The Stanley Cup finals begin tonight in Newark. You can impress your friends during Game 1 by dropping some of these nuggets of knowledge, courtesy of the N.H.L.

title: When a Countess Holds Court
description: BEFORE she played herself on TV as a real housewife of New York, and before she became a countess through marriage and remained one after the divorce, LuAnn de Lesseps was a licensed practical nurse from Connecticut.

title: Wildlife Refuges Raise Property Values, Study Shows
description: Beyond the scenic views or flora and fauna, metropolitan area homeowners who live near a national wildlife refuge now have a different reason to appreciate the proximity. Research shows that such homes have higher property values than those that are farther from a reserve.

title: College Grads Flock to Some Cities, Forgoing Others
description: There is a growing disparity among cities that have a surfeit of college graduates, like Washington, and those, like Dayton, Ohio, that are trying to attract more grads, an analysis by the Brookings Institution indicated. College graduates are increasingly important economic drivers, particularly in cities that have largely lost their manufacturing sectors and the accessible jobs they provide.

title: Sweden 1912: For Marathoners, a Breath of Fresh Air
description: One hundred years ago the Summer Olympics were held in Stockholm. As we count down the days to London 2012, well take a look back at what was happening at the Games a century ago.

title: Mary Meekers Views on Mobile
description: Mary Meeker, the Internet analyst now with the venture capital firm Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, presented the latest version of her influential Internet Trends report at the All Things D conference on Wednesday. The report showed that Internet growth is being driven largely by developing countries, with China adding 215 million Internet users between 2008 and 2011. It also shows the explosion of mobile, which has been rapid, but still has a lot of room to grow. There are 953 million smartphone subscriptions, but 6.1 billion mobile phone subscriptions. There are still some concerns about how to monetize mobile Internet use. Ms. Meeker argues that the prospects are good, but that it will take time. The slides from Ms. Meekers presentation are embedded below.

title: Samsung Takes On iPod Touch, With Flair
description: In the swimming pools worth of ink that has been spilled on Apple over the years, not enough fuss has been made about the iPod Touch.

title: Debating the Merits of Patent Warfare
description: RANCHO PALOS VERDES, Calif.  Nathan Myhrvold, the founder and chief executive of Intellectual Ventures, says he doesnt care much whether people in the technology industry like him. Many people in the tech industry seem happy to oblige him.

title: Obama Video on Fox News Criticized as Attack Ad
description: 6:53 p.m. | Updated The Fox News Channel came under withering criticism on Wednesday for a four-minute video broadcast on its morning show Fox & Friends that portrayed President Obamas tenure as a series of failed promises.

title: A.E.P. Backs Down on Coal Plant Retrofit
description: American Electric Power conceded defeat on Wednesday, at least temporarily, in its push to save Big Sandy, its 49-year-old coal-burning plant in eastern Kentucky, surprising state officials there by withdrawing its $1 billion plan to retrofit the power plant so that it can meet tough new federal environmental regulations.

title: To Hear Doc Watson, You Really Had to See Him
description: Doc Watson, who died on Tuesday at age 89, was the first truly great guitar player I ever saw up close. For me, growing up in Santa Monica, Calif., in the 1950s meant that great musicians were only manifested on records and radio, making it hard to catch a glimpse of the person behind the layers of sound and presentation. You knew people like Hank Snow and Merle Travis were great, but you couldnt be sure how much the Nudie suits and custom boots had contributed to the sound you heard on KXLA radio.

title: History, 4 Wheels at a Time
description: The Great Tail Fin Wars of the late 1950s, between Chrysler and Cadillac; the Prius-Hummer face-offs of the early 2000s; the Cinderella transformation of the drab little Ford Falcon into the snazzy Mustang; and the even more startling metamorphosis of Hitlers Volkswagen into the American countercultures car of choice in the 60s and 70s  these are just some of the wonderfully entertaining real-life stories in Paul Ingrassias book Engines of Change: A History of the American Dream in Fifteen Cars.

title: Efforts to Save Endangered Hawaiian Birds
description: David J. Flaspohler, an avian ecologist and conservation biologist at Michigan Technological University, writes from Hawaii, where he is studying the influence of human activities on birds and the natural ecosystems that support them.

title: In San Francisco, Reviving Irish-American Whiskey
description: Irish-American whiskey has returned.

title: For Some, Exercise May Increase Heart Risk
description: Could exercise actually be bad for some healthy people? A well-known group of researchers, including one who helped write the scientific paper justifying national guidelines that promote exercise for all, say the answer may be a qualified yes.

title: The Get | Chances Elliott Stripe Tees
description: Founded by Julia Leach, a former executive vice president and creative director for Kate Spade, Chance is a T-shirt company turned total-lifestyle brand. Take Leachs latest California collection (her second), for example. It includes not only a group of simple and thoughtfully designed striped tees in fresh West Coast colors, but also all of the things that support a summer well spent wearing them: sheared cotton towels that read Seashore and Poolside, espadrilles, Turkish foutas (multi-use textiles) and straw fedoras, to start. This month the designer adds yet another must-have to the mix  a limited edition long-sleeve style featuring a wiggly stripe hand-drawn by the artist Elliott Puckette, a friend of Leachs. I wanted the shirt to appear to be a canvas, Leach says. I didnt want trims or excessive stitching to interfere with the grace of the lines. Available in four colors  soft black, pink, sky blue and pool blue  the Pima cotton tees echo Puckettes preferred palette. For her, the design process began as ink on paper. Ordinarily I etch the lines in my paintings, which is fairly laborious and slow, she says. I found the process of drawing these lines instead very meditative and fluid. Here, the artist Leanne Shapton surrounds herself with all four. Wouldnt you?

title: Obama Extends the Export-Import Bank
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama signed a bill on Wednesday that extends the life of the Export-Import Bank through 2014, ending an unexpectedly fierce political fight over an institution dedicated to financing American exports abroad.

title: Three Varied Tools for Blogging With a Hand-Held
description: Being a dedicated blogger once meant accepting life as a laptop nomad or being shackled to a desktop workstation.

title: Newly Released Books
description: Two dads, one real and one fictional, navigate their new realities, while novelists embrace the drama in a railroad accident and an assassination. Meanwhile the woman-behind-the-great-man genre welcomes George Balanchine and a ballerina wife into the fold.

title: Revisiting the Romantics at a Breathless Sprint
description: There are only a few artists so popular that Carnegie Hall will place chairs onstage to accommodate the large audiences they invariably attract, as the pianist Lang Lang did on Tuesday evening for his solo recital there.

title: TimesCast | Flame Fallout in Iran
description: Iran confirmed that Flame, a data-mining virus, had spread into the computer systems of high-ranking Iranian officials.

title: Father and Son, and Other Pairings
description: John Pizzarelli has the gift of gab in more ways than one. A great storyteller, he can spin the tiniest anecdote about the musicians life into a sidesplitting absurdist yarn. As a guitarist who leads his own quartet, he instigates high-speed musical conversations within the group that have the fast, frisky playfulness of a pro basketball team tossing off a victory. Propelling the ensembles signature bounce are Mr. Pizzarellis younger brother, Martin, on bass, the drummer Tony Tedesco and Larry Fuller on piano.

title: Bakers Run Ends, One Rally Short
description: Watching Brian Bakers straight-sets win over Xavier Malisse on Monday, I sensed a moment, late in the third set, when Baker began to lose his legs. Playing eight matches in eight days has a way of wearing a person down, and Baker, despite a two-sets-to-love lead, needed to put Malisse away in the third set tiebreaker. He stepped up his aggressive play and pressured Malisse into some forced errors, and won the match to continue his magical ascendance up the rankings.

title: Playing Up the Humor When Fools Fall in Love
description: When two ballerinas share a full-length narrative ballet, they are usually rivals, fighting over the same man, often to the death. In La Bayadre, which American Ballet Theater performed at the Metropolitan Opera House last week, one woman poisons another. In Alexei Ratmanskys Bright Stream, Ballet Theaters latest offering, a husband strays, but the two toe-shoed objects of his affection stick together in solidarity.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Zuckerbergs Tipping and Google Tablet
description: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Wednesday. See more here.

title: Romneys Favorable Ratings Are Up in New Poll
description: Mitt Romneys positive ratings have improved and Michelle Obama remains as popular as ever, according to two new national telephone surveys.

title: Pictures of the Day: Lebanon and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Lebanon, West Bank, Spain and Argentina.

title: Taking Her Leave
description: IT was a little more than a year ago that the New York City socialite Amanda Brooks was appointed fashion director of Barneys New York, to some cluck-clucking in the industry. After all, Ms. Brooks, 38, had little experience in retail, other than acting as a muse and later creative director to the fashion label Tuleh, and was more often photographed in preppy classics than the avant-garde brands for which Barneys had been known under the stewardship of her well-regarded predecessor, Julie Gilhart. As the blog Fashionista put it, Weve always thought of Brooks as more of a Bergdorf girl.

title: Back to I  NY, With More About Whats to Love
description: ALBANY  The Cuomo administration wants to put the New York back in I  NY.

title: Fluent in the Hard-Core Joy of Monk
description: Thelonious Monks music stands for many things  intuitive rigor, rugged refinement, a system of intervallic order  but what often goes underused by his interpreters is its baseline condition of pleasure. That particular lapse is not a problem for the pianist Eric Reed. During his sold-out first set at Dizzys Club Coca-Cola on Tuesday night, he played six Monk compositions with thoughtful attunement to their essence. He also made them seem about as cheery and buoyant as a bunch of balloons held by the string.

title: Adding Some Guesswork to Memorabilia Sales, Just for Televised Fun
description: Ah, the stresses of the memorabilia sellers on Final Offer, Discoverys new entry in what might be called How Much Can I Get for My Stuff Television. Four buyers, but no clue as to which one is willing to pay the most. If only I could drill into their heads and see what theyre thinking, these hopefuls must be musing.

title: Were Fox News and We Approved This Message
description: Its hardly controversial to say that Fox News serves the Republican agenda. Certainly theres a rightward slant to their commentary programs, which I actually think is fine. (The Times opinion section generally has a leftward slant.) Whats problematic is that their opinion and news offerings are often indistinguishable, leading to accusations of bias.

title: Turning Your Phone Into a Photo Studio
description: SO your smartphone has a camera; now what? It is probably time to get some apps.

title: Small Cameras That Can Switch Focus or Ride a Bike
description: POINT-AND-SHOOT cameras are being assaulted on all fronts. Smartphones are threatening to make pocket-size cameras unnecessary by offering passable results on a device many people are already carrying around. Meanwhile, photographers who want better performance are likely to be tempted by mirrorless interchangeable lens cameras, which are shrinking to nearly pocket size while offering features like those found on professional-level, single-lens reflex cameras.

title: Duets, Ensembles, Dance Music and Arias, All in the Lobby
description: Only a musician with theatrical imagination and pluck would have walked into the artsy lobby of the Gershwin Hotel in the Flatiron district of Manhattan and seen its potential as a space for quirky opera productions. That is what happened in 2009, when the harpsichordist, pianist and conductor Jennifer Peterson founded the performance company Operamission.

title: Sociopathic Thoughts With a Twist
description: The triple bill at Rumsey Playfield on Tuesday night was a snapshot of current pop: calculated, crisp, insistently catchy, selectively nostalgic and diligently seeking twists.

title: Toys That Will Bring Out the Boy in Any Dad
description: FEW things can peel away the layers of maturity from a man like a well-made remote-controlled toy helicopter. In the spirit of helping Dad remember his boyhood, here is a roundup of recent toys that the children might enjoy too. We have tried to include something for all ages, abilities and budgets.

title: Cake Shops Struggles
description: A Lower East Side club that served as an incubator for celebrated indie bands hopes an Internet fund-raising campaign will allow it to stay open.

title: For Gamers, a Kind of Christmas Comes Early
description: With the annual Electronic Entertainment Expo (known as E3) next week in Los Angeles, most of the video game industry is focused on the future. But that doesnt mean there arent great games on the market right now.

title: Recreating Lost Instants in a Reconstructed Ballet
description: WASHINGTON  Dance, the art of the uncapturable present tense, continually loses its past. As a result, the world of ballet is forever characterized by nostalgia for stagings that exist only in memory but that exert extraordinary force there.

title: Jol Robuchon to Close at the Four Seasons
description: The Four Seasons Hotel and LAtelier de Jol Robuchon have issued a joint announcement that they will not renew their operating agreement and that the restaurant will close June 30. The agreement is amicable, both parties said.

title: Crumbs From the Crowd to Pay the Bills
description: Cake Shop, a Lower East Side club that served as an incubator for celebrated indie bands like Vampire Weekend and the Dirty Projectors, is facing a financial crisis and has started a novel Internet fund-raising campaign to keep its doors from closing.

title: Madeline Miller Wins Orange Prize
description: Madeline Miller, an American debut novelist, won the Orange Prize on Wednesday for her book, The Song of Achilles, a lyrical retelling of The Iliad that was published by Bloomsbury in Britain and Ecco, an imprint of HarperCollins, in the United States.

title: The Secrets of a High-Quality Vinyl Record
description: TURNTABLES, those once-arcane machines for playing records, have staged a big comeback as a hipster essential, like cocktails with artisan bitters and skinny jeans with rolled cuffs over oxfords without socks.

title: Red, Blue and Purple: Hollywood Tries Bipartisan Bashing
description: LOS ANGELES  Will Ferrell plays Cam Brady, apparently a Blue Dog Democrat.

title: In New Digital Comics, Each Tap Holds a Surprise
description: AVENGERS VS. X-MEN is giving fans what they have long come to expect from Marvel Comics: epic slugfests and earth-shattering perils rendered vividly on the page by prominent writers and artists. But this time around, the publisher has added something new: its first Infinite Comic, a digital-only prelude to Avengers vs. X-Men that was released with issue No. 1 of the print series last month. It represents another step by the comic book industry toward embracing the digital format, and one that holds the potential to push traditional comic book storytelling to a new level.

title: No One Needs to Know Youre Absent-Minded
description: YOU may have seen the advertisements for a cellphone with a really big number pad.

title: Goldman Pairs at Eastern States Regional
description: The Goldman Pairs is the oldest bridge pair event still being held. The first was played in 1929. The winners of the 84th edition, last Sunday at the Eastern States Regional in Manhattan, were Franco Baseggio and Andrew Stark of New York City. They finished one and a half boards ahead of George Krizel of Feasterville-Trevose, Pa., and Albert Shekhter of New York City. Third were Murray Melton of Las Vegas and Marty Seligman of Philadelphia.

title: Daddy, What Were Compact Discs?
description: ONE day, when my children are a little older, I will gather them close and I will tell them about how I lived through the Great Format Wars.

title: The Buzz
description: A PREVIEW of the must-attend parties, talked-about openings and fashionable nightspots for the week ahead.

title: In Praise of Typing, the Clattering Kind
description: AMID the civil hush of the New Main San Francisco Public Library, I recently experienced an aspect to writing Id all but forgotten: noise. It happened in a workspace called the Typewriter Room. Operating the machine that gives the room its name, I struck the T key, then the H key, and for the first time in at least two decades, I was rewarded with the bracing clackety-clack of analog-era content production.

title: Up-to-Date Tricks for Aging Wheels
description: CARS on American highways are getting older. The average vehicle is now nearly 11 years old, up from about nine years in 2001, according to the R. L. Polk automotive research company. That means many drivers in the dads and grads cohort are probably candidates for a technology upgrade. Fortunately, there are plenty of options for gift givers, as varied as high-tech collision warning systems and phone-related devices intended to prevent driver distraction.

title: New Police Photo of Suspect in Patz Case
description: Here is the police photograph of Pedro Hernandez, 51, who was arrested last week and charged in the death of Etan Patz, the 6-year-old boy who disappeared from a SoHo street in 1979. Mr. Hernandez has been charged with second-degree murder. He is being held at Bellevue Hospital Center.

title: A Guide to Deciphering the Language of Smartphones
description: BUYING a smartphone, whether for yourself or as a gift, is a harrowing process made all the more mystifying by the language the marketers use. Every year they add new lingo and ever trickier claims  all networks cant be the fastest, can they?

title: M.L.S. Fans Get Chance to Argue For Stadium on Hudson River
description: A joint public meeting of the Hudson River Park Trust and the Park Advisory Council is being held on Thursday that will have an enormous impact on a potential future for Major League Soccer at Manhattans Pier 40, on the Hudson River.

title: Going Beyond the Wand to the Brain
description: ZENITHS Flash-Matic, the original wireless TV remote invented by Eugene Polley, looked like an intergalactic weapon, and no wonder. It was born at the same time as the Flash Gordon TV series, which ran from 1954 to 1955.

title: First, Some Rules
description: As the source of numerous marital skirmishes and intrafamily feuds, the battle for control of the remote is an undeniable irritant in many homes. But for all that, little has been written about the etiquette of using the clicker, said Peter Post, the great-grandson of Emily Post and author of Essential Manners for Men.

title: Mike Daisey Returns to the Apple Story, With Journalists as Targets
description: Mike Daisey was last seen apologizing for exaggerations and falsehoods in his influential one-man show The Agony and Ecstasy of Steve Jobs about the working conditions at the Chinese factories that make many Apple devices.

title: Mubaraks Sons Charged With Insider Trading
description: CAIRO  Prosecutors charged Gamal and Alaa Mubarak, the imprisoned sons of former President Hosni Mubarak, with insider stock trading on Wednesday, just three days before both men are expected to hear the verdict in a criminal trial charging them with corruption during their fathers three decades of rule.

title: Pushing All Our Buttons
description: IT started out in the 1950s as an effort-saving gadget, like the electric can opener or electronic car keys. It evolved into a necessity, a cultural magic wand that has transformed the relationship of viewers to their televisions, and the style and content of the programs on view.

title: CFDA Fashion Awards 2012 Nominees
description: Some on the list are very familiar faces, others are newer nominees.

title: Prosecutors New Assistant on Staten Island: Therapy Dog
description: Crime victims on Staten Island have a new assistant to the district attorney to help get them through the often re-traumatizing judicial process.

title: Summer Without Splinters
description: I USUALLY dont like to tackle a home improvement project until bloodshed or bankruptcy is imminent, but sometimes you just cant tell.

title: A Palazzos Rebirth
description: A 15th-century Renaissance palazzo in Florence, Italy, is made modern.

title: Sleeping in the Cradle of Opera
description: FLORENCE, Italy

title: Just When You Got Digital Technology, Film Is Back
description: When is the last time you took a photo with an old-school camera  the kind that doesnt have a wireless connection, needs to be loaded with finicky rolls of film and is too bulky to slide into a back pocket?

title: At 86, Kit Currie Is Still Reinventing the Box
description: Kit Currie recently showed a visitor around the West Village apartment she has lived in since the late 1970s. There are lots of books, probably because Ms. Currie, who is 86 and was born in England, spent more than 40 years working for rare book dealers like Bertram Rota in London, Dawsons in Los Angeles and H. P. Kraus in New York. She also has dozens of origami boxes on display  some of the pieces she has made over the years.

description: Q.  How does virtual staging compare with physical staging, and is one better than the other?

description: Claire Pijoulat and Odile Hainaut, who are the founders of WantedDesign, a design show and event program that ran concurrently with the recent International Contemporary Furniture Fair, went shopping around the Flatiron district to look at bistro chairs for sale.

title: Bistro Chairs
description: CLAIRE PIJOULAT and Odile Hainaut have lived in New York for a combined 21 years, yet neither is quite used to the sight of people hustling down the street carrying coffee.

title: Cable News Ratings Fall Across the Board, From Fox to MSNBC
description: Is a presidential election a turnoff to news viewers, even those who generally like to hear political opinions reflected in cable news shows?

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: Rei Kawakubo, of Comme des Garons, is being honored with a lifetime achievement award.

title: Like Mona Lisa, Ever So Veiled
description: TO appreciate the designs of Rei Kawakubo, the woman behind the label Comme des Garons, it helps to be a specialist in fashion, or something of a kook.

title: A Hybrid That Runs on Foot Power and Beer
description: AMSTERDAM  Eight British bankers in orange jumpsuits, their ID patches embroidered with the names of Tolkien characters, were in town for a bachelor weekend (Frodo was getting married). They had just finished a two-hour city tour on a beer bike. Arwen fell off! said a very cheerful Pippin. He almost killed himself!

description: The United States-Brazil match is, for the American team, Game No. 2 in an 18-day stretch culminating in the Concacaf World Cup qualifier at Guatemala on June 12.

description: To the Editor:

title: Kleiner Perkins Fires Back in Sex Discrimination Case
description: The venture capital firm Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, sued this month by a junior partner who said she had been sexually harassed and then punished for complaining, fired back on Thursday afternoon.

title: Lidstrom Set to Announce Whether Hes Playing or Retiring
description: Detroit General Manager Ken Holland declined to say Wednesday whether Red Wings defenseman Nicklas Lidstrom will announce his retirement at a news conference scheduled for Thursday morning in Detroit.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,974 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

title: Polish Premier Denounces Obama for Referring to a Polish Death Camp
description: WASHINGTON  On May 28 of last year, President Obama stood next to Prime Minister Donald Tusk of Poland in Warsaw and declared he would support new rules to help more Poles get tourist visas to the United States. If youve lived in Chicago and you havent become a little bit Polish, Mr. Obama joked, theres something wrong with you.

title: Former Justice Stevens Portrays Court as Inconsistent After Citizens United
description: Justice John Paul Stevens, who retired from the Supreme Court two years ago, accused his former colleagues in a speech Wednesday night of inconsistency, if not incoherence, in their rulings in the aftermath of Citizens United v. Federal Election Commission, the blockbuster 2010 campaign finance decision.

title: N.H.L. Labor Talks to Begin Soon, Bettman Says
description: NEWARK  Negotiations on a new contract between the N.H.L. and the Players Association will begin within the next few weeks, Commissioner Gary Bettman said Wednesday. Earlier this month the league sent the union notification that it was terminating the current agreement on Sept. 15.

title: You Can Go Home Again
description: THEYRE back.

title: Mets in No Rush to Negotiate With Wright
description: Jeff Wilpon, the chief operating officer of the Mets, said Wednesday that the organization was in no hurry to initiate contract negotiations with David Wright, the teams star third baseman.

title: Things I Saw  No. 13
description: Suggestions for what youd like Jason to see and draw may be sent to thingsisaw@nytimes.com.

title: Students Press for Action on Immigration
description: Young illegal immigrants, saying President Obama has done little to diminish the threat of deportations they face despite repeated promises, have started a campaign to press him to use executive powers to allow them to remain legally in the country.

title: Graff Diamonds Pulls $1 Billion I.P.O. in Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG  Graff Diamonds said it pulled an initial public offering here that had planned to raise $1 billion, the third such deal in the city to be withdrawn this week due to falling global markets.

title: Michael J. ONeill, Ex-Editor of The Daily News, Dies at 89
description: Michael J. ONeill, a former editor of The Daily News in New York who directed its breathless coverage of the Son of Sam serial killer, then became a strong national voice for responsible media behavior, died on Tuesday at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 89.

title: Shopping Calendar Gets a School Day
description: A MAGAZINE for teenage girls will try, joined by marketers and retailers, to add another special day to the American marketing calendar already crowded with celebrations both real (Christmas, Halloween) and fanciful (Black Friday, Cyber Monday).

title: The Tale of Ticks and Other Excess
description: I cannot tell you what a relief it was when I discovered that the multibillion-dollar trading loss at JPMorgan was because of deer.

title: Tougher Drug Rules Ordered at Belmont, With Extra Scrutiny on ONeill
description: The 144th running of the Belmont Stakes may or may not produce horse racings 12th Triple Crown champion, but New York racing officials are taking measures to ensure that Ill Have Anothers bid to sweep the series is contested on a level playing field and without illegal drugs.

title: In Milwaukee Post, Cardinal Authorized Paying Abusers
description: Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan of New York authorized payments of as much as $20,000 to sexually abusive priests as an incentive for them to agree to dismissal from the priesthood when he was the archbishop of Milwaukee.

title: Markets and Morals
description: Does it bother you that an online casino paid a Utah woman, Kari Smith, who needed money for her sons education, $10,000 to tattoo its Web site on her forehead?

title: The Fire Next Term
description: Nerves are jangling across the ideological spectrum as the end of the Supreme Court term approaches. So confident just weeks ago, conservatives now appear oddly rattled, beset with sudden worries over the prospect that Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. may fail to do their bidding and could actually vote to uphold the health care law. Leading conservative columnists have devoted their energy during the past week to bucking up the chief justice.

title: That Unused Hour on Your Parking Receipt? You Might Think About Selling It
description: For its most single-minded users, the citys transportation system has long offered the occasional opportunity for profit.

title: Education Budget Basics for Next Year

Weakness in Facebook Stock Adds to Pause in I.P.O.s
description: In the days since the highly anticipated opening of Facebook turned into a flop last week, the impact has become worse as would-be issuers have taken a second look at what theyre getting into.

title: Too Much Power for a President
description: It has been clear for years that the Obama administration believes the shadow war on terrorism gives it the power to choose targets for assassination, including Americans, without any oversight. On Tuesday, The New York Times revealed who was actually making the final decision on the biggest killings and drone strikes: President Obama himself. And that is very troubling.

title: For the White House, a Wary Wait as Syria Boils
description: WASHINGTON  After ordering American forces to Libya last year, President Obama declared that he had tackled a humanitarian crisis more decisively than his predecessors.

title: Hornets Land Top Pick in N.B.A. Draft
description: Anthony Davis ended his lone season of college basketball by cutting down the nets in the Louisiana Superdome after helping Kentucky win the national championship. Now, it looks as if he will make New Orleans his permanent home as the Hornets won the No.1 pick in the N.B.A. draft lottery on Wednesday night in New York.

title: The Credit History Underclass
description: Millions of Americans with damaged credit records are at risk of being unfairly denied job opportunities by companies that use credit histories to screen applicants. Faced with growing public complaints, seven states have rightly limited the use of credit histories by potential employers. Federal, state and local lawmakers who are considering similar legislation are on the right track.

title: Leo Dillon
description: Mr. Dillon and his wife, Diane, produced artwork that praised for its vibrancy, ecumenicalism and beauty.

title: Charles Taylor and the Next 50 Years
description: In his fancy suit, yellow tie and wire-rimmed glasses, Charles Taylor, the former president of Liberia, looked deceptively respectable as he sat waiting for his sentencing on Wednesday. No one was fooled, least of all the judge at an international criminal court near The Hague who gave the former warlord 50 years in prison for his role in instigating murder, mutilation, rape, sexual slavery and the use of child soldiers in Sierra Leones horrifying civil war during the 1990s.

title: Down by 2-0, Thunder Grab for Lifeline
description: SAN ANTONIO  Intentionally fouling a 6-foot-11 backup center five times in a 54-second span of the third quarter might sound like the final desperate act of a team on the brink of elimination.

title: Sexual Harassment Settlement by School District Is in Dispute
description: LOS ANGELES  Last week, officials with the Los Angeles Unified School District announced that they had settled with a senior employee who accused former Superintendent Ramon C. Cortines of sexual harassment. But that settlement appears to be coming undone, and the matter could be on the way to a long legal battle.

title: Leo Dillon, Celebrated Illustrator of Childrens Books, Is Dead at 79
description: Leo Dillon, who with his wife and longtime collaborator, Diane, was one of the worlds pre-eminent illustrators for young people, producing artwork  praised for its vibrancy, ecumenicalism and sheer sumptuous beauty  that was a seamless amalgam of both their hands, died on Saturday in Brooklyn. He was 79.

title: Bases Loaded, and the Yankees Are Coming Up Empty
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  A year ago the Yankees were the most productive team in baseball with the bases loaded, hitting 10 grand slams and scoring 146 runs.

title: Escaped Bees Bring a Visit From the Police
description: Animals will get restless if left unattended in a sweltering parked car.

title: Doc Watson
description: In the 1960s, nearly every aspiring guitarist spent a lot of time sitting beside a record player, setting the needle on the vinyl, listening to a few bars and then trying to pick out the notes on the guitar. (Now, of course, there are apps to make this easier.) You would do this over and over and over again. With a little patience, a song would give up its secrets. And the more songs that gave up their secrets, the easier the learning became. For a lot of us young guitarists, that process came to a halt when we first heard Doc Watson, who died on Tuesday at 89.

title: A Peace Plan in Name Only
description: Cairo

title: Training to Spot Tree Decay Is Urged for Parks Workers
description: Arborists and tree-care experts say that New York City could significantly improve public safety by ensuring that the workers who evaluate trees understand the warning signs of decay and failure.

title: Lightning Strikes Feed Volatile Fire Season
description: DENVER  Driven by high winds, brittle conditions and lightning strikes, wildfires raged across swaths of the Southwest and the Midwest on Wednesday, the latest rash of blazes in what has already been an especially volatile fire season.

title: Berlin Exhibition Highlights Soviet Architecture
description: Eager to distance themselves from their imperialist past and embody the new ideals of the Soviet state, the architects of Communist Russia created avant-garde structures with a social purpose. Through July 9, the exhibition Building the Revolution: Soviet Art and Architecture 1915-1935 at the Martin-Gropius-Bau (Niederkirchnerstrasse 7; 49-30-254-86-0) in Berlin combines vintage photographs, period artwork and current images to explore the Constructivist movement that rose out of the Russian Revolution.

title: Comptroller Says Contractor on 911 System Billed Millions in Inappropriate Charges
description: A major contractor on New York Citys troubled 911 emergency-dispatch system inappropriately billed at least $2.5 million, and possibly up to $50 million, for tasks as varied as opening an office door and killing water bugs in a bathroom, according to an audit released on Wednesday by John C. Liu, the city comptroller.

title: U.S. Still Learning, With Brazil as Teacher
description: LANDOVER, Md.  When the United States crashed out of the mens Olympic qualifying tournament earlier this spring, it was seen as an incredible disappointment, an opportunity missed for the top young American players who lost out on a chance to play on some of the sports grandest stages at the London Games.

title: New York Plans to Ban Sale of Big Sizes of Sugary Drinks
description: New York City plans to enact a far-reaching ban on the sale of large sodas and other sugary drinks at restaurants, movie theaters and street carts, in the most ambitious effort yet by the Bloomberg administration to combat rising obesity.

title: Dont Bring Me Down
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  The word BANDBOXES was a new one on me; I always thought they were called hatboxes, but you can put any old thing in a bandbox I guess, not just a hat.

title: Should Latin America End the War on Drugs?
M.T.A. Agrees to Allow Its Workers to Wear Religious Headgear
description: Muslim and Sikh transit workers will be allowed to wear religious head coverings while on the job under a settlement with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority announced on Wednesday. The agreement ended a winding legal case propelled by the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: On Campus, New Deals With Banks
description: College campuses have long been attractive hunting grounds for financial institutions looking for new customers.

title: Amid Uproar, Graphic Painting of South African President Is Removed From Gallery
description: JOHANNESBURG  To the artist and a gallery director, it was a scathing piece of satire  a riff on Soviet-style propaganda aimed at a powerful president with a controversial sexual history who presides over a liberation movement-turned-political party that many here feel has lost its revolutionary appeal.

title: Researchers Find Clues in Malware
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Security experts have only begun examining the thousands of lines of code that make up Flame, an extensive, data-mining computer virus that has been designed to steal information from computers across the Middle East, but already digital clues point to its creators and capabilities.

title: 2 Publishers Deny Claim of E-Book Price Fixing
description: The governments complaint piles innuendo on top of innuendo. It is based entirely on the little circumstantial evidence it was able to locate. And it sides with a monopolist.

title: American Idol and Its Owner to Undergo a Retooling
description: The company that owns the rights to the hit television series American Idol is reorganizing and changing its name in an effort to diversify as a broader-based media company, in recognition that its biggest moneymaker, Idol, has finally begun to lose momentum.

title: Brazils Political Class Jolted by Claim That Ex-Leader Pressed a High Court Judge
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Brazils political establishment is being shaken by a claim that Luiz Incio Lula da Silva, the countrys most influential contemporary political leader, put pressure on a high court judge to delay a trial over a vote-buying scandal involving high-ranking members of the governing Workers Party.

title: Governor Throws Weight Behind Senate Candidate
description: SOMERVILLE, Mass.  In a last-minute change of heart, Gov. Deval Patrick of Massachusetts, who said last year that he would stay neutral in the race against Senator Scott P. Brown until Democrats had settled on a candidate, endorsed the embattled Elizabeth Warren on Wednesday.

title: Syria Sees No Need for Journalists to Investigate Massacre
description: Updated | Thursday, 8:43 a.m. Just hours after a correspondent for Britains Channel 4 News filed a video report from the Syrian village of Houla, where dozens of children were killed in a massacre last week, Syrias ambassador to the United Nations made it clear that his government would not be swayed by witness accounts of the killings gathered by journalists.

title: Geek Chic: Be N Er Dy Tote Bag
description: A fashion statement with a science angle, as seen at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute commencement weekend on the shoulder of a talented chemistry major.

title: Colombia: Rebels Release Journalist
description: The countrys largest rebel group on Wednesday released a French freelance journalist whom it had held captive for more than a month. The group, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC, had claimed that the journalist, Romeo Langlois, was a prisoner of war. He was taken captive on April 28 when he accompanied Colombian Army soldiers on an antidrug mission. The soldiers got into a firefight with the FARC, which gets most of its income from drug trafficking. Four soldiers and a policeman were killed. Mr. Langlois said that he was tired but in good health.

title: Tibetan Woman Dies in Self-Immolation
description: A Tibetan mother of three died after setting fire to herself on Wednesday in the county of Ngaba, known in Chinese as Aba. The woman, in her mid-30s, was identified by Free Tibet, an advocacy group, as Rechok. She set fire to herself outside the Jonang Dzamthang monastery in the town of Barma, Free Tibet reported. The group added that Rechok had tended to the familys animals in the last few days and then traveled to town to kill herself. Radio Free Asia identified the woman as Rikyo, 33.

title: After 8 Days and No Edwards Verdict, Alternate Jurors Are Sent Home
description: GREENSBORO, N.C.  After more than 45 hours of jury deliberations over eight days, there is still no verdict on whether former Senator John Edwards is guilty of violating federal campaign laws.

title: Player Ratings: U.S. (1) vs. Brazil (4)
description: The United States national teams match against Brazil on Wednesday night was Game No. 2 in an 18-day stretch culminating in the Concacaf World Cup qualifier at Guatemala on June 12.

title: Bolivian Politician Takes Refuge at Brazilian Embassy
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  A prominent Bolivian opposition politician has taken refuge in the Brazilian Embassy in La Paz, claiming that he is being persecuted by the administration of President Evo Morales for accusing government officials of human rights abuses, drug trafficking and corruption.

title: Gay Marriage Ban Challenged in Illinois
description: CHICAGO  Less than a month after President Obama endorsed gay marriage, two dozen same-sex couples filed two separate lawsuits in the presidents home state on Wednesday, arguing that it is unconstitutional for Illinois to deny them the right to wed.

title: Kenya: Suspect Is Sought in Blast
description: Kenyan authorities were looking for several people who they believe planted a homemade bomb at a crowded market in Nairobi on Monday. Originally, the police said that the explosion, which injured more than 30 people but killed no one, was caused by an electrical malfunction. But on Wednesday, Kenyas largest newspaper, The Daily Nation, published a mug shot of a foreign terrorism suspect who the police say has extensive bomb-making experience and recently entered the country from Somalia. Kenya has suffered several relatively small bomb attacks since it sent forces into Somalia in October to fight the Shabab, a militant Islamist group.

title: Down With Religion?
description: Everyone knows that America is far more religious than most other developed countries.

title: Mets Rough Up Lee, but Bullpen Breaks Down
description: Minutes after Lucas Duda broke out at the plate Wednesday night, the Mets bullpen broke down in a big way on the mound.

title: Rhode Island: Deal May Avert Bankruptcy
description: A tentative deal between the city of Providence and its workers and retirees will prevent the city from going into bankruptcy, Mayor Angel Taveras said Wednesday. Mr. Taveras announced that retirees, current safety officials and current municipal workers agreed to a 10-year suspension of cost-of-living increases for most pensions  and limitations thereafter  and the migration of their health care plans onto Medicare. He had said the city would run out of money in June if it did not lower its pension obligations and increase voluntary contributions from the citys tax-exempt institutions; the city has since secured deals on increased payments with universities and hospitals.

title: For a High Price, SAT Available in Summer
description: For the first time, the SAT exam will be offered outside the school year  but only to students enrolled in a $4,500 summer program for gifted students on the Amherst College campus. Elizabeth Stone, an independent college counselor in California, calls the Aug. 3 exam unfair and elitist, since other students, including hers, cannot take the SAT until October. Robert Schaeffer, public education director of FairTest, said students want the opportunity to take the SAT over the summer, free from the pressures of daily school work. The College Board said that exam is a pilot to evaluate the feasibility of summer tests.

title: An American Diplomat in Moscow Takes Flak on Twitter

title: Rhode Island: State Surrenders Suspect in Killing
description: A suspect in a killing at the center of a lengthy custody battle between federal prosecutors and Rhode Island was handed over to federal authorities on Wednesday, when he was arraigned in a Federal District Court before a magistrate judge. Jason W. Pleau, 34, is accused of killing a gas station attendant in 2010. Gov. Lincoln Chafee refused to surrender Mr. Pleau in 2011, arguing that doing so could expose him to the death penalty, which Rhode Island does not have. title: Washington: Ruling Against Border Patrol Backup
description: The practice of Forest Service officers requesting language interpretation and security backup from Border Patrol agents during stops of Spanish-speaking people is discriminatory, according to a federal administrative ruling made public this week. The ruling, by Joe Leonard Jr., the assistant secretary for civil rights of the Department of Agriculture, said requesting interpretation assistance was merely an excuse to target Latino individuals for immigration enforcement. The ruling came in response to a claim by the companion of a Mexican man who drowned in a river on the Olympic Peninsula of Washington last year after a Border Patrol officer, summoned by a Forest Service officer, chased the man into the woods. The couple had been stopped on national forestland while picking salal, an evergreen shrub used in floral arrangements. The ruling included disciplinary actions against some employees, and it ordered the Forest Service to create new guidelines for dealing with people who speak limited English.

title: Stone Links: Philosophy, American Style
description: In this essay, adapted from his book America the Philosophical, Carlin Romano rebuts the common charge  shared by Tocqueville  that American culture is essentially anti-philosophical. Thats only true, he says, if we think of philosophical engagement as the academy would have us, namely, as tantamount to knowledge of the Western philosophical canon. While its true that Americans are less familiar with that canon than some of their European counterparts, it neednt be true that they are philosophically averse, so long as we take philosophy not to inhere in any body of knowledge, or in the application of any particular method  conceptual analysis, phenomenology and so forth  but rather in an imaginatively critical cast of mind. Taken this way, America turns out to be the most philosophical culture on the planet.

Almost on cue, two groundskeepers roll silently by in a modified golf cart picking up small twigs and limbs. They give a jaunty wave and move on. In the silence, I listen to the birds and the rustle of the leaves. A small group of mares graze in contentment next to the fence. There are gold and purple iris in bloom and blooming clematis is being trained to climb a tree near the entrance. The gate blends in with the iconic Kentucky stone fences. It is serene.

To wit: Oxfords New College was last considered new in the 14th century. (Even the obsolete term New World is newer.) Students here get into the act, many dressing in tweed coats, sometimes even with elbow patches, and ordering pints of cask ale at pubs that have been in business for nearly four-fifths of a millennium. But Oxford has a modern side, too: night spots blare house and electronic music; restaurants serve modern takes on local food and exotic ethnic cuisine; and comfortable boutique hotels and bed-and- breakfasts beat medieval lodging houses for comfort any day. title: The Darker Side of the Story
description: Im not sure this counts as a spoiler of anything other than Universals sleek and seductive marketing campaign  which has properly emphasized crows, swords and Charlize Therons hair  but there are actually some dwarfs in the new movie Snow White and the Huntsman. The small fellows who befriend the exiled princess here are nothing like the grumpy, sneezy, dopey guys you remember from the Disney version. The actors who play them (including Ian McShane, Eddie Marsan, Ray Winstone and the great Bob Hoskins, all digitally shrunken) might otherwise have been assembled for a nasty little Cockney gangster film. These dwarfs are industrious, but they dont whistle while they work. Their most memorable song is a haunting dirge performed at the funeral pyre of a fallen comrade. So take note: There is nothing cute about this movie.

title: On Cusp of History, Remembering One of the Greats
description: Who is the greatest racehorse of all time? It is a fruitless but enjoyable debate. In America, you might argue for the pre-eminence of Lexington in the 19th century, and Secretariat in the 20th. Many of us in Europe would nominate St Simon (1881-1908) and Sea Bird II (1962-1973) from those centuries; we might also suggest that our current champion, Frankel, has the potential to join these ranks. But if superiority over contemporaries, enduring fame and influence on the breed are measures, no horse has surpassed Eclipse (1764-1789).

The car was exhumed recently, wearing a thick patina of dust, from the former estate of William K. title: Another Marathon for Isner, but This Time He Loses
description: PARIS  This time, it turned out differently after all that effort. This time, John Isner lost to an unseeded Frenchman at a Grand Slam tournament with the fifth-set score deep, though not nearly as deep, into double digits.

title: Whats Wrong with Soda?
description: Whatever your opinion on Mayor Michael Bloombergs proposal to ban the sale of large sugary drinks in restaurants and movie theaters in New York City  overdue public health effort? or the worst kind of nanny state-ism?  its worth revisiting Is Sugar Toxic? in which Gary Taubes puts forward a scientific case against sugar. Taubes argues that sugar (and by that he means both high-fructose corn syrup and the granulated stuff) does not amount to just empty calories; it is also chemically and singularly harmful at least if consumed in sufficient quantities. Sugary drinks come in for especially harsh rebuke:

title: 20 More Cookbooks
description: ALAIN DUCASSE NATURE: Simple, Healthy, and Good. By Alain Ducasse with Paula Neyrat and Christophe Saintagne. (Rizzoli, $45.) The great French chef surprises with a lighter take on his favorite flavors.

title: Territorial Claims in South China Sea
description: Six countries claim conflicting territorial rights in the South China Sea, a region rich in oil, gas, fishing and mineral resources.

title: Free Kayaking on the Hudson River
description: As the weather turns warmer, city dwellers inevitably seek out the water, and many now happily get their fix without leaving town. Whether its on City Island or in Tubby Hook, in the Rockaways or in Red Hook, you dont have to look hard to find opportunities for boating, swimming and surfing.

title: Officer Charged With Lying About Mans Arrest
description: The homeowner was accused of trying to run over a police officer in the driveway outside his house. He was charged with felony reckless endangerment and spent three nights in jail.

title: Design in the Service of Subversion
description: A person working in almost any field could have written a book like How to Be a Graphic Designer Without Losing Your Soul: designers dont have a monopoly on worker alienation, after all. But that title of Adrian Shaughnessys 2005 book reflects the special circumstances of graphic designers, who generally practice their art in the service of clients and commerce.

title: High School Teacher, Accused of Having Sex With Student, Surrenders to Police
Legislative Panel Rejects 2nd Christie Pick for State Supreme Court
description: TRENTON  A New Jersey Senate panel rejected on Thursday the second of two men nominated by Gov. Chris Christie to the states highest court, dealing another blow to the governors attempt to reshape what he has criticized as an overly liberal and activist institution.

title: Making Quite a Show of Dying
description: To Christians in the Middle Ages, dying was the equivalent of a giddy elevator ride. You either shot straight up to an air-conditioned luxury penthouse, dropped down to the basement boiler room or got stuck on a stuffy mezzanine, from which, with luck and lots of prayers said by family and friends, you might eventually rise.

title: Of Saints and Sinners, in a Fevered Mexico
description: For Greater Glory, an old-fashioned, Hollywood-style epic that overlays thundering hoof beats with a humid layer of piety, remembers the Cristero War, a bitter 20th-century conflict in which persecuted Roman Catholics rose up against the anticlerical Mexican government.

title: The Secret Lives of Dangerous Hackers
description: In December 2010 the heat-seeking Internet pranksters known as Anonymous attacked PayPal, the online bill-paying business. PayPal had been a conduit for donations to WikiLeaks, the rogue whistle-blower site, until WikiLeaks released a huge cache of State Department internal messages. PayPal cut off donations to the WikiLeaks Web site. Then PayPals own site was shut down, as Anonymous did what it did best: exaggerate the weight of its own influence.

title: Classics in the Palms of His Hands
description: Pier Jacopo Alari Bonacolsi (about 1455-1528)  or, as he was known, Antico, the antique one  was one of the most skilled and innovative sculptors of the early Italian Renaissance, celebrated during his lifetime for impeccably neo-Classical bronze statuettes of pagan heroes and gods. But his achievements were swamped and obscured by wave upon wave of generic desktop-size bronzes in the ensuing centuries, and his name was forgotten until early-20th-century art historians rediscovered him.

title: Beating the System With Tainted Brownies and Tainted Minds
description: One accomplishment of the stoner comedy High School, although Im not sure accomplishment is the right term, is to evoke a state of drugged stupefaction in which the connections between words are lost, and nothing makes sense.

title: Women on the Verge of Everything
description: THE decision to devote the main galleries of the New Museum in Lower Manhattan to female artists this spring didnt happen by all of us sitting down and saying, Lets do a round of shows by women, Massimiliano Gioni, the museums associate director and director of exhibitions, said. Rather, as often happens when a number of curators are involved in planning a season, there was a cacophony of suggestions involving all kinds of artists.

title: Speeding Toward Englishtown, and Hauling an Uncommon Pedigree
description: For Alexis DeJoria, drag racing is the consummate concentrated thrill.

title: Turning a Charity Symbol Into a Corporate Logo
description: In Pink Ribbons, Inc. the director La Pool takes aim at the breast cancer movement and the corporations that benefit from its ubiquitous rosy symbol of awareness and action. Yet for all the stellar intentions; revelatory evidence; and thoughtful, wall-to-wall interviewees, this frustratingly overstuffed documentary indulges more in spraying buckshot than stalking a target.

title: Amid Uncertainty on Euro, Europeans Hedge Their Bets
description: There is an unfortunate logic to bank runs. The rational thing for any depositor to do is to join in the run if there is even the smallest possibility that the bank really is in danger of failing. If you pull your money out and the bank survives, the costs of your mistake are tiny compared to the costs if the bank fails with your money in it.

title: At Annual Meeting, Wal-Mart to Confront Shareholder Unrest
description: ROGERS, Ark.  As Wal-Mart celebrates its 50th anniversary at its annual shareholders meeting on Friday, the company is expected to face some of the staunchest opposition in years to the continued tenure of several board members and its chief executive, as well as some corporate policies.

title: A Broadway Hangout, Old Chum
description: IN a room deep below the streets of the Theater District last week, it looked as if a Broadway show was a few frantic days from opening night. Carpenters drilled as other workers huddled over a glowing iPad. The set designer John Lee Beatty stood atop a banquette staining a picture frame. The lighting designer Ken Billington watched while spotlights brightened and dimmed onstage. The producer Richard Frankel monitored the commotion.

description: To the Editor:

title: A Dying Village Gets a Curious Visitor
description: A neorealist ghost story, a documentary fable, a postcard from a vanishing world, Julia Murats Found Memories takes place in Jotuomba, a tiny, fictitious rural village in northern Brazil. To call Jotuomba a place that time forgot would be less a clich than an accurate description, since the aging, dwindling population  a quarrelsome pair of shopkeepers, a haggard priest, an assortment of idle agricultural workers and dedicated drinkers  seems to exist beyond the reach of modernity.

description: Fourchu lobsters are back, and this year, there are more.

title: Judge Allows Class-Action Suit Over Googles Book Scanning
description: A federal judge in Manhattan granted class-action status on Thursday to authors suing Google over the companys ambitious book-scanning project, allowing the long-stalled case to move forward.

title: Roger Revelles 1980 Discussion of CO2 and Climate Risks
description: Roger Revelle, one of the pioneering researchers in the study of the human influence on the atmosphere, carbon cycle and climate, gave a prescient lecture on carbon dioxide, climate and the oceans in 1980 that was recorded by the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory and now surfaces via the Web site Climate Science TV.

title: A Hangout for Locals
description: The Black Whale, a restaurant on City Island in the Bronx, has no water view, but plenty of history to appeal to local residents.

title: A New Class of Cancer Drugs May Be Less Toxic
description: Fern Saitowitzs advanced breast cancer was controlled for about a year by the drug Herceptin and a toxic chemotherapy agent. But her hair fell out, her fingernails turned black and she was constantly fatigued.

title: Trial Lawyers Support of Republican Candidates Yields Less Than Stellar Results
description: Trial-lawyer-backed is a label ready-made for Republicans attack ads in tort-reform-happy Texas. But if the 2012 primaries are any guide, the plaintiffs bar is becoming less shy about investing in the Republican side of the ballot  and Republican candidates are not being bashful about accepting the money.

title: Status Quo Between 2 Sudans Is Not Quite War, Not Quite Peace
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  For the first time in months, after killing scores if not hundreds of each others men, Sudan and South Sudan are back at the negotiating table, wrangled into peace talks by an increasingly worried international coalition, including the United States and China, that was terrified that the two countries were on the brink of a cataclysmic war.
